HEADLINE: WEEKEND EXCURSION;
O Little Town Of . . . You Know

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM 

DATELINE: BETHLEHEM, Pa.

 BODY:
The Central Moravian Church and its lamplit, bowler-capped belfry is a venerated local landmark in the Lehigh Valley of eastern Pennsylvania, and never more so than at Christmas.
But when you love a thing too much, you can get careless, and this is where David Griffiths comes in. Mr. Griffiths, 73, a member of the congregation for five years, is also its safety director, a more modest version of the corporate positions he held before he retired. His challenge now is making sure that on Christmas Eve the 200-year-old sanctuary will not be consumed by the flames of 1,000 beeswax candles in the hands of holiday-loving amateurs -- his fellow congregants. 
 Still, he was eager to be hospitable.
"Got some time? I'll show you around."
Mr. Griffiths's brand of easy affability is on display in nearly every store, restaurant and museum here. Bethlehem (pronounced BETH-lum by many natives of the area) has 72,000 citizens, and a couple of days in town could easily persuade you that they all know and even like one another. If that's true, it's because they share the same story, and it's not about steel.
It is Christmastime in Christmas City USA, and for all the economic turmoil this Bethlehem has endured over the years, it is, thankfully, half a world away from its West Bank namesake, a city where tourist buses are scarce, and a careless candle flame is the least of its problems.
Christmas in Bethlehem, Pa., is, believe it or not, still mostly about Christmas. It is Bethlehem's annual birthday party for itself, as well as a celebration of Jesus' birth in a city named expressly to commemorate his historical birthplace.
Yes, you can shop here for Christmas gifts: an enormous seasonal tent village called Christkindlmart sells every imaginable kind of holiday decoration and craft. But it turns out that Bethlehem, 90 miles southeast of Manhattan, is primarily intent on sharing its music, joy and light. Fifth Avenue it's not. The mall it's not. Corny it's not.
From Thanksgiving through the New Year, this city keeps to a nonstop schedule of choral and instrumental concerts, sightseeing tours and ethnic holiday celebrations.
Bethlehem is compact, as cities go, and one whose colonial pride and religious inheritance survived the rise and fall of the giant steel company that for a century appropriated not only its host's name but also, some say, its soul. And while it's true that the Christmas City designation was a Chamber of Commerce promotion that dates from 1937, the designation seems organic, not synthetic.
And so Bethlehem has learned to glow at Christmas in a way it never did when it was a steel town.
 
A Steel Foundation
In its heyday, the Bethlehem Steel plant, stretching five miles along the south bank of the Lehigh River, lighted the sky with the furious flames from its blast furnaces, which drew on the river to help cool the machinery that fabricated guns for battleships and beams for the nation's tallest skyscrapers. It was the second largest steel maker, after United States Steel, and as many as 30,000 men once worked here in hellish heat and deafening clamor. Downsizing began in 1985; the plant closed forever in 1998. Now the 850 employees who remain do their work in ordinary office buildings.
In wintry dusk, the stacks and sheds and rail spurs built by Charles M. Schwab are black hulks along an invisible river, silhouetted by starlight and by the twinkling skeins of lights on bridges, roof lines, trees and in nearly every window in town.
The brightest single light source is atop South Mountain, just above the Lehigh University campus, where the Star of Bethlehem -- 81 feet tall, 53 feet across -- shines year-round, a modern symbol of a modest religious enclave of Moravians, a Protestant denomination from Germany that settled here in 1740.
If there is anyone in the city who doesn't know the story of Count Nicholas Ludwig von Zinzendorf, the Lutheran nobleman who sheltered and encouraged the Moravians on his estate in Saxony, it's not because it's a secret. Zinzendorf's influence -- not to mention his portrait -- is everywhere to be found, particularly on the city's north bank, where the original settlers encamped and built the homes, the grist mills, the tanneries and the church that sustained them.
It was Zinzendorf, tradition holds, who named the city on Christmas Eve 1741, at the first candlelight communion service in the settlement's first house, now the site of the Hotel Bethlehem, on Main Street.
Choosing the hymn "Jesus, Call Thou Me," Zinzendorf emphasized its second verse:
Not Jerusalem -- lowly Bethlehem
'Twas that gave us Christ to save us,
Not Jerusalem.
The early Moravians of Pennsylvania and those of prior settlements in Georgia and North Carolina were latter-day disciples of the martyr Jan Hus, who was burned at the stake for heresy in 1415. Hus had invited Rome's displeasure after he was ordained to preach at Bethlehem Chapel in Prague and began conducting Mass in Czech instead of Latin.
 
A Refuge From Violence
In the 17th century, the religious and territorial upheavals of the Thirty Years' War pushed the Moravians further underground. By the early 18th century, they resurfaced under the protection and patronage of the wealthy and devout Zinzendorf. The denomination's original name, Unitas Fratrum, or Unity of Brethren, gave way to the more familiar Moravian, named for the province to which many had fled as refugees from sectarian violence.
The Moravians, hard-working pacifists who cherished music and education, came to Pennsylvania to bring Christianity to unaffiliated Germans as well as to indigenous Indians. They also sent missions to the West Indies and later to Africa. Of the 700,000 Moravians worldwide today, 60 percent live in Tanzania and South Africa. Only 60,000 are in the United States.
Behind the cluster of the settlement's original buildings off Church Street is an open tract of land called God's Acre, a burial ground with stones laid flat in neat rows. Side by side, names like Johann Sperbach (1716-1803) and Catharine Justina Pietsch (1785-1833) share ground with baptized Indians such as "Joseph, a Mohican, dep. July 21, 1746." Interred here, too, is another Mohican, named Tshoop, who is believed to be the model for Uncas in James Fenimore Cooper's "Last of the Mohicans."
The city's oldest structure, known as the Gemeinhaus, is one of the Moravians' first, a five-story log house built in 1741 and now covered in clapboard. Its second-floor meeting room served as the first sanctuary.
Today the building is the Moravian Museum of Bethlehem and is open for guided tours. A half-dozen other historic structures, the Sun Inn, the Kemmerer Museum of Decorative Arts and the John S. Goundie House (he was a brewer and early mayor) provide vivid snapshots of the city's younger days.
For those pressed for time, the evening bus tour makes the most sense. A full-size charter bus leaves the Visitors Center on West Broad Street on the hour from 5 to 9 p.m. For $6 you get a complete sense of a colonial village that became a steel city in the late 19th century and lived to tell the tale.
The night I went, the guide was Chris Holub, an insurance man by day, a 19th-century Moravian tour guide by night. Wearing a simple brown-cotton tunic and knee pants, Mr. Holub followed a script carefully timed to juggle traffic, architecture and history, but there was genuine enthusiasm besides.
"One of my ancestors was a man named Solomon Jennings," he said. "He did three important things. Two were good and one was really bad."
Among the good things Jennings did was to carve a trail from Philadelphia to Bethlehem and later operate a rope ferry across the Lehigh River. His ethical downfall, however, proceeded from a swindle known as the walking purchase.
In a property dispute with local Indians, Jennings and his buddies insisted that a long-dead chief had deeded an enormous tract to the settlers based on the distance a man could walk in a day and a half. Unprepared to contest the claim outright, the Indians agreed to a walk-off.
Unknown to them, however, Jennings had hired professional walkers to blaze the trail ahead of time. On the big day, one of the walkers, a professional athlete named Marshall, walked all the way to the Poconos, to a town now called Marshall's Creek.
 
Lighting the Lights
The bus tour meanders through narrow lanes, past the mansions of the steel and railway tycoons, across the river and up the mountain to the Star of Bethlehem. But the lights that count are down below, and not just on the historic north side of the river.
As in most old industrial cities, people arranged themselves by class, and such traditions, bound by economics, die hard. In Bethlehem, particularly during the decades of big steel, the plant workers and those of lesser means lived in South Bethlehem, a separate municipality until the city consolidated in 1918. Southside, as it's now called, was the neighborhood that became home to generations of Irish, Poles, Czechs, Hungarians, Italians and Puerto Ricans who gave their lives to steel so their children might move up to the Northside or out of town entirely.
Although Mexicans, Dominicans and other Latin American immigrants have begun to move in, Southside retains the sense of a spirited, if densely packed, community of strivers. There are 130 churches in Bethlehem, and scores of them are in Southside, every few blocks within walking distance of the old mill: Our Lady of Pompeii, St. Stanislaus, Holy Infancy. And here and there, a small corner saloon. Bethelehem Steel's executives had the Saucon Valley Country Club and its championship golf course; the working man had his own retreat, the Happy Tap, just off Third Street, near the river.
But Southside or Northside, the lights are just as bright. By the 1960's, competing lighting motifs grew particularly garish. Since then, by general municipal agreement, the south strings multicolored lights, a tribute to its diversity, and the north strings white lights.
 
The Single Candle
Still, Bethlehem's most distinctive light is the single candle in each window, in homage to Zinzendorf, for whom a residence -- Lichtenburg, or castle of light -- was built in Germany centuries ago. It is said that during Advent, each of Lichtenburg's windows was lighted to welcome the baby Jesus. The tradition was revived here in the late 1920's by the president of the Moravian Seminary and College for Women, according to "Christmas in Bethlehem," by Vangie Roby Sweitzer, an illustrated history published this year by the Central Moravian Church.
This quiet, centuries-old symbol endures, as does this close-knit Pennsylvania community.
Its mayor, Donald T. Cunningham Jr., 34, became the youngest mayor in the state when he was was elected three years ago. His roots here go back five generations; his father, a grandfather and two great-grandfathers worked at Bethlehem Steel.
"We were luckier than some of the western towns," he said, naming Pittsburgh, Johnstown and McKeesport. "They announced closings in the early 80's, and by the mid-80's they were gone. We had 15 years."
Still, he said, it was hard to balance what is now a $40 million annual budget on a constantly eroding tax base. The slide seems to have ended. Industrial parks dot the landscape. And the old steel mill, which occupies a sixth of Bethlehem's 20 square miles, is in line for renewal as a retail center and satellite museum of the Smithsonian Institution.
"Every community has to have a reason to be proud of itself," Mr. Cunningham said. "For many years it was Bethlehem Steel. But Bethlehem has always managed to be more than just steel. Christmas traditions give our community an identity. After all, I guess Christmas predates Bethlehem Steel."
 
Of Sights, Sounds and Sustenance
 
Bethlehem, Pa., is about 90 miles southeast of New York City. A sampling of attractions, along with travel information. All locations are in Bethlehem, unless otherwise noted.
 
What to Do
 
BACH CHOIR OF BETHLEHEM. In celebration of the nativity. Tomorrow night at 8 at First Presbyterian Church of Allentown, 3231 West Tilghman Street, Allentown; Sunday at 4 p.m. at First Presbyterian Church of Bethlehem, 2344 Center Street. Tickets, $16 to $28; students under 13, $5; students 14 to 22, $8. Information: (610) 866-4382 or (888) 743-3100.
 
CANDLELIGHT CONCERTS. Through Dec. 26. Saturdays and Sundays at 6 p.m. at Christ Church, 75 East Market Street. Seasonal music by the members of the Moravian College music faculty. Tickets: $6; children 12 and under, $3. Information: (610) 865-6565.
 
 OLD CHAPEL ORGAN RECITALS. Through Dec. 30. Mondays through Fridays at 4:30 p.m. in the Old Chapel at Central Moravian Church, Hechwelder Place at Church Street. Free. (610) 867-2996.
 
 BETHLEHEM NIGHT LIGHT TOUR. Narrated hourlong bus tour of Bethlehem's historic areas. Tours leave from Visitors Center, 52 West Broad Street, from 5 to 9 p.m. Through Jan. 2. Tickets: $6; children 12 and under, $3. (610) 868-1513 or (800) 360-8687.
 
 CHRISTMAS WALKING TOURS. A guide in colonial garb conducts a one-hour tour of the Northside historic district. Through Jan. 2; daily, 2 to 7 p.m., starting at the Visitors Center.Tickets: $6; children 12 and under, $3.(610) 868-1513.
 
 CHRISTKINDLMART. An annual smorgasbord of handmade crafts, trinkets, Christmas decorations and food in two large heated tents at Main and Spring Streets, near the Monocacy Creek. Musicians entertain throughout the day. Thursdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Through Dec. 17. Admission, $4; children 12 and under, free.
 
What to See
 
MORAVIAN MUSEUM. 66 Church Street, (610) 867-0173. Guided tours. Open daily, noon to 5 p.m. Artifacts of early Moravian life in one of the community's earliest log buildings.
 
 KEMMERER MUSEUM OF DECORATIVE ARTS. 427 New Street, (610) 868-6868. A variety of exhibits on Colonial and Victorian Bethlehem.
 
 MORAVIAN BOOKSTORE, 428 Main Street, (610) 866-5481. In continuous operation since 1745. Now includes gift shop, Christmas shop and cafe.
 
Where to Stay
 
BETHLEHEM INN BED AND BREAKFAST, 476 North New Street; (610) 867-4985. A restored 1845 house with four guest rooms, in the northside historic district. Rooms with en suite bathroom and breakfast, $105 to $120.
 
 SAYRE MANSION INN, 250 Wyandotte Street, (610) 882-2100. Bed and breakfast, $90 to $135 a night for a single, with $10 per extra person.
 
 RADISSON HOTEL BETHLEHEM, 437 Main Street; (610)-867-2200. Bed and breakfast, $129 to $149; without breakfast, $119 to $189.
 
 NATIONAL CHAINS. The Bethlehem-Allentown area is served by various chains, including Comfort Inn, Holiday Inn and Marriott.
 
Where to Eat
 
BETHLEHEM BREW WORKS, 569 Main Street, (610) 882-1300. Brewery and restaurant at the corner of Broad Street. Sandwiches, full lunches and dinners, and desserts.
 
 GRANNY McCARTHY'S TEA ROOM, at Donegal Square, 34 Main Street, (610) 861-7631. Lunch and afternoon tea and scones. Open past 6 p.m. on weekends during Christmas season.
 
 SUN INN, 564 Main Street, (610) 974-9451; lunch and dinner in an inn that dates to 1760 and served George and Martha Washington, Benjamin Franklin and the Marquis de Lafayette.
 
Getting There
 
BY CAR. Bethlehem is a two-and-a-half-hour drive from New York City. Take the Lincoln Tunnel or the George Washington Bridge to the Garden State Parkway. Follow the parkway south to Exit 142, picking up Interstate 78 West. In Pennsylvania, take Route 22 west to Route 378 south.
 
 BY BUS. Trans-Bridge Lines serves Bethlehem from the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Midtown; round-trip fare is $25.75. Information: (610) 868-6001.
 
Tourist Information
 
THE WEB. The site www.bethtour.org has information on lodging, dining, concerts and attractions.

An article in Weekend yesterday about visiting Bethlehem, Pa., to see the Christmas decorations misstated the city's location. It is 90 miles southwest of Manhattan, not southeast.

HEADLINE: U.S. Academic Research

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A Dec. 2 letter, commenting on the right of graduate students to unionize at universities, criticized the quality of American academic research. If American research universities produce low-quality research and have minimal economic impact, why are they the envy of the world?
By any measure of success, research universities have significantly increased the knowledge base in science and engineering and the material well-being of our society. What's more, technological advances spawned by our universities -- from the Internet to medical scanners to computer chips -- have fueled the growth of the economy. 
 We acknowledge that conditions for graduate students must be improved. Reasonable people may disagree on whether unionizing will achieve this. But we all should agree on this much: The American system of research universities is without peer.
 
WILLIAM A. WULF
JOHN HENNESSY
Washington, Dec. 6, 2000
 
The writers are, respectively, president of the National Academy of Engineering and president of Stanford University.

HEADLINE: Israel's Economic Engine

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Palestinian Economy in Ruins, U.N. Says" (news article, Dec. 6):
Although eventual economic cooperation will lead to a stronger economy for both Israel and the Palestinian Authority, Israel's economy remains on an upward trajectory and faces less of an impact from recent events than your article implies. Palestinian workers make up approximately 1 percent of Israel's labor force and work primarily in agriculture and construction. 
 High technology remains the engine of Israel's economic growth, and now accounts for 18 percent of the gross domestic product. (Tourism accounts for only 3 percent.)
High-tech businesses continue to operate at full capacity, and American companies continue to invest in Israel. Most recently, Broadcom announced that it would acquire VisionTech, an Israeli chip manufacturer, for $770 million, and Bear, Stearns just opened its first Israeli investment banking branch in Tel Aviv. These companies understand the long-term value of investing in Israel.
 
RON CHAIMOVSKI
Economic Minister to North America
New York, Dec. 7, 2000

HEADLINE: If It's Funny, You Laugh, But Why?

BYLINE: By EMILY EAKIN 

 BODY:
Plato wanted it tightly regulated in his Republic. Socrates thought it should be used sparingly -- like salt. Pythagoras swore off it entirely and forbid his followers to indulge.
For the ancient Greeks, laughter was serious stuff. Some, like Plato, thought it could incite violence and disrupt the social order. Others, like Aristotle, thought it was what distinguished men from beasts. Such notions may sound, well, laughable to modern ears. But the Greeks' guiding assumption -- there is nothing funny about laughter -- turns out to be thoroughly up to date. 
 History is littered with the sober efforts of learned men to make sense of giggles and guffaws. The question of whether Jesus had ever laughed so consumed medieval Christian scholars that the University of Paris devoted an entire conference to it in the 13th century. (The evidence was apparently inconclusive. On the advice of his religious consultants, Louis IX, who was later canonized, hedged his bets by never chuckling on Fridays.)
The Renaissance brought Hobbes's superiority theory (laughter marks the sudden attainment of power over someone else), which gave way first to Kant's incongruity theory (laughter occurs when perceptions don't conform to logical expectations), and, finally, to Freud's relief theory (laughter releases pent-up nervous energy.)
But the theorizing did not stop there. Today, laughter is a thriving, if not notably jolly, field of study whose members are scattered across the academic spectrum, from literature and history to linguistics and neuroscience.
One prominent venue for specialists is Humor, the academic journal of the International Society for Humor Studies, founded in 1976. A glance at a current issue is sufficient to get a feel for its contributors' general disposition toward their subject matter. Flow charts and regression analysis figure prominently in an article quantifying humorous responses to television ads, while an essay on ethnic humor in the Netherlands features tables quantifying jokes about Turks and Surinamese by unflattering stereotype.
"Humor is hard to study because it's extremely complicated and has so many different manifestations," explained Lawrence Mintz, the journal's editor and a professor of American Studies at the University of Maryland at College Park. "We are not in the business of being funny."
Humor contributors may not be playing for laughs, but most want to understand why certain jokes or situations tend to elicit them. Other laughter scholars, however, aren't really interested in laughter at all. Instead, they look at expressions of humor as a way of understanding broad, high-minded issues like politics, economics and individual identity.
For his new book, "Peals of Laughter: The Culture of Laughers in the 18th Century" (Calmann-Levy), for example, the French historian Antoine de Baecque pored over the minutes of the sessions of the French Constitutional Assembly for the years 1789 to 1791 -- three particularly volatile years of the Revolution. Even though laughter was explicitly forbidden by the Assembly's internal code of conduct, which called for serene and democratic deliberations, de Baecque found 408 recorded incidents of laughter, an average of nearly one every other day. What began in early sessions as collective titters at inept speakers soon gave way to outbursts that cut sharply along partisan lines.
For de Baecque, this was clear evidence that political divisions between the revolutionaries and the royalists were crystallizing. Laughter, he writes, "had become a political weapon among others in the arsenal, an effective weapon that individual parties utilized to distinguish themselves, to attack one another within the assembly."
Politics also plays a role in "The Senses of Humor, Self and Laughter in Modern America" (Cornell University Press), by Daniel Wickberg, a professor at University of Texas at Dallas. In the 1930's, Mr. Wickberg argues, laughter became a trait that distinguished democracies from dictatorships. "How long is it since a laugh has been heard on a public platform in Germany or Soviet Russia?" asked a New York Times editorial in 1939, while the comedian Bob Hope championed humor as a potent weapon for American G.I.s': "Where Hitlerism and fascism and Tojoism have set in, they take with them . . . their sense of humor, and its ready infection is being spread through countries and people they visit."
Joke analyses and cultural histories of humor may tell us any number of things, says Robert Provine, a neuroscientist at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County, but they may not get us any closer to understanding laughter. For that, he argues, only science will do. In his new book "Laughter: A Scientific Investigation" (Viking), Mr. Provine disputes the idea that laughter has much to do with humor -- or with cultural and political fluctuations, for that matter.
After analyzing 1,200 randomly recorded "laughter episodes," Mr. Provine concluded that most laughter is produced by speakers, not listeners, and that it is typically not triggered by witticisms. (Mr. Provine's list of laugh-producing lines wouldn't pass muster with kindergartners.) Moreover, he discovered a gender disparity in laugh rates, with women far surpassing men: the only situation in which a speaker laughed less often than his audience occurred when a man was talking to a woman.
Mr. Provine believes laughter responses may be innate. Women may laugh in the presence of a dominant male, for example. But whatever the explanation, Mr. Provine is convinced that laughter is not under conscious control.
"The key insights into laughter cannot come simply from thinking about it," he said. "Some of the most brilliant people in the history of our species from Plato on have tried to explain it. But laughter is not accessible to reason alone."
On that point, Mr. Provine concurs with Jonathan Swift, the Irish satirist who, 300 years ago, remarked:
What Humor is, not all the Tribe
Of Logick-mongers can describe.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Polyphony of Howls and Screams

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY 

 BODY:
To see them arriving in their suits and ties, you might think the 30 men who make up the Mieskuoro Huutajat men's choir are just another polite, stodgy group of yodelers. Then, all of the sudden, they start screaming at you.
Mieskuoro Huutajat (pronounced HOO-tah-yaht), you see, is Finnish for "men's choir shouters," and that's exactly what this group of singers do when they perform: shout traditional songs and national anthems at the top their lungs. 
 And while that might sound as appealing as an evening with the primal scream theorist Arthur Janov, the group has developed a devoted cult in Europe, releasing four albums and touring Germany, France and England. Tomorrow, the group will bring its high-decibel repertory to the United States, with a performance at 7 P.M. at the Brooklyn Academy of Music as part of the Bang on a Can marathon.
What's the appeal? Well, while shouting may sound simple -- and grating -- the group's sound is surprisingly textured: howls, whistles, moans and sighs are all part of it, as are a varied set of uptempo rhythms. Add to that the fact that very few of the Huutajat's songs last longer than two minutes, and you have a quirky, if slightly surreal, phenomenon.
The group was formed in 1987 by Petri Sirvio and Antti Penttila, two would-be punk rock stars from the northern Finnish city of Oulu, a city of some 100,000 people 400 miles north of Helsinki. A former pulp-and-paper industrial city, Oulu is best known for its high-tech labs owned by Nokia, the Helsinki-based conglomerate that is the world's biggest manufacturer of cellular phones.
Mr. Sirvio, 38, the group's full-time composer, said the idea for Huutajat came out of combination of boredom and barroom joshing.
"It was half joking, half serious," he said. "We were just making jokes, but these jokes wouldn't leave our mind."
"In Iceland, they say its very traditional to shout against the wind," he continued. "But in our area, the only traditional art form for the voice is the tradition of being quiet."
At first, Mr. Sirvio said, the group was only 18 members strong, a motley collection of lapsed classical musicians, unemployed punk rockers and many with no musical background at all.
"We were talking it up in some popular bars," he said. "They didn't come from church."
After several rehearsals, the group made its debut on Dec. 6, 1987 at a student center at the University of Oulu. In a nod to propriety, they donned black ties -- made of rubber cut from tires -- and wore cheap black suits because "we could afford them." (Nokia was an early sponsor, Mr. Sirvio said, because they "made the tires.")
But it was their choice of material -- anthems and patriotic songs -- that was risky, especially since it was Finland's Independence Day.
"I expected some people will get mad and fight," Mr. Sirvio said. "But the biggest surprise was that everybody liked us."
Since then, the group's popularity has swelled its size, with more than 100 different members cycling through over the last decade. Typical of the group's singers, who rehearse weekly year round and are paid only a small stipend when touring, is Marko Pyhahuhta.
Mr. Pyhahuhta, 30, is a graduate student who said he joined Huutajat in 1995 as "a type of therapy."
"I have," he said quietly, "a lot of excess energy."
The group now has more than 40 songs in its repertory. Mr. Sirvio usually cuts an anthem's text down to a few phrases, which are then chanted, screamed and yelled.
The group's version of "The Star-Spangled Banner," for instance, consists of a repeated chorus of "Say can you see, oh! Say can you see, oh!" punctuated by the sound of falling bombs and a sung coda of "Our flag was still there."
A live recording of this song ends, as many of Huutajat's do, with the sound of applause and a laughing audience.
Indeed, said Mr. Sirvio, the original idea of Huutajat -- as a serious lark -- is still there.
"It's really just a bunch of guys with the same attitude and same sense of humor," he said. "And I have the privilege once a week to have 30 guys scream at me."

HEADLINE: U.S. Jobs Report Is Another Indication of a Slowing Economy

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
American businesses continued to increase their work forces last month, but at a slower rate than in the first half of the year, offering another sign that the United States economy has cooled yet is not approaching a recession.
The unemployment rate remained roughly flat in November, rising to 4 percent from 3.9 percent in October, according to the government's monthly jobs report. The rate has now remained between 3.9 percent and 4.1 percent for 14 consecutive months, reflecting the tightest labor market since 1970. 
 The report -- which also showed workweeks becoming shorter -- comes on top of recent declines in the stock market, consumer confidence and the growth of business investment. Together, the data portray an economy that has moved into a new stage of its decade-long expansion, buffeted by a weak manufacturing sector but sustained by resilient service industries.
"The economy is softening, but there is nothing in this report that suggests it is collapsing," said William C. Dudley, the chief domestic economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The employment numbers added to a sense among economists and investors that the Federal Reserve would probably cut interest rates, in an effort to encourage spending, sometime in the coming months. The major stock indexes all rose yesterday, with technology stocks leading the way and helping the Nasdaq composite index to jump 164.77 points, or 6 percent, to close at 2,917.43.
Still, the employment report provided clear evidence that economic growth has slowed, and analysts -- from Wall Street economists to Fed governors -- say the speed of the change has caught them by surprise.
The number of workers who wanted full-time work but settled for a part-time job rose sharply in November. Almost 3.5 million workers -- 280,000 more than in October -- either had their hours curtailed or accepted a part-time job because they could not find a full-time one, according to the government's survey of households. Since July, that measure has risen 13 percent.
Over all, the average workweek for nonsupervisory employees in the private sector fell slightly, to 34.3 hours from 34.4 hours in October. It has now been below 35.5 for five consecutive months, after spending all of 1998 and 1999 at or above that level.
Nearly all of the decline has occurred in the industrial sector of the economy. In November, the average workweeks in the construction and manufacturing industries dropped to their lowest levels since 1997.
"Manufacturers are still cutting back employment to boost productivity in the face of enormous global competition," said Edward Yardeni, the chief investment strategist at Deutsche Bank Securities.
With the nation's labor markets remaining tight, many companies are reacting to the slowdown by reducing employees' hours, rather than laying off workers who might be difficult to rehire later, economists say.
But manufacturing and construction companies are not adding workers, either. Employment in those sectors also remained flat for the second consecutive month in November. By contrast, service businesses, many of which are immune to foreign competition, continued to add people to their staffs. Retail payrolls grew by 46,000 in November, hospitals added 15,000 jobs and restaurants added 17,000.
In total, 131.9 million Americans held jobs last month, an increase of 94,000 from October, according to the government's survey of businesses. Federal and local governments dragged the number down, as schools and the United States Postal Service both hired fewer people than had been expected.
Private employment -- seen as a more reliable gauge of the economy -- rose by 148,000, which was above its average of 122,000 since July. But the average remains much lower than it was during the prior 18 months, when businesses added almost 200,000 jobs a month.
The hiring binge has kept the unemployment rate low even as many new people have entered the work force. Wages, in turn, have risen, growing 0.4 percent last month, a faster rate than earlier in the year.
That increase often translates into a robust raise for workers -- and causes executives to worry about inflation -- but the decline in working hours helped keep paychecks nearly the same as they had been in October. In November, average weekly earnings for nonsupervisory employees increased 0.1 percent, to $478.
The continuing decline in the price of imports has also helped assuage executives' concerns about inflation, said Lakshman Achuthan, the managing director of the Economic Cycle Research Institute, a research group in New York. As a result, most analysts expect the Fed to lower interest rates soon, despite the low unemployment.
Economists also note that the government's monthly jobs report measures where the economy has been, rather than predicting where it is going. Many forward-looking indicators are drawing a more pessimistic picture of economic activity.
The University of Michigan said yesterday that its consumer confidence index, compiled from surveys, had fallen 9 percent between November and mid-December. On Thursday, a Gallup poll showed that for the first time since 1996 more people think the economy is worsening than believe it is improving.
If meteorologists are correct, and this winter is colder than recent ones have been, the current moderate level of pessimism could grow worse, Mr. Dudley of Goldman, Sachs said. During harsh winters, heating bills rise, while new construction projects and discretionary shopping trips fall off.

HEADLINE: Cuba Threatens to Cut Off Phone Service to the States

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
In a season when Cubans traditionally reach out to one other across the Florida Straits, the Cuban government announced today that it would cut off phone service with the United States next week unless American phone companies paid a new 10 percent tax.
President Fidel Castro of Cuba first announced the surcharge in October after Congress approved antiterrorism legislation that would use frozen Cuban assets in the United States to compensate relatives of anti-Castro exiles killed in 1996. The men were killed in a Cuban attack on two planes flown by exiles into Cuban airspace. 
 Cuba today set a deadline of Dec. 15, saying the tax bills were coming due.
The Clinton administration has forbidden American carriers from paying the surcharge, which would add 24 cents a minute to rates that experts say are already among the highest in the world.
Such a unilateral increase is not allowed under a seven-year-old deal between the countries that renewed direct phone links and set terms for splitting the profits from calls, administration officials argue.
"It is unfortunate that while the world continues to open up to the people of Cuba, the Cuban government is threatening to deny Cuban citizens the ability to talk with family members," said Philip Reeker, a State Department spokesman.
Cutting off phone service would have personal and political implications. For hundreds of thousands of Cuban exiles, mostly based in South Florida, direct phone links in recent years have helped restore family ties that were severed by the cold war. Telephone service, moreover, has been a cornerstone of the administration's efforts to build bridges among ordinary citizens, beyond the reach of Cuban government control.
Exile groups said Mr. Castro's ultimatum amounted to extortion.
"Just as we are entering this holiday season, he is prepared to summarily cut what has become a vital emotional link between Cuban families to avoid facing up to his culpability in the death of U.S. citizens," said Dennis Hays, executive vice president of the Cuban American National Foundation, the leading exile lobby.
Cuban officials countered that they were merely seeking to recoup money that rightfully belong to the Cuban state. The antiterrorism law, which offered relief to Americans with claims against such nations as Iran and Libya, authorized using Cuban money held in escrow by the Treasury Department -- valued at more than $120 million -- to pay damages to relatives of the exile pilots killed four years ago.
The families are to receive at least $50 million plus interest, and possibly as much as $37 million more, depending on final court rulings.
Luis Fernandez, a spokesman for the Cuban Interests Section in Washington, said the airmen, members of the Miami exile group Brothers to the Rescue, were provocateurs and were shot down by Cuban fighters after flying into Cuban airspace. The new American law rewards acts of terrorism, he contended.
"It's going to encourage people to do more of that kind of thing, because they know they will be supported by the U.S. government," Mr. Fernandez said.
Cuba will rescind the new phone tax once it has offset the money lost from its escrow account, he said.
"As soon as we recover all these funds to compensate the families," Mr. Fernandez said, "the tax will disappear."
Callers across the Florida Straits racked up 135 million minutes on the phone in 1998, according to the U.S.-Cuba Trade and Economic Council, a office based in New York that advises American businesses about Cuba. Although 90 percent of the calls originated in the United States, the profits were split evenly, between American carriers and the Cuban phone company, known by the acronym Etecsa.
Etecsa received $86 million that year from the American companies.
The American phone carriers are caught in the middle. The half-dozen firms that provide service to Cuba have been barred by the administration from paying the tax. And Cuba has said it will not allow the companies to route calls through third countries and pay the tax from abroad.
A spokesman for AT&T, one of the main carriers to Cuba, said his company had not paid the tax and was waiting for further guidance from the administration.
Enrique Lopez, a telecommunications consultant with AKL Group International in Miami, said Cuba's tax, if paid, would provide Havana an additional $42 million a year. Even without the surcharge, phone calls to Cuba -- with rates up to $1.20 a minute -- are among the most expensive in the world, he said.
"That's pretty aggressive stuff," said Mr. Lopez, who made clear that he did not think the Castro government was bluffing. "They will definitely pull the cord and make it very difficult and frustrating."

HEADLINE: John Liscio, 51, Bond Newsletter Publisher

 BODY:
John Liscio, who wrote and published The Liscio Report, a financial newsletter, died on Nov. 29 at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 51 and lived in Upper Montclair, N.J.
The cause was liver and kidney failure related to hepatitis C, said his wife, Frances. 
 Mr. Liscio, whose motto was "To trust is good, not to trust is better," founded his influential bond market newsletter in 1992 after working briefly as a senior editor of U.S. News & World Report. In the late 1980's and early 90's, he was on the staff of the financial weekly Barron's.
In October, Barron's said that Mr. Liscio had made a success of himself on his own, writing for the last eight years The Liscio Report, "an astute and irreverent look at the credit markets and economy."
Mr. Liscio told Barron's at that time: "I don't try to forecast. I don't think forecasting is something within the realm of human possibility." But he had made a reputation for himself by forecasting the recession in the early 1990's.
He was born in Manhattan, graduated from Fordham Preparatory School in the Bronx and received a bachelor's degree from Fordham University.
After serving in the Marine Corps, he began working as a financial writer and analyst in the late 1970's.
Surviving are his wife of 14 years, Frances Pelzman Liscio, who is a humor writer; a daughter, Laura, 11; a son, Gregory, 9; his parents, Armand and Josephine Liscio of Delray Beach, Fla.; and a sister, Jeanette Kamciyan of Boca Raton, Fla.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Nasdaq Rises 6% on Hopes Profit Warnings Are Done
The Nasdaq composite index jumped 164.77 points, or 6 percent, to 2,917.43, on the strength of technology companies like Intel and Cisco Systems and a positive jobs report.
Other markets rose as well. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 26.34 points, or 2 percent, to 1,369.89. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 95.55 points, or 0.9 percent, to 10,712.91. After hours, the picture was not as rosy, as investors sent shares sharply lower in reaction to more uncertainty about the presidential election's outcome. Page C3. 

Ruling on Internet Radio Broadcasts
Radio stations that make their broadcasts available over the Internet must pay fees to record companies, the United States Copyright Office has ruled, in a decision the radio stations assert conflicts with federal law. C14.
 
California's Power Crisis Persists
Despite California's mild winter so far, the state is in a crisis so severe that it was forced to take action to avoid running out of power. And if the electricity shortage continues, Californians soon could be required to darken their homes if rolling hourlong blackouts are instituted across the state as a last resort. A9.
 
Oil Prices Fall Anticipating Iraq News
A United Nations committee approved December prices for Iraq's oil shipments, allowing the country to resume exports. The benchmark contract for January crude oil in New York settled at $28.44 a barrel, down 91 cents, or 3.1 percent, on expectations that Iraq would start shipping oil again. C2.
 
Clinton to Consider Milken Pardon
Before he exits the White House next month, President Clinton might shower pardons on a host of people, including several Whitewater figures and, most notably, Michael R. Milken, left, the former Wall Street financier. Mr. Milken's pardon application has been raised directly with the president by a major Democratic contributor and Clinton financial benefactor. A9.
 
No New Business for Equitable Life
The Equitable Life Assurance Society said it would not seek new business after an unsuccessful six-month search for a buyer. Equitable owes at least $2.2 billion to holders of policies with guaranteed annuities. The insurer put itself up for sale in July after the House of Lords ruled it unlawfully cut bonuses to some policyholders. C2.
 
Court Denies Bankruptcy Request
A Belgian court denied a request for bankruptcy protection from Lernout & Hauspie, the maker of speech-recognition software, saying that the company had not presented a revamping plan. The company, which is facing lawsuits and growing scrutiny over accounting irregularities, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in Delaware on Nov. 29. C2.
 
Pataki Approves Big Board Complex
Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation enabling New York City to finance a 50-story trading complex and office tower for the New York Stock Exchange, across the street from its historic home on Wall Street. B1.
 
Hicks, Muse Drops Manville Buyout
Bear Stearns and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst abandoned a proposed buyout of Johns Manville after Manville said it would not accept a bid below the $3 billion the prospective buyers offered in June. C3.
 
Sogo Chief Told to Pay Damages
A Tokyo court ordered Hiroo Mizushima, the top executive of Sogo, a bankrupt Japanese retailer, to pay the company $54.7 million in damages for losses that he and 16 other executives were accused of causing as the company was collapsing. C2.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Shares Rally as Intel Rises, Before Latest Electoral Twist

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Technology stocks shot higher yesterday after investors witnessed a surprising performance in Intel and received some good news on the economy, and Wall Street, for a time, seemed confident that the presidential election stalemate might soon be over.
But just as the stock market closed, investors began bracing for even more uncertainty about the election's outcome. 
 Vice President Al Gore won a major victory when the Florida Supreme Court ruled 4 to 3 that thousands of disputed ballots should be counted by hand. If that decision stands, Mr. Gore could win Florida and the election. But the Florida Legislature is expected to step in to appoint presidential electors who support Gov. George W. Bush.
Faced with a renewal of the protracted election battle, the initial reaction of investors was negative. In after-hours trading, the futures contract on the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index plunged 47 points, or 3.4 percent.
Earlier, the actual S.& P. 500 ended trading up 26.34 points, or 2 percent, to 1,369.89. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 95.55 points, or 0.9 percent, to 10,712.91. But the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index was by far the biggest winner, jumping 164.77 points, or 6 percent, to 2,917.43.
Technology stocks were led higher in part by Intel, the world's largest chip maker, which buoyed spirits early by rallying despite its warning late Thursday that its fourth-quarter sales would be lower than expected. Intel gained $1.69, to close at $34.
Intel's rebound against its own warning could be a sign that investors have already discounted most of the bad news from the technology sector. But it could also be a result of the fact that analysts had already warned of a sales shortfall ahead of Intel's announcement after the close of the market Thursday.
"The bad news is in the stock, and the rest of the market is getting a boost from that," said Richard E. Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason Wood Walker in Baltimore. "I think it is saying that these stocks have reached a fundamental value."
Other technology stocks joined the surge, including Cisco Systems, up $2.44, to $52.38; JDS Uniphase, up $6.50, to $73.50; and Oracle, up $1.75, to $30.06. Even Microsoft, which declined Thursday after its earnings prospects were downgraded by Goldman, Sachs, managed to climb, rising $1.31, to $54.44.
The government, meanwhile, reported that job growth moderated in November but did not slow to a pace that indicated the economy was abruptly decelerating.
The Labor Department said 94,000 new nonfarm jobs were created. While that was less than the 140,000 expected, much of the difference was because of a drop in government employment. Private-sector jobs rose by 148,000. The unemployment rate edged up to 4 percent from 3.9 percent in October.
"These are soft-landing numbers thus far," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Fleming Asset Management. "These numbers are not pointing to a recession."
In the bond market, yields rose and prices, which move in the opposite direction, fell until 4 p.m. as some investors put their money in stocks and others may have taken profits after a sharp three-day rally.
But after the Florida Supreme Court issued its decision just after 4 p.m., the bond market reversed itself, wiping out most of its losses. The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note was unchanged at 5.30 percent as the price inched up 1/32, to 102 13/32. The yield had been up to 5.34 percent before the court announcement. The yield on the 30-year bond inched up to only 5.51 percent from 5.50 percent.
In the background yesterday, the stock market benefited from two other positives. One was the signal on Tuesday from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, who indicated that the central bank was ready to reduce short-term interest rates if the economy slowed drastically. For many investors, this means the economy is more likely to experience a soft landing rather than a recession.
The second, until the Florida Supreme Court decision, was that the uncertainty about the presidential election appeared to be near its end. Shortly after 2:15 p.m., it was announced that Democrats had lost their challenge to absentee ballots in two Florida counties. If the Democrats had won and these ballots were invalidated, the election could have swung in favor of Mr. Gore.
And technology stocks may be reaching a bottom. Mr. Cripps said Motorola was a good example of how much some of those issues have been beaten down. Motorola announced before the market opened Thursday that its fourth-quarter revenue and earnings would fall short of forecasts. The indication of its opening stock price was $16, the lowest price for Motorola relative to its sales and earnings since the recession of 1990-1991, Mr. Cripps said.
Motorola rebounded some yesterday, wiping out its losses of the last week, by climbing $1.06, to $18.75.
Mr. Cripps said the driving force behind stocks was changing from momentum investing to value investing. But he warned that investors were becoming risk averse, and that "is not good for technology stocks."

HEADLINE: After Summer of Power Woes, California Is Hurting Again

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8

 BODY:
It was not supposed to be like this.
Families asked to turn off their Christmas lights. Businesses required to shut down for hours for days on end. Utility executives demanding relief from the governor, warning that the state's electrical system is on the verge of collapse. 
 After California's summer electricity troubles passed with the hot weather, most executives and state officials thought they had bought a year's time to find a solution to the energy problems. But despite a mild winter here so far, the state is again in the midst of a crisis so severe it was forced to take unprecedented measures on Thursday to avoid running out of power. And if this week's electricity shortage continues, Californians soon could be asked to darken their homes if rolling hourlong blackouts are instituted across the state as a last resort.
For most energy experts it is an unheard of situation given that air conditioners, a culprit last summer, are largely idle in the winter.
"People are in a heap of trouble," said S. David Freeman, general manager of the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power, which owns its own power generation operations and is not likely to be affected like other large cities. "This shouldn't happen this time of year."
But an unusually large number of the state's power generators were shut down for maintenance or to comply with air quality standards. On some days, as much as one-third of the electricity the state needed during the peak wintertime hours of 4 p.m. to 7 p.m. was not available, energy officials said. As such, the California Independent System Operator, which manages the electricity system for 75 percent of the state, had to pay as much as four times more to import it than what it might have paid a California producer.
To make matters worse, wholesale natural gas prices are up as much as 10-fold over this time last year. With a cold front expected across the West this weekend, that means consumers not only run the risk of seeing their lights dimmed, but also sticker shock when they see their gas bills.
"I fear what will happen when these bills start to arrive," said Stephen L. Baum, chairman of energy services company Sempra Energy.
Mr. Baum said customers, including those served by Sempra's subsidiary, San Diego Gas and Electric, are likely to see rates double.
Of course, no one foresaw such a predicament four years ago, when California, the world's seventh-largest economy, decided to deregulate its electric industry. Then electricity reserves in the state were running as high as 30 percent, industry executives estimate. Most people believed that competition would lower prices for consumers and businesses alike. But now reserves are running dangerously low -- as little as 1.5 percent daily -- causing concern for utilities and politicians alike.
State officials, for their part, are trying to get to the bottom of why so many power plants are idled now. Air quality regulators today eased up on restrictions for some power plants to help provide much-needed electricity. But late Tuesday evening, representatives from the Public Utilities Commission showed up unannounced at several shut-down power plants, spanning the state from Oxnard, near Santa Barbara, to Shasta County in the north. There, said Loretta Lynch, president of the commission, they interviewed executives, examined machinery and reviewed maintenance logs to verify that indeed the plants were shut down for the reasons they gave.
Not everyone has welcomed the commission. Some power generators refused to let them in, Ms. Lynch said, although now they have all complied with the commission's requests. A report on the commission's finding could come next week, she added. But consumer advocates wonder if the commission visits will really yield any useful information.
"What are they looking for?" asked Douglas Heller, of the Foundation for Taxpayer and Consumer Rights in Santa Monica. "Seeing if they have an oil can out?"
The electricity mess in California has become a public relations nightmare for Gov. Gray Davis. On Tuesday, for instance, hours before he was set to flip the switch on the lights for the state's Christmas tree, industry executives said the Independent System Operator was scrambling to find more than 1,000 megawatts of electricity it was short that day. One megawatt is enough to serve about 1,000 homes. The system operator squeaked by at the last minute, the energy executives said, paying more than $1,000 per megawatt for electricity imported from the Pacific Northwest. By contrast, the price cap for electricity bought in California is usually $250 per megawatt. As such, Mr. Davis gave a brief speech, flipped the switch, then turned the lights off after 25 minutes.
Ms. Lynch insisted in an interview on Thursday that there was no emergency. She was seated in a dark San Francisco office then, she said, the only light glowing from a computer screen, because the state had required employees to turn off their lights to conserve energy.
"We have the power," Ms. Lynch said, noting that the state's power generators can generate 44,000 megawatts of electricity. But she agreed that something must be done to understand why one-quarter of that amount -- about 11,000 megawatts -- is unable to be tapped because the generators are not up and running. "From my perspective, people want a magic pill and they aren't going to get it," she added.
The federal Energy Regulatory Commission is expected to announce on Wednesday what steps it is willing to take to help California.
Despite Ms. Lynch's assurances, nerves are frayed. "I'm getting tired of people saying we have plenty of energy when we don't have it," said Terry Winter, chief executive of the independent operator.
Take Thursday night, when the operator was forced to announce a final-stage emergency that gave the state the authority to call for statewide rolling blackouts, the first time in California's history. At 3 p.m. a power generator went off-line for difficulties resulting in the loss of 500 megawatts of electricity.
That caused the emergency, Mr. Winter said. "That is how close we are to the margin."

HEADLINE: Pataki Signs Law Enabling City to Finance Tower for Stock Exchange

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation yesterday enabling the city to finance a long-stalled plan to build a major 50-story trading complex and office tower for the New York Stock Exchange in the city's financial district.
And two years after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced plans for the heavily subsidized project, city officials once again said that they were close to signing a nonbinding agreement with the New York Exchange for the trading complex across the street from its historic home on Wall Street. The 10-story trading complex, with the 1.3-million-square-foot office tower on top of it, would be on a block bounded by Wall, Broad and William Streets and Exchange Place. 
 Despite the sudden flurry of activity, the project still faces mounting costs and doubts about its viability. Unable to find a developer willing to build the tower without a major office tenant, the Giuliani administration is hoping that it can develop some momentum over the next year by buying the property and demolishing the existing office buildings on the site. That, they said, should make the project more tangible and help lure a tenant, whose rent is intended to offset the costs.
But real estate executives said that it may be harder to find a tenant as more office space becomes available downtown and the rent required for the proposed tower soars. At the same time, the estimated cost of buying the land and building the trading complex has jumped to about $960 million, from $700 million two years ago. The city would provide $905 million in tax breaks, and the state $160 million.
Real estate executives and some urban planners are now saying the project has become too costly and may be unnecessary given the advent of electronic trading, although the stock exchange maintains that it has outgrown its space and needs a new trading complex to remain the capital of world finance.
"A lot of very smart people have spent a lot of time on this project," said Douglas Durst, a developer whose family owns seven million square feet of office space in Manhattan. "But I'm afraid that it's no longer a case of build it and they will come, but build it and you'll lose it."
Michael Carey, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, did not return calls requesting comment.
According to people involved in the project, the city had hoped that the stock exchange would finally sign a letter of intent at its board meeting on Thursday and that the Empire State Development Corporation would approve the environmental impact statement for the project at its Dec. 13 board meeting. But it was not to be, although, they added, there were no major issues separating the two sides.
Ray Pellecchia, a spokesman for the New York Stock Exchange, would say only, "We're continuing to work on it." But the continual delays have cast a cloud over the project.
"There's no buzz anywhere that this is a viable project," said one person who has worked on the proposal from the the beginning.
The legislation signed by the governor, however, would allow the city to issue bonds for the project and permit the state to condemn the development site. "The state is honoring its commitment to keep the exchange downtown," said Charles A. Gargano, the chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation. "It's now up to the stock exchange to decide when it wants to move forward."
Alice Meaker, director of Good Jobs New York, an advocacy group supported by private foundations and unions, said, "This is the costliest deal in state history, and it may also be the most dubious.
"It's the most lucrative industry in New York. If corporate welfare were means-tested the same way family welfare is, Wall Street wouldn't qualify for subsidies."
Two years ago, Richard A. Grasso, chairman of the New York Exchange, threatened to move to New Jersey if the city could not help it expand outside its 97-year-old home on Wall Street. Fearing the dissolution of the financial district, Mr. Giuliani announced a tentative agreement in December 1998 to build a $400 million complex and provide $160 million in tax breaks. The stock exchange, in turn, would pay $10 million a year in rent and invest $350 million in new equipment and technology.
But negotiations with the stock exchange have gone slowly ever since, as the project has grown more expensive. The estimated cost of the land is now as high as $450 million. The cost of the trading complex is now set at $535 million, with $225 million coming from the state, $255 million from the city and $55 million from the stock exchange. But instead of two 50,000-square-foot trading floors, there are now plans for only one, with some expansion space.
"It's smaller than what we talked about on Day 1," Mr. Pellecchia said, "but it's still very significant."
Three weeks ago, the stock exchange opened a new computerized 8,000-square-foot trading floor at 30 Broad Street that handles about 15 percent of its trading volume.
In any event, the city has had little luck in luring tenants like Goldman, Sachs and the American International Group to the tower. Last summer, the city asked four major developers if they would be interested in building the project and owning the office tower. But no one was willing to meet the stock exchange's prime condition: to finish it by 2005, with or without a tenant.
Many brokers said that corporations might find the security measures and street closings imposed by the stock exchange unappealing and the rents prohibitive.
Three real estate executives who have talked with city officials say that the tower itself would cost over $500 million, requiring rents of about $65 a square foot -- Midtown prices at a downtown location. (Downtown rents on average are $20 a square foot less.)
And while there was little vacant space a year ago, the proposed tower would be competing with some large blocks of space coming on the market at 55 Water Street, 60 Wall Street and elsewhere. In addition, the city is selling a development site at Greenwich and Warren Streets, and early next year, the state plans to sell a large site at Battery Park City.
"The original rationale for the project has been gradually eroded," said Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University. "There has been a resurgence of real estate in Lower Manhattan. And the exchange has already deployed new technology by opening a satellite facility."

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a new law that lets New York City finance a trading complex and office tower for the New York Stock Exchange misstated the proposed subsidies. The $905 million figure was for cash from city and state (not city tax breaks) and the $160 million was for tax breaks from city and state (not just the state).

LENGTH: 1411 words

HEADLINE: The Big Lie

BYLINE: By V. R. Berghahn; V. R. Berghahn is the Seth Low professor of history and the director of the Institute for the Study of Europe at Columbia University.

 BODY:

 THE THIRD REICH
 A New History.
 By Michael Burleigh.
 Illustrated. 965 pp. New York:
 Hill & Wang. $40. 
 Forty years ago the American journalist William S. Shirer published "The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich." The book became an instant best seller -- notwithstanding its emphasis on foreign policy and military conquest -- and an entire generation of college students plowed through at least some of its 1,400 pages.
Since then there have been any number of Hitler biographies and histories of the Third Reich. Now, with "The Third Reich: A New History," Michael Burleigh successfully adds another interpretation, one that, as he puts it, tells a "very 20th-century story" about the "almost total, moral collapse of an advanced industrial society at the heart of Europe" and about "sections of the German elites and masses of ordinary people" who "chose to abdicate their individual critical faculties in favor of a politics based on faith, hope, hatred and sentimental collective self-regard for their own race and nation."
The subtitle's promise of "a new history" is no mere sales ploy. Burleigh, who is currently the William R. Kenan visiting professor at Washington and Lee University in Virginia, is well regarded as a scholar, the author of several studies on Nazi racism and mass murder. Here he makes good use of an important advantage he holds over such major biographers of Hitler as Joachim Fest and Ian Kershaw. Whereas they took the life of an individual as their point of departure and constant return, Burleigh is freer to pick and choose his central arguments.
Still, this is not a comprehensive history of the Third Reich, a synthesis of all that we have learned about the Nazi dictatorship since Shirer. There are significant aspects of National Socialism that go unmentioned -- for instance, the Nazi economy and the daily life of ordinary Germans. Burleigh believes that if we are to understand this period of German history, the focus must be on police terror, racism, forced sterilization, euthanasia and industrialized mass murder. Why examine Nazi kultur, if this was in essence a barbaric unkultur?
Burleigh's choice of themes is determined by his overall understanding of Nazism. He sees it as both a totalitarian system and a political religion. With his emphasis on the concept of totalitarianism, he places himself in a long line of scholars, which includes Hannah Arendt and Jacob Talmon, who have studied European fascism, and Nazism as its most radical version, within an explicitly comparative framework. In their view, Stalinist Russia and Nazi Germany were modern terroristic dictatorships that were basically (though not entirely) alike, and in any case quite different from Mussolini's Italy or Franco's Spain.
The drawback to this approach is that Burleigh is under pressure to remind the reader at regular intervals of the similarities between Nazism and Communism, but his comparisons amount to no more than very brief references to the Soviet Union. The benefit of his adherence to a theory that sees affinities between the two totalitarian systems is that it enables him to counter a widespread view in the English-speaking world that all Germans were enthusiastic Nazis. In the Third Reich, as he makes clear in a chapter entitled " 'Miss Becker, Your Head Is at Stake, Your Head Is Wobbling,' "Nazi terror from above and the demise of the rule of law started just a few days after Hitler's assumption of power in January 1933. Thenceforth the penalties of opposition became higher and higher. In the first nine months alone, at least 100,000 people, most of them leftist Germans, were thrown into hastily erected concentration camps. Others ended up in ordinary prisons and many died. Countless more were roughed up by rampaging brownshirts in broad daylight or taken into police custody on trumped-up political charges. By 1936, a brutal police state had penetrated virtually all spheres of life.
Among the victims of the first hours of Nazi rule were Germany's Jews. But again, in his quest to draw a nuanced picture, Burleigh shies away from broad generalizations about "the Germans." He stresses that contemporary reports tell many different stories about the level of German anti-Semitism. Above all, his descriptions of the regime's early criminality provide him with the setting for the violence that makes up the central chapters of this book.
Burleigh's analysis is divided into accounts of Nazi barbarism against the domestic population in peacetime and against both foreign and domestic populations during the war. He offers the most comprehensive account to date of how tens of thousands of men and women were forcibly sterilized before the war, how further tens of thousands became victims of a program designed to murder the mentally and physically handicapped, the infirm and the "asocials" (a vague category into which all those who did not conform to Nazi social norms could be fitted). Burleigh is also very good at describing the progressively deteriorating position of Jews and other minorities.
His story gets ever more unsettling as he moves into the war period and examines the mass murder of Jews and Polish elites, and the crazed plans for the resettlement of millions of people. Drawing on the latest research on the genesis of the Holocaust, he offers an illuminating analysis of highly dynamic decision-making processes at the top and at the level of provincial administrators and SS leaders. Here the book challenges Daniel Jonah Goldhagen, who explained the "final solution" in terms of what he called an "eliminationist anti-Semitism" of ordinary Germans. Time and again Burleigh presents other voices and urges us to listen to them, even if they were those of a minority -- islands of humanity in a sea of bloodshed and indifference.
Perhaps the greatest value of this book lies in how it brings together the many jigsaw pieces that produced the Holocaust and other Nazi atrocities. While the murder of Europe's Jews outside the Soviet Union proceeded at specially built camps with methods first tested on the handicapped before the war, the SS Einsatzgruppen and their auxiliaries shot Soviet Jews individually in "Jew hunts," searching for them in the smallest hut and hamlet. At the same time, some four million Soviet Army P.O.W.'s were either executed at the point of capture or deliberately left to die in makeshift open-air camps. Further millions of civilians fell victim to antipartisan swoops and reprisal killings. The reader will put this "new history" down feeling mentally exhausted, emotionally drained and depressed at realizing what human beings are capable of doing to totally innocent fellow human beings.
In trying to explain these unnerving events Burleigh argues that Nazism was a "political religion," a "Hitler cult" that by promising a biologically fixed utopia drove its followers to horrific extremes. The pseudoreligious fanaticism with which Hitler, Himmler and the other perpetrators pursued their enormous crimes to the bitter end is certainly staggering. Nor can there be any doubt that Nazism appealed to millions of Germans because it promised not merely prosperity but greatness, even salvation.
At the same time this study contains plenty of evidence of outright cynicism, "intentional chaos," technocratic rationality, opportunism and crudely calculating manipulation that partly undermines the author's cult hypothesis. What may have looked like utter confusion was in fact a cunningly orchestrated program, one that was able to mobilize such groups as Germany's elites, who were not simply delirious with religious hope and hatred. Other more specialized works, like Frank Bajohr's study of the city of Hamburg, have shown that the amount of nepotism and cold-blooded corruption under the Third Reich was just incredible.
But throughout, Burleigh demonstrates a subtle feel for the particulars, those gray zones of life where wrenching human dilemmas confronted those who cheered and served Hitler as well as those who resisted him. By explicitly shifting away from a focus on anonymous structures, by examining individual action and responsibility so powerfully, Burleigh leaves a reader wondering if it was really necessary for him to put so much emphasis on his totalitarianism and religious cult theories. The cumulative effect of the stories he tells over 900 pages is in itself overwhelming enough.

HEADLINE: Ordaining the Presidents

BYLINE: By Julia Preston; Julia Preston recently completed a five-year tour as a correspondent in Mexico for The Times.

 BODY:

 PERPETUATING POWER
 How Mexican Presidents Were Chosen.
 By Jorge G. Castaneda.
 Translated by Padraic Arthur Smithies.
 248 pp. New York:
 The New Press. $26. 
 Jorge G. Casta--eda, who has been named Mexico's foreign minister by President Vicente Fox Quesada, was a familiar figure to those Americans who follow Mexico even before his recent appointment. Because he is both quick of wit and bilingual, he is often sought by American journalists, especially television correspondents, for a pithy phrase to elucidate the latest crisis. For some years now, through his columns in Newsweek and several newspapers, and through the courses he teaches at New York University, Castaneda has been a leading interpreter of Mexico's politics to confounded observers beyond its borders.
"Perpetuating Power," however, makes it clear that Castaneda is more than a master of the Mexican sound bite. With this unusually revealing explication of the inner workings of three decades of presidential succession, Castaneda establishes himself as one of the most insightful Mexican intellectuals of his generation.
Several years ago, Castaneda set out to write a systematic anthropology of the pivotal ritual of Mexican politics -- the handover of power from one omnipotent president to the next -- based on personal accounts from those best prepared to provide the raw data: the four living ex-presidents, Luis Echeverria, Jose Lopez Portillo, Miguel de la Madrid and Carlos Salinas de Gortari.
In itself the idea was a breakthrough. Theater, ruse and mystery were always key components of el sistema, as Mexicans called the all-embracing single-party state that began its domination in the 1920's. To cite the most obvious example, the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, staged elaborate presidential elections every six years, even though the next president had already been chosen by the incumbent. That choice (known as the dedazo, the finger tap) took place in hushed tones behind closed palace doors, in a rite that was always portrayed as too sacred and subtle to be exposed to scrutiny by the common citizen.
Castaneda has pierced through that scrim, and even though he has been a sassy opponent of the PRI regime, he got the interviews he needed. The book consists of essays analyzing each succession since 1970, followed by transcribed talks with the former presidents.
Castaneda's timing is part of the brilliance of his book. It was published in Mexico before the presidential election last July 2, when, after years of popular ferment, Mexicans were finally allowed an open and clean vote. They chose Vicente Fox, an opposition leader, ousting the PRI regime after 71 years in power. The dedazo will never be employed again. Castaneda took his group portrait in the final twilight, when the PRI system was still full of its old arrogance.
Twentieth-century Mexico has long been a conundrum. On the one hand, the PRI was the most stable regime in Latin America, providing continuity and economic growth while other countries struggled with revolution or dictatorship. But the PRI also subjected Mexicans to spectacularly venal, arbitrary and sometimes violent government. How, then, did it keep itself in power?
Castaneda helps resolve the puzzle. The "nearly magical clockwork" by which each president settled on the one to follow him was fully understood only by a handful of top PRI politicians trained in years of service in the temples of government. The game held together because it was limited to a small core of competitors who accepted the rules since the prize -- the right to rule like a king -- was so alluring.
At the same time, Castaneda shows how the selection process was based increasingly on the personal idiosyncrasies, ambitions, fears and tactical skills of the incumbent and the candidates to be his candidate -- based, in short, on anything but a consideration of the best policy path for Mexico. In 1970, Luis Echeverria perceived that President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz would instinctively reject any official who attempted a dialogue with the opposition, then severely weakened by the 1968 massacre of student protesters in Tlatelolco Plaza. Echeverria, the highest cabinet official, conspicuously avoided any talks, winning the tap for himself and leaving Mexico with scars that have not healed to this day.
Similarly, at least twice the favor of the sitting president was won by contenders who concealed crucial information about the decline of the economy. Castaneda tells how Carlos Salinas annihilated an opponent who made the mistake of being candid with President de la Madrid about looming economic perils, which did in fact materialize after Salinas became the candidate.
The selection process had myriad unwritten codes, some curious, many perverse. Most dangerous, betrayal was integral to the drama. The president, who needed to conserve his own power by keeping the competition alive as long as possible, had to deceive with false encouragement the two or three contenders he did not intend to tap.
Castaneda draws a distinction between those successions in which the president acted by choice and others where he had no choice he liked and acted instead by elimination. But either way, the dedazo generated jealousies and bitterness that built up within the system.
Knowing that the intermingling of personal and political was important in the closed PRI regime, Castaneda offers rich stories of romantic dalliance and political swordplay. While each presidential interview provides new material, the most expansive is with Lopez Portillo, who acknowledges that the greatest of political decisions was often made by factors with "the weight of a hair."
When it was first released in Mexico, Castaneda's book caused a sensation as Mexicans scrambled to get a look inside the inner sanctum of power. In Padraic Arthur Smithies's translation, "Perpetuating Power" is shorter by about half than the original. To make it more accessible to non-Mexicans, the entire manuscript was pruned and the explanatory essays were placed before the interviews. Still, even the translated version is not for beginners. It relies on countless references to Mexican events and politicians with no introductory detail.
Castaneda was an early supporter of Vicente Fox from the left. Now the president and his foreign minister must face the challenge laid out in this book. They must prove that electoral democracy can control and channel the "furor and delirium" of Mexican politics, as Castaneda puts it, more effectively than the PRI.
