HEADLINE: A Realist's Picaresque

BYLINE: By Laura Secor; Laura Secor is a senior editor at Lingua Franca.

 BODY:

 Eastward to Tartary
 Travels in the Balkans,
 the Middle East, and the Caucasus.
 By Robert D. Kaplan.
 364 pp. New York:
 Random House. $26.95. 
 Robert D. Kaplan would like to show you the world -- from Plovdiv, Bulgaria, to Tbilisi, Georgia, and beyond. He will shuttle you across the Caspian Sea, from Baku to Turkmenbashi, on a squalid freighter where beautiful women in old nightgowns carry "shopping bags full of evil-smelling food." There is just about no place Kaplan, a prolific travel writer and political journalist, hasn't visited. Erudite and intrepid, with a pantheon of elite contacts all over the world, he is a deft guide to wherever he chooses to lead you.
But "Eastward to Tartary" is not only an account of Kaplan's travels in the Balkans, the Middle East and the Caucasus. It is also a revealing study of what Kaplan frequently calls the "new Silk Roads" now winding through formerly closed lands. Caspian oil, Kaplan predicts, and the pipelines that will funnel it to the West, are about to wreak enormous changes in this part of the world, already shattered by the fall of the Soviet Union. "What the Balkans were to the 1990's," Kaplan writes, "the Caspian region might be to the first decade of the new century: an explosive region that draws in the Great Powers."
But be forewarned: Kaplan is not a disinterested guide. He is a realist, on the model of Henry Kissinger. Self-interest and power politics govern affairs of state, Kaplan admonishes, and it's for the best that they do: "Self-interest at its healthiest implicitly recognizes the self-interest of others, and therein lies the possibility of compromise. A rigid moral position admits few compromises." Consistent with this view is Kaplan's contention that authoritarian regimes are often preferable to weak democracies. In the countries he visits, Kaplan claims, "civil society will likely be introduced only by force and Machiavellian tactics." If we want to see Western ideals, not to mention vital American interests, protected in these regions, he maintains, we must be prepared to exercise a strong economic and military hand.
Inevitably, this outlook raises disturbing moral questions: How can competing self-interests in, say, the Middle East be reconciled without considerations of principle and justice? Why recommend for others a form of government we would find unacceptable for ourselves? And Kaplan never explains what would compel authoritarian governments to undermine themselves by building democratic institutions. The hard-nosed realism with which he regards fledgling democracies seems to soften when he considers the motives of dictators or the negotiability of power, blood, lust and greed. Elections, he rightly notes, have brought nationalist demagogues to power in places like Bosnia. But so have military coups, civil wars, foreign interventions and other nondemocratic means. True, democracies abroad could produce leaders, and politics, we dislike. But this is perhaps the single worst reason to oppose them.
Despite Kaplan's avowed commitment to realist precepts, "Eastward to Tartary" often seems animated by a more troubling view of the world. Something Kaplan calls "national character" plays a significant role in his analysis. The notion of collective national identity is, he recognizes, unpopular among intellectuals. "However, a viewpoint is not necessarily inaccurate because it happens to be morally risky and pessimistic," he says, "especially if it helps explain phenomena that are otherwise unexplainable."
But national identity turns out to be an exceedingly weak explanatory tool. Kaplan relays in all seriousness the following comment from one of his contacts: "In Georgia, a civil war was necessary because of the kind of people we are. The real cause of the war is our medievalness."
His depiction of Stalin as an "Oriental" despot "from the Caucasus mountains, where Russia ends and the Near East begins," is equally fatuous: "To say that the Oriental influence was merely incidental to his character is to ignore its essentials. The monumental use of terror, the very grandeur of his personality cult and the use of prison labor for gigantic public works projects echo the ancient Assyrian and Mesopotamian tyrannies."
Soviet totalitarianism did not originate with Stalin's Oriental character. Nor were its means unique to the East -- Kaplan's description applies equally to that very Western tyrant Adolf Hitler. To be sure, in "Balkan Ghosts," an earlier work from 1993, Kaplan blamed Yugoslavia for Hitler: "Nazism, for instance, can claim Balkan origins. Among the flophouses of Vienna, a breeding ground of ethnic resentments close to the southern Slavic world, Hitler learned how to hate so infectiously."
"Eastward to Tartary" is in part a sequel to "Balkan Ghosts." With its acknowledged debt to Rebecca West, "Balkan Ghosts" was a prime example of the genre that scholars of the region call "Balkanism": the Western traveler ventures across the frontier of what he or she considers civilization, and finds in the Balkans a land of animal passions, mysticism, violence and sensuality. "The Balkans" is a name not for a peninsula in southeast Europe but for Enlightened Europe's id unleashed -- primitive, repellent, titillating. "This was a time-capsule world: a dim stage upon which people raged, spilled blood, experienced visions and ecstasies," Kaplan wrote in 1993.
"Eastward to Tartary" is a more sophisticated work than "Balkan Ghosts." Kaplan has matured as a stylist and as a political analyst, but he can still describe Turkish political parties as "chieftaincies" and rhapsodize about the "pagan mystery" and "dusky sensuality" underlying Eastern Orthodoxy. East and West are not compass directions for him but categories freighted with imaginative significance. Thus, downtown Budapest is in the West, but its impoverished outskirts lie in the East; Georgia is largely in the East, but its oil terminal and capital city are outposts of the West; rural Azerbaijan is in the East, but its capital, Baku, is "a little piece of Europe"; and Armenia, despite its geographical location, is in the Balkans. The result is a frustratingly fragmented picture, with a West that cannot have produced Hitler and an East that cannot include rationality or cosmopolitanism.
Such suprageographical divisions recall the work of Samuel P. Huntington, the Harvard political theorist who published a famous article, "The Clash of Civilizations?," in Foreign Affairs in 1993, and turned that article into the book "The Clash of Civilizations and the Remaking of World Order" a few years later. Both Huntington and Kaplan see in the map of the ancient world a set of tectonic plates that move beneath the current one, causing its quakes and upheavals and ultimately determining its fate. For Kaplan, this perspective leads to the impression that history moves backward. As he tells one contact in Lebanon, "Middle East politics are like those of the ancient world -- a Greek or a Roman could understand them better than an American." Envisioning the collapse of Syria and Georgia, new alliances formed along commerce routes, the end of the bipolar Arab-Israeli conflict and the birth of "more complex systems of strife," Kaplan characteristically remarks, "It would be like ancient times."
There is a romantic appeal to this picture of history unfurling in reverse, but it unduly minimizes the significance of recent events. The 20th century has, after all, produced more than its own share of bloodshed and conquest. Even in the Balkans, so famously obsessed with ancient history, it is the living memory of World War II that has been recapitulated and manipulated to most malign effect. The rise and fall of empires, the eddies that carry cultural influences across the globe and back again, the contemporary distribution of power and resources among nations, the changing world order outside of Europe, the rise of United States power -- all these things make for a world not cleaved along archaic frontiers but shaped by infinitely complex and layered relationships.
Kaplan's parsing and splitting between the East and the West, as well as his heavy-handed invocation of the distant past, do a disservice to his considerable knowledge of ancient history and his acute observations of the troubles ahead. For he tends to boil away much of the world's subtlety and complexity -- its capacity to be at once sensual and sophisticated, vicious and civilized, shaped by the distant and the recent past, by history but also by politics, by self-interest but also by principle. To integrate all of this into a coherent whole is the great challenge. Should Kaplan attempt it, he might show us a more realistic world than "Eastward to Tartary," for all its discernment, evokes.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 64; Column 3; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 575 words

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 12-10-00: Economics of: Fuel-Cell Cars;
Ulterior Motors

BYLINE: By Alec Appelbaum 

 BODY:

The collapse of the climate talks in the Netherlands last month isn't likely to impede the development of easy-on-the-environment cars in this country. California is still requiring that 10 percent of the cars sold there be emission free by 2003, and Massachusetts and New York are adopting similar laws. All the big automakers are promising to sell so-called fuel-cell cars by 2004, but should we have to wait even that long? After all, fuel-cell technology -- which harnesses the energy released when hydrogen is combined with oxygen from the air (water instead of carbon dioxide is the byproduct) -- has been around for more than 150 years. Last month, both Ford and DaimlerChrysler showed off prototype cars powered by environment-friendly hydrogen. We could use those now: Americans are responsible for the release of more than two tons of vehicle-produced greenhouse gases a year per person. Bringing cleaner cars to the marketplace, however, has been fraught with obstacles.
 
THE CELL
Department of Energy studies indicate fuel cells today would cost $141 per kilowatt. (A kilowatt will boil a quart of cool water in six minutes; a 75-kilowatt car engine is roughly the equal of a 100-horsepower engine.) But the car industry believes fuel-cell engines won't compete with conventional ones until they cost less than $50 a kilowatt; Directed Technologies, a consulting company, expects that fuel-cell systems will eventually cost $37 a kilowatt. Paul Lancaster, vice president for finance for the Canadian fuel-cell maker Ballard Power Systems, says his company could compete economically with conventional engines at that price if it sold enough fuel cells yearly to power the equivalent of 300,000 cars. 

THE FUEL
Ford says it can mass-produce hydrogen cars once 10,000 natural-gas-reforming pumps -- at $250,000 to $1.5 million each -- are installed at filling stations around the country. (The National Renewable Energy Laboratory is testing ways to extract hydrogen from algae, but natural gas is more viable for now.) Gasoline can be converted to hydrogen fuel inside individual cars, but this means costly additions to the fuel-cell system (and carbon emissions). An Energy Department study has concluded that producing hydrogen for fuel-cell use today would cost the equivalent of $1.92 per gallon.
 
THE CHICKEN (CELL) AND THE EGG (FUEL)
Which must come first? Inspiration may, in fact, come from an extravehicular source. International Fuel Cells says around 35 fuel-cell systems a year are sold to power buildings (200 total so far); those generating electricity for the Conde Nast building in Times Square and the First National Bank of Omaha's data center are the most visible. According to Jae Edmonds, an economist at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, "piping around hydrogen becomes much more plausible" as more big buildings deploy the technology. Another way to speed up the merger of fuel cells and cars: make the cars use less fuel. Amory Lovins, a physicist and designer, founded Hypercar Inc. to build light cars from carbon fiber, which he says would yield fuel efficiency many times greater than that of steel cars; Zoltek, one of two big American suppliers, aims to sell carbon fiber for $5 per pound next year, which could make it competitive with steel. Many admire Lovins's ingenuity, if not his business instincts: picture the lawyers after the first accident. -- Alec Appelbaum

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TICKER: BLDP (NASDAQ) (55%); BLD (TSX) (55%);

SECTION: Section 11; Page 5; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1596 words

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Holmdel, N.J.;
Grazing Cattle and a Growing Population

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW 

 BODY:
BEEF cattle graze in a pasture across Crawfords Corner Road from the Holmdel, N.J., municipal complex, just a quarter mile from sprawling million-dollar custom homes. About one-third open space, including 2,000 acres of farmland, this 17.9-square-mile Monmouth County community has excellent schools and easy access to New York City via the Garden State Parkway.
It also is home to one of the most prestigious performing arts centers in the state, the PNC Bank Arts Center, formerly the Garden State Arts Center, and to Lucent Technologies, the former Bell Laboratories. 
 "The problem is that everyone wants to move here," Mayor Gary D. Aumiller said. "If we are not careful, development will take over our open space that people move here for."
Mayor Aumiller, like many other Holmdel residents, is concerned about the rapid growth in population, from 11,000 in 1990 to about 15,500 today. Nowhere is that growth felt more than in the 3,400-student Holmdel public school system, which completed a $19.5 million expansion in 1998 and is already overcrowded again, compared to other areas of the state. Class size from prekindergarten to sixth grade averages 23, and in grades 7 to 12 the average is 25, compared with a state average of 21.
"We are still growing by 4 percent per year," said Dr. Leigh S. Byron, the superintendent of schools. "We have appointed a committee of politicians, school officials, parents and senior citizens to help us decide how to meet the challenge of growth. We will have to either expand the schools again or build another school."
Mayor Aumiller defines his administration's mission as "controlled growth" after the 1990's, which saw the development of 900 town houses and hundreds of new homes on half-acre lots in the northern section, near the Hazlet line. The town council has opposed efforts by developers to have the sewer system, which serves only the northern third of the township, extended south.
This has allowed the township to enforce 2 1/2-acre zoning for the construction of new housing in the southern part and has complicated the already rigorous review processes for new subdivision applications. The net result is that approvals for new construction projects often take two years or more.
"There's not a year when we are not sued by developers," the mayor said. "If we allowed sewers in the south, we would be unable to defend our zoning, and the developers would force us to open large tracts to much more housing."
At the same time as it tries to restrict development, the township is raising money for the purchase of open space through a special property tax of 2.5 cents per $100 of assessed valuation.
At the end of November, 70 single-family homes were listed for sale on the Multiple Listing Service. Prices ranged from $161,900 for a small three-bedroom, one-bath colonial on Bethany Road in the northern section, to $1,750,000 for a five-bedroom, six-bath contemporary with a four-car garage on Arbor Lane in the southern section. "Priced correctly, a house here will sell within three weeks," said Claude Ranieri, broker-owner of Re/Max American Reality Associates.
Typically, 1,500-square-foot, three-bedroom split-levels, bilevels and ranches on a half acre or less on streets like Crescent Road or Miller Avenue in the northern section sell for from $230,000 to $325,000, Mr. Ranieri said. Fifteen-year-old four-bedroom colonials on half- to one-acre lots in the northern section start at about $380,000 and go as high as $840,000.
Among the more prestigious streets is Takolusa Drive, in the northeastern section. Built in the 1980's in a variety of custom styles, some of the homes were originally sold with new Mercedes automobiles in their garages. Four homes are currently listed for sale on Takolusa, ranging from $799,000 to $1.3 million.
THERE are five town-house developments, all in the sewered northern section. The largest is the Orchard, a 347-unit community built in the early 1990's off Laurel Avenue and Route 35. Two-bedroom units in the Orchards recently sold for from $205,000 to $225,000, with three-bedrooms going for about $15,000 more.
The few rental units in town are mainly town houses. Typically, two-bedrooms rent for between $1,800 and $2,000 a month, with three-bedrooms going for about $250 more.
Among the newer residents are Frank P. Covino, his wife, Jean M. Covino, and their two children, Adam, 8, and Chelsea, 2. The Covinos, who own a chain of college bookstores, moved to Holmdel two years ago for the school system, Mr. Covino said. They bought a 16-year-old four-bedroom colonial on one acre on Red Coach Lane in the northern section.
"Although we are very happy with the community and the way families are involved in their children's sporting events," Mr. Covino said, "we had no idea that the school population would explode so quickly. Had we known that, we might have reconsidered our choice."
Just down the road from the Covinos is an example of the town's growth. Ground has just been broken on a new development called Highgate, which has approval for 117 homes. "Since these won't be small homes, figure three children per household and you see the problem," Mr. Covino said.
Despite Holmdel's current growth, it was actually a late bloomer. The first European settlers arrived in the late 17th century, according to Linda Madge, president of the Holmdel Historical Society. The brothers Obadiah and Jonathan Holmes, who were sons of a famous Connecticut Baptist minister, also named Obadiah Holmes, began farming in the area.
Other early settlers included an Englishman, Richard Stout, and a Dutch captain, John Bowne, an ancestor of President Abraham Lincoln. Originally called Baptistown, it adopted the name Holmdel in 1857 to open a post office. Baptistown was already the name of a municipality in northern New Jersey.
Holmdel remained a sleepy farming community until the early 1960's, when the American Telephone & Telegraph Company acquired a 400-acre tract and started building its Bell Labs research facility on the site. That complex, off Crawfords Corner Road, was spun off from AT&T as Lucent Technologies and now includes about two million square feet of floor space and employs nearly 5,000 people.
"Bell Labs started our population growth and established the character of the town," said Mayor Aumiller, who moved to Holmdel as a Bell Labs scientist. "Until the 1980's, scientists were the predominant population group. But now we also have many Wall Street people and professionals -- doctors and lawyers."
Holmdel's commercial activity is mainly on New Jersey Route 35, which has a series of strip malls, and in the Holmdel Town Center, which has approximately 30 stores, including the township's only supermarket and four restaurants. Among the best-known stores on the highway is Dearborn Farms, situated in an old red barn. It sells fruits, vegetables and plants.
Holmdel has four public schools -- Village (kindergarten through second grade), Indian Hill (third through sixth grade), William R. Satz (seventh and eighth grade) and Holmdel High School. The main beneficiary of the recent expansion was Indian Hill, which added a wing that included a gymnasium, science laboratories and 34 rooms.
Dr. Byron, the schools superintendent, said that despite the overcrowding the school system provides "quality education that mirrors the best private schools." The high school's College Board scores, a combined mathematics and verbal average of 1,176, are 160 points above the state average. Last year, 97 percent of Holmdel High School's 210-student graduating class went on to higher education. The high school offers 11 advanced placement courses in the sciences, English, economics, computers, history and government.
The school system emphasizes technology, with computers introduced in prekindergarten classes. Much of the technology is provided by local organizations, which infuse about a quarter million dollars a year into the system for extras not included in the school budget. The largest of these organizations, the Holmdel Foundation for Economic Excellence, has raised $100,000 in each of the last three years for computers and science equipment, and mini-grants of up to $1,500 each for special projects.
HOLMDEL has two Roman Catholic schools, both coeducational -- St. John Vianney High School for ninth through 12th grades, and St. Benedict School for kindergarten through eighth grade.
Holmdel has six municipal parks, the largest of which is the 30-acre Crossfarms Park off Longstreet Road. It has three baseball diamonds, two soccer fields and one football field. Also in the township is Holmdel Park, a 343-acre Monmouth County park, Holmdel Park, which includes playgrounds, a sledding hill, nature trails, fishing and skating ponds, an arboretum and Longstreet Farm, a working 1890's farm.
Perhaps the most outstanding recreational facility in Holmdel is the PNC Bank Arts Center, which was built by the Garden State Parkway Authority and is at Exit 114 of the parkway. A world-class concert and entertainment center, the facility is now holding its Holiday Light Spectacular, which includes 130 displays and more than a million lights spread over a two-mile driving trail.
The center also has the New Jersey Vietnam Veterans Memorial and the Vietnam Era Educational Center. The memorial consists of 366 granite slabs, one for each day, including Feb. 29, arranged in a 200-foot circle. It lists the 1,553 state residents killed or missing in action in Vietnam.

Mr. Wilson lived in Holmdel and Mr. Penzias was a resident of Highland Park, N.J., about 25 miles to the north.

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Sills's Queens At Last Reclaim Their Thrones

BYLINE: By MATTHEW GUREWITSCH 

 BODY:
IN the office of the chairman of Lincoln Center hangs a whimsical yet imposing memento of its occupant's former life. A queen-size quilt, three panels wide by five panels high, hand-stitched by the women of the San Diego Opera Guild (their own names sewn into the back), it depicts highlights from the career of Beverly Sills, America's most scintillating diva of the last half-century. The faces of the characters she played are bisque china. The dresses are cut from snippets of her own original costumes. And at the center of the assembly -- circled by the likes of Handel's Cleopatra, Bellini's Norma, Massenet's Manon, Lehar's Merry Widow and Douglas Moore's Baby Doe -- stand Donizetti's three Tudor queens.
On top, Gloriana herself: Elizabeth as aging icon, from "Roberto Devereux." Next down, Elizabeth's mother, the hapless Anne Boleyn, or Anna Bolena. And at the bottom, Elizabeth's seditious Mary, Queen of Scots, or Mary Stuart, best known to those who learn their history at the opera house as Maria Stuarda. A quarter-century ago, they ruled across the plaza at the New York City Opera. Right now, in a boxed CD reissue by Deutsche Grammophon (289 465 967-2; seven CD's), they rule the Billboard charts and bask in a straight five-star approval rating from the customer-reviewers of Amazon.com. 
 Informally, the works in which the three queens appear -- "Anna Bolena" (1830), "Maria Stuarda" (1835) and "Roberto Devereux" (1837) -- have come to be known as Donizetti's "Tudor trilogy," a coinage that gained currency three decades ago, as Ms. Sills took them on, in reverse chronological order, at the City Opera. In fact, the composer conceived them independently, to librettos by different authors, and introduced them in three different theaters, in Milan and Naples.
Elizabeth, the prima donna of "Roberto Devereux," is the seconda donna of "Maria Stuarda," so the "trilogy" required different sopranos in that part, defying conventional continuity. And truth to tell, the operas' structural similarities (collapsing emotional triangles, a backdrop of courtiers hanging around for fatal decisions being made offstage) make them less than optimal companion pieces.
Never mind. As everyone recognized from the start of the project, Ms. Sills was making history in her own right. Her Elizabeth -- chalked visage a masterpiece of maquillage, gown 55 pounds of artfully draped and ornamented upholstery velvet -- made the cover of Time.
The notion of linking the three operas had been as much an economy measure as an artistic statement, allowing big corners to be cut on decor and wardrobe. The productions, in tautly theatrical period style, were "devised and directed" by Tito Capobianco with crucial assistance from his wife, Gigi Capobianco. The sets were Ming Cho Lee's, the costumes (perhaps a mite overdressy and literal to current tastes) by Jose Va rona. Julius Rudel, then the general director of the City Opera, conducted "Devereux" and "Bolena," passing the baton to Charles Wilson for "Stuarda."
On both sides of the footlights, the air was electric. In the first "Devereux," Ms. Sills slapped Placido Domingo so hard, his mustache came unstuck and reattached itself under his eye. (Luckily, his back was to the audience.) At the end of one "Stuarda," as Mary's head lay on the block under the raised ax of the executioner, a woman's voice from the house pierced the tense silence with a cry, "No, no!" As the climax to the whole affair, Ms. Sills tackled all three operas not only within a single season (a schedule devised to boost subscription sales) but also within a single week.
Not surprisingly, the excitement created demand for recordings, and the triptych was duly taped in London, beginning with "Devereux" in 1969. The others followed at two-year intervals. This was deep in the LP era -- and unfortunately, for any who hoped for the Sills queens' timely reappearance at the advent of the CD, the label was Audio Treasury, a minor subsidiary of ABC that was subsequently absorbed into other corporations indifferent to the concerns of the classical market. Sprung from limbo, the recordings now take their place of honor alongside BMG's reissue of Ms. Sills's classic RCA Victor "Julius Caesar," EMI's studio versions of her "Traviata" and "Manon" from the 70's (still in the CD catalog after a dozen years), and, from VAI, a live "Tales of Hoffmann" from New Orleans, a souvenir of the diva's glory years of the late 60's, with Ms. Sills singing the four heroines in one night.
"I'll never be one of those women who goes home and plays her records," she said recently at her desk at Lincoln Center. "Some of them, I haven't even heard. I finally listened to 'Manon,' which I like. I haven't listened to these three ladies. But I'm glad they're there. In the end, that's all that's left of a career."
By her own account, Ms. Sills at first felt no great itch to play Elizabeth. Only a nine-page letter from her coach Roland Gagnon -- which she kept for years in her "Deve reux" score (one of the few she has not given away) -- persuaded her to take another look. And what captured her imagination when she did was not the music but a couple of lines of text: "Pria d'offender chi nascea del tremendo ottavo Enrico,/ Scender vivo nel sepolcro tu dovevi, o traditor" ("Before insulting the scion of the awe-striking Henry VIII,/ Better, o traitor, you had descended living to the tomb").
"I couldn't wait to turn around and deliver that line," she says. "It's like shooting off a cannon."
That her slender, silvery, chimelike voice in no way resembled a cannon did not trouble her. "The voice didn't matter," she says. "What mattered was what Elizabeth was saying." This from an artist who always regretted her limited possibilities in Verdi: "It isn't that I couldn't have sung the notes. But to hear the 'Miserere' in 'Il Trovatore' in my voice would have disappointed me, so what would the point have been in that?"
And here lies the crux of the spellbinding threefold achievement documented in the long-awaited reissue. From the point of view of vocal stereotype -- a point of view surely not altogether irrelevant to the composer's intentions -- Ms. Sills was strange casting for the "Devereux" Elizabeth. The aged monarch's proud, fierce yet vulnerable personality seems at crucial points to imply a bitter, smoldering timbre, more complex than the shimmering, clear-water purity Ms. Sills displayed on the heights. That her soprano lacked force in the middle and lower registers, turning gray and approaching speech, might also have given her pause.
Who knows? Had she heard, for instance, the coruscating Turkish diva and Donizetti champion Leyla Gencer in the part -- as an interested listener can do today in Gala's budget recording live from Naples in 1964 -- she might have backed off completely. But for all intents and purposes, Ms. Sills was inscribing a blank page. The flurry of interest in neglected Donizetti that began sweeping Europe in the late 50's (the "Anna Bolena" of Maria Callas at La Scala in 1957 is also germane) took place beyond her ken and that of her audiences.
"My sound did not disappoint me in the part," Ms. Sills now says of Elizabeth. "I didn't have an enormous, heavy orchestra to ride over. It didn't occur to me that the music required a voice different from mine, and I don't think that it did."
Encountering (or re-encountering) Ms. Sills's three queens on disc feels like meeting them for the first time, and the diva is right: the voice, as such, did not matter. She could weight lines by sheer phrasing, rather than by tone, investing descending lines with the inexorable pull of gravity itself. The passage that first attracted her makes the perfect test case, lying as it does in the heart of the diva's parched midregister. But as noted, the orchestra is on good behavior, underpinning the vocal line first with plucked chords and then with long legato lines that hum with drama but present the singer with no significant competition.
Ms. Gencer's reading here, delivered with the pulsing, full-blooded heft of the Verdian she was, has a mournful pathos. Ms. Sills, by contrast, lands each word -- and Donizetti has her repeat the most frightening of them over and over -- like a deliberate plunge of a dagger, twisting it again in every wound. Toward the end her cold fury spends itself in fleeting grief. The last word -- "traditor" ("traitor") -- comes forth in a gulping tone that sounds exhausted and destroyed.
Ms. Sills has said that she always resisted "normal," "standard" interpretations of her characters. Her social-climbing chambermaid Adele, in "Die Fledermaus," a role she assumed late in her career, drank a little: a Carol Burnett-worthy choice dictated by Ms. Sill's stature, figure, years and personality, none of them compatible with the simperings of the conventional soubrette.
But deep down, she was never an artist who played her roles as extensions of herself (as many of today's most exciting artists do), nor one who went prowling for "angles." With every resource at her disposal -- pose, gesture and costume no less than words, notes and phrases -- she probed for the palpable reality of the women she played. She steeped herself in the history of the Tudor queens. Though she was scarcely above showing off her brilliant technique, her musical embellishments had to stand the test of dramatic expressivity. Trills -- and hers were perfection -- might be comic or tragic, bedazzled or bereft. An interpolated high D in the final act of "Deve reux" -- omitted in the recording at the insistence of the conductor, Charles Mackerras -- was never, in Ms. Sills's mind, a high note for the sake of a high note.
"At this point, Elizabeth is a frail, dying woman," she says. "Toward the end of her life, she was afraid to lie down, because she thought she would die if she did. So she sat up until she dropped. As long as I could sing the high D piano and not belt it out, it was right to do it. I didn't want audiences to say, 'Look, she's singing a high D.' That was not the point. It had to be a plaintive wail." The note is heard on VAI's video of a performance at Wolf Trap in 1975, by which time the heights had become effortful, but the dramatic integrity of the choice is not in doubt.
The three-queens set is full of such epiphanies. No doubt the most tremendous occurs in Mary's great confrontation with Elizabeth, from whom Mary hopes to gain a royal pardon. But Elizabeth's taunts sting Mary's pride, and she responds in kind, throwing Elizabeth's questionable legitimacy in her face, luxuriating in suicidal satisfaction. As Anna Bolena, Ms. Sills twists, sometimes piteously, sometimes hysterically, on a hook of the deceitful character's own contriving, and if the overall effort falls short of the other two, the fault lies with the ramshackle construction of the drama.
Much remains to say of the recordings, but we must be brief. Of the City Opera casts, not one other principal survived. Mr. Domingo, contractually unavailable for "Deve reux," was very honorably replaced by Robert Ilosfalvy, a Hungarian whose mature and manly sound makes a telling contrast to the honeyed lyricism of the Welshman Stuart Burrows in the (lesser) tenor leads of the other operas.
In "Devereux," Beverly Wolff, taking over as Sara, Duchess of Nottingham, from Susan Marsee, painted a poignant figure in rich and golden tones. Spelling Pauline Tinsley, the Elizabeth of the "Stuarda" recording is none other than Eileen Farrell, whose only other major recording of a complete opera was as Marie in "Wozzeck," and while her doubling of Italian consonants is strictly hit or miss, the authority of the voice and the presence are like a force of nature. Anna Bolena's reluctant nemesis, Giovanna (Jane) Seymour -- another of Ms. Marsee's City Opera roles -- fell to Shirley Verrett, blending impulsive passion with her characteristic aristocratic finesse.
THE principal male role as yet unmentioned is the distant, disenchanted Henry VIII of "Anna Bolena," originally Robert Hale but in the recording Paul Plishka, his hauteur seldom tempered by any audible stirring of the heart.
As noted, "Devereux" was recorded in 1969, a year in advance of the City Opera production. Ms. Sills notes that for dramatic veracity, the stage version stripped away much of the bel canto embellishment heard on disc. The orchestra was the Royal Philharmonic. "Stuarda," with the London Philharmonic, was led by Aldo Ceccato (1971). Mr. Rudel, leading the London Symphony, finally got his chance with "Bolena" (1973). Each opera involved a different London chorus.
A final note. When Ms. Sills segued (literally overnight) from City Opera house diva to general manager, she did her best to keep the three queens in the active repertory. In 1980, she cast Olivia Stapp as Anna Bolena; in 1981, Ashley Putnam appeared as Maria Stuarda: valiant attempts that failed to establish an accepted line of succession. Then, in 1985, came the devastating fire at the costume warehouse that threatened to put the City Opera out of business. Replacing the costly Tudor wardrobe was out of the question.
"If it hadn't been for the fire," Ms. Sills says today, "I probably would have brought 'Devereux' back." As luck would have it, her three costumes for the opera were out on a tour -- "in Romania somewhere," she says -- and so survived. But really, who was at hand to wear them? No hand-me-downs for Lauren Flanigan when, several administrations later, the City Opera at last gave "Devereux" a second chance with the new production that opened the current season. Even so, the new Elizabeth could not escape Ms. Sills's long shadow.

PUB-DATE: December 10, 2000

SECTION: Section 2; Page 37; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1718 words

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
Arranging to Capture Ambiguous Moments

BYLINE: By VICKI GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y.

 BODY:
SOME people are resigned to the way things are and some are not. Some artists are resigned to the limitations of their craft, some even delight in them; some do not. Many photographers do not. Resignation does not fit well in their pockets.
All of them know that their medium is irrevocably tied to the here and now: the here of material existence before the lens, and the now of the discrete moment when the shutter opens. Cameras are obviously ill equipped to handle matters of pure intellect, philosophy or conjecture, the past, the future or extended time. Some photographers simply consider these facts a challenge. 
 Graciela Iturbide, the Mexican photographer, is like that. Sometimes she uses her camera to register the discrete moment when the world sends a message that interests her; at other times, she rearranges the world to great advantage. "Images of the Spirit: Photographs by Graciela Iturbide," a fine exhibition of more than 100 black-and-white photographs at the Parrish Art Museum here, makes clear her preference for elusive circumstances that are hard to extract from life in a fraction of a second.
She finds ways to photograph transitions, ambiguities and inferences, as in images of transvestites who present themselves as women and seem so for a moment. She works with states of becoming and of vanishing, such as a woman playing a piano in a cemetery while totally veiled in mist as if she were a ghost, or a man whose upper body has turned to a mere swipe of gray, as if a region of shadows were progressively taking him over. Ms. Iturbide also puts a high value on events and enterprises that read as metaphor and symbol, like a commercial slaughter of a goat that she captions "Lamb of God."
The show, which is on view through Jan. 7, was organized by the Alfred Stieglitz Center at the Philadelphia Museum of Art and is accompanied by a book of 81 images published by Aperture. It will travel to Santa Fe, N.M., and Austin, Tex., next year.
Ms. Iturbide, born in 1942, was already married and the mother of three children when she decided to be a film director. She switched to still photography after a course with Manuel Alvarez Bravo, Mexico's first modernist master, and she worked as his assistant for a year and a half. His influence is palpable in her lighting, in occasional compositions and in a general tenor of sweet, melancholy poetry, but she is far more committed to staged tableaus and symbolic gesture than he, and her voice is her own.
She depicts (and sometimes enlarges on) a country in constant transition, where old and new exist side by side and reformulate themselves as they go. Sometimes these shifts are simply generational (and probably inexorable). In "Matron," a woman sits in some splendor, wearing a traditional dress embroidered with flowers, a pleated flounce at the hem of her long skirt, while two women behind her arrange her hair. At the side of the picture, a boy in a Spider-Man T-shirt and paper party hat casually aims a toy pistol.
Such apparently incompatible elements frequently keep company in these photographs. Indian and folk traditions share space with contemporary pop while the mythic goes head to head with the commonplace and life with death. As for death, reverent or mocking or frightening or angry or resigned or cynical or admonitory reminders of it recur all over Mexico and turn up again and again in Ms. Iturbide's work. She quotes Jean Cocteau: "The only way to conquer death is through photography." (How fitting that Cocteau, master of Surrealism, should locate the solution to the insoluble problem of being human in a flat copy of life, a representation for those who can still draw breath to contemplate while waiting to die themselves.) Ms. Iturbide trains the instrument that kills death on the celebrations of its existence.
A procession where the women are masked as young beauties and the men as gruesome, smiling skeletons and dagger-toothed devils looks like an Ensor painting transferred to the street. The European tale of Death and the Maiden, compelling to artists from Hans Baldung Grien in the 16th century to Edvard Munch in the 19th -- gripping to Schubert, too -- evidently made its way to Mexico.
A photograph called "Death Bride" compresses the two figures into one, the fiction come to photographic life. A woman in a bridal gown, one arm extended to the side as if to offer shelter under her long veil, stares blackly at us through the socket holes of a death's head. In "House of Death," people on the street pass by a mural of a skeleton in bridal gown and veil. In "First Communion," a girl in a long, lacy communion dress sports a sad skull mask over her face. Behind her, people wearing ordinary clothes and ordinary faces smile with the pleasure of it all.
Mexico, of course, makes a holiday of the Day of the Dead, when bakeries turn out sugar skulls for those who would devour death. The only country that honors death more regularly is the country of photography. Photography cannot help memorializing a living instant, but that instant dies even as it is recorded. Photographic portraits outlast and supposedly immortalize both their subjects and their makers, as Cocteau noted. (So do paintings and sculpture, ars being longa and vita brevis.) Yet many photographic portraits are as anonymous as skeletons; though they continue to exist and may even fascinate, they cannot be said to have cheated death out of much that is worthwhile.
Octavio Paz, the Nobel Prize-winning author, observed that Mexicans do not find anything on this side of death worth the effort of trying to cheat the Grim Reaper: "The Mexican's indifference toward death is fostered by his indifference toward life." At any rate, Ms. Iturbide takes note of death attending the living in their off hours. (She herself had a child who died at a very young age.) A woman nursing a drink and a cigarette in a bar sits before a mural of a skull with a hotel bedroom in one of its empty eye sockets -- a site for a tryst? for the beginning of life? In the other socket, two people lie in hospital beds, and a tombstone looms in the hollow that was once a nose.
Ms. Iturbide grew up in what she has called a "bourgeois, conservative, deeply Catholic" environment that emphasized the Hispanic rather than the Indian culture of Mexico, but since at least the 1920's many Mexicans have argued that the pre-Columbian cultures represent the bedrock of the country. Ms. Iturbide is clearly fascinated by persistent Indian ways of life, but she is equally interested in accommodations to the present.
"Angel Woman" is a picture of a woman in a long skirt and veil working her way to the top of a high cliff leading to the route across the desert. In one hand she carries a boom box. The wall text says she belongs to a group of Indians who sell their crafts to Americans, earning enough to buy themselves music that blooms in the desert silence. Many traditional ways continue largely because of rampant poverty, which is a great preserver of what people of means consider charming, but a changing world exerts its pressure.
All societies are in flux, but Mexico has long been a land of dramatic differences, unexpected adaptations, and a sense of self-identity that is a mix of indigenous, ancient and contemporary Western ways. It has never been a univalent culture. The Spanish conquest irrevocably altered the Mesoamerican societies when it did not destroy them, combining races, religions and customs, and recent events in economics and politics have continued to readjust the mix.
This makes the land rich in opportunities to observe things that are not at all what they seem. Mexicans take a widespread delight in open pretense, with costumes and masks making almost anyone, at least provisionally, into something other than what they are. Fiestas are celebrated on any pretext whatever -- Paz once wrote that Mexican poverty "can be measured by the frequency and luxuriousness of our holidays," wealthy countries having neither the time nor need for them. Fiestas give adults license to play dress-up, whether in wish fulfillment or to defend against the evil Other by mocking it and assuming its power for a day.
Enthralled by such unscripted popular dramas, Ms. Iturbide produces a theatrical art, sometimes finding, sometimes inventing the theatrics. The show at the Parrish includes a display of Mexican masks from the Museo del Barrio in Manhattan, solid evidence of the hold that fantasy and magic and the assumption of other selves have on the Mexican spirit.
The photographer also sees, or sets up, contrasts, disruptions, displacements and mysteries everywhere. Religion is omnipresent and not entirely reliable. In "Our Lady of the Iguanas," a woman wears a mad crown of live lizards boldly thrusting this way and that above her everyday print dress. A child holding a statue of the Virgin Mary stands before a painted angel who has vampire teeth and a skull decorating her robe. A man garbed as Jesus, with a crown of thorns and blood running down his chest, is partially obscured by large white-feathered wings on either side of him -- angels upstaging their Savior.
Secular life is equally mysterious and evocative. A woman faces us squarely but her vision, and ours of her, is blocked by a mask over her eyes; a puzzled toddler studies her for clues. Another woman carries sticks through a cemetery, making her way through a flurry of dragonflies so vast it might be a gathering of all the souls ever buried there. An old man in white shirt and trousers and dark sneakers is enthroned on a great chair with fierce jaguar heads and claws -- in the middle of a deserted dirt road.
Ms. Iturbide finds visual moments that, cut off from the circumstances that produced them, acquire a metaphorical charge. She devises tableaus that pay homage to ambiguity and owe a debt to poetry. These are not pictures to be deciphered (unless, perhaps, you are Mexican) but to be savored for their mournful pungency and whispering allusions. They write a personal fable of a country that seems to be continually in process, continually negotiating its way between one kind of existence and another, where people who are not resigned to the way things are opt for transformation instead.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 10, 2000

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 4; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 3035 words

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
Admiring Itself in A Thousand Mirrors

BYLINE: By JONATHAN MANDELL; Jonathan Mandell is editor of GothamGazette.com, a Web site about New York City published by Citizens Union Foundation.

 BODY:
THERE was another murder on my block one morning recently -- not a real one, another one for television. When I stepped into the courtyard of my apartment building, there were dozens of "police officers" securing the crime scene against my neighbors, who, late to work, were trying to push past the cast, the crew and the tons of camera equipment.
"Nice neighborhood," a detective was saying sarcastically to a newspaper columnist, played by Oliver Platt, as the camera rolled. "Last month we had a murder-suicide here. A rape of a cleaning lady over there." 
 I don't recall too many real murder-suicides lately on my block, which is a quiet one in Greenwich Village, but it may well be famous for violence throughout the country. This particular scene for a new television series called "Deadline" was never broadcast because the show was canceled after just a few episodes. But a couple of years ago "Law and Order" staged a mob hit across the street, in front of a venerable Off-Broadway theater. Before that, two thugs beat up Spike Lee and Denzel Washington in the back alley of that theater, which had become a jazz club for Mr. Lee's film "Mo' Better Blues." For as long as I can remember, there has been shooting on the street, though shooting through the lens of a camera.
What's most striking is not how incongruous these images of this particular block are but how hungry television producers, filmmakers, photographers, painters, curators and just about everybody else connected to art or entertainment seem to be for images of it, of the neighborhood, of all of New York City.
This is nothing new. On the same street as these simulated crimes is the building where Berenice Abbott lived for decades, on a corner she photographed frequently. In 1929 she moved back to New York from Paris seized by a "fantastic passion" to do for New York what the photographer Eugene Atget had done for the City of Lights. For the next decade, she methodically catalogued the city in pictures, a project that she named "Changing New York."
Before that, at the start of the 20th century, a nearby corner was the subject of paintings by George Luks and John Sloan, two of the six original Ashcan artists, who were the first group of respected painters to make the street life of New York their primary subject. And even before that, street scenes of New York were popular in prints, in maps, even on vases and dinner bowls and wallpaper.
But if this ever-changing (yet somehow always familiar) city has generated a never-ending supply of pictures, the truth is, there may never have been a time before now when so many of these images of New York, both old and new, have been on display.
"There's a time for everything; this is in the air now," said Philippe de Montebello, the director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which is currently presenting "Art and the Empire City: New York, 1825-1861." Among the exhibition's 310 objects (which include period furniture and costumes, portraits, sculpture and silverware) are scenes of the city as depicted in architectural drawings, watercolors, prints, maps, oil paintings, the oldest surviving daguerreotypes and, yes, vases and bowls and wallpaper. Mr. de Montebello believes it is the first time in the Metropolitan's 130-year history that the museum has had an exhibition on this scale about the city in which it resides.
"It is interesting how it has all come together at the same time," said Betsy Gotbaum, the director of the New-York Historical Society, where the Henry Luce 3rd Center for the Study of American Culture opened last month. This has enabled the Society, for one of the few times since its founding in 1804, to put on permanent display most of its collection -- some 40,000 objects and images, almost all of which have some connection with New York.
"Why is this happening right now? I think people across the country are in awe of us," said Robert Macdonald, the director of the Museum of the City of New York. One of the museum's current exhibitions is entitled "Painting the Town, Cityscapes of New York," offering two centuries' worth of views in oil. Mr. Macdonald said that next year the museum would also begin construction on a $50 million project to double its size, the highlight of which will be the building of a New York City History Learning Center.
Some have explained this surge as part of a momentum begun two years ago with the celebration of the Centennial of Consolidation, the joining together in 1898 of the five boroughs into the City of Greater New York. Others say it has something to do with the millennium, a natural time to look at the one place in the world most habitually razed and resurrected. Still others believe it is because the city has come back to a glory it long held, with the economy up, crime down and subway trains no longer covered in graffiti.
Those with a grasp of the city's history, though, might understand that in these new displays New York is resuming a tradition that has been with it nearly from the beginning. Like the ticker-tape parades that have been given along the "canyon of heroes" for the past 114 years, the celebration of the images of New York is something akin to a business strategy by the world's richest, most energetic and most diverse Chamber of Commerce. New Yorkers, by their active self-mythologizing, are once again marketing their city to outsiders -- and trying as well to reassure themselves.
The images being "marketed" are not just old ones, of course. There are many painters and photographers who continue to make the city their subject. There are also about a dozen prime-time television series being shot entirely on location in New York, according to the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting, possibly more than ever before, the office says, and certainly the most since the 1950's. About half the series are new this season, including "100 Centre Street" (created by Sidney Lumet for the A & E channel) and "Welcome to New York" on CBS. Last year, there were 209 feature films shot in the city, three times as many as 15 years ago. These television shows and films spent an incredible 22,000 shooting days last year on location somewhere in the streets of New York.
If the statistics are unprecedented, they do not even take into account the many more movies and television shows that are supposed to take place here, even though they are actually shot in Vancouver or Toronto or on a set in Los Angeles. Popular "New York" shows like "NYPD Blue," "Friends" and "Will and Grace" are produced elsewhere (as is "Spin City" starting this season, now that Michael J. Fox has left it). This season, many of the new shows are explicitly set but not shot in New York City, including "The Geena Davis Show."
"Most of these shows create a kind of mythic, hip young New York," said James Sanders, who is writing a book titled "Celluloid Skyline" about the image of New York in film and television. "They've restored the city to a place it had held for 60 years, from the turn of the century, an impossibly romantic and exciting place that exists nowhere else. Even 'Sex and the City,' which is very specifically unwholesome, with a dark edge, is a return to New York as a glamorous place."
Mr. Sanders is also the co-creator, with Ric Burns, of "New York: A Documentary Film," the first 10 hours of which were broadcast on PBS last year. Like many people who make New York their subject, Mr. Sanders and Mr. Burns can't seem to get enough; they are now completing two more two-hour episodes, bringing the saga up to the present day, and plan to show them later this season.
Along with the television series, they have written (with Lisa Ades) a companion book, the 575-page "New York: An Illustrated History." Only in New York could the sheer number of titles on the subject of the city almost drown out this and three other mammoth projects that anywhere else would surely stand out, if not stand alone: the new 636-page catalog of the Met show, edited by the curators Catherine Hoover Voorsanger and John Howat; the 1,350-page "Encyclopedia of the City of New York," edited by Kenneth Jackson, which was published in 1995; and the 1,382-page "Gotham: A History of New York City to 1898," by Edwin G. Burrows and Mike Wallace, winner of a Pulitzer Prize last year.
"There is a cottage industry of people who work on nothing but books about New York City," said Mr. Howat. Indeed, New York seems to have been a subject for nearly every major American writer since Washington Irving. It took an extra century for major American artists to depict the city, and plenty have stayed away from it as a subject. Still, measured by quantity alone, all the words about the city are but the arch in Washington Square Park when put beside the World Trade Center of images.
"When you think of Paris, you think of the Arc de Triomphe and the Eiffel Tower," Mr. Burns said. "You say New York, and the imagination bristles with images: Wall Street, Fifth Avenue, Greenwich Village, the Statue of Liberty." He mentioned a half-dozen more. "There is no other American place, with the exception of the American West as a whole, that has so captured the imagination of the world."
When Mr. Burns began gathering the material for his series a decade ago, he said, he found it "startling" how many images of the city existed, some going as far back as the 17th century.
"We've always been self-regarding," explained John Howat, the chairman of the Met's Departments of American Art, who came up with the idea for "Art and the Empire City" some six years ago.
The reason may be not just cultural or psychological but practical, a form of marketing. Unlike the other early American cities, whose settlers had sought religious or political freedom, New York was always a place where people came to make a buck.
It is no coincidence that Wall Street was one of the first places to be depicted in New York. Amid an entire wall of cityscapes at the Luce Center is an oil painting by Francis Guy from around 1800 picturing Wall Street. It is focused on (and titled) the "Tontine Coffee House." Just a few years earlier, a group of stockbrokers had built the coffeehouse not only as a place to eat and hear the latest news but also as an early marketplace for commodities like ships, real estate and slaves.
Whatever the formal quality of Guy's painting, it is rich in information, showing the new American flag flying from the roof, the brokers conversing on the balcony, the many masts in the busy harbor just down the street, the plentiful supplies being unloaded. All this was Guy's obvious effort to establish Wall Street as the center of a busy, prosperous American city.
New Yorkers were proud that Wall Street was a place where news happened, even when the news was bad. Both "Painting the Town" and "Art and the Empire City" include versions of Nicolino Calyo's gouache on paper, published as a newspaper illustration, of the Great Fire of 1835. Viewed from the top of the Bank of America, the painting focuses on the flames engulfing the Merchant's Exchange. Also in the Met exhibition is an 1858 oil painting by James H. Cafferty and Charles G. Rosenberg, titled "Wall Street, Half Past 2 O'Clock, October 13, 1857," which shows brokers crowding Wall Street in the midst of a panic.
That Wall Street has long been as much a symbol of finance as an actual place is evident from William Holbrook Beard's 1879 allegory, "The Bulls and Bears in the Market," on display at the New-York Historical Society. The animals fill the street beneath the clearly marked New York Stock Exchange, attacking one another.
The arrival of the 20th century only increased artists' interest in Wall Street as a subject, appealing especially to the American Impressionists like Childe Hassam and Colin Campbell Cooper, who suffused it with an air of romance. Photographers were also captivated. Paul Strand's most famous photograph is surely the one he took in 1915 of people on their way to work dwarfed by the ominously looming Morgan Bank. One of Berenice Abbott's most frequently reproduced images is her 1938 aerial view "Wall Street District." Whether in art, photography, television, the 1987 Oliver Stone movie (or the 1996 Whoopi Goldberg movie "The Associate"), Wall Street remains one of the most depicted places in New York, and in the world.
"As New York was the mercantile center of the country and eventually the world, it was more self-consciously thinking of its image," said Margaret Heilbrun, the director of the library at the New-York Historical Society. One way to enhance its image was to mount a collective effort to make New York not just the business but the cultural capital of the nation; this helps explain the existence of the Society itself, as well as the founding of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1870 and the Metropolitan Opera in 1883.
But there was a more literal way to heighten the image of New York. Ms. Heilbrun is also the curator of "Inventing the Skyline," a current exhibition at the Society about Cass Gilbert, the architect of the Woolworth Building and other early skyscrapers. Chicago was the city where skyscrapers were in a sense invented, but it was New York that saw both the business opportunities in more office space to rent out and the marketing value of having a unique, immediately identifiable and awe-inspiring skyline.
One revelation of the city scenes in the three museums is how long New Yorkers had anticipated the skyline. Watercolors and prints going back as far as the 18th century, but especially those in the 19th, offer sweeping views of the New York Harbor and bird's-eye views of the broad streets, particularly Broadway, taken from skyscraper-high vantage points situated either in imaginary heavens or man-made ones.
"Church spires were the skyscrapers of the time," Ms. Heilbrun explained. An unsigned oil painting, believed to be from 1761, at the Luce Center shows the East River waterfront with a proud fleet of ships. At the Met exhibition, there is a hand-colored aquatint engraved by Henry Papprill around 1848 showing the city from the steeple of Saint Paul's Church. At the Museum of the City of New York is Anthony Imbert's painting "The Erie Canal Celebration, New York, 1825," a scene of the harbor that looks like an early version of Op Sail, the ships' masts competing with the spires of an unmistakable early skyline.
After the canal was completed, New York became the undisputed business capital of the country. It was the center of manufacturing, and this included the manufacturing of images. New York was where the artists lived and where the publishing companies flourished, attracting photographers from all over. "By the late 1850's, we had more photographers working here than in Paris and London combined," said Ms. Voorsanger of the Met. New York was also the first home of the movie industry and of television production.
It was just natural that the image manufacturers would look for subjects close at hand. But this did not happen immediately. In the era covered by "Art and the Empire City," the most respected painters of the day, Thomas Cole and the rest of the Hudson River School, lived in New York City but never painted a scene here. They traveled to the Catskills, or even to the Andes.
New York was the place where they sold their art; the nation's first art gallery, Luman Reed's, was in New York. The city was also where they socialized and taught and were admired; the most influential art institutions in the nation were here; the National Academy of Design, for example, which was founded the same year the Erie Canal was completed, 1825.
For actual scenes of the city, New Yorkers of the era relied mostly on the new technology of lithography and on such novelty items as blue Staffordshire dinnerware. One platter on display at the Met depicts the arrival of the Marquis de Lafayette, a hero of the American Revolution, at Castle Garden in 1824, with cannons blasting in salute. This was obviously popular: the Luce Center features an entire dinner set with the same scene.
The gun blasts for the Marquis seem of a very different caliber from those simulated on my block. But shows like "Deadline" -- out of step with the "Seinfeld" descendants that fill most of this season's television lineup -- are rooted in a different New York tradition, one that has existed at least since the Ashcan artists: it is intent on capturing the city in all its gritty reality, even if it has to add a bit of grit.
It should not be so surprising to learn, then, that the executive producer of "Deadline," Robert Palm, found inspiration for the particular episode shot on my block from "Stag at Sharkey's," the famous painting from 1909 by the Ashcan artist George Bellows depicting two boxers pummeling each other. The connection with the episode is that the murder victim, a former movie star now a mobster's moll (is this a likely neighbor?), hung out at a boxing club.
It was up to Tom Ross, the location manager, to find a boxing club that looked like the one in Bellows's painting. "In L.A., if I had said I wanted a boxing club like the one in 'Stag at Sharkey's,' they would have said, 'Huh?' " Mr. Palm said.
But it was all in a week's work for Mr. Ross, just one of more than a dozen locations he had to find for that particular episode, about seven of them exterior shots. He estimates that he is one of some 50 full-time location managers in New York, all of them looking for a steady supply of the "real" New York. "It's becoming harder and harder," Mr. Ross said. The real estate market is tight; New Yorkers have become more savvy, so they charge more; competition from the other shows is fierce.
And there is one other problem. Oliver Platt pointed it out as he sat in the set of "Deadline," the actual old newsroom of The New York Post on South Street, with the Brooklyn Bridge in clear view out the window. He looked nonplused. "People are going to say: 'Oh, for God's sake, the Brooklyn Bridge. Couldn't they be a little more original?' " he complained. "But it's not a backdrop. We're actually here."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1311 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Westchester;
Taking Stock of a Mammoth Entertainment Center

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE

 BODY:
FOURTEEN months after opening the $190 million New Roc City, a major mall devoted to entertainment and sports outlets, its developer, Louis Cappelli, professes to be pleased with the project.
New Roc City is a beige stone complex covering a full block in downtown New Rochelle that replaced a retail mall anchored by Macy's. It includes a 18-screen movie theater and an Imax theater; an arcade with bumper cars, video games, pinball and a simulated roller coaster among others diversions; twin ice-skating rinks; a supermarket; three restaurants; a hotel; and a fitness club. On the roof above the four-story complex, there is the Space Shot, an amusement park ride whose soaring tower is modeled after the Eiffel Tower, which sends an intrepid dozen people at a time 235 feet in the air and then drops them in a free fall. 
 Despite these attractions, however, the mall's attendance has fallen far short of expectations -- it had 3.1 million visitors in its first 12 months, compared with projections for 5.5 million -- and, until recently, more than 72,000 square feet of its 500,000 square feet of retail space were vacant.
Meanwhile, at City Hall, elected officials have compared the tax dollars generated with the costs of patrolling and otherwise maintaining municipal services, including a police substation, at the facility -- not to mention their $24 million investment in the center's parking garage. Mayor Timothy C. Idoni reported that costs exceeded revenues by about $400,000 during the first year.
In addition, two major tenants have made filings that indicate they are in financial difficulty. Family Golf Centers, the parent company of Sports Plus Skate Nation, which rents 138,000 square feet of space here, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in May. When asked how the financial concerns of the parent firm might affect Sports Plus, which runs two ice rinks and a video arcade at New Roc City, William Reitzig, a spokesman for Family Golf Centers, said, "No comment."
Regal Cinemas, based in Knoxville, Tenn., which owns 18 screens of movies and the Imax theater at the complex, said in a regulatory filing last month that it was considering bankruptcy or a financial restructuring.
So why is Mr. Cappelli calling New Roc City a "heck of a success story," especially as the economy shows signs of slowing?
One answer, of course, is that he wants to promote his huge investment, but in addition, he says, economic forecasts show that entertainment centers are good investments and that people will reach into their pockets to pay for this kind of fun no matter how poorly the rest of the economy fares.
CLEARLY, the developer is also optimistic because of people like Sonya Foster and her wide-eyed granddaughter Shalya, 2, who strolled happily along the futuristic corridors of the mammoth center on a recent weekday morning, and Elizabeth Gonzalez and Carmen Gonzalez, cousins who attend high school in New Rochelle and who were skimming the ice on one of Sports Plus's rinks.
Mr. Cappelli called his family entertainment center resilient and "recession proof," and some economists think he is correct.
"If you're a guy and you have a girl, well, you have to take her out ice skating or to the game rooms," the developer said. As for parents, "what are you going to do if times are bad -- tell your kids you can't afford to go to the movies?"
"Of course not!" he said.
"No matter how good or bad times are, you always want to see 'The Grinch,' " Mr. Cappelli added, referring to Regal Cinemas' offerings. "If the stock market drops, it could even drive you to movies for consolation," he said.
Despite the parent company's recent financial problems, Regal Cinemas at New Roc City is consistently among the company's three best performers nationwide, according to Richard Westerling, senior vice president of marketing. Among all movie theaters in the country, it is in the top 100.
Thomas J. Spitznas, an economist in Mount Vernon, agreed that while parents may do without things for themselves during a downturn, "they never like to deny their kids."
"They may hold back on the big-ticket items like a car," Mr. Spitznas said, "or wait until next year for a new dishwasher, but the service industry, movies especially, are not so recession-sensitive."
While absorption of space and attendance rates did not meet expectations the first year, there were other positive indicators. For one, a 124-unit Residence Inn by Marriott at New Roc City, which is part of the complex, is often filled to capacity.
Also, Jeffrey J. Castaldo, executive director of real estate for the complex, said he had recently secured four new leases for New Roc City for 52,000 square of mall space. This would fill the complex above 95 percent of capacity.
The new tenants are a bowling alley, a baseball training center, a sports memorabilia shop and locker rooms for college ice hockey teams.
In what is billed as "an extreme bowling center," the newly opened 17-lane New Roc 'N Bowl features black lights and glow-in-the-dark balls and pins.
A nationally franchised Frozen Ropes Baseball Training Center, featuring baseball and softball clinics and camps, one-on-one instruction, batting cages and video analysis, is also bound for New Roc City, along with Steiner Sports Marketing, a maker and retailer of signed collectibles and other sports memorabilia.
In addition, the men's and women's hockey teams of Manhattanville College have rented locker-room space, joining students from Iona College, who also play on the large rink against other teams from the Division I Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference.
Spectators can watch games while dining in Reunions, a sports bar and pool hall next to the rink. Kelly Bararuk, a player from Iona, said last week as he raced for practice that games were now drawing big crowds in the rink, which has seats for 500.
The new tenants join other businesses like Bally Total Fitness, Modell's sporting goods and Applebee's.
Also, even though Mr. Cappelli jettisoned plans for a planned office complex at New Roc City, he has decided to put 100 luxury apartments in its place. In part, he opted for the apartments because the entrance to the building is from the parking lot, and it lacks what he calls "a street presence" desirable for offices.
"Of course, that's good from an apartment dweller's point of view, especially for security reasons," Mr. Cappelli added. The developer said 50 percent of the apartments were already rented, mainly to young professionals and empty-nesters. A one-bedroom apartment with a den at New Roc City is renting for $2,500 a month.
IN June, when the apartment complex is ready to be occupied, the developer will begin construction on a 320,000-square-foot office, hotel and condominium project on Huguenot Street across from the parking lot at New Roc City.
Dollars, attendance figures, vacancy rates and other hard data aside, the bottom line for many is that at the very least New Roc City has injected new life and energy into what was until recently a flagging downtown area.
"New Rochelle was a tired metropolitan area," Mr. Castaldo said. "It's not that anymore."
Mayor Idoni agreed. He said that on a recent weekend evening, he could barely find a parking space at the mall and lines were long at the movies. As for the balance sheet at City Hall, he predicted that "revenues will sort themselves out in the next year."
Meanwhile, New Roc City is being watched carefully by other municipalities. Mr. Cappelli said Glen Cove and Albany had inspected the site and were making inquiries about building similar entertainment complexes in their areas.
He also said he "would love to go" to White Plains, where the developer Tishman Speyer has bowed out of a plan to build a multiplex theater, retail and entertainment center in the downtown.

HEADLINE: A LA CARTE;
For the Thrifty, a Room With a View

BYLINE: By RICHARD JAY SCHOLEM 

 BODY:
CRYSTAL clear or wild and stormy, in moonlight or sunlight, P. W.'s Chowder House, at Brewer's Capri Marina in Port Washington, has a striking waterfront view of Manhasset Bay. At night, lights twinkle in the distance; at dusk the fading rays of the sun shimmer on mirror-smooth water. In warm weather, diners sit on an outdoor deck under umbrellas to take in the sailboat-seagull scene.
When the weather turns brisk, they retreat under the roof to the deck's heated section and inside to the more formal Corinthian dining room and the bar room with its windows, wood and water views. 
 Restaurants with sensational settings are rarely affordable for budget conscious diners. But P. W.'s Chowder house, the newest member of the Hudson River Waterfront Group, at 45 Orchard Beach Boulevard (516-767-7924), is an exception.
The restaurant, as it battened down the hatches for its first winter, introduced a number of low-priced options in an effort to entice diners during the cold weather months. Yet, it still takes timing, planning and strategy to eat economically at a restaurant where most starters are priced at $7.50 or more and all but one entree costs at least $18.95. (Lower-priced alternatives are the eight sandwich platters that cost from $7.50 to $12.95 and the five entree-size salads in the $8.95 to $11.95 range.)
The three days to consider are Mondays, when the elderly receive a 20 percent discount; Tuesdays, when three pastas are available for $13.95 each; and Thursdays, when the prime rib goes for $14.95. There's also a $17.95 Sunday brunch.
Thrifty patrons at P. W.'s must carefully pick and choose, not only the right day, but the right dish as well because the kitchen is as uneven as the harbor's surface in a hurricane. Most of the food here will neither do a tap dance on a gourmet's heart nor drive anyone out the door muttering. But is somewhere in between, about evenly divided.
Chowder, the restaurant's namesake dish, is a perfect example. There are three (all $5.50) on the menu: a New England, heavy with clams, potatoes and vegetables in a thin though tasty broth; a corn and crab entry that will appeal to those who like creamed corn with but a few threads of crab; and a Manhattan that's a rather routine vegetable soup with a scattering of clams rather than the expected spicy seafood brew.
Two of the three special nights are in that same up and down pattern. The plate-covering piece of crusty, charred, on-the-bone prime rib, perched on a scramble of sweet potatoes, onions and peppers I devoured on a Thursday night, was a genuine bargain at $14.95 (it's $23.95 on the a la carte menu) but two of those $12.95 Tuesday night pastas were, at best, routine renditions. Penne primavera, with chicken, contained stringy, chewy meat, just a scant hint of julienned vegetables and a watery, pallid sauce. Spaghetti with salmon in a basil-flecked cream sauce was somewhat better but both benefited from substantial infusions of salt and cheese.
Plus-side starters to consider are a large load of feathery, tender calamari ($8.95); three small, nicely seasoned meat-filled crab cakes ($8.95); a creamy Caesar salad ($6.95) of crisp romaine and crunchy croutons covered by a cheesy, tasty homemade dressing; and a heap of tiny, delicate (though lukewarm) steamers ($8.95). Forget the oysters Rockefeller ($9.50) -- the spinach leaves slathered over gritty oysters bore little resemblance to the creamy, chopped spinach, bread crumbs, butter, vividly seasoned classic.
Sandwiches, though served with slightly soggy French fries, are recommended. The husky half-pound burger ($7.50), laced with lively seasonings, is a solid choice, and the lobster B.L.T. ($12.95) is an inspired blending of a club sandwich with fresh Maine lobster.
Entrees worth remembering are the pan-seared eight-ounce filet mignon ($21.95) wrapped in smoky bacon and presented with a mellow bordelaise sauce, and a baby roasted chicken ($14.95) alive with juices. A diminutive, rather bland chunk of halibut with some dabs of saffron sauce didn't justify its $21.95 tab, but a generous portion of grilled pineapple-glazed tuna on grilled pineapple rings with a pyramid of vegetables did. Most entrees are accompanied by baby carrots, good green and yellow beans and too-stiff mashed potatoes.
The breadbasket here contains unfortunate rolls that are in the commercial fodder category, while standard sweets from an off-premises bakery are unexciting. The genial young wait staff aims to please but needs more training. Dishes were cleared while some diners at the table were still eating and although we were the only people in the dining room on a slow Monday, our servers still didn't know who ordered which dish.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: County and Dot-Com Team Up on Web Link;
Office Space In Westchester

 BODY:
In one of the first deals of its kind, a government has teamed up with a dot-com business to help tenants, building owners and brokers find office space. Westchester's Office of Economic Development and Yale Robbins, a New York City publisher of real estate information, are offering the free service to help businesses expanding in or relocating to Westchester.
Salvatore J. Carrera, the county's director of economic development, said Westchester had chosen Yale Robbins's MrOfficeSpace.com because it is the only free service of its kind in the New York area. 
 The Web site is available through the economic development section of the county's home page, www.Westchestergov.com/economic/, under the link to "Office Space Currently Available."
The Internet address for MrOfficeSpace.com, which was started by Yale Robbins in September, is www.mrofficespace.com. Users can search by several criteria, including size, rent and location.
The Westchester site, which is updated every 14 to 30 days, includes photographs, map links and the names and numbers of rental agents. E-mail alerts can also be requested when new properties come available.
MrOfficeSpace.com, which has plans to expand to other areas on the East Coast, now lists available commercial space in Connecticut, New York City, the Hudson Valley and parts of New Jersey.
