HEADLINE: Coming Soon to Hollywood: a Mixed-Use Building

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
DEVELOPERS plan to start construction next spring on the Hollywood Marketplace, a project which seems almost a microcosm of the Hollywood district here -- a single building that combines apartments, retail space, historic preservation and even advertising billboards.
The $80 million project, which is being developed by a partnership of Regent Properties, a local developer, and P&A Erie of Chicago, is also notable for providing the first new market-rate housing to be built during the current wave of Hollywood redevelopment, as well as the first major residential mixed-use project in the district. 
 Last spring, the Los Angeles City Council approved construction of the 326,000-square-foot project, a six-story building that is expected to cover a full city block at the northwest corner of Sunset Boulevard and Vine Street. The ground level is entirely devoted to retail space, with commitments already signed from Borders Books, Bed Bath and Beyond and Cost Plus Imports.
Upper levels of the building will contain 300 market-rate apartments, most of which are studios and one- and two-bedroom units, reflecting the target market of single young professionals who work in entertainment companies or in technology-related fields.
The project will also incorporate a portion of the historic facade on Vine Street of the TAV Celebrity Theater, built originally in 1937 as a broadcast studio for the American Broadcasting Company.
Market-rate housing is a "healthy sign" for Hollywood, which has attracted plentiful retail activity and movie theaters, but virtually no upscale apartments to date, said Jeffrey Skorneck, manager for special designated projects for the Los Angeles Community Redevelopment Area.
"If this housing can work at Sunset and Vine," he added, "there will be more viability for market-rate residential elsewhere in the district."
While the final rents have not been set, Douglas Brown, a partner at Regent Properties, said he expected rents to be slightly higher than $2 per square foot monthly. This is comparable to those found in nearby neighborhoods, like Los Feliz or Beechwood Canyon, which are popular with midlevel professionals in the entertainment industry.
Vine Street, the setting of the project, is an incongruous mix of brick buildings from the 1930's and 40's with undistinguished commercial buildings from the 1960's and 70's, which now look faded and downmarket.
Sunset and Vine is "the SoHo of 25 years ago," Mr. Brown said. "It's cool, funky, fun and edgy."
Currently, the intersection is a major node of Hollywood redevelopment, with three of the four corners devoted to large-scale projects. To the east, the developer Tom Gilmore of Los Angeles is rehabbing an older office building. Across Sunset Boulevard from the Hollywood Marketplace project, Pacific Theaters Realty Group plans to add 4,000 theater seats and retail space to a site surrounding the Cinerama Dome, a landmark geodesic theater built in 1963.
THE developers of the Hollywood Market, in fact, originally planned a project similar to the Cinerama Dome that combined a multiplex theater and shopping.
A 1998 lawsuit over parking brought by a rival developer, however, delayed development for a year. During that time, one major tenant, the Good Guys, a national appliance retailer, pulled out of the project, while the prospective theater operator, Mann Theaters of Los Angeles, filed a Chapter 11 bankruptcy.
"With other major theater operators facing bankruptcy or expected to announce bankruptcy shortly, we decided against the multiplex," Mr. Brown said.
After Regent settled the lawsuit last year, the company reformulated the project as a combination of retail operations at street level with apartments above.
While residential mixed-use development is common in the Bay Area and on the East Coast, hybrid projects remain unusual in Los Angeles and untested in Hollywood. The developers, Mr. Skorneck said, are "rolling the dice to some extent, based on what they have seen in other cities, such as San Francisco, and saying, 'Why not in Hollywood?' "
Mr. Brown of Regent Properties acknowledged the high-density project was unusual for Los Angeles. "It's as urban and dense as you can get in Southern California," the developer said.
He seemed confident, however, that the Hollywood housing market would support the project. "From a real estate developer perspective, the project has a good foundation: a huge local population, a huge shortage of housing and people who want to live in Hollywood," Mr. Brown said. He characterized his target market as "hip, but not necessarily urban pioneers."
The adjacency of major employers -- including Capitol Records; Universal Pictures; the Klasky-Csupo animated cartoon company, the producers of the "Rugrats" films; and other creative and high-tech businesses -- suggest that the apartment complex will have a large pool of potential renters among people who work in Hollywood and want to avoid long commutes on the increasingly congested roads and freeways of Los Angeles, according to Mr. Skorneck.
THE "heart of Hollywood" location, in addition, may be attractive to many young professionals who work in those companies, he added. "They have a very urban lifestyle, with lots of clubbing and partying," Mr. Skorneck said.
The urban profile of the project is exemplified in one of its most unusual design features: the integration of advertising billboards into the design of the facade.
While the combination of architecture and advertising might offend some purists, "signage was one of the things that we're excited about," said the project designer, William Roschen, principal of Roschen Van Cleve of Los Angeles. The firm is designing the project in association with Thomas Cox & Associates of Irvine, Calif., and MCG Architects of Pasadena, Calif. Sussman Prejza, an environmental design firm in Culver City, Calif., is designing the advertising apparatus for the building.
Not only does Mr. Roschen embrace the concept of signs, but he also thinks a building that incorporates signs into its facade is better off then being "colonized" by an insensitively sited billboard built nearby by somebody else. The billboards on the facade have historic roots on Vine Street, where the modernist Richard Neutra designed an office building in 1933 for the film executive Carl Laemmle of Universal Studios that included billboards trumpeting his latest film releases. (The building survives in a much altered form at Hollywood and Vine, without the signs.)
The architects also plan to mark the corner of Sunset and Vine with what Mr. Roschen called a "corner icon," or a columnlike structure that will incorporate both an electronic display and advertising.
The signs are part of the complexity that a project in present-day Hollywood needs, according to the architect.
"We think that kind of urbanity is something that is appropriate for that type of housing," Mr. Roschen said. "If housing is going to happen on Vine Street, it should have that kind of urban energy."
"We are thrilled to death," he added, "to see all these things coming together in one project."

HEADLINE: College Hopefuls Face Stronger Competition

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW 

 BODY:
FRIDAY is a big day for Brad Glick. Dec. 15 is the date when he and thousands more Long Island high school seniors expect a letter telling them whether they were accepted to the colleges of their choice under the "early decision" plan.
It's not that Brad, a Syosset High School senior, will lose all hope of going to Cornell if the university turns down his early-decision application. Instead, he believes it will give him an advantage in Cornell's general-admissions sweepstakes, which will run into next summer. 
 "I hope that my decision to apply early will give me an edge over other students who might be equally qualified candidates for admission," Brad said. "This year, so many kids are applying to Cornell that it makes the competition even worse."
Early decision is a high-stakes gamble in which a student picks one school and if accepted, is pledged to go there even if a better school says yes later. It is one of many tactics employed by college-bound students nationwide who are struggling with a situation in which the number of applicants is rising faster than the number of slots in next year's freshman class.
But for students on Long Island and elsewhere in the New York suburbs, the problem is worse than a national supply-and-demand imbalance. The better students seeking the better schools are the core of the competition, and in it, New York suburban students' academic strength is, paradoxically, their greatest disadvantage.
Long Island's many fine high schools are good at turning out high-achieving students. But the Island produces so many well-qualified graduates that they compete against one another to get into colleges where geographic and socioeconomic diversity is prized.
These are not the merely good students. Thousands of high school seniors throughout Long Island who have A-plus averages in honors courses, near-perfect SAT scores, served as presidents of clubs and captains of teams and volunteered hours every week for community service are worrying that they will not be accepted by the colleges and universities of their choice.
"Sure, I'm nervous," said Logan Rich, a classmate of Brad's who sent an early-decision application to the University of Pennsylvania. "The admission standards have gotten harder since my older sister applied to college a few years ago. Because there are too many qualified kids in the applicant pool, many of us won't get into the colleges of our first choice."
A high grade average and great SAT scores are no longer enough, said Nicole Liebman, also from Syosset High. She is hoping to go to George Washington University.
"During high school I got involved in different community service projects, and I probably wouldn't have done the majority of it if it wasn't for college," Nicole said. "As the same kids are applying to the same colleges, schools that we thought were our safety schools are no longer safe."
College officials will not publicly acknowledge that the problem exists. Doris Davis, the associate provost for admissions and enrollment at Cornell, insisted that Long Island students were not at a disadvantage.
"Universities have never used a system that pits students within a school or a region against one another," she said. "The process is individual, and there are no quotas for the number of individuals from any one school or area."
Many Long Island students, guidance counselors and parents remain skeptical. "They tell us that there are no quotas, but no one really believes that," said Alaina Gurwitz, a senior at Jericho High School and an early-decision applicant at New York University. "Particularly coming from a small school like Jericho, it's doubtful that N.Y.U. will take more than one student early decision. I may be qualified, but there's another student in my class who also applied early, and he has better credentials. I'm afraid we won't both get in."
Jan Goldstein, the guidance director for the Herricks school district, said: "I don't believe there are quotas per se. But when colleges finish reviewing all of their applications and look at the final numbers, if they find that out of the 300 kids they set aside for acceptance, 75 are from the Northeast and 55 from Long Island, they may look again at those applications in an attempt to attain a diverse student population."
Dr. Lee Weitzman is a parent of a senior at Hewlett High School. "Coming from Long Island, my daughter is at a disadvantage," said Dr. Weitzman, whose daughter Jessica applied early to Emory University. "There are so many well-qualified students in our community who have worked extremely hard throughout high school, performed at a level that demonstrates their competency, shown leadership qualities and a commitment to community activities that sets them apart from other students. Yet they now feel as if they are competing against one another and have to worry about getting into colleges in which they definitely deserve admission."
The geographic factor is not the only one making competition tougher for the Island's high school seniors. The raw numbers are not in their favor.
"Last year's graduates, born in 1982, made up the largest high school graduating class nationwide in two generations," said Thomas Ganes, the chairman of the guidance department at Great Neck South High School. "As the numbers of students applying to college increases, the pressure felt by high school seniors gets even greater."
A study by the National Association for College Admissions Counselors found that 74 percent of the colleges surveyed reported an increase in the number of freshman applications for fall 2000 admission.
Finally, a strong economy has allowed more families to afford private colleges, and the Internet has helped many students from across the country to become more aware of colleges they might never have considered.
"More strong students from the middle of Iowa are now thinking that they don't have to stay in Iowa for college but can come to Princeton or Penn," Ms. Goldstein said.
This trend makes it more difficult for Long Island students, Dr. Ganes said. "Take the University of Maryland, for example," he said. "Before last year, Long Island students were often accepted with an 87-88 average. This year, it's written right on the application that you need a 90 average to apply. The kids hear this, and they become more cautious about the whole admissions process because there are no longer any guarantees."
Barbara Lubel of Roslyn, whose eldest son is now a sophomore at Penn, has noticed a significant difference in admissions standards in the last two years. This week, her second son will hear if he was accepted to Yale.
"It seems that there is more pressure on the kids than ever before," Ms. Lubel said. "There are so many similarly qualified students today who are all applying to the same schools and competing against one another."
Joyce Bisso, the principal of Hewlett High, cited "a tremendous level of stress among our students."
"While the acceptances are still very credible," she added, "we're hearing about rejections from places that a few years earlier would never have rejected a student with this kind of academic profile."
There is a sense among students that applications for early decision carry more weight for admissions counselors, Ms. Bisso said. But early-decision applications are just part of a complex process that for many students often starts several years before they are seniors and includes private SAT tutors, hired college advisers and long-term strategies designed to make students more attractive to college admissions officers.
The best colleges may well be searching for what sets a student apart from everyone else.
"During high school I took Japanese, and in college I'll continue to play basketball," said Erin Connolly, a Syosset senior. "I think I've done a lot of things because in the back of my head I thought they might look good for college."
Enrollment numbers are up for the SAT classes run by Test Takers, a tutoring company with four Long Island locations. Its president, Frank Pomilla, said that enrollment was particularly high this year for preparatory classes for the College Board subject tests, not always required by colleges but usually taken by those seeking the more selective schools.
Shawn Pappas, a Syosset senior, said: "It's like a game. You have to try to sell yourself, and to show a college why it needs you."
The college frenzy is largely limited to the more affluent communities, in which parents are often highly educated and have high aspirations for their children. In blue-collar communities, smaller percentages of students are applying to colleges, particularly the Ivy League schools.
"Our kids don't have the economic advantages to be able to pay for private tutors and college consultants," said Les Black, the school superintendent in Brentwood. "I guess the good news is that they don't feel the intense pressure from the competition that kids in some of the other communities do."

LENGTH: 2263 words

HEADLINE: A Job Worth Having And Many Who May Want It

BYLINE: By AL BAKER 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY

 BODY:
WHEN Nassau County leaders sidestepped the train wreck that would have been a state takeover of the county's finances, they also preserved the county executive's post as something of value. Ever since, the big question here has not been whether the race for county executive has begun. It has been how big a political free-for-all county voters can expect in the 11 months till Election Day 2001.
On Nov. 28, the day he sealed an agreement for a financial rescue plan, Thomas S. Gulotta, the longtime county executive, was noncommittal about his political plans. "We'll deal with that next year," was all he would say on the topic. 
 Should he run, Mr. Gulotta, 56, would be seeking his fourth four-year term. Could he win, even in a likely fight within his own Republican Party, is another question. The county Republican organization has disowned him, and two Democrats -- Thomas P. DiNapoli, a state assemblyman and the county Democratic chairman, and Thomas R. Suozzi, the mayor of Glen Cove -- have not officially entered the race but are behaving like candidates for Mr. Gulotta's job.
"It's incredible -- you've got the potential for a war in both parties," said Howard A. Scarrow, a professor of political science at the State University at Stony Brook. "Both parties are potentially split by two people who may want to run. It could be a very bloody year."
Mr. Gulotta has an imposing $2.5 million campaign fund but has suffered grave damage over his handling of county finances, with the prospect of further pitfalls as he executes a 2001 budget under the scrutiny of a hostile county Legislature and a skeptical state watchdog, the Nassau Interim Finance Agency.
A NIFA takeover has been averted, for the time being. But there are serious questions about whether the plan will work. Some say the revenue estimates were too optimistic. And there are doubts about whether Mr. Gulotta can stay within budget.
As Republicans watch and wait, some familiar names from the ranks of their renowned political machine have surfaced as possible challengers to Mr. Gulotta.
Those include Denis Dillon, the county district attorney; Michael Balboni and Charles Fuschillo Jr., both state senators; Richard Guardino, the top official in the Town of Hempstead; Peter King, the congressman; Donna Ferrara, the state assemblywoman, and Fred Parola, the county comptroller. And there was talk about an as-yet-undiscovered candidate from the private sector: a successful business person in the mold of a Jon Corzine, the senator-elect from New Jersey.
"My opinion is that we should look at our current bullpen of elected officials and go beyond that and look at prominent businesswomen and businessmen who have administrative skills, potential financial wherewithal and electability," said Bruce Blakeman, the Republican former presiding officer of the county Legislature. "I think there are quite a few people who would be attractive." He wouldn't say who he had in mind.
Not since 1977 have Nassau Republicans held a primary for the county executive nomination. That year, the incumbent, Ralph Caso, lost to Francis Purcell, the party-backed candidate and eventual winner in a three-way primary.
"I wasn't the most popular guy because they thought I was an outsider, but then I was the best vote-getter," Mr. Purcell, 82, said from his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Asked for his thoughts about a potential repeat of 1977 next year, Mr. Purcell said: "I don't even know if Mr. Gulotta is going to run again. But do I think he can win? No, I don't. I don't think he has the backing."
Democrats, also pointing to history, say this may be their best chance to capture the office since the days of Eugene H. Nickerson, who served from 1962 to 1970. But, as Professor Scarrow said, neither Mr. DiNapoli nor Mr. Suozzi may be willing to sit on the sidelines.
Mr. Suozzi held a $250-a-plate fund-raising dinner at a restaurant in Carle Place on Nov. 30. The next day, Mr. DiNapoli was publicly speaking about plans to start his own local fund-raising committee.
On the Republican side, last month's election and the averting of the state takeover gave cause to celebrate. The county's five Republican incumbents in the state Senate were re-elected and the party reduced Democratic inroads in the Town Board in Hempstead, considered the foundation of the Republicans' once-ironclad control of county politics. And Mr. Gulotta was able to win back some political high ground by securing approval of a 2001 county budget that carried only a 7.9 percent tax increase, not the 15.4 percent proposed by the Democratic legislative majority.
"Tom Gulotta was the person most fighting for cutting the tax increases and for spending cuts," said Kieran Mahoney, a Republican political consultant and adviser to Mr. Gulotta. "And that, I think, will be important for the voters of Nassau County if he chooses to run."
Democrats counter that they won six of eight Supreme Court judgeships. Still, a collective cheer could be heard from Westbury, where the county's Republican Party chairman, Joseph N. Mondello, staunched the historic county legislative losses of 1999 by spending about $2 million on town board races. Mr. Mondello has also been trying to line up a ticket for the 2001 races, including for county executive.
As early as the beginning of this year, Mr. Mondello approached Mr. Dillon, 66, the longtime county district attorney, and asked him to consider running for county executive in 2001.
"I told Mr. Mondello that I am not running," Mr. Dillon said recently. "I am running for district attorney next year, if I run for anything."
Mr. Dillon said he could point to "a wealth of candidates" whom Mr. Mondello could choose from for county executive. But Mr. Dillon and others said Mr. Mondello planned to do some political polling on a host of potential candidates before making any firm decisions.
Mr. Parola, the county comptroller, said those polls would show what the electorate thinks of Mr. Gulotta and whether other Republican politicians are linked with what he said was Mr. Gulotta's mismanagement of the county finances.
"If, in fact, he has tainted all the incumbents, then you may well have to go with a whole slate of outsiders," said Mr. Parola, 54. "Joe wants to do what is best, and I think he is going to talk to Tom and look at the polls. I think if Tom is viable, then he will run Tom. If Tom is not viable, I think he will ask Tom to step aside for the good of the party and the good of Tom himself."
But Professor Scarrow said the voters still seemed angry over the condition of the county under Mr. Gulotta's leadership. "I don't see why you need the polls," he said. "The fact that people put the Democrats in charge of the Legislature last year, I think that is all the polling you need."
Some local Republicans say a presidential victory by George W. Bush might create a job opening for Mr. Gulotta outside of Nassau, perhaps in a move orchestrated by Governor Pataki, a Bush ally who is facing re-election in 2002 and needs a strong organization in Nassau, which has the largest Republican enrollment of any county in the state.
"Whatever we are talking about now, the whole thing could change in eight months," said Bruce Nyman, the city manager in Long Beach and former Democratic leader in the county Legislature. "Gulotta could be the ambassador to Belize or something."
Mr. King said Mr. Mondello was "very concerned" about the county executive race. He agreed that after the polling, Mr. Mondello would probably seek an alternative candidate and then hope he could persuade Mr. Gulotta to step aside. But that may not be so easy.
"He told me he feels he is in good shape," Mr. King said, referring to Mr. Gulotta. "I would say the odds are against him, but I would never count Gulotta out."
Mr. King, 56, ruled out running. "Quite a few people have mentioned it to me," he said, "but I told them no, I really don't want to be county executive."
Mr. Guardino, 50, is up for re-election as Hempstead town supervisor next year and, as one aide put it, it is critical to have someone strong at the top of the town ticket. Ms. Ferrara, 41, did not return calls to her Westbury office seeking comment. Mr. Balboni, 41, fresh from re-election to the state Senate, said no one had approached him about any future elective office.
"I have had no discussions and no interest in any office other than the state Senate," he said.
Whoever wins -- Republican or Democrat -- Mr. Mondello said the tough fiscal decisions that lie ahead will probably be carried out more effectively by someone who sees the job lasting just one term.
"I feel strongly about that," Mr. Mondello said. "This county executive is going to have to know the word no."
On the Democratic side, Mr. Suozzi, 38, appears ready for a costly battle. In an interview, he said he had a war chest of nearly $700,000. At this rate, Mr. Suozzi said he could expect to raise $1.5 million to $2 million. Every cent of it may be needed should a fight with Mr. Gulotta be necessary. But he may need another $1 million to wage a primary, should Mr. DiNapoli seek the party nomination, said Jay Jacobs, who is Mr. Suozzi's campaign chairman.
It would be a shame, those close to Mr. Suozzi said, if he was forced to empty his campaign coffers in a primary battle with Mr. DiNapoli.
"That would diminish our ability to help those legislators in those tough seats," Mr. Jacobs said. "I don't want to have this phrased as a blame-game statement. I am just giving the realities."
After his landslide re-election to the state Assembly this year, Mr. DiNapoli said he had about $100,000 left in his campaign fund, a significant portion of which he said he could transfer to a county executive race. But money is a minor concern, he said.
"I don't doubt that I can compete with any of the other Toms that are out there in that department," said Mr. DiNapoli, 46. "But money is not what this campaign is about. This is not going to be about the glitzy TV commercials. It is going to be about the candidates' past performance and future ability. And money can't buy all of that."
Both Mr. Suozzi and Mr. DiNapoli blame the years of one-party Republican rule in Nassau County for its ongoing fiscal woes. Both claim to have just the right mix of experience to lift the county from its depths of near-bankruptcy and restore its reputation as a vibrant suburb.
Mr. Nyman, who insisted he would not run for county executive himself, said: "I like both of them. I like either one of them. I mean, I like any Democrat. We have got two wonderful candidates right now."
Mr. DiNapoli was tapped in 1999 to rebuild the county's troubled Democratic Party and orchestrated the first Democratic takeover of the county Legislature in nearly 100 years.
Mr. DiNapoli said he had "gotten a great deal of encouragement" by those in and out of his party to run for county executive. Should he lose, he would not face re-election in the Assembly until 2002.
Some Democrats say that after 14 years in the state Assembly, where he co-sponsored many pieces of legislation with Republicans -- including the law to help bail out Nassau County -- Mr. DiNapoli would be a welcome conciliator in the often fractious atmosphere of county government.
"He looks for the positive, rather than separating and conquering," said Larry Aaronson, the first vice chairman of the county Democratic committee. "He is tremendously suited for that."
But the party chairmanship, which is by nature partisan and combative, is ill-suited for a conciliatory role, and Mr. DiNapoli suggested that he would not keep the chairman's post while running for county executive.
Mr. DiNapoli called himself "the accidental assemblyman" and said the chance to run in Nassau County would be "a real opportunity to help the people."
"The county is in need of real leadership," he added, "and that kind of a challenge is very appealing to me."
Mr. Suozzi said it was his experience as the mayor of Glen Cove that made him particularly suited for running the county government. When he was first elected seven years ago, Glen Cove had a multimillion-dollar deficit and a bond rating that hovered just above junk status, a situation like the county's today. Mr. Suozzi raised taxes, balanced the budget, cut the workforce and began cleaning up the city's downtown and waterfront in the process.
"I am a problem-solver," said Mr. Suozzi, whose current term ends at the end of 2001. "Glen Cove now has the highest bond rating since the 1970's. There is also a new sense of pride and optimism in our city."
Mr. Suozzi said he wanted to restore pride in the county as well. With its fine beaches and "strong communities," he said, Nassau is one of the finest places to live.
But Mr. Suozzi said a vision for the county's future could be articulated until the current crisis was solved. "Nassau County should be the best county in the country, instead of the laughingstock all the way from the boardrooms of Wall Street to the corridors of power in Albany," he said. "I've got the fire in my belly."
So far, there are no other Democratic hopefuls on the horizon. Not even Ben Zwirn, who nearly unseated Mr. Gulotta in 1993, is currently considering another run. But he has lots of ideas about taxes, patronage, essential county services and the economy.
"I'd love to raise these issues on a countywide scale, but I don't see myself being a candidate," he said. "But I have learned in life that you can't rule anything out."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Edgewater Mixed-Use Project Has Traditional Look

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: EDGEWATER

 BODY:
PILES will soon be driven deep into a patch of former industrial land along the Hudson River here for a mixed-use enclave called the Promenade that is being designed as a throwback to an old-fashioned downtown Main Street replete with residences above shops.
When completed by 2002, the development, which is to cost more than $75 million, will include 160,000 square feet of stores as well as five restaurants topped by 325 one- to three-bedroom rental apartments. There will also be two hotels with a total of 360 rooms, 20,000 square feet of space for professional offices, a public riverfront walkway and 1,500 parking spaces on the 15-acre site. It is just north of Gorge and River Roads in this Bergen County community at the base of the Palisades' cliffs, not far from the George Washington Bridge. 
 The mix of uses will be in two rows of interconnecting brick buildings each with varying elevations of three to six stories. Three mainly interconnected structures on each side will face a central landscaped boulevard extending from River Road eastward to the river.
The parking garage will be mostly below grade and accessible to the street-level commercial activity by escalator or to the residences by elevator. There is also limited street-level parking.
The Promenade project is being designed by Barrett Ginsberg of Denville, N.J., and developed by Starwood Heller Properties, a joint venture between Starwood Capital Group of Greenwich, Conn., and G. Heller Enterprises of Edgewater. Already in place are 162 modularly constructed rental and condominium apartments that the developers put up in the last 20 months on a pier jutting 800 feet into the water. Most of those units have been sold or leased.
In addition, National Amusements of Dedham, Mass., recently completed a 16-screen movie theater on 15 adjacent acres it purchased earlier from Starwood Heller. The theater is to open next Thursday.
The project is the latest addition to the resurgent mile-long waterfront of this former factory town. In the last several years numerous new rental and condominium buildings have been built or are being constructed with a total of up to 1,600 residences. The borough's population has increased in the last decade to 6,300, from 5,001 in 1990.
This activity has caused some worries in the community, intensified by a fire this summer that destroyed an unfinished apartment complex, nine houses and 12 cars and left 45 people homeless. (The fire, which was declared an accident, began on the block of an incomplete 408-unit rental project, which was rising at the site of the former Alcoa factory. The developer, AvalonBay Communities of Alexandria, Va., with offices in Princeton, is rebuilding.)
ONE significant concern is that the growth will overwhelm this pencil-shaped community, despite a widening of River Road, the main street that snakes through it. In response a group of residents, the Independent Coalition for a Better Edgewater, is campaigning for the borough to acquire the last developable waterfront parcels and preserve them as open space.
Mayor Bryan Christiansen said Edgewater has problems, particularly traffic. But he said this would be the case even if there were no development in Edgewater, given the growth in residential construction in neighboring riverfront towns.
While the activity seems to be happening all at once, he added, approvals for most of the buildings under way were in place for years and waited for a strong economy to move ahead. In addition, most of the activity is turning land that once held abandoned factories or crumbling piers into taxpaying properties, he said, adding that after years of financial struggle the borough will soon "see a big bump up in its ratable base and its coffers fill."
The entire 32-acre Promenade parcel, including the pier, was formerly occupied by the Celotex Corporation, which manufactured wallboard. Four years ago Starwood Heller purchased the site for more than $15 million from the Manhattan developer Leonard Litwin and since then has razed the old plant and cleaned the land of contaminants.
Explaining the purchase, Gene Heller, Starwood's chief executive, said, "The real reason Edgewater developed is the rebuilding of River Road, and with that any properties along the road were going to become more valuable."
Mr. Heller is no stranger to the Edgewater waterfront. In 1996 his company built Edgewater Commons, a 390,000-square-foot retail center along River Road just north of the Promenade site, which eventually was sold. Farther north on River Road he is completing 64 rentals above 74,000 square feet of retail space.
At the Promenade site, Mr. Heller said, the first steps were to develop the pier as housing to capitalize on the location and to sell 15 of the upland acres to National Amusements for the movie theater. These actions, he said, would offset land costs and "bring activity and people to the site."
As for the rest of the upland acres, he said the initial idea was "to put up a few big box retail stores and call it a day." But, Mr. Heller said, borough officials wanted something more than a retail area centered on a big discount, home-improvement or office-supply chain and something different from Edgewater Commons, which is a big open-air retail center. This eventually led to the current mixed-use concept. He added, " This will offer an unmall-like area and set us apart from our competition."
Mayor Christiansen said the mix of uses "is appropriate for the land, given its location, and will draw people to shop and live" at the development.
Retail professionals said consumers and retailers these days are looking to downtowns as an option to suburban malls. That does not mean malls are a thing of the past, said Malachy Kavanagh, spokesman for the International Council of Shopping Centers in Manhattan. But, he said, there are fewer of them being built nationally, and those that are constructed are huge and include entertainment components to broaden their reach.
IN turn, neighborhood shopping centers are appealing to time-pressed consumers, who see them as easier to get in and out of than malls, especially for small errands. Mr. Kavanagh added that some retailers, especially large chains that are not dependent on other stores to draw consumers, like them instead of malls because they provide street visibility for their stores and nearby parking for their customers. By adding residences and office space, Mr. Kavanagh said, developers provide "a built-in audience for the retail space."
Faith Hope Consolo of Garrick-Aug Associates, a retail leasing firm in Manhattan, added that the audience for riverfront retail space is expanding as "the migration from Manhattan these days" by employers "has been to the Jersey waterfront, not Westchester or Brooklyn." Ms. Consolo said that even though "the retail market has cooled a little" in the region, Manhattan retailers continue to expand to Connecticut, New Jersey and Westchester County.
Retailers have responded to the Promenade. Seventy-five percent of the 160,000 square feet in about 40 shops has been preleased, said Tod Heller, Starwood Heller's vice president of marketing and leasing, and Gene Heller's son. Tenants include the Gap, the Limited, Pier 1 Imports, Ann Taylor and Eddie Bauer. Annual rents range from $26 to $35 a square foot. Negotiations with operators for the hotels -- one with 220 rooms, the other with 140 -- are also under way.
"The people moving to or already living at the riverfront are fairly affluent," Tod Heller said. "The Promenade will give them a shopping experience that doesn't exist along the riverfront."
And what of the market for waterfront residential rentals? "It's slowing," said Robert P. Antonicello, president of the ACI Group, a real estate services firm in Jersey City.
Because of the stock market's swings. people have become cautious, Mr. Antonicello said, adding, however, that there still "is demand for quality well-priced units." Average rents have remained stable in the last year at $26 to $28 a square foot, he said.
At the Promenade, where planned amenities include a swimming pool, the apartments will have 850 to 1,400 square feet and are expected to rent for an average of $25 to $26 a square foot. That means a two-bedroom, 1,250 square foot unit would rent for about $2,600 or $2,700 a month.
"The financing for the project is based on today's rents or less," Gene Heller said, "so we're not looking for continued inflation for it to work."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2558 words

HEADLINE: The Soul of the Ultimate Machine

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: LA JOLLA, Calif.

 BODY:
THE Silicon Valley crowd that assembled last week in a San Francisco airport hotel had come to hear about mobile electronic commerce, a most immediate concern for people who spend many of their waking hours thinking about whether their latest e-business solution will merit venture capital dollars.
They learned about something very different. 
 Instead of talking about buying Barbies online, the astrophysicist Larry Smarr came to tell them about what he calls "the emerging planetary supercomputer." The Internet, he explained, is evolving into a single vast computer fashioned out of billions of interconnected processors. Then he went another step: "The real question, from a software point of view, is: Will it become self-aware?"
To Dr. Smarr, the idea of a thinking machine that might emerge spontaneously from billions of interconnected large and small computers isn't harebrained at all. He said he was simply extrapolating a series of significant trends that, to him, are remarkably obvious. And when it comes to extrapolating trends and forecasting technological revolutions, Dr. Smarr is worth listening to.
Fifteen years ago -- prehistory in Internet terms -- Dr. Smarr persuaded the federal government to establish supercomputer centers for civilian research. That bit of brass led to the birth of technologies like the Web browser and advanced computer-graphics programs that allow scientists to see how hurricanes work and let moviegoers stare dinosaurs in the eye. Along the way, he also helped expand a network of computers that were owned by military contractors, corporations and universities into what is now called the Internet.
Now Dr. Smarr has persuaded Gov. Gray Davis of California to put him in charge of the California Institute of Telecommunications and Information Technology, a new state-financed research academy in this seaside San Diego suburb, with the goal of envisioning the future -- and making it happen. Governor Davis announced his decision to authorize Dr. Smarr's institute and two others on Thursday.
And what Dr. Smarr sees is this: the rapid emergence of a much more extensive cyberspace that will essentially mirror the physical world. He imagines bridges that are covered with a fabric of computerized sensors that will automatically tell engineers where earthquake damage has occurred. Or a world in which intelligent buildings whisper directions to visitors on the way to their destinations.
"The emerging information grid is going to be far more pervasive than the electric power grid is today," he said.
STILL, the idea that the Internet may transform itself into a global computational grid with a mind of its own has generally been considered far-out stuff from the pages of science fiction novels.
The idea of a thinking machine may sound outrageous, but Dr. Smarr's record has made him one of the world's most respected computer technologists. He created the research center that contributed to the development of the Internet and then invented the graphical browser -- marketed as the Netscape Navigator and Internet Explorer -- that opened the Net to the masses.
As director of the computer research institute announced on Thursday, he is now in the position to test even his most far-out ideas. The institute will be established with more than $300 million in state and private funds over four years.
Based jointly at the University of California campuses at San Diego and Irvine, it will focus on engineering new types of sensors, creating an advanced digital wireless Internet and designing a new class of distributed-computing machines, which break a problem into separate pieces to speed calculations. It will also work on applying those technologies to problems in the environment and transportation, as well as to genomic medicine and new-media arts.
Several times in the past, Dr. Smarr had equally radical ideas about where computing was headed, and each time he correctly spotted the Next Big Thing.
He founded the National Center for Supercomputer Applications at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign in 1985, and helped to develop a network that linked it to the nation's other four supercomputer centers.
His center also did pioneering work in scientific visualization, and one of its brightest scientists, Stefen Fangmeier, went on to become a leading graphics animator in Hollywood. There, he helped to create special effects for movies like "Jurassic Park" and "The Perfect Storm."
Yet those advances pale beside the fact that seven years ago, a small group of student and faculty researchers working at Dr. Smarr's center created the first graphical Web browser, Mosaic, igniting the World Wide Web and the electronic-commerce explosion.
The center's advances flowed directly from Dr. Smarr's passion over the last three decades: to use powerful computers to improve the quality of science. His goal in developing the supercomputer centers was to give tools to scientists that had once been available only to bomb designers and code breakers.
The Internet and the World Wide Web grew in part from his drive to build better computer tools to permit scientists to collaborate and share information.
"He fostered the kind of environment that I had always associated with Xerox Palo Alto Research Center or Bell Labs," said Marc Andreessen, the Netscape cofounder, referring to two widely admired information technology laboratories. "People were free to follow their instincts. He tends to attract really, really smart people and gives them the latitude to pursue their ideas."
But Mr. Andreessen added that while he was there, the University of Illinois shared at least one weakness with the Xerox lab in Silicon Valley: It had a hard time bringing innovations to the marketplace. Mr. Andreessen was able to start Netscape by licensing the institute's Mosaic technology, but only after overcoming the university's resistance, he said.
"What they never got at N.C.S.A., what they never had, was a culture of entrepreneurial spinoffs," said Mr. Andreessen, adding that the culture had since changed. "If he can add that at the new institute, a culture that permits people to go off and start companies, then I think he will really have something."
OVER one and a half decades at the Illinois supercomputer center, Dr. Smarr built a reputation as a scientist who helped to develop the use of computers by both elite scientists and millions of nontechnical Web surfers.
"Larry has had a huge impact," said Robert R. Borchers, director of the division of advanced scientific computing at the National Science Foundation. "He's a legitimate scientist, and he's usually one step or two ahead of the trend on technology."
Dr. Smarr's new institute will draw together more than 200 faculty members at the San Diego and Irvine campuses to re-invent the Internet using technologies like optical fiber cables, digital wireless networks and micro-electro-mechanical systems, or MEMS.
Since the end of the cold war, this part of Southern California has changed from a stronghold of the military and aerospace industries into a center for wireless, optical, semiconductor and biotechnology companies.
Dr. Smarr settled on this area -- 400 miles south of Silicon Valley -- because it was both a center for high technology and a fertile ground for what he calls "I.P.O. capitalism."
"Based on the electronic-commerce boom that followed the development of the Mosaic Web browser, I realized that a new model of growth was emerging," he said. "I knew I had to get to a place where there was an explosive private sector."
Among the companies that have already committed themselves to investing $140 million in Dr. Smarr's new institute, dubbed Cal-(IT)2 , are I.B.M., Sun Microsystems, Qualcomm, Boeing, Broadcom, Ericsson, Microsoft, Intersil, ST Microelectronics and Sony.
Dr. Smarr's plan is to use the institute to attack a few very difficult problems with what he calls "mega-computers" -- thousands or even millions of separate computers lashed together with optical fibers via the Internet.
The most dramatic challenge for the institute, considering its location in automobile-choked Southern California, is to build a prototype for an "intelligent transportation infrastructure." It would use the Internet to wirelessly link sensor arrays under freeways with computers in cars. Dr. Smarr believes that it will be possible to build a giant computing grid that can control traffic more effectively.
"When your computer knows where each car is planning to go, it is a problem you can solve," he said.
The challenge is that a computer that large has never been built, much less programmed. Such a machine would have what Dr. Smarr calls an "effervescent" architecture. It would comprise millions of parts -- processors, communications links and storage units -- that come and go unpredictably.
"Larry's plan is to take the Web into the physical world," said Ramesh Rao, a professor of electrical engineering at the University of California at San Diego.
Many people in the computer industry believe that if such a machine is to be built, Dr. Smarr is the ideal person to lead the quest.
"He has long years of experience in the hardest part of this whole business," said Richard Shaffer, president of Technological Partners, a computer industry consulting firm. "That's getting software to work together across lots and lots of processors."
Dr. Smarr's obsessive search for more computing speed derived from his theoretical work as a student in the 1970's. Then, as a first-year graduate student at Stanford, he was trying to apply Einstein's general theory of relativity to the collision of two black holes.
At the time, the only way to get access to enough computer power to start the experiments needed to test his theories was to turn to the nation's nuclear weapons laboratories.
Dr. Smarr had gone to Stanford to study with Leonard Schiff, one of the world's leading experts in relativity theory. But Dr. Schiff died unexpectedly during Dr. Smarr's first year in graduate school. After moving to the University of Texas at Austin, Dr. Smarr linked up with another group of relativity experts. He eventually received a Ph.D.
AT Texas, his adviser told him bluntly to get top-secret nuclear weapons clearance so he could go to the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California and "learn from the great ones."
For Dr. Smarr, contact with the weapons labs was what he now describes as a Promethean experience. Early on, he found that a problem that would take eight hours to run on a Digital Equipment VAX computer at the University of Texas would require just two minutes on one of the weapons laboratories' supercomputers.
Several years later, as a post-doctoral researcher at Harvard, he was a regular visitor at weapons labs, flying in for a few days at a time and cadging time on supercomputers to run simulations of thermonuclear forces far more awesome than the hydrogen-bomb makers had imagined.
"It was what I called 'interstitial' living," he said. "I would show up on Friday afternoons and ask, 'Hey, are you guys going to be running your bomb codes this weekend?' "
The experience transformed him. The lab visits were like ventures into an advanced civilization with powerful tools beyond the grasp of mere mortals.
"I remember going back to Harvard and feeling like being an alien landing on a primitive planet," he said.
In 1983, as a junior faculty member at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Dr. Smarr did something unprecedented. He sent an unsolicited, $50 million proposal to the director of the National Science Foundation, George Keyworth. In it, he called for the creation of a supercomputer center at the university to give civilian scientists the same access to powerful computers that was enjoyed at the nation's weapons labs.
At about the same time, Sid Karin, a scientist at General Atomics, a contractor at the University of California at San Diego, sent a similar proposal to the government. Two years later, the National Science Foundation acted, setting up a nationwide network of five centers dedicated to broadening scientific access to supercomputers.
Dr. Smarr still frets over how little the nation supports both the direct and indirect benefits of the centers. "What our society doesn't understand is how critical investment in basic science and technology is to advances in society," he said.
California is counting on such a spinoff effect from its three new research institutes.
Dr. Smarr draws parallels to the nation's land-grant universities of more than 100 years ago. "This is really just back to the future," he said. "Why did the citizens of the Midwest allow their tax dollars to be spent on agricultural research? Because it led directly to more economic productivity."
And what America's agrarian economy of the 19th century found in basic scientific research, Dr. Smarr sees in the proliferation of networked microprocessors in the next decade. Not only is the power of individual computer processors growing at an exponential rate, but the number of interconnected computers and computing devices is exploding.
On Monday, at the San Francisco conference, Dr. Smarr described a networked world in which the number of personal computers would soon double, to one billion. Moreover, there will soon be three billion Internet-connected cell phones -- and, more important, as many as 16 billion Internet-connected computers embedded in everything from automobiles to toasters.
It is a world, he said, in which a world of Net-connected computers and electronic sensors "overlay" the real world in such a way that computer power enhances every human action. For example, he sees a time when supercomputers let scientists see hurricane damage as it occurs, as spy satellites work for the military today.
"We're talking about something very radical," he said. "This is the world we're coming to. It's an enchanted world where everything has processors in it linked by the Internet."
HE defends his vision of the future of cyberspace with the certainty of a physicist. Computer processing power is advancing so rapidly, he said, that society is likely to soon go through a revolution as dramatic as the "phase change" when water changes into ice.
For that reason, Dr. Smarr said he plans to hold regular conferences at Cal-(IT)2 about the consequences of scientific and technological change.
Dr. Smarr is not the only computer researcher grappling with the social consequences of wildly accelerating computer power. William Joy, co-founder of Sun Microsystems, recently wrote an article in Wired magazine warning about the potential perils of intelligent machines. Two well-known computer researchers, Hans Moravec and Raymond Kurzweil, have also written books this year about the likelihood of the emergence of intelligent machines.
Mr. Joy's article has touched off a debate among computer scientists about the consequences of their work. Dr. Smarr said he believes that computer scientists may need to grapple with the challenges, perhaps meeting in the same way as biologists did in 1975 at the Asilomar Conference to face the ethical challenges of biotechnology.
In Dr. Smarr's Brave New Cyberspace, the answer shouldn't be long in coming.

Chart: "Net Gains"
Some highlights in Larry Smarr's career promoting the Internet.
 
Fall 1983 -- Dr. Smarr writes a proposal to the National Science Foundation, requesting a supercomputer for the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Ralph Simmons, then head of the physics department, travels with Dr. Smarr to deliver the unsolicited proposal, addressed simply to Director, N.S.F.
 
March 1985 -- The National Center for Supercomputer Applications is established under a five-year foundation grant.
 
April 1987 -- An advanced scientific graphics program begins at the supercomputer center.
 
Fall 1987 -- NCSA Telnet, the center's first major software release, makes its debut. By 1991 it has more than 100,000 users.
 
October 1988 -- A Cray-2 supercomputer is installed. It has four processors and can perform about 1.7 billion calculations a second.
 
April 1993 -- NCSA Mosaic, the first user-friendly Web browser, is released. At the time, there are about 200 World Wide Web servers in the world.
 
1994 -- Mosaic has several million users and has effectively given birth to the dot-com industry, which is projected to be worth $1 trillion by 2001.
 
February 1997 -- Dr. Smarr is appointed to the President's Information Technology Advisory Committee.
 
October 1997 -- The National Computational Science Alliance becomes a reality. A partnership of some 50 institutions across the country, it is charged with making a prototype of the National Technology Grid. This is an unprecedented effort in which the whole is truly greater than the sum of its parts, Dr. Smarr says. In essence, we are establishing a virtual community that shares its knowledge and pools its resources to create the computational and information infrastructure of the 21st century that will support the next generation of scientific and engineering research.
 
May 2000 -- Dr. Smarr joins the computer science and engineering faculty at the University of California at San Diego. Relying on the national distributed-computing network that he has helped advance for more than 15 years, he remains an adviser to the National Computational Science Alliance.
(Source: National Center for Supercomputing Applications, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign)(pg. 16)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Coming to America to Learn a Secret: Boldness

BYLINE: By LYNNLEY BROWNING 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
SWITZERLAND, the land of Heidi, neutrality, chocolate and secret bank accounts, is not known for a business culture that encourages daring new ideas. And that is exactly what is worrying the Swiss government, which has watched in dismay as America's brash young executives spawn the hot companies and vast wealth of the new economy.
So in an uncharacteristic move, Switzerland has opened a mission in Cambridge, Mass., that is intended to help the country discover its inner entrepreneur. 
 Less Old World consulate and more 21st-century conduit to the Boston area's hotbed of technological and academic innovation, the outpost aims to encourage a new generation of Swiss businesspeople to think more like their American counterparts.
"We don't have a culture of, 'Let's grow big and fast and be master of the world,' " said Dr. Xavier L. Comtesse, 52, a Swiss diplomat who heads the mission, known as the Swiss House for Advanced Research and Education. "You never hear a Swiss say, 'I want to change the world,' like you do here. We need to take more risks."
Other countries with similar aspirations have taken notice of Swiss House, which is a research organization, consulting firm, incubator and meeting space rolled into one. Near the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Harvard University, in a region with the largest concentration of start-ups and venture capitalists after Silicon Valley in California, the outpost is described in a government brochure as "a privileged observatory of the efficient American innovation and technology transfer system."
With open cubicles, a conference table, and a pillow-lined "pit," Swiss House offers Swiss entrepreneurs a place to fire up their laptops, make phone calls, network and absorb the culture of the new economy.
Swiss House officially opened in October, after a prolonged renovation, but it has been operating for many months. Last May, it held a European start-ups conference with M.I.T. In January, Swiss House and M.I.T. will sponsor a biotechnology conference.
Swiss House has also asked Clarity Capital and Atlas Venture, two venture capital firms based in Boston, to participate in business development seminars for young Swiss executives and to screen business pitches from Swiss start-ups. Saleena Goel, an associate at Atlas, and Chad M. Jackson, a principal at Clarity, said they were interested in both proposals.
The outpost was also host recently for a delegation of Swiss information technology researchers and entrepreneurs, including some from Fastcom Technology, a digital camera maker and software distributor in Lausanne. Some members of the delegation visited M.I.T.'s Media Laboratory to learn how to translate technologies from the laboratory to the market. Others met with representatives of Putnam Investments, the Boston mutual fund company, which invests in emerging foreign companies.
And in tandem with a Swiss foundation, the outpost sponsored a business-idea contest for Swiss entrepreneurs last January. Nearly two dozen winners were awarded one-week crash courses in entrepreneurialism at M.I.T.
The course, called "a brain transplant for potential European entrepreneurs" by Kenneth P. Morse, managing director of M.I.T.'s Entrepreneurship Center, covered issues like customer focus, building management and raising money for start-ups.
"The Swiss know they have a problem," Mr. Morse said. "They're taught to fear risk and failure. They're conservative and conventional. Their culture doesn't favor entrepreneurialism. But they're coming out of the closet."
A case in point is Swiss House's commercial "spin-off," called Swiss Entrepreneurs Network Development, or SEND. Operating at Swiss House but registered as a private United States company, it is a consulting firm for Swiss start-ups. One project is to find an American acquisition target for a new Swiss company, Bioring, which makes medical devices. Aceair, a manufacturer of small aircraft, is using SEND to find legal counsel as it expands into the United States.
"My idea," said Pascal Marmier, SEND's Swiss director, "is to radiate U.S. entrepreneurial skills back into Switzerland."
Mr. Marmier, 27, a lawyer by training, is paid through grants and investments from Venture Partners, one of Switzerland's biggest venture capital firms, and SpaceVest, an investment firm in Reston, Va.
An artfully designed space of glass, blond-wood floors and chrome, surrounded by Webcams, flat panel displays and giant video conference screens, Swiss House has the feel of a high-technology start-up -- albeit one with a big interior-design budget. It even has a corporate-style advisory board; one member is Paul Sagan, president of Akamai Technologies, the Internet services company based in Cambridge.
The operating costs of Swiss House are paid by the Swiss government. But the $2 million cost of buying and renovating the red-brick building, a former grocery store, was financed by Lombard Odier, a 202-year-old private bank in Geneva. The bank hopes to organize seminars at Swiss House on how American high-tech start-ups do business.
Dr. Comtesse proposed the mission to the Swiss government in 1997, when he was the science counselor at the Swiss Embassy in Washington. Nearly two years later, Bern approved, but the deal was delayed by local homeowners who sued to block it out of concern that Swiss House would change their residential neighborhood. A judge ruled in favor of the Swiss.
The outpost idea appears to be spreading: officials from Britain, Ireland, Japan and Finland have asked Swiss House how to set up similar missions. Australia, Singapore and Canada established outposts this year in San Francisco and Silicon Valley.
Despite its small size, Switzerland is prosperous and is home to much potential start-up capital, and researchers there have developed promising biotechnologies and computer technologies. Nevertheless, the country ranks only 10th in Western Europe in private equity investing, which includes venture capital financing for new companies -- far behind Britain, France and Germany, according to the European Private Equity and Venture Capital Association, a trade group based in Brussels.
IN the United States, venture capitalists have poured hundreds of billions of dollars into risky start-ups in recent years. But Switzerland's secretive venture capital funds and financial institutions, daunted by high taxes, tend to invest in well-established Swiss companies or abroad. Swiss stock options are taxed so prohibitively that they are usually a burden, rather than a springboard to personal wealth or an incentive to build a good company quickly.
And while the American new economy has been fueled in part by the willingness of executives to put aside their dot-com failures, Swiss laws that make it difficult to write off debts can render an entrepreneur's failed venture his last.
Whether Swiss House can turn the Swiss into new-economy capitalists is unclear. Ms. Goel at Atlas Venture said that for Swiss House guests, learning a new entrepreneurial culture "will be a hurdle."
Dr. Comtesse sees Swiss House as a beachhead for changing a less-than-innovative mind-set. "Americans think differently," he said. "We need to have more dreamers."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Dissecting the Nature of the Downturn

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
NOW that Alan Greenspan is on record as alert to the economic slowdown unfolding in the United States, investors can breathe a collective sigh of relief and start buying stocks again. Or can they?
The equity indexes bounced back last week, on the hope that imminent interest-rate cuts would deliver the economy and corporate profits from disaster. But this time it may not be that simple. All economic slowdowns are not created equal, and some economists believe that the characteristics of the current one are more worrisome than equity investors seem to think. 
 "An important question for the Fed in the months ahead will be whether the economy is decelerating in a way that it desires," said Henry Willmore, chief United States economist at Barclays Capital in New York. "Answering this question entails more than simply looking at G.D.P. growth."
Instead, investors must look at how much of the growth in gross domestic product comes from productivity increases and how much from job creation. One force -- slower job growth -- would be far preferable for the Fed and would have better results for investors, Mr. Willmore said.
If the economic slowdown comes from more modest job creation than the nation has seen recently, the Fed will be pleased because it means that inflation stays in check. In Mr. Willmore's view, the Fed would like to see employment growing by 50,000 to 100,000 jobs a month.
If, however, growth stalls because productivity falls, it will keep the Fed policy makers on inflation alert and thus less likely to cut rates aggressively. Slowing productivity means that companies cannot offset rising wages with higher earnings. "This puts more pressure on firms to pass through cost increases to consumers and has a negative effect on consumer prices," Mr. Willmore explained.
The steep nature of the deceleration is what troubles Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "As recently as the second quarter of 2000, the year-over-year growth rate of real G.D.P. in America was 6.1 percent," he said. "That rate by the middle of next year will be about 1.9 percent, a 4.2-percentage-point deceleration."
Mr. Roach pointed out that such a drop would exceed the sharpest decline -- of about three percentage points -- seen in the recession of 1990-91. "The deceleration we're seeing now was last seen in 1982," he said. "This is a recession-style compression in the growth rate. It's coming with great speed. And that speed of compression really could be destabilizing in influencing business decisions with respect to capital spending and could even be unsettling to consumer expectations."
At the same time, Mr. Roach sees no new sources of growth elsewhere in the world to pick up the slack for the United States. Indeed, because America has been the most powerful engine of global growth in recent years, its weakness would have a greater impact.
Mr. Roach said economic growth in the United States accounted for 30 percent of total global growth between 1997 and 2000, in excess of America's 22 percent share of the world G.D.P. A result, he added, is a 40 percent chance of a hard landing.
Mr. Roach said the Fed chairman's speech this week signaled that he was prepared to do more to avoid a hard landing, but that is not where Mr. Greenspan thinks the economy is heading. "He'll be reactive, not proactive," he said. "Whatever the Fed does early next year will be too little, too late to forestall the outcome in 2001. The next round of Fed easing will have more of a bearing on the upturn that follows than on the slowdown that lies ahead."

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
In Fund Ads, the Weeks That Weren't

BYLINE: By DANNY HAKIM 

 BODY:
THE stock market is doing great. Honest. Just look at a recent crop of mutual fund advertisements.
Check out the ad in the Dec. 4 issue of Barron's, the one with the eight guys in sweats doing push-ups on a football field, with the stern headline, "American Discipline." According to the ad, the American Century Vista fund, which invests heavily in technology stocks, had a 12-month return of 108.1 percent. Imagine that. No sign here of all that doomsday claptrap about technology stocks. 
Then there is the T. Rowe Price Science & Technology fund, which, according to a recent ad in Business Week, had a 12-month return of 38.4 percent. The $19 billion Fidelity Aggressive Growth fund? Up 49.3 percent, according to a recent ad in this and other newspapers. Scudder 21st Century Growth? Up 40.6 percent.
A bear market? What bear market?
The stock market may be in general decline, but everything is still blooming in the land of mutual fund marketers. Their message this holiday season is simple: Try to remember the end of September -- or at least what your 12-month mutual fund returns were back then -- and try to forget that the Standard & Poor's 500 index is down 6.8 percent so far this year.
Fund companies defend their advertisements by pointing to Securities and Exchange Commission rules that require them to include in their performance advertising their 1-, 5-, and 10-year returns through the end of a fund's most recent quarter.
But Cynthia M. Fornelli, a senior adviser to the head of the S.E.C.'s investment management division, said the agency was considering changes in its rules. "Maybe it's not enough to rely on the last quarter of performance numbers if something extraordinary happens in the interim that makes those numbers misleading," Ms. Fornelli said. "I would remind people that there is currently an anti-fraud provision in our rules that may require such updating."
The National Association of Securities Dealers, which reviews fund ads to make sure that they comply with the S.E.C. rules and its own, has issued two additional guidelines. In 1999, it said that more performance data might be necessary if "the fund's performance suffers materially" after the end of the most recent quarter. An official said last week that the guideline was meant more for catastrophes, like the impact of a currency devaluation on an emerging-markets fund, than for market corrections.
This year, it added a recommendation."If a fund's recent performance was the result of its investment focus in an unusually 'hot' industry or other factors that may not continue to exist," the association said in a notice, "we believe members should include prominent, cautionary language."
Fidelity and American Century note that in recent weeks, they have added stronger caveats to the usual "past performance is no guarantee of future results" in their fine print. "Current performance may be lower than performance stated," the Fidelity advertisement says.
T. Rowe Price, however, disagrees with the N.A.S.D.'s 1999 guideline. "The N.A.S.D. notice is just a recommendation," said Jane White, a spokeswoman. "We have discussed it with them at length and disagree with them. We use the S.E.C. guideline."
BECAUSE the markets have been down this year, especially since September, adjusting the one-year returns through the date the ads actually appeared yields a bleak picture: T. Rowe Price Science & Technology was down 12.9 percent. American Century Vista was up 14.9 percent, far below the triple-digit gains in the ad. Scudder Kemper 21st Century Growth was down 0.42 percent.
Fidelity Aggressive Growth, meanwhile, was down 4.12 percent. Fidelity's Nov. 20 ad also lists the fund's top, five-star ranking from Morningstar Inc. But try to catch a falling star: By the time the ad appeared, Morningstar had downgraded the fund to four stars.
Neal Litvak, president of Fidelity's retail marketing division, regretted the disparity. "That would not be my preference to have that happen," he said. Since then, he said, Fidelity ads, besides adding stronger caveats, have moved away from emphasizing individual funds.
"We're trying now to modify those performance ads so they show a wider range of products," Mr. Litvak said. "They show small numbers as well as big numbers."
At least Fidelity, T. Rowe Price, Scudder Kemper and American Century include fine print. Then there is Dow Jones, publisher of The Wall Street Journal and Barron's. In several recent ads in The Journal, the company promotes its Dow Jones industrial average and the 19 different companies and exchanges that sell mutual funds and other products tracking the average, for which Dow Jones collects licensing fees.
The ad calls the average "an unbeatable equation with an extraordinary return" and encourages investors to "contact your financial sales professional." The prominently displayed numbers, including a 25.22 percent one-year return, are impressive.
But the ad has no fine print that says when the return was posted. When the ad appeared on Dec. 4, the Dow was down 5.7 percent over the previous 52 weeks. If you guessed that the advertised return was through the end of September, you would be wrong. It was from the 1999 calendar year.
Because it is not a fund company, Dow Jones is not subject to the same regulatory standards. But besides using a favorable period to calculate returns, Mercer Bullard, a former lawyer for the S.E.C.'s investment management division, said, the ad neglected to take into account the fund fees that would reduce performance. Mr. Bullard, who now runs Fund Democracy, a fund shareholder advocacy group, said that if he was still at the S.E.C., "I would refer it to an enforcement liaison."
He said that while it would not be easy to establish the S.E.C.'s jurisdiction, "in the S.E.C.'s favor, this is a very misleading ad."
Richard Tofel, a Dow Jones spokesman, said that despite its note to call one's financial adviser, the ad was not truly aimed at individuals. "The ad is soliciting people to offer such funds, not people to invest in such funds," he said, pointing out that the message at the bottom of the ad invites investment companies to arrange licensing.
Some fund companies show more current results. In a recent ad, Warburg Pincus listed its Capital Appreciation fund with a 45.2 percent one-year return through Sept. 30. Next to that number, displayed as prominently, was the year-to-date return through October. It was 4.19 percent, a glimpse of reality in mutual fund Fantasia.

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
Why Junk Bonds May Not Look That Bad After All

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
KATHLEEN C. GAFFNEY, a bond portfolio manager at Loomis Sayles & Company in Boston, was saying last Tuesday morning that corporate and high-yield bonds were an attractive bet. Why? People think the economic outlook is much worse than it is, she said.
"We're not talking about a recession; we're just talking about an economic slowdown," she said in an interview. As one reason for her confidence, she cited her belief that the Federal Reserve and its chairman, Alan Greenspan, would cut interest rates quickly if they thought the economy was in danger of falling into a recession. 
 What she did not know was that Mr. Greenspan was proving her right, even as she spoke. In a speech to an audience of bankers that morning, he signaled the central bank's readiness to cut short-term interest rates if it saw any recession threat.
Some analysts have interpreted his remarks as suggesting that there will be an interest rate cut as early as the end of January, when Fed policy makers meet for the first time in the new year. Others said Mr. Greenspan was making a pre-emptive strike against a tax cut by a possible Bush administration. Last Sunday, Dick Cheney, George W. Bush's running mate, said the economy "may well be on the front edge of recession" and argued that the danger was a further justification for Mr. Bush's proposed tax cut of $1.3 trillion.
Other analysts contend that Mr. Greenspan is worried that the corporate bond market could seize up as it did in 1998, after Russia defaulted and a large American hedge fund collapsed, threatening to choke off the credit needed to keep the economy moving ahead. While Mr. Greenspan said there was yet no comparison to 1998, he cut rates three times that year to ease credit strains. He cut rates in July 1990 for the same reason.
Whatever his motives, Mr. Greenspan's reassurance improved the outlook for high-yield and corporate bonds.
But looking better is not difficult, especially for high-yield bonds, which have been shunned recently as fears of slowing growth and falling earnings raised credit concerns about many companies.
High-yield, or junk, bonds have been victims of a huge sell-off that pushed yields higher but slashed the prices of the bonds. According to a Merrill Lynch index, the high-yield sector is down 7.2 percent for the year through November. Most of that decline has come in the last two months.
What makes junk bonds attractive right now, of course, is their yield. Junk bonds, on average, are paying more than 14 percent -- nearly three times current Treasury yields -- while investment grade bonds of big companies are yielding 7.5 percent, according to Merrill Lynch bond indexes. On top of that is the prospect that the prices of high-yield bonds will eventually rally if current concerns about the economy prove unwarranted. Mr. Greenspan has said he will do his best to prove that those concerns are overblown.
Martin S. Fridson, Merrill Lynch's chief high-yield strategist, thinks that things could get a little worse before they get better, but that Mr. Greenspan's signal "is a move in the right direction."
BUT Mr. Fridson warned that the high-yield recoveries of 1991 and of 1998 did not happen until short-term interest rates had fallen well below long-term rates, a sign that the economy was poised to grow nicely, thereby lessening credit concerns. Right now the yield curve is inverted, with the 5.35 percent yield on the Treasury's 10-year note well below the 6.04 percent on the Treasury's three-month bill. That is because the Fed has pushed short-term interest rates higher over the last year and a half, while investors, expecting growth and inflation to slow, will accept lower rates on longer maturities.
Still, Mr. Fridson said, high yield is very attractive, even if things do get worse before they get better.
Look at it this way: Even if it takes a year for high-yield bond prices to move up, with 14 percent interest rates, you are being paid nicely to wait.
