HEADLINE: Consumers Across the Nation Are Facing Sharp Increases in Health Care Costs in 2001

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Consumers across the country will face double-digit increases in their health care costs starting next month, reflecting the biggest surge in medical inflation since the early 1990's. The increases will show up in larger deductions from paychecks and higher deductibles and payments for care, especially prescription drugs.
Employers learned earlier this year that their health care premiums would be increasing between 10 and 30 percent in 2001. Most companies are absorbing the majority of the hefty increases, hoping to retain important employees in a tight labor market, but they are sharing the burden with workers. And at some companies, employees are paying a growing share of the costs. 
 As their health care expenses rise, low-income workers and the self-employed may decide to drop coverage altogether. Although the number of Americans without insurance dipped to 42.6 million last year from 44.3 million in 1998 as many temporary workers moved up to jobs with benefits, health policy experts say rising costs for 2001 may lead to an increase in the number of people without insurance.
"If the double-digit increases continue and the economy turns down, that could eventually drive the uninsured to 50 million or higher," said Jack Meyer, president of the nonprofit Economic and Social Policy Research Institute in Washington.
"My concern is that when costs go too high, there will be a certain number of companies and employees who will say they can't afford it," said Marshall Abrahams, president of Desks Inc., a Denver office supply firm with 50 employees.
Employers facing double-digit premium increases are "starting to get panicky," said Janet Trautwein, policy director of the National Association of Health Underwriters, an insurance agents group.
"Rates are going up dramatically in some parts of the country," Ms. Trautwein said. "Some employers have reduced their contributions and some have changed the benefits" to make them less costly, she said.
Large employers are raising payroll deductions by 20 percent, on average, while adding 15 percent to what workers pay in deductibles and copayments, said Kenneth L. Sperling, a health care expert at Hewitt Associates, the benefits consulting firm.
Over all, employees of large companies will pay 18 percent more, or $1,401 on average, in 2001, according to a Hewitt survey of 350 employers with six million workers and dependents. The employers' health care costs will rise 9.8 percent to $4,026 per employee. Combined costs for these companies and their workers will rise 17 percent, Hewitt said.
Costs are increasing for government employees as well. In the federal employees' health plan, the nation's largest, monthly payroll deductions will rise 14 percent to $74.23 in January for most single employees, and increase 21 percent to $175.30 for families, said Bill Pierce, a spokesman for Blue Cross and Blue Shield, which covers about half of the eight million federal workers and retirees. The annual deductible and employee payments for hospital and outpatient care will also rise.
The trustees of the 1.2 million-member California Public Employees' Retirement System, the nation's second-largest health plan, will meet this week to deal with cost increases as high as 24 percent for 230,000 members of the system's financially troubled "preferred provider organizations," networks of preselected doctors and hospitals. The retirement system's staff is suggesting cuts in coverage to keep down the increase in premiums.
The staff proposals include doubling the annual deductible employees pay, to $1,000 a family, and adding a $50 payment for emergency room visits.
But for 850,000 of the California public employees, who are in H.M.O.'s, several unions rejected cuts in benefits last summer. Their premiums were then raised 9.2 percent for 2001.
Employers have been paying most of the increase in health care costs over the last two years in order to retain workers in a tight labor market. But if the economy slows, that could change. "The American public is in for a shock when the recession comes," said Jon R. Gabel, vice president of the Health Research and Educational Trust, an independent research affiliate of the American Hospital Association. "They have no idea how much health care costs have increased over the last five or six years."
Big companies that offer choices of health plans have long arranged reduced premiums for low-cost plans. If workers choose a more expensive plan, they often have to pay the difference in charges, said Dave Rahill, a health care consultant in New York with William M. Mercer, benefits consultants.
With health insurance costs rising, small companies are more likely to follow suit and offer their employees more choices. Many are joining health care purchasing alliances that offer an array of choices, so their workers can also choose between joining a low-cost plan or spending more if they want better protection.
Gary Ahlquist, a senior vice president at Booz-Allen & Hamilton, a management consulting firm, predicted that as costs increase, more employees will choose high-deductible insurance, with lower premiums. That insurance may appeal to healthy people who are willing to risk paying $1,000 or even $2,500 if they need care, he said.
That would mark a change from past years. High deductibles "have not been particularly successful" in finding customers, said Greg Scandlen, a senior health policy fellow in Washington at the National Center for Policy Analysis, a conservative research center.
That may be because "rank-and-file employees don't have the resources to draw on, if they have to come up with $1,000 quickly," said Richard Ostuw, a health care expert with the Watson Wyatt consulting firm.
"When we raised prices, people left," said Mark Weinberg, group president of individual and small employer business at Wellpoint Health Networks, based in California. "A certain percentage went uninsured" rather than pay higher premiums.
Wellpoint's California Blue Cross unit, which covers 850,000 individuals in the state, is also trying to give consumers more options, lowering premiums to appeal to individuals without insurance. At the same time, it is asking members who need care to pay more. Under some policies, patients would pay 25 percent of the charges for anything other than visits to the doctor, generic drugs and preventive care, as well as a separate deductible for brand-name drugs.
"Seventy percent of any population spends $150 or less on health care in a year," Mr. Weinberg said.
"This is a watershed time for us," he added. "Either we, as an industry, recognize these cost trends and make the right decisions," or the customers will drift away, going without insurance or trying Internet-based alternatives to the managed care companies.
But some employees have few choices. Until last year, Harlequin Books, a publishing company, paid the entire cost of health coverage for its 40 employees in New York as well as the 20 members of its national sales force. The company gradually introduced cost-sharing, requiring employees to cover 5 percent of health coverage premiums this year and 8 percent in 2001, when Harlequin's premiums will rise by 14 percent.
"It's a problem for the employees," said Linda Kleinman, manager of human resources and administration. "They don't earn princely sums. Publishing salaries are not like those in dot-com companies."

HEADLINE: With Trepidation, Saudi Arabia Meets the World

BYLINE: By SUSAN SACHS 

DATELINE: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia

 BODY:
Prince Sultan bin Salman is a familiar face in Saudi Arabia. A strapping former Air Force pilot, he flew as an astronaut on an American space shuttle 15 years ago, is a grandson of the nation's founder, the son of a well-known governor, and now the nation's tourism chief.
But on a recent trip to a village market near Taif he saw firsthand what it might be like to arrive a stranger in the conservative and provincial kingdom. 
 The prince and his aides pulled out their cameras to take photographs of the market scene, all part of their research for the budding tourism industry. It took but an instant, the prince recalled, before they were the center of hostile attention from the local people. One old man, sure they were outsiders with bad intentions despite their traditional Saudi dress, grabbed a big stick and chased them.
The incident underlined the challenges facing Saudi Arabia as it attempts to open up to influences, and visits, from the world outside. Its lesson was not lost on Prince Sultan. "You just can't bring thousands of people in and let them out and about," he said, in an analysis that applies to much more than his own tourism project. "We are going to move carefully and cautiously."
Though they have yet to bear fruit, reforms have been set in motion that aim to diversify the economy and create jobs. But the overriding question is whether the royal family can execute economic reforms and open up the kingdom of 22 million people without also sharpening demands for political change.
Crown Prince Abdullah, Saudi Arabia's de facto ruler, has proposed several steps over the last two years. The government has for the first time offered foreigners the chance to own property and open a business without a Saudi national as a majority stakeholder. And a new General Investment Authority has been set up to seek foreign investors in gas development, power industries and desalination of sea water.
The government has said it intends to set up a capital market, which would require new standards of openness for Saudi companies. It has also started work on reforming its legal system and trade regulations, all in pursuit of membership in the World Trade Organization. And it has signed international treaties and conventions on human rights.
Each of these steps would mean that Saudi Arabia, a country that follows a combination of Islamic law and ancient tribal traditions, will be pressed to acknowledge international norms. And in those cases where its own norms differ, Saudi Arabia will be pressed to explain itself as never before.
"At the high levels, the interest is there and the thinking is clear," said Saleh Mutabbakani, a businessman in Jidda who has put together ventures with foreign partners.
But many Saudis simply resist change. "They might not know why they are against it, but they are," he said. "One problem is that religion and tradition have melted together and people don't think about the difference."
For a society accustomed to its king and princes, where foreign publications are censored, where the study of Western philosophy is banned, and where women may appear publicly only if swathed in black cloth, there are minefields ahead.
"We are motivated to join the W.T.O. and be part of the wider world and its institutions," said a senior Saudi official. "But it's a trial. As we look at how we are reflected in the eyes of the world, we are going to see what's missing in our reflection."
The kingdom has responded fiercely to unexpected change in the past. In 1965, then King Faisal, a modernizer with a flair for dramatic gestures, introduced television. Tribal leaders and members of the king's own family, including a nephew who ultimately assassinated the king, denounced the newfangled invention as the work of the devil.
When American and European soldiers, male and female, poured into Saudi Arabia for the Persian Gulf war 10 years ago, a group of educated women in Riyadh, emboldened by the presence of Westerners, flouted the ban on women drivers. They were arrested, and those who worked lost their jobs. Alarmed at the intrusion of the soldiers, radical Islamic preachers attacked the Saudi ruling family. The preachers were arrested.
Liberals and conservatives alike sent letters to the king asking for more participation in decision making. They were arrested or vilified in semiofficial newspapers, but King Fahd finally made good on a promise by his elder brother in 1956 to create an appointed council to advise him.
Introducing foreign ideas about competition, freedom of movement and human rights could again provoke a public backlash, some Saudi officials acknowledged, but not an earthquake. "The dynamics here have changed," said Prince Sultan. "The country is different than it used to be."
Still, each change may have a ripple effect on the country's political dynamics, many Saudis said. For example, if companies are required to follow standard accounting rules, demands may also intensify for more openness in the government.
"The first thing people are asking for is transparency from the government," said a banker in Riyadh. "Before we ask private companies to show their figures and all the guts of their business, we need to know what the government programs and spending plans are. How else can you expect people to invest or bring back money from abroad?"
Similarly, some Saudis said they believe that outside pressure is their only hope of putting a check on police powers, elevating human rights and reforming the judicial system, which is run according to Islamic law.
"There are no lawyers," said a Saudi writer. "You don't have the right to be told why you're being taken to jail. The judges are corrupt. And yet we hear all the time that if you attack Saudi Arabia's human rights record, you are attacking Islam."
The government has made human rights a priority and intends to respond forcefully to its critics, said Prince Turki bin Muhammed, an undersecretary who is in charge of relations with international organizations.
Saudi Arabia has ratified four conventions on human rights and discrimination against women, though it submitted formal reservations. And prompted by its acceptance of international treaties and trade rules, the government is considering creation of an appellate court and a codification of defendants' rights.
But conflict with international norms is inevitable. Like many nations that have adopted the Islamic legal code, Saudi Arabia gives a woman's testimony in court only half the weight of a man's. Religious freedom, as the State Department has noted, does not exist. Only Muslims may be citizens.
Even if the government wanted to change what Western critics regard as discriminatory laws, many Saudis said, it would risk enraging conservatives inside the country.
"I am a member of a tribe," said Fahad al-Harthi, an urbane member of the Majlis who holds a doctorate in humanities from the Sorbonne in Paris and runs a new newspaper called Al Watan.
"That identity and connection is crucial to me," he added. "And no matter how I might feel about it, I can tell you that if I were to let my wife drive, the next day I would no longer be considered a part of my tribe. That's how strong the societal pressures are."
While market reforms and economic opening may have wrought political changes in some countries, many Saudis said the chances of that happening in their nation are slim.
"If we had elections, there would be only two kinds of people on the Majlis: tribal chiefs, no matter how uneducated or bad, and businessmen," said one influential Saudi prince. "We take into account what those people want, but there is a big difference between giving them what you think they should have or having them grab it from you."
"We can never have political parties," the prince added, "because we are all of one party -- the party of God."

HEADLINE: CONTESTING THE VOTE: THE BUSH CAMP;
For Texas Governor's Camp, 'Nightmare Situation' Was Only a Bad Dream

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER and FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 9

 BODY:
Inside the Texas Governor's Mansion on Friday evening, Gov. George W. Bush's aides had a term for the scene they knew would begin to unfold today on television, as Florida counties began recounting disputed ballots.
"The nightmare scenario," one adviser said. "A nightmare because it's uncontrolled, and because the political damage could be severe." 
 Yet by this afternoon, moments after the United States Supreme Court stepped in to stop the count, the roller-coaster mood of the Bush camp was suddenly back to one of confidence. For now, they didn't have to worry about the prospect that a recount might give Mr. Gore a lead for the first time since election night.
That would create not only a legal problem but a political one: public opinion could quickly follow the numbers. And if the headlines blare that Mr. Gore won not only the national popular vote by 300,000 votes, but a narrow majority in Florida as well, one aide said, it "could change the political dynamic of the last month."
Not often in the past month has the Bush camp been through a scare like the one it had Friday night and today until just after lunch, when the recounts were halted by the 5-4 decision of the United States Supreme Court. And even that victory brought less of a sense of elation to Mr. Bush's aides than a sense of utter confusion. "I'm going to go crazy," said one Bush aide in Florida. "If somebody really wanted me to go insane, this is the way to do it." Another aide, remembering times when victory seemed within grasp, only to slip away, asked: "How many times have we been here before?"
For his part, Mr. Bush stayed out of sight today. After an early-morning briefing he left Austin for his ranch in Crawford, Tex., about 90 minutes away. He heard the news of the stay on a cell phone, aides said, while driving two magazine reporters around his property in a Suburban. "That's great news, that's great," he told Donald L. Evans, his campaign chairman, who was on the other end of the line in Florida. Later, he called back for details.
Many of Mr. Bush's remaining campaign staff members here had flown to Florida on Friday night on a hastily arranged charter flight dispatched to send reinforcements to James A. Baker III, the former secretary of state, who is running the Florida legal wars. They were followed this morning by Mr. Evans and Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's top political strategist.
Mr. Bush spoke several times today with Mr. Baker, but the reality was that there were few decisions left to make. "It's in the hands of the supremes now," one aide said, "and everyone knows what everyone else's argument is going to be."
That did not dampen the frequency of conference calls between Tallahassee and Austin, however, with several of Mr. Bush's top advisers cautioning, before the United States Supreme Court halted the recount, that should the vote count swing to Mr. Gore's favor, the strategy of turning to the Florida Legislature to put up its own slate of electors could engender a political backlash.
"It's a way of winning, but winning ugly," one said.
The fear was that the wave of public opinion that seemed to be building against Mr. Gore until Friday, that he should finish his one last legal appeal and then concede the election, could begin to swing the other way.
No one knew, of course, who would prevail in a recount, but the Bush team has assumed that Mr. Gore would not be fighting so hard to get the count started if he wasn't assuming he would win.
One Bush aide said Friday that in the campaign's view, the hand-recounted tally in Florida would include figures that "we don't think would be fair, or accurate." But in an election this close, any count would clearly be within a statistical margin of counting error that make any numbers suspect. The perception of who won would become as important as the numbers themselves.
That is why so many of Mr. Bush's advisers want the United States Supreme Court to settle the issue -- and why they took heart from today's injunction. If the court permanently bars recounts of the disputed ballots, Mr. Bush's advisers have concluded, that would be the best politically for the Republican candidate -- putting the court's imprimatur on his presidency.
"In spite of all the deep-seated emotion about this, Baker believes that it's important, though not essential, to Bush's presidency that he win from the U.S. Supreme Court as opposed to winning the other way," one adviser said, referring to action by the Florida Legislature, with support from Gov. Jeb Bush, Mr. Bush's brother. But he quickly added: "The Legislature is perfectly constitutional and legitimate, and they're going to play that card if they have to."
In their public comments, Mr. Bush's aides have continued the strategy Mr. Baker laid out on Friday night and again today: to attack the Florida Supreme Court and commend, at every turn, the United States Supreme Court. Dan Bartlett, a spokesman for the campaign here, talked this morning of "liberal, activist judges" on the Florida Supreme Court who ignored, he said, the existence of an "accurate and reliable count of the vote in Florida."
"We're already seeing massive confusion," Mr. Bartlett said before the United States Supreme Court halted the recount. "These counties have been asked to manufacture votes on behalf of their neighbors," he said, by divining the intent of voters using vague and inconsistent standards. By this afternoon, after the halt, Karen Hughes, Mr. Bush's communications director, was talking about the "sense of comfort the American people will feel as the highest court in the land gets involved."
But in the moments before the recount stopped, at least some of Mr. Bush's advisers had noted that the judges who were reviewing the 9,000 "undercount" ballots from Miami-Dade County appeared to be using a stricter standard than the county's canvassing board used before it suspended its recount three weeks ago. If that standard was applied around the state, they suggested, Mr. Bush could prevail -- a result that they believed would prove the quickest road to a concession by Mr. Gore.
The spin about how the votes might turn out ended as soon as the United States Supreme Court action suggested the recount might end as well. It was replaced by brief celebrations surrounding the injunction, followed by apprehension that the 5-4 majority might not hold on Monday. ("Every day, we're up, we're down, we're in, we're out," said one aide. "I've become almost anesthetized to all of this stuff.")
Of course, this was hardly the way that Mr. Bush and his top advisers had envisioned this weekend playing out.
All week, the Texas governor had nurtured an air of inevitability about his move to the White House. His spokesmen were reporting that he was receiving daily intelligence briefings, and those briefings apparently gave Mr. Bush the confidence to issue a warning to potential terrorists that they should not even think of taking advantage of this moment of electoral indecisiveness.
Mr. Bush's aides were already talking about the economy, warning that a slowdown could turn into an economic downturn, and using that prospect to build support for their proposed tax cuts as an economic stimulus package. Mr. Bush even said he had decided on the composition of his White House staff, and aides hinted that announcements were ready to flow as soon as Mr. Gore conceded.
There was talk of a Bush trip late next week to Washington, perhaps to meet Mr. Gore and Congressional leaders, maybe even to take the measure of the Oval Office.
Now the short-term challenges are obvious. Few in the campaign underestimate the challenges ahead, even if the United States Supreme Court paves their way to a victory.
Nearly half the time presidents ordinarily enjoy to organize a transition has slipped away, with only one or two officials in place. If the recount that was cut short today in Florida ultimately restarts, and leads to lengthy legislative or court battles, or ultimately ends up in the House and Senate, the next president would have had only days to get a Cabinet and staff prepared.
The medium-term challenge is more severe. No matter who takes office on Jan. 20, the chances have now been heightened that half the Congress will regard his election as tainted, if not illegitimate. That is why Mr. Bush's aides have been so concerned about throwing the election into the Florida Legislature or even Congress. In both forums, Mr. Bush would likely win.
But in both, it would be regarded as a partisan victory.
"That would not be an insurmountable challenge," one Bush policy adviser said late Friday. "We understand the need to govern from the middle."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Whispers Turn to Talk of Eliminating Clubs

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Commissioner Bud Selig, an executive of a team said, is studying contraction. No, not contractions like don't and wouldn't and aren't, but contraction as in consolidation, as in eliminating teams.
"I can't honestly say I've done that," Selig said when asked about his study. "There are people who like contraction. What I have said relative to contraction is the problems are so significant that every option is on the table. That's one of them. We're no more advanced than that. There's nothing critical about it." 
 Jerry McMorris of Colorado, Larry Lucchino of San Diego and Peter Angelos of Baltimore have been the leading proponents of paring the number of teams to something less than 30.
"They believe in it very strongly," Selig acknowledged. "There are others who don't. I've heard from both sides. I've encouraged people who want to talk to me about it to do so."
Even if it is only a signal to owners to discuss the issue, the commissioner seems to have changed his position on contraction. Earlier this year, when talk of it surfaced, he said he was aware of the talk but added, "I really don't accept that."
Study or not, the idea of contraction has arisen because some owners see it as the solution, or part of the solution, to baseball's economic problems. The owners see the problems as being created by player salaries, which continue to soar and leave low-revenue clubs lagging further behind the high-revenue teams.
Over several days last week, for example, the Colorado Rockies signed two free-agent pitchers for a total of $174.5 million. They acted just days after the Yankees signed Mike Mussina for $88.5 million.
The Montreal Expos have not signed any players to those types of contracts lately. They are Exhibit A in the contraction debate. Jeffrey Loria, the club's relatively new owner, dismisses the talk.
"We are still struggling," he said, "but we are confident that our situation will be resolved when baseball resolves its problems. I plan on being in this game a very long time. I cannot imagine anything that would take place that would take me away from this game that I love."
The Expos are scheduled to receive about $24 million this year, most among the 13 recipients under baseball's revenue-sharing plan. Their revenue problems were exacerbated by their inability to get a reasonable amount of money for local television rights. The $800,000 they were offered would not have paid one player making the average salary.
Loria, faced with the likelihood that the Expos will not get a new stadium in Montreal, would be far better off if he moved the team, perhaps to northern Virginia. The Oakland Athletics, another candidate for extinction in the eyes of some owners, would benefit from a move to the San Jose area.
But owners of teams that draw fans and television viewers from those prospective locations, the Baltimore Orioles and the San Francisco Giants, have balked at the possibility of those moves. And Selig said recently that relocation would not be considered until a new labor agreement was in place. The contract expires at the end of next season.
Some skeptics have suggested that talk of contraction is a negotiating ploy, aimed at making the union nervous about losing jobs so that it would concede some important economic issues. Donald Fehr, however, did not sound like a concerned labor leader when he was asked about the possibility of losing teams.
"If that becomes a real possibility, I assume they'll talk to us about it," Fehr said. Asked if the owners could act unilaterally, he said: "I don't know. This isn't something we have an opinion on. If it becomes real, we'll have an opinion."
None of the owners linked contraction to labor negotiations. McMorris, in fact, called it "a last resort."
"I only talked about it in the beginning," he said, "because if all else fails and they can't support a team in a market, we have to look at what we're doing with revenue sharing and the central fund sharing that's going to some of these places."
Contraction, McMorris added, was "brainstormed during our sessions with the blue ribbon panel." He referred to the committee that produced a report on the state of baseball's economy, making recommendations about revenue sharing and payroll taxes. "If the recommendations outlined in this report are implemented," it said, "there should be no immediate need for contraction."
But the owners who favor contraction believe management could gain control of player salaries because jobs would be in greater demand and players would sign for less money than they make now. They feel the present system creates salary inflation by having too much money chasing too few players.
Eliminating two to six teams, some proponents believe, would be ideal, creating a higher quality of baseball as well as lower salaries.
Montreal, Minnesota, Oakland and the two Florida teams are the candidates most often mentioned. No owner of those teams, however, would find the idea palatable even though Major League Baseball would pay for the franchises.
"I don't think anything has been moved that far along," McMorris said. "I know Bud is being thoughtful." He estimated that roughly half the owners would favor contraction but added, "I don't think there's been enough serious analysis or discussion to come to a conclusion."
 
Disney on the Dole
Imagine stopping at a red light at a street corner on Manhattan's West Side and suddenly seeing Michael Eisner race over to the car and begin wiping the windshield, simultaneously holding out his other hand. Or walking down Broadway and having him jump out holding a tin cup.
Eisner runs the Walt Disney Company. Disney owns the Anaheim Angels. The Angels are a big-market team that has operated itself into small-market status. They are one of 13 teams this year that will receive handouts from baseball's revenue-sharing plan. They are scheduled to receive about $8 million.
The Philadelphia Phillies are on the dole for about $12 million, the same as the Pittsburgh Pirates. Pittsburgh is a village compared with Philadelphia. The Florida Marlins, who won the World Series only three years ago, will receive about $15 million, same as the Milwaukee Brewers, placing them third among the recipients.
Montreal will receive the most money, about $24 million. Minnesota is next at about $21 million, meaning it will get more money than the $16.5 million it paid its players.
As they were at the end of the World Series, the Yankees ($22 million) and the Mets ($18 million) are 1-2 among the 17 teams that will pay out about $164 million in revenue-sharing funds. They are followed by Cleveland ($13 million), Atlanta ($12 million) and Boston ($12 million).
 
Cone's Life Goes On
For David Cone, life on the mound did not end with the pitch to Mike Piazza for the third out in the fifth inning of Game 4 of the World Series.
"I think you constantly have to prove yourself," Cone said, taking a break from workouts in Tampa, Fla. "I know the position I'm in right now. That's why I'm down here working so hard. If someone wants to come and watch me throw, come on. If I have to hold a tryout camp, I will."
He laughed. "I say that half jokingly," he continued, "but that's how serious I am. When I do show up for spring training, I'll be ready to go."
Cone, let loose by the Yankees last week after five-plus seasons, knows he is in no position to dictate where he plays or how much a team has to pay him to play. A 4-14 record at the age of 37 tends to obviate that.
"What I'm looking for is the challenge," he said, "a situation where I can play a prominent role and help a team." He was agreeable to leaving the Yankees because he believed his role as their No. 5 starter would not have met that desire.
"I understand the position that I'm in," he said. "I also feel it was just a Murphy's Law year for me. I do believe I was turning things around before I dislocated my left shoulder."
Steve Fehr, Cone's agent, is beginning to take calls from prospective employers and was as confident as Cone that he would pitch, and pitch productively, next season.
Cone said he was working hard to straighten out his mechanics and get in midseason shape. "I think much of my problem last year was mechanical," he said, "experimenting too much. I'm working to fix that. I don't believe you can fall that far that fast in one year. It was just one year."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Mets Still Optimistic About Finding Pitching Help

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 9

 BODY:
The scuttlebutt floated through the halls at baseball's winter meetings today. One general manager said he heard from someone with the Atlanta Braves that they were hot in pursuit of Seattle Mariners shortstop Alex Rodriguez. It seemed very likely that Rodriguez would wind up choosing between the Braves and the Texas Rangers.
The same general manager said the Cleveland Indians were back in the quest for outfielder Manny Ramirez, whose agent later acknowledged that he had continued talking with the Indians and had even exchanged new proposals earlier in the week. But as the agent spoke on the phone, two executives of the Boston Red Sox sat in a room down the hall in his office in Newport Beach, Calif., taking a respite from their second successive day of negotiations. 
 The Mets, their general manager said, "were not getting crazy in the Manny Ramirez chase." But Jeff Moorad, Ramirez's agent, said he would nevertheless meet with Steve Phillips here at the winter meetings on Sunday.
Ramirez and Rodriguez were the two premier free agents remaining. The other two had signed with new teams, Mike Mussina with the Yankees and Mike Hampton with the Colorado Rockies.
Hampton appeared at the Wyndham Anatole Hotel here today, explaining that he loved his season with the Mets but proclaiming the Rockies to be "our kind of people," Colorado "our kind of place." It is so much Hampton's kind of place that his father and his wife's parents will eventually move there.
"This is a family decision from top to bottom," he said, "not just myself and my wife."
Hampton's defection, despite the Mets' seven-year, $105 million offer, left the Mets with decisions to make. They have to fill his spot in their starting rotation, and Phillips continued talking to agents and other general managers seeking that pitcher and one other starter.
"I feel confident we're going to be able to fill our holes in a way that we'll feel good about our pitching staff," Phillips said.
Could Phillips leave here Monday night with a pitcher? "I think there's a chance," he said. "We have enough irons in the fire that there's a chance we'll get something done."
Phillips didn't mention any names, but he has been talking with the agents for Kevin Appier, Bobby J. Jones and David Cone. Dan Horwits, Appier's agent, said the Mets "economically are a little bit behind other clubs."
Phillips has also talked with other general managers, including those who currently employ Pedro Astacio and David Wells.
"I'd say we're talking about pitchers you can slot in to the rotation in front of Rick Reed and behind Rick Reed," Phillips said. "The likelihood is we'll slot somebody in front and somebody behind."
But it didn't appear that he would be inserting Ramirez in the right-field slot.
"We have the luxury of having young, productive outfielders that are affordable," Phillips said. "Affordable and productive enough that it allows you to consider spending your money in other areas, particularly pitching. We also have depth coming up in the organization with outfielders. We feel we have enough depth that mortgaging the organization for an outfielder is not really in the best interests of the club."
Moorad, also the agent for Jones, the Mets' free-agent pitcher, said Phillips had made it clear that he was going to continue to focus on pitching. "But he's also interested in sitting down and talking about Manny in Dallas," Moorad said. "I intend to see him sooner rather than later."
Moorad said he also planned to meet here with John Hart, the Indians' general manager. "We've talked daily for probably the last 10 days," he said. "We exchanged proposals earlier this week. It's fair to say we each took a shot at a creative approach."
Each side has turned down the other's proposals. Their inability to reach an agreement to keep Ramirez in Cleveland has enabled the Red Sox to jump into the breach. Dan Duquette, the Red Sox general manager, and Mike Port, another club executive, arrived at Moorad's office Friday and were still there yesterday. "It's been an intense couple of days," Moorad said. "We've shared an awful lot of ideas in an effort to find common ground, but at this stage common ground is still eluding us."
What the Red Sox offered, the agent said, was not enough to scoop up Ramirez without Moorad seeing Hart first here on Sunday. "I've committed to John that I would see him," Moorad said.
Before Mark Rodgers, Hampton's agent, contacted the Rockies to begin final negotiations, he said he told Hampton, "I think I can go back to the Mets and get you more money."
But, Rodgers said, "He said it's not about the money."
A skeptical Phillips said, "It's always about money, especially when it's not about money."
The Rockies announced that their eight-year deal with Hampton was worth $123.8 million. However, that total includes subsequent interest on the deferred $19 million of his $20 million signing bonus.
The basic contract is worth $121 million, which is still the biggest contract a baseball player has ever received. The contract includes an option for a ninth year at a $20 million salary or a $6 million buyout.
But what about pitching at Coors Field, the black hole for all pitchers?
"There's no doubt it's the toughest place to pitch," Hampton said. "It takes total mental and physical concentration and effort. It's going to be a true test. It's a test I look forward to."

HEADLINE: Effort to Repair Armenia and Azerbaijan Ties

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Dec. 9

 BODY:
In the effort to resolve the smoldering conflict over Azerbaijan's mountainous enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh, international negotiators are trying to assemble an aid package that would help make peace palatable to the bitterly opposed peoples of Armenia and Azerbaijan.
This week, they secured what was portrayed as an important promise from the Turks to restore regional trade and to aid both neighboring Azerbaijan, an increasingly close ally of Turkey, and Armenia, historically a foe, if peace is agreed. 
 While avoiding specifics, Foreign Minister Ismail Cem of Turkey told American and French negotiators on Friday that his country would play a substantial role, participants said.
"We came here to highlight the important role that Turkey would play and to coordinate with Turkey on the steps we are taking to try to move forward in the peace talks," Carey Cavanaugh, the special American negotiator for Nagorno-Karabakh, said in a telephone interview.
For Turkey, helping put the economies back together would enhance its campaign to become a major regional power. The country is closely aligned with Azerbaijan and has been making inroads with the former Soviet republics in Central Asia.
For the United States, France and Russia, which are trying jointly to broker a peace between Armenia and Azerbaijan, the pledge from Turkey offers another incentive to offer the warring countries.
The dispute over Nagorno-Karabakh, an Armenian-inhabited enclave within Azerbaijan, has proven intractable, and the impasse threatens to affect the stability of an important swath of territory stretching from Russia to Iran. In 1992, Armenian-backed troops pushed hundreds of thousands of Azeris out of Nagorno-Karabakh and proclaimed it an independent state. A cease-fire agreement was reached in 1994, but skirmishes persist and at least 100 people have been killed this year.
In addition, an estimated one million Azeris displaced by the fighting remain in wretched refugee camps. Blockaded by Azerbaijan and Turkey, Armenia's once-thriving economy has collapsed.
The only hint of progress has been sporadic meetings in recent months between President Heydar Aliyev of Azerbaijan and President Robert Kocharian of Armenia.
But Western diplomats said both leaders face political trouble and personal danger if they are perceived as giving up too much. So the negotiators are trying to assemble a multi-billion-dollar international rebuilding package to make peace more acceptable in both countries, and to spur on the talks.
The issue is sensitive for the Turkish foreign minister. Relations with Armenia -- always tense -- worsened in recent months after Armenian-Americans nearly persuaded Congress to declare the mass killing of Armenians by the Ottoman Empire in 1915 a genocide. Still, Mr. Cem said peace would help normalize relations between Turkey and Armenia and possibly bring the resumption of trade along the border, which has been closed since 1993.
To highlight the possibilities for renewed regional trade, Mr. Cavanaugh and his French counterpart, Jean-Jacques Gaillarde, crossed the border between Turkey and Azerbaijan today to meet up with Nikolai Gribkov, a Russian diplomat who is also trying to negotiate peace for Nagorno-Karabakh. The team plans to cross into the no man's land between Armenia and Azerbaijan on Sunday to meet with military leaders. Four people were killed last month along the border and the sides have exchanged mortar and sniper fire in recent days.
"They say they think all the mines have been cleared," Mr. Cavanaugh said. Last July, Mr. Cavanaugh donned a flak jacket and helmet and walked three-quarters of a mile down a three-foot-wide path through a minefield for a similar session.
After meetings with military commanders from both sides next week, the negotiators will have separate discussions on new peace proposals with Mr. Kocharian and Mr. Aliyev.

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
Admiring Houston's Creative Bent

BYLINE: By DAISANN McLANE 

 BODY:
MY first trip to Houston, about 20 years ago, was on assignment for Rolling Stone. There I interviewed a rock musician with a 10-gallon hat and a foot-long beard who, as it happened, also sat on the board of the city's Museum of Contemporary Arts. I was impressed by this, because it suggested that Houston was a city that embraced, even encouraged, eccentricity.
The Rand McNally road map of Houston that I used for navigation in the 1980's is half the size of the 2000 version I bought to guide me through the city on my three-day trip there early last November. Using the new map was like trying to fold a bedsheet in the breeze. Houston, the fourth-largest city in the United States, has outgrown first one, then another beltway loop since my first visit. Immigrants from all over the world -- from Iran to Nicaragua, the Philippines to Trinidad, India to Vietnam -- have added new spices to Houston's three-alarm chili. 
 Perhaps the most interesting barometer of Houston's changes is that the bearded rock star, Billy Gibbons of ZZ Top, has traded in his cowboy hat for a Moroccan knit skullcap and is learning to play African-style guitar.
Eccentric and eclectic though it may be, Houston nevertheless has a rather conventional American travel infrastructure; its hotel landscape is dominated by Hyatt and Marriott at the top of the pile (where prices hover between $150 and $200 a night), and Super 8, Motel 6 and Hampton Inn at the low end (where I saw prices as low as $59.99 for a clean but cookie-cutter room by a freeway interchange).
My needs fall somewhere in between those of the expense-account business executive and the long-haul trucker. I dug into the guidebooks, surfed the Internet and called up friends, hoping to find an affordable room with some local atmosphere.
Eventually I found a couple of possibilities. The first was a place I'd heard about five years ago when I was in Houston to write about a trial. The pro bono defense team, from South Texas, had encamped itself at the Allen Park Inn, a vintage 1960's motel just west of the downtown area that is owned by a Houstonian. An investigation on the Internet revealed that the Allen Park Inn had recently been voted "best budget hotel" by CitySearch.com's Houston outlet. The listed rack rate of $89, though, seemed high -- and it didn't even include Houston's 16.25 percent hotel tax. But I called, and a friendly reservations clerk gave me a price quote of $69 (with tax, $82) for the day I wanted, so I booked -- and was pleased with my standard-issue room, which was large enough for me to practice yoga around the king bed.
I also knew there were interesting lodging possibilities in Houston's Museum District, a leafy residential area west of downtown within walking distance of some of Houston's, and America's, biggest art attractions (the Menil Collection, Rothko Chapel, and Museums of Fine Arts and Contemporary Arts). A handful of Victorian houses there have been converted to bed-and-breakfast establishments and seem to be doing a brisk business. I had to call several before I found an opening for the two midweek nights I needed at the right price. And at Robin's Nest Bed-and-Breakfast the room I wanted (the cheapest of the four guest rooms, at $89 a night) was taken. So I had to reserve a larger room, at $99.
Still, I wasn't upset -- my large, airy room had a bathroom with zebra-print curtains and a French Provincial style cabinet in the bedroom. The rest of the two-story house was bursting with personality and animal prints -- hand-painted giraffes adorned the stairway walls -- and I slept well in an antique queen bed appointed with half a dozen pillows and a feather bed.
America's oil and gas capital, not surprisingly, is a city that's hard to negotiate without a car. Finding one at the best price involved an entire morning of Internet surfing and telephoning, hands on the calculator. The bewildering, ever-changing fares of the airlines are nothing compared with the Nasdaq-like rate fluctuations of a midsized automobile at car rental companies. After price shopping on several online travel services like Expedia, Travelocity and Cheap Tickets, then leafing through the ads and coupons in my latest issue of AAA's Car & Travel Magazine, I got price quotes on a week's rental out of Houston with a return in San Antonio (my next stop) that ranged from $225 to $450, before insurance. Most of the quotes didn't include any of the four separate taxes and fees levied on car renters in the state of Texas. In the end, I got the best deal by simply calling up the 800 number of National Car Rental and telling the reservationist I was an AAA member. National's weekly rate of $264.92, before insurance, included the Sports Authority Tax, the Concession Recoup Fee, the Property Tax License and Title Fee, and the Rental Tax. Curiously, it was cheaper than any of the rates available to me through the AAA Web site.
I took it. And when at George Bush International Airport in Houston I was offered a free upgrade from a midsized car to an intermediate, I didn't hesitate a minute before jumping behind the wheel of a maraschino-red Grand Am .
The next day I pulled this flashy number up to the curb by the house of Cleveland Turner, known to his neighbors in Houston's Third Ward as the "Flower Man." Mr. Turner was relaxing in a lawn chair out in the street in front of his house -- not on the sidewalk or in the yard, because those areas were packed with assorted farm implements, hobby horses, windmills, mirrors, stuffed animals, plastic lawn ornaments and handmade mobiles. "Nice car," he smiled, and invited me to sit down and chat.
Which I did, eagerly. Mr. Turner, in his mid-60's, is one of Houston's best-known practitioners of a folk art that ethnographers have labeled the yard show. A yard show is a house and/or lot that, through the creativity and imagination of its owner, has been transformed, with junk and found objects, into what a museum curator might term an installation, or what a grumpy neighbor might call an eyesore. Houston is a hotbed of yard shows, in part because the city has few zoning regulations, but mostly, I suspect, because the hometown of Howard Hughes and 12-inch beards is a haven of idiosyncratics.
Houston's yard shows and their creators are well known among Texans (they've been featured over the years, in local newspapers and magazines) and American folklorists, and are slowly emerging as a Houston tourist attraction. The most famous of them all, the Orange Show, dates back to the late 1950's. When its creator, Jeff McKissack, died in the early 80's, an independent foundation formed to maintain the property as a museum. The Orange Show Foundation now serves as an unofficial center for information about Houston's yard shows; it runs occasional tours of the sites, and will point out the locations for travelers who want to see them independently.
I did my own tour, using a map I'd found in an old issue of Texas Highway magazine. I started at the Orange Show, in a drab neighborhood of ranch houses near the University of Houston. Walking through a creaking iron turnstile into its riot of orange-painted farm machinery, steam engine wheels, flags and whirring weather vanes, I felt as if I'd wandered into an abandoned circus. The reasons why McKissack, a retired postal worker, created the block-long installation in the first place are obscure. He believed in the restorative properties of oranges, and the Orange Show's walls are emblazoned with exhortations to "Love Oranges and Live."
Puzzling over the Orange Show's mysteries, I got back into the Grand Am and moved on. After a few wrong turns under the Interstate, I found the neon purple house called Pigdom, so called because its facade has been decorated with pictures of pigs and highway signs warning that one is approaching "Hog Heaven." I stood and watched the door for a while, curious as to what the inhabitants of a hog heaven might look like (all the yard shows except the Orange Show are owner-occupied). But no one emerged from the pen.
MY little tour was starting to feel like a treasure hunt as I drove in circles through streets of quiet houses, searching for flashes of glittery inspiration, towers of gorgeous junk. It occurred to me, turning into a street in an old West Houston area called the Camp Logan Extension, that I was getting a great introduction not only to Houston's folk artists but to some of the city's oldest neighborhoods as well.
In the middle of Malone Street, flanked by quiet, modest bungalows, the Beer Can House sparkled in the morning sun. It was an ordinary ranch house until its owner decided to incorporate 50,000 aluminum beer cans into its facade, which now dazzles like a mirage. Long strings of can tops, hung like beaded curtains, tinkle in the breeze.
But still no owner appeared. So when I finally got lucky and met Mr. Turner, the Flower Man, I was brimming with questions about these houses-cum-obsessions. He was happy to answer them all.
"I was in the hospital, drying out from Skid Row, and I had a vision," Mr. Turner said. "And I saw this beauty, swirling all around." Released from the hospital, Mr. Turner began working on a literal interpretation of his vision, using objects, artifacts and plants from his native Mississippi, including cotton, yams and peanuts. "I use junk. Only junk. Nothing new," he explained his aesthetic succinctly. "You have to find the beauty in the junk."
After I had seen Mr. Turner's house, he invited me to join him on a tour of Row Houses, a block of shotgun houses in Houston's historically black Third Ward that have been renovated (with corporate money) and turned into art galleries that showcase work by local artists -- including Mr. Turner himself. Then he guided me to a tiny trailer parked in an empty lot from which delicious smoky meat smells wafted. At Gumbeaux's truck I wolfed down a tender hot beef sandwich ($3.75).
When we arrived back at Mr. Turner's house, a television crew from the Disney Channel was setting up to interview him.
My personal tour of yard shows and of local art spaces with Mr. Turner gave me new eyes with which to view the superb collection of French and Spanish Surrealist paintings in the Menil Collection. I imagined Mr. Turner admiring Dali's visions and approving of the materials used by Max Ernst. And as I entered the separate, brilliantly designed gallery that showcases the work of the Abstract Expressionist Cy Twombly, I began to have some visions of my own. Smiling at the artist's dancing pencil marks and cryptic but exuberant doodles and phrases, I imagined taking Twombly over to the equally cryptic and exuberant Orange Show.
Houston's worlds of popular and fine art, I observed, shared more than aesthetics -- they shared economic policy. The yard shows, the Menil Collection and the Contemporary Arts Museum are absolutely free (the Orange Show and Row Houses welcome donations). And if you plan your visit to the Museum of Fine Arts for a Thursday (which I did), that museum is free, too. Since I was spending no money at all on my art spree, I felt fine about spending a slow, rainy afternoon over a three-course lunch (about $37, with wine and tip) at one of Houston's trendy restaurants, a Latin American fusion place called Americas not far from the Galleria shopping mall.
Inside its dark, Art Nouveau-ish space, decorated with glittery mirrored tiles and Gaudi-like pillars, I swirled my "fettuccine" around a fork, wondering how in the world the chef had managed to craft something that looked exactly like Italian noodles from strips of a corn tortilla. Like Mr. Turner, the chef had fashioned something elegant from an unexpected source. I gave silent thanks -- to all of Houston's idiosyncratic, creative spirits as I savored something that looked like fettuccine but tasted vaguely like a taco.
 
The bottom line: Beer Can House to fine arts
 I spent $137 a day during three days and nights in Houston on food, hotel and activities.
 
Air Fare
My ticket on Continental Airlines, (800) 525-0280, took me from La Guardia to Houston, and then from San Antonio back to La Guardia; the fare was $336.50.
 
Car
National Car Rental, (800) 227-7368, gave me the best weekly rate: $264.92, including tax for a midsize car. At the airport in Houston I got an upgrade to an intermediate-sized car at no extra charge. I dropped the car off at San Antonio airport, again at no additional charge.
 
Hotels
The Allen Park Inn, 2121 Allen Parkway, (713) 521-9321, www.allen parkinn.com is an old-fashioned two-story motel right out of the 60's, complete with a courtyard pool ringed by thatch-covered picnic tables. My room was on the ground floor, facing the courtyard; it was bigger than what you'd get in most chain hotels and had a king-sized bed, cable TV, telephone and bathroom with tub and shower. My single was $82 with tax.
Robin's Nest Bed-and-Breakfast Inn, 4104 Greeley Street, (800) 622-8343, www.therobin.com, has four rooms done up in a quirky Victorian tropical style. Mine was big, had a queen bed, a private bath and a small cable TV tucked discreetly inside a French Provincial-style cabinet. The rate was $99, or $115.50 with tax. A homemade breakfast (eggs, fresh biscuits, cereal and somewhat weak coffee) is included.
 
Restaurants
I splurged on an interesting pan-Latin lunch at the large, trendy restaurant Americas, 1800 Post Oak Boulevard, (713) 961-1492. My "fettuccine" made from tortillas poached in a lobster bisque and presented with grilled shrimp in a lobster sauce, plus a salad, dessert, and glass of Chilean wine, came to $31.
Houston has a huge Vietnamese community, so I was eager to try that cuisine. But the food at the stylish Mo Mong, 1201 Westheimer, (713) 524-5664), was somewhat disappointing. A dinner of two courses, with no drinks, came to $27.
At the corner of Southmore and Dowling Streets in Houston's Third Ward, there's a small empty lot where a truck belonging to the Gumbeaux Restaurant, 5200 Dowling, (713) 520-9962), is parked. The barbecue beef sandwich, served on white bread, ($3.75) is superb.
 
Activities
The Orange Show, 2401 Munger Street, is open to visitors on Saturdays and Sundays from noon to 5 p.m.; in practice, you can usually visit during the day on weekdays (I called ahead to ask permission.) On weekends there's an admission charge of $1; donations at other times are welcome. (The show closes on Saturday till mid-March for restorations.) The Orange Show Foundation, (713) 926-6368, which runs the attractions, also sponsors tours of Houston yard shows.
Some of the other landmark Houston yard shows can be observed from the outside, but they are not open for inspection, since they're private homes. I visited the Beer Can House, 222 Malone Street, north of Memorial Drive, a bungalow covered with a skin of 50,000 beer cans, and Pigdom, 4208 Crawford Street, near the corner of Eagle Street, a house painted purple and dedicated as a whimsical shrine to the porcine.
Cleveland Turner, creator of the Flower Man's House, is often sitting in front of his place at the corner of Sampson and Francis Streets in the Third Ward (his address is 3317 Sampson).
About a mile from Mr. Turner's house are the Row Houses, 2501 Holman Street, www.projectrowhouses .org, (713) 526-7662), restored and revamped as community gallery spaces.
The Menil Collection and the Cy Twombly Gallery, 1515 Sul Ross, (713) 525-9400) are both free. They're open from 11 a.m to 7 p.m., Wednesday through Sunday.
Thursdays are free (other days $5) at Houston's Museum of Fine Arts, 1001 Bissonet and 5601 Main, (713) 639-7300, sprawling buildings with excellent collections -- I especially enjoyed the gold jewelry from West Africa. Across the street at the Contemporary Arts Museum, (713) 284-8250, which rotates its exhibitions every month or so, all days are free. Both museums are closed Mondays. DAISANN McLANE

HEADLINE: Folk Lore

BYLINE: By Robert Christgau; Robert Christgau is a senior editor at The Village Voice and the author of "Christgau's Consumer Guide: Albums of the '90s."

 BODY:

 ROMANCING THE FOLK
 Public Memory & American Roots Music.
 By Benjamin Filene.
 Illustrated. 325 pp. Chapel Hill:
 The University of North Carolina Press.
 Cloth, $49.95. Paper, $19.95. 
 BENJAMIN FILENE'S premise -- that the realities of artistic practice "call into question . . . rigid definitions of 'pure' folk music" -- is by now so widely accepted that even purists have to live with it. His conclusion, "that the backward glance can be more than nostalgic -- that memory can create American culture anew," never discusses the American present in the detail it deserves. But in between these two rhetorical disappointments, "Romancing the Folk" proves a fascinating history of an idea and a shape-shifting body of song.
Filene, a historian at the Minnesota Historical Society, declares himself unconcerned with who the proper creators of "folk music" might be, and he never gets very specific about what forces in modern life rendered their presumably unspoiled isolation so enticing to those bent on redefining America's past. What interests him is how the concept of "folk" was adjusted according to the tastes, needs and ambitions of those who dedicated their lives to it, and the varieties of music such reconceptualizations brought to the surface. Filene traces the way changing notions of the "pure" and the slightly less exclusionary "authentic" -- always counterposed to a vaguely defined "commercial" -- inflected what folk music genres were disseminated and how they were performed, and the profound effect these ideas exerted on all of American pop music and its overlapping audiences. The folklorists, academics, bureaucrats and entrepreneurs who dominate his story are colorful characters, and they are joined by artists who inspire Filene to critical heights few historians approach.
He begins at the unavoidable beginning: with Francis James Child, the Harvard Shakespeare scholar whose name lives on in the Child ballads he canonized in "The English and Scottish Popular Ballads" in 1882, and then with the English folklorist Cecil Sharp, who after years of scouring his homeland crossed the ocean in 1916 to certify a great mother lode of "authentic" Child ballads transcribed in an Appalachia he idealized as a simulacrum of England past. In keeping with the reflexively racist nativism of the time, this pseudoscientific research marginalized black American song, which had been attracting white chroniclers since the Civil War. It also denied that Sharp's Appalachian subjects exercised any legitimate aesthetic prerogatives in choosing or (heaven forfend) changing the songs he elected to preserve -- not to mention the commercially distributed music and black music they also performed, which he dismissed as irrelevant.
It was commercial exploiters like Ralph Peer, the traveling talent scout and soon-to-be publishing mogul, who first secured phonograph records of the breakdowns, ballads and blues that dominate what we now think of as folk music. But another wayward Harvard professor with a passion for authenticity forever changed how such recordings were understood. Where Child and Sharp condescended to folk music's creators as passive conduits of a static, immemorial tradition, John Lomax and his doubly influential son, Alan, honored them as active producers of an evolving one. The Lomaxes sought out both new variants on old material and contemporary topical songs, as long as they were convinced their subjects had generated the music without input from the increasingly inescapable mass media. Lugging a 350-pound recording machine through the South on a 1933 song-hunting expedition that eventually gained them entree to the Library of Congress, the Lomaxes came upon Huddie Ledbetter, who as Leadbelly became the first folk "primitive" sold as such. Imposing their own standards of authenticity, the Lomaxes urged their discovery ("a nigger to the core of his being," John Lomax once remarked) to remain "raw" -- as Filene puts it, "premodern, unrestrainedly emotive and noncommercial"; they even put him onstage in convict's stripes. Yet at the same time they encouraged him to insert spoken explanations and political messages into songs that had never required them before. Moreover, as Filene's diligent analysis of successive recordings of "Mister Tom Hughes' Town" makes clear, Leadbelly himself deliberately sentimentalized, desexualized, sweetened and slowed his music to cater to listeners who preferred their authenticity tamed further.
For Filene, no career better epitomizes the professional quandary of the putative folk musician than that of another Lomax discovery, Muddy Waters. Spurred first by Mississippi-born Chicagoans nostalgic for home and later by folkies and rock 'n' rollers with related but distinct notions of what authenticity might entail, this paragon of the true Delta never stopped adjusting to fashion. Quickly abandoning a sophistication tailored to the pop blues of the day, first freeing and then simplifying his beat, deploying a broad spectrum of electric and acoustic timbres, putting his all into Willie Dixon lyrics that stylized and commodified the macho voodoo of the "hoochie coochie man," Waters made some awkward records. But at his frequent best he bent his overwhelming physical presence to recombinant interpretive genius, adapting usages he had absorbed in one place and time to the social and aural realities of another.
Alan Lomax and New Deal allies like the Federal Writers' Project popularizer B. A. Botkin were more open-minded about who qualified as folk than John Lomax, much less Child and Sharp -- Anglo-Saxon heritage, white skin and even rural isolation were no longer a priori requirements. But even though this folk establishment had built its own economic infrastructure -- dominated by genteel, progressively inclined outsiders, with considerable support in government and academia -- not until the 1960's, if then, was it equipped to appreciate the hit-making likes of Waters, whose crucial patron was the highly unidealistic record executive Leonard Chess. That establishment's direct legacy was the line running from Woody Guthrie and Pete Seeger, himself the son of a left-wing classical composer turned folklore honcho. Filene is plainly inspired by Seeger, whose music and persona he describes with a nuanced complexity that could almost beguile one into pulling out records whose bug-eyed earnestness has not worn well with casual fans. And he is obviously right to identify the apostate Bob Dylan, who so enraged Seeger by playing electric instruments at the Newport Folk Festival in 1965, as the last half-century's most original explorer of the folk idea.
But Dylan is so protean and prolix that you can use him to explore any number of things, and parsing his songs is a favorite ploy of intellectuals set on demonstrating their intimacy with popular culture. So given Filene's interest in the remade past, he should have gone easier on Dylan's 60's output, concentrating instead on the records of the 90's, which he stuffs in at the very end. A new vision of America's musical and spiritual past has been half-articulated during the past decade in two Dylan albums reprising often obscure canonical material combined with his folk-sounding, Grammy-winning "Time Out of Mind" (1997) and the rerelease of Harry Smith's 1952 "Anthology of American Folk Music." Rooted in the recordings of Peer and his contemporaries, and in the Lomaxes' collecting as well, this work spins a vision of pre-World War I America as Bizarroworld Lost -- a site of magic, myth and mystery, a place where honest men told their desperate truths and vanished into the dust. This vision has risen up alongside the wide-ranging and inchoate folkie culture that is busy being born right now -- a culture that stretches from black blues neotraditionalists to the punky faux honky-tonkers of the alt-country movement.
There is no reason to believe that the new vision is any more factual than those that preceded it. It is merely the richest and most recent story certain seekers after the real and the beautiful have devised for themselves. In an era when increasingly interconnected and information-laden media have rendered both reality and beauty harder to grasp, and to live for, such stories play the vital function of sparking new kinds of musical creation -- the products of which, at their best, transcend their theoretical underpinnings as the best art always does. Filene has set himself the task of telling the stories' story. If he has failed to bring them into the present, no doubt that is because he too finds more comfort and inspiration in the past.

HEADLINE: COMING TO GRIPS WITH THE WEB: A FOUNDER;
An Archetypal Entrepreneur Says Mere Profits Are Not Enough

 BODY:
In a single day, Aug. 9, 1995, Marc Andreessen became the epitome of the Web entrepreneur: 20-something, technonerdy and, thanks to a successful initial public stock offering, suddenly worth $58 million.
A few years earlier, while a student at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Mr. Andreessen had been one of the developers of Mosaic, a free software program that was the first popular Web browser. With Jim Clark, the Silicon Valley entrepreneur, Mr. Andreessen subsequently founded Netscape Communications. Netscape created a commercial version of Mosaic --and started a phenomenon when the company's stock soared 92 percent on that first day of trading in August 1995, even though Netscape was profitless. 
 Suddenly, every young geek wanted to start a Web business and become the next Marc Andreessen.
Mr. Andreessen, now 29 and the co-founder and chairman of Loudcloud, a Web-development company, recently spoke with John Markoff of The Times about the Web, then and now.
 
Q. What's most in line with what you expected when you were developing the Web?
 
A. It was really hard to predict that there would be any uptake. The first release of Mosaic went to 12 people, literally. They then passed it on to 100 people each, and before long we had 100 and then 1,000 and then 10,000 users and then a million users and we were like, "Whoa!" When I started going to parties and people I'd never met started to say, "What about this Mosaic thing," then I knew something was happening.
 
Q. What's been the biggest surprise?
 
A. That ranks as the biggest surprise. And then the next biggest surprise was the opportunity to build a business, and then the biggest surprise after that was the boom that came in 1996, '97, '98. And then the growth of the companies like Amazon and eBay.
 
Q. What has Microsoft's impact on the Web been?
 
A. The conventional wisdom in Silicon Valley right now -- not shared by me -- is that Microsoft had an impact on the Internet in the mid-1990's but no longer does. Then there is another view among Microsoft boosters that says that they have an 80 to 90 percent browser share, and with all of their different initiatives and software development efforts they are going to be a major factor.
The truth is probably somewhere in the middle, although probably closer to the actual Microsoft point of view because they are still a very, very powerful company that has a tremendous amount of influence over software. And at the end of the day the Internet is still all about software.
 
Q. What can we learn from the e-commerce meltdown of the last couple months?
 
A. You've got to build a real business. A lot of people have it wrong right now. They say the key is you have to be profitable. It's actually not enough in modern business; you have to be hugely, insanely profitable to build a lasting business in the modern economy. The landscape is so competitive. Just think about what it would take to compete with Amazon.
 
Q. So far the Web has been a PC phenomenon. How quickly will cell phones and digital appliances replace the PC?
 
A. It's not clear it's an issue of displacement. The user experience is very different, and one thing people have always underestimated is the importance of the user experience. You have a different-size screen and a different kind of keyboard.
I think all of the attempts to graft a browser interface on top of a cell phone are going to fail. The key is you have to say, "O.K., what do people really want to do when they're mobile?" Probably some level of e-mail, probably some level of information access, like traffic reports. Maybe or maybe not e-commerce or what they're calling "mobile commerce."
 
Q. What might be the next big impact of the Web?
 
A. Most companies still have not integrated the Web into their fundamental operations. That's the biggest thing on the business side. The consumer phenomenon is extremely hard to predict. Nobody predicted eBay or Amazon in its modern form, nobody predicted instant messaging.

HEADLINE: COMING TO GRIPS WITH THE WEB: ESSAY;
Fast-Changing Genie Alters the World

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
At the outset, it was a free and simple map to the buried treasures of the information age.
Then it morphed into something else, fueling an astounding "new economy" gold rush that at its peak last year contributed several trillion dollars in new wealth to the nation's stock markets. (Lately, things have not panned out as well for the prospectors.) 
 In a remarkably short period, the World Wide Web has touched or has promised to alter -- some would say threaten -- virtually every aspect of modern life. The Web has caused giant corporations to adjust their business strategies, whether General Electric, General Motors or General Mills. And such are the abilities of the Web to "scale" -- whether up or down -- that it is also restoring craft and commerce in remote Cambodian villages. (Click on www.villageleap.com to view the current selection of woven scarves from the village of Robib in north central Cambodia. Major credit cards cheerfully accepted.)
The Web has been hailed as the most significant computing advance of the 20th century, and yet to see the Web as a single, static invention is to miss the point. Today's Web is not yesterday's, or tomorrow's.
Initially, the Web simply exploited the most powerful attribute of what was then a collection of computer networks called the Internet. That attribute, simply put, was the ability to share information globally and, when everything was working, instantaneously.
Recall that during this same period, in the early 1990's, companies like America Online and Prodigy were trying to keep computer users corralled within proprietary online services. Such services, which by that point had attracted only a few million users combined, were designed to make customers captive audiences of whatever "content" the network operators chose to provide. (It says as much about the adaptability of America Online's executives, as it does about evolving technology, that AOL has been able to turn itself into one of Web's most popular brand names.)
Compared with the old proprietary approach, the Web had a truly worldwide reach -- even if going overseas meant little more, at first, than checking the Webcam that was trained on a coffee pot in a Cambridge University computer lab.
The Web's strengths were precisely what many experts had long viewed as the Internet's weakness: the so-called "any to any" quality that treated all computers on the network as equals. Unlike the telephone network, in the words of David Eisenberg, the former Bell Labs researcher, the Internet was the ultimate "stupid" network, because all the intelligence and the power resided at the end points, not in the middle.
As with the Internet itself, the Web's roots lay in the late 1960's. Back then, Douglas Engelbart, a young engineer leading a small team of researchers at Stanford Research Institute, and Ted Nelson, a social scientist working solo, had independently come up with an idea that came to be called hypertext. With hypertext, information that allows the cross-referencing of digital documents is encoded right into the documents.
But it was not until 1990 that Tim Berners-Lee, a British programmer at the CERN physics research center in Geneva, developed hypertext markup language -- or HTML, the embedded referencing system that is encoded into each Web document. It was HTML, followed a few years later by easy-to-use Web browser software like Mosaic (and Mosaic's commercial offshoot, Netscape Navigator), that made today's Web feasible.
But feasibility also came in a confluence of related technologies that made computers usable by nontechnical people: mice pointing devices; graphical, or image-based, interfaces; widespread commercial access to the Internet; and perhaps most important, affordable personal computers with sufficient power to search for and display graphical information.
The Web turned the formerly text-based Internet into a multimedia system. And as technology continues to evolve, the Web is incorporating elements of all other media -- print publishing, telephones, music and even television and movies. (Of course, as anyone who has conducted an Internet phone conversation or downloaded a Web video can attest, the medium is not yet always as good as the message.)
Where does the Web go next?
As it moves beyond the PC onto hand-held devices, tablet computers and other so-called digital appliances, while spinning out a gossamer matrix of fiber optic cables and wireless antennas, the Web seems intent on living up to its World Wide name. Today, about half the nation's population has access to the Web via PC's. Within a few years, the Web could be accessible by half the global population, although in many cases the access will be through digital cell phones and other wireless devices.
Another watershed technology is also starting to redefine the Webscape. Until now, the Web has largely involved humans retrieving information from machines. But now comes a protocol known as XML, for Extensible Markup Language. XML organizes data so that computers can communicate directly without human intervention.
Within the next three years, XML is expected to be at the heart of the next-generation Web. And the cultural implications may be even more profound than with the first generation.
One possibility is the creation of vast automated global markets in which suppliers and manufacturers can let their computers find, buy and sell goods and services roboticly. Or genetic researchers looking for gene therapies could turn their computers loose to sift through one another's databases to identify and propose medically promising possibilities.
What are the consequences, if many routines of modern life can be conducted without human intervention?
Though the Web was initially hailed as a global digital library of Alexandria, it soon became apparent that the free flow of digital information had a darker side. The last seven years of the Web have brought new social challenges, including new threats to privacy and intellectual property law. Whether music, child pornography or hate speech, the flow of information across geographic, legal and cultural boundaries is now virtually unstoppable.
What will happen in technology's next generation, when Web machines routinely speak directly to other machines? A grand utopian transformation? Or is the world about to embark on the dark course described in Arthur C. Clarke's 1965 short story, "Dial F for Frankenstein"? The story details the first moments of a globally connected computer network, in which the network becomes a sentient being -- though one that behaves like a 2-year-old child.
In reality, the impact of the Web's next generation will probably resemble the current one, with changes taking root on the broad middle ground between human perfection and willful machine tantrums. The only certainty may be this: The world will not have time to comfortably contemplate the consequences, for the next chapter in Web's history is already hurtling forward, in Internet time.
