HEADLINE: New Economy;
Science fiction has long been the role model for the Internet world. But how does the reality fit in with the fantasy?

BYLINE: By John Schwartz 

 BODY:
CYBERSPACE didn't turn out quite as advertised.
Not that I'm complaining. I spend hours a day online, whether grabbing the news and mail, doing research, becoming involved in discussions, or simply wandering in the ether. But nothing I've encountered online has ever matched the experience the novelist William Gibson described in "Neuromancer," the first installment in an influential 1980's trilogy. "Neuromancer" gave countless readers their first vision of what might come to pass when they themselves could "jack in" to a worldwide network: 
 A gray disk, the color of Chiba sky.
Now --
Disk beginning to rotate, faster, becoming a sphere of paler gray. Expanding --
And flowed, flowered for him, fluid neon origami trick, the unfolding of his distanceless home, his country, transparent 3D chessboard extending to infinity. Inner eye opening to the stepped scarlet pyramid of the Eastern Seaboard Fission Authority burning beyond the green cubes of Mitsubishi Bank of America, and high and very far away he saw the spiral arms of military systems, forever beyond his reach.
This does not happen on a visit to Walmart.com.
But not for lack of trying on behalf of the technovisioneers, who labored to recreate the online experiences envisioned by authors like Mr. Gibson and Neal Stephenson -- and, incidentally, to become rich in the process. In the biggest collaborative act of creation since M. C. Escher drew a pair of hands drawing each other, the World Wide Web and the so-called new economy have looked to the literature of science fiction for a sense of direction and of style.
The cross-fertilization worked both ways. In an afterword to the edition of the "Neuromancer" trilogy produced on floppy disc by the Voyager Company in 1991, Mr. Gibson said his "direct inspiration" for the elegant little machines his characters use to reach cyberspace was a billboard advertising the sleek, portable Apple IIc computer.
"This seductive little unit, looking not that much bigger, really, than your present-day Powerbook, was depicted dangling from a handle in the hand of some unseen suit with a nicely laundered cuff," he wrote. "I didn't know that you had to lug the monitor around, as well, plus a bulky little transformer and another disk drive that weighed nearly as much as the computer itself."
The headlong rush toward a future of our own design was stirred with hyperactive fervor by publications like Wired magazine, which put the science fiction writer Bruce Sterling on its first-ever cover in March 1993, and Mr. Gibson a few months later.
"At Wired, we often talked about whether we were finding a revolution or making one," Kevin Kelly, a former executive editor of the magazine, said in an e-mail message. "We did both, of course."
"The acts of finding and creating are exactly identical," Mr. Kelly added. "There is no conceptual difference."
If this seems overstated, Mr. Kelly asks what's wrong with that. "I think hype gets a bum rap," he said. "Hype is the derogatory term for the good practice of imagining what we are creating, because unless we can imagine it we can not find it or make it."
"And the more the idea is rounded out by description and anticipation, the more it is believed and articulated, the more possible it becomes," he said. "This is why science fiction is now the theology of our times."
It's so seductive. We're not just fantasizing, or peddling hype: we're building the future -- leading the way! A problem with that kind of thinking is that dreams might not be the best models for things that have to survive the harsh light of day.
For a while there, the hypemongers of the World Wide Web were able to dangle, virtually, any idea and the venture capital moneymen would open their pockets. Take the company public and the day traders and home investors would claw at each other for a chance to give up their cash. From moment to moment, the buzzword would change. "We're a portal." "We're a community." "We're B2B." "B2C." Too seldom did anyone ask if the business made sense, or if it could ever make money.
At the height of the silliness last winter, a buddy of mine, Doug Levy, performed an impromptu experiment. Mr. Levy, a former newspaper reporter, was working as a manager for the online drugstore PlanetRX, and he was showing a Canadian friend around Silicon Valley. He took her to one of those parties that is all about networking -- young singles on the make, looking for love, for money or some mixture of the two.
At such events, people usually talk about their work. Doug didn't feel like talking about his company, which wasn't hiring at the time anyway. So he decided to invent a company. He recalls thinking that he would "make up something that was so ridiculous that people wouldn't want to talk to me."
In honor of his Canadian visitor, he told anyone who struck up a conversation with him that he was starting an Internet-based company that focused on hockey. He was developing a training system, he explained, in which the user would attach location sensors to his skates, which would transmit up-to-the-second information to a radio-equipped Palm VII handheld computer. The machine would then be able to give skating and hockey guidance, in real time.
Mr. Levy giggled just recalling the sheer idiocy of the idea: "What's the last thing somebody wants to do when learning to play hockey or learning to skate? Looking at the screen of a handheld!"
As the night progressed, however, he found that his little joke was being heard dead earnest. "I wound up having engineers following me around the room, handing me their business cards and saying they could write the Java script for my site," he said.
That was then. Now the Nasdaq composite is 42 percent below its high point set in March. And Mr. Levy's PlanetRX, like so many other Internet start-ups, seldom is referred to without the modifier "troubled." (He has left the company to become a consultant to technology companies.)
Even after the Nasdaq meltdown was well under way, the message that reality actually does matter hadn't quite sunk in. A few months later, Mr. Levy was sitting at another dull party and again amusing himself with talk of his hockey-training idea. He hoped it it might discourage a drunken techie from continuing to bend his ear.
Instead, the listener was soon lobbying for the position of chief technology officer of Mr. Levy's hockey company. "He thought he had it all figured out," Mr. Levy recalled. "He thought of other sports where the same technology could be used."
When Mr. Gibson, the novelist, imagined cyberspace, he called it a "consensual hallucination." Maybe things did turn out as advertised, after all.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1558 words

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Weak Retail And Dot-coms Take a Toll

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT and JIM RUTENBERG 

 BODY:
The last week brought a barrage of bad news from marketers and the media that some described as the gloomiest since the recession years of the early 1990's.
There were reports of sudden sharp slowdowns in the sales of mainstay products like personal computers, automobiles, appliances and apparel. Layoffs were announced by Knight Ridder. Hiring freezes were imposed by the News Corporation, parent of networks like Fox Broadcasting and Fox News Channel, and the NBC unit of General Electric, which also asked division heads to reconsider Christmas parties and even to cut back on newspaper subscriptions. 
 Consumer confidence in a closely watched index compiled by the University of Michigan skidded to its lowest level in more than two years. And Dow Jones & Company reduced its profit estimates for 2001 in the face of a decline in advertising lineage, as did the Tribune Company.
An advertising slowdown usually happens in slow motion, "but this time, it's like the market fell off a cliff," said Bill Cella, director for broadcast and programming at Universal McCann in New York, the media services unit of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising. "The fourth quarter has been virtually a dead quarter for ad spending." McCann is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group, owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies.
"We're at the precipice, looking a little scared," said Jon Mandel, co-managing director at MediaCom in New York, the media services agency owned by the Grey Global Group.
As bad as conditions appeared, they could look much worse in just a couple of weeks, if the early sluggishness in holiday shopping or the slump in sales of cars and trucks is not reversed.
So are the unusually prosperous times that advertisers, agencies and the media have enjoyed most recently coming to an abrupt end? The prevailing opinion, like the electorate on Nov. 7, is closely divided. For every top executive who says the sky is falling, it seems, there is another who perceives the deluge to be pennies from heaven.
"It's like the stock market," said Paul Rittenberg, senior vice president for ad sales at Fox News Channel in New York. "For the last five or six years, it's been double-digit increases every year, and all of the sudden it comes to a screeching halt."
Don Logan, chief executive at Time Inc. in New York, the giant magazine publishing division of Time Warner, agreed.
"We've had extraordinary increases for the last couple years," Mr. Logan said. "Some of it was fueled by the dot-coms, whose spending we hadn't seen before, and it showed up in television and print especially."
"Our rate of growth is slower in the fourth quarter than the year before," he added, because "many of those dot-coms are not here anymore."
The disappearance of an estimated $200 million in dot-com spending is a major reason for the extreme softness in fourth-quarter revenue for some media, like local television stations and the so-called scatter market, where advertisers buy time on broadcast TV networks soon before the commercials run. Indeed, there is widespread agreement among network executives and ad buyers that this is the slowest fourth-quarter scatter market since the Gulf War and recession days of 1991.
The dot-coms "spent like drunken monkeys trying to build their brands," said one television executive. "They were willing to pay any price. They were unsophisticated and in a hurry." The executive did not want to be identified for fear of alienating those companies if by some chance they ever get back on their feet and resume advertising.
"Dot-com money was like a fool's gold rush," said Gene DeWitt, chairman and chief executive at Optimedia US in New York, a media services agency that is part of the Optimedia division of the Publicis Groupe. "The fools may still be around, but the gold is gone."
Not only is the gold gone, but it vanished so quickly. Decisions to buy or not to buy -- and reversals of those decisions -- are now made at breakneck speed and at the last minute. So when demand is rising, there's a stampede to buy and prices can soar. Conversely, when demand is falling, there's a stampede away from buying and prices can plunge.
"When we're doing some buying, it's very affordable," Mr. Cella at Universal McCann said. "Where for years there had been 25, 30 percent increases, we haven't seen that at all."
"There's a bit of a correction," he added, that was inevitable after the euphoric, inflated markets of 1999 and early this year. That has clearly given buyers much greater leverage over sellers than has been the case recently, to the point where some agencies that bought commercial time at record rates in the "upfront," or advance, market for the 2000-2001 TV season may be thinking of trying to sweeten the terms of those deals.
One factor weakening the advertising outlook is a disparity in performance between some local and national media. For instance, according to Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at Universal McCann, spending for ads in local newspapers will increase 4.4 percent in 2000 from 1999 -- far less than the 13 percent increase for spending for ads in national newspapers. The reason Mr. Coen gave was continued sluggishness in ads from retailers.
For 2001, Mr. Coen predicted, ad spending in local newspapers will lag their national counterparts again, and for the same reason, with a 4 percent gain versus a 7 percent gain.
Another factor contributing to the weakness is that "there are no major events on the calendar" besides the Super Bowl to act "as engines to drive things forward," said Kevin Malloy, chief executive for international operations at the Starcom MediaVest Group in New York, a media services agency owned by the Bcom3 Group.
Dan Rank, head of national TV buying for the OMD USA division of Optimum Media Direction in New York, part of the Omnicom Group, estimated that the biggest media event of 2000, the Summer Olympics, "sucked a couple of hundred million dollars in incremental money" into the third quarter, weakening the fourth quarter.
Add that missing money to the absent dot-com dollars and spending cutbacks by consumer-product advertisers whose business has suddenly softened "and six hundred, seven hundred, eight hundred million dollars is gone," Mr. Rank estimated, "and that's all it takes" to cool a feverish market down to frigid.
"Is advertising spending being cut on a wholesale basis?" he asked rhetorically. "No. Is it being cut 5 or 6 percent? Yes. And in our business, 5 or 6 percent means the difference between a great year and a not-so-great year."
The question now is, how long does the slowdown last? And will it accelerate into a downward spiral?
"It's a softening, but it's not a crashing," said Jack Kliger, president and chief executive at Hachette Filipacchi Magazines in New York, part of the Lagardere Group, which owns publications like Elle, Premiere and Woman's Day. "We don't think we're in a recession or heading into one."
"How many years have we been running pretty hot, five, six?" he asked. "There's a certain digestion now. Our outlook for next year is for growth in the low-to-mid single digits, versus a revenue gain for 2000 of from 8 to 10 percent."
Mr. Kliger has expansion plans for 2001 that include the introduction of Elle Girl, aimed at teenage readers, and adding more editorial pages to the movie magazine Premiere.
"A good idea is a good idea not only in the best of times," he said. "There is certainly no recession among teens, and entertainment does well in many economies."
The new year will get off to a strong start at CBS, owned by Viacom, which is carrying Super Bowl XXXV and introducing a sequel to the summer hit "Survivor."
"For the first quarter, the jury is still out right now, but it looks strong," said Joseph Abruzzese, president for network sales at CBS in New York.
Mr. Malloy at Starcom MediaVest said: "I don't think the sky is falling. What we're seeing is a flattening of advertisers' budgets, or maybe slight increases."
One big advertiser, the Ford division of the Ford Motor Company, is budgeting a "fairly flat" figure for 2001 compared with 2000, said Julie Roehm, car marketing communications manager in Dearborn, Mich., "but we haven't cut back."
Rather, "we have gotten better at how we spend," she added, citing an elaborate campaign with a fashion theme for the Ford Focus line that will run in Hachette Filipacchi magazines, as well as other campaigns that combine spending in print, television and Internet media. Ford does not disclose spending data, but the 2000 budget to advertise Ford division products is about $750 million.
Automotive advertising, the largest category for all media, "is kind of a mixed bag" for 2001 at Time Inc., Mr. Logan said. "Imports continue to be strong; with Detroit, we expect to have a decent year."
Over all, "we expect '01 will be a pretty good year," he added, after the media get through the fourth quarter and the problems caused by "many companies trying to shore up earnings" through spending cuts.
As a sign of that cautiously optimistic outlook, Time Inc., unlike other media companies, is not asking that holiday parties be canceled.
"As a matter of fact, I'm going to all of them," Mr. Logan said, laughing, "all of them that I can."

HEADLINE: Johnson City Journal;
In Winter, Hill Country Texans Live by Their Watts

BYLINE: By ROSS E. MILLOY 

DATELINE: JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Dec. 8

 BODY:
Back in 1990, Norma Honeycutt realized that this quiet ranching community of about 900 people, named for an uncle of President Lyndon B. Johnson, was dying a slow economic death.
"The cattle business had just about dried up," Mrs. Honeycutt recalled recently. "There was only one grocery store left, all the storefronts downtown had been abandoned, and our kids were moving away to take jobs in the bigger cities." 
 Even the town's usually reliable source of tourist revenue, President Johnson's boyhood home, was languishing, a victim of dreary winter weather and fading memories of the 36th president.
"The whole place was drab and humdrum and even the people who lived in Johnson City didn't want to be here in wintertime," said Mrs. Honeycutt, a retired insurance executive.
But that was before Mrs. Honeycutt, now 64, used money raised from bake sales to dress up the Blanco County Courthouse here with Christmas lights -- thousands of Christmas lights -- and thus began a movement that has become a major winter tourist attraction in Central Texas.
"The scariest time was that first night, when we had a big crowd gathered around the courthouse to turn the lights on all at once. We kept saying, 'Let there be light, let there be light,' and nothing happened," she recalled recently. "It turned out that the old electrician manning the light switch was deaf and couldn't hear us."
Eventually, the lights came on, and what Mrs. Honeycutt began that evening in 1990 has grown in the intervening decade into the Texas Hill Country Regional Lighting Trail. The trail is a chain of 12 small cities, strung out over 150 miles of rolling hills in Central Texas, that set their main streets ablaze with millions of sparkling lights each year between Thanksgiving and New Year's Eve.
The Lighting Trail attracts thousands of visitors each year, drawn not just by the lights but by a series of related events, including arts and crafts shows, parades of Christmas-lighted horses and wagons and seasonal ethnic festivals capitalizing on the cultural history of the area, Mrs. Honeycutt said.
"Every one of our storefronts is occupied nowadays, and a lot of the business people tell me they couldn't make it through the winter without the tourists coming to see all the lights," she said, adding modestly, "Of course, just calling them 'lights' doesn't really capture what we do out here."
From tiny Bulverde in the south, near San Antonio, to even tinier Goldthwaite in the north, the town squares and area homes are alight with every imaginable kind of Christmas display: glowing candy canes and snowflakes are mounted on power poles along the streets; winged angels soar over leaping reindeer in brilliantly lighted trees; wagons with Santas wearing cowboy hats are drawn skyward by horses; carousels, windmills, snowmen, toy soldiers and, of course, many versions of three wise men are all formed by dazzling arrays of multicolored lights in a hundred different settings.
Many displays mingle Christmas traditions with Western themes or the towns' cultural heritage. At a Weihnachten celebration last week in nearby Fredericksburg, 52 trees in the Marketplatz were decorated as they might have been by the town's founding German ancestors, and 400 people participated in a traditional candlelight prayer parade among a half-dozen of the town's churches. At the Bethany Lutheran Church, a live Nativity scene featured Sunday school students playing the Holy Family. (The scene was not overly solemn. At one point, the children, barely suppressing giggles as an adult urged them to remain motionless, turned a tinsel wreath into a flying Frisbee, and the Virgin Mary very nearly was hit in the head.)
There are now more than a million Christmas lights in Johnson City alone, said Nick Nelson, who gives guided carriage rides through town during the season. He explained the spirit behind the displays by pointing to a chain of lights on the courthouse lawn that spelled out "Hill Country Style."
"That means do it up big, do it up right, and that's just what we do," Mr. Nelson said. "A lot of people come out here and can't believe that a little town like this can put on such an amazing show."
Ray and June Heim, who traveled nearly 500 miles from near Lubbock with a family friend, Wanda Miller, just to see the lights, said the visit was an annual tradition.
"We just love to see all the small towns lit up, and we love to eat the German food over in Fredericksburg," Mrs. Heim said.
Though Mrs. Honeycutt is less active in the lighting project these days, her brainchild has expanded to include the Hill Country communities of Blanco, Burnet, Canyon Lake, Dripping Springs, Llano, Mason, Marble Falls and Round Mountain.
"There's just too much to see in one night, so we recommend that people take two or three days to see all 12 cities," said Deborah Farquhar-Garner, who now directs the Lighting Trail's activities from its headquarters in Fredericksburg.
Mrs. Farquhar-Garner estimates that hundreds of thousands of visitors have seen the lights in the last decade, but she said no one knows exactly how many, nor their exact financial impact on the Hill Country.
"We don't even know for sure how many lights are involved," she said, "but we think it's somewhere over seven million. We just know we're getting an awful lot of people spending an awful lot of money, and it's been great."

HEADLINE: CONTESTING THE VOTE: THE BIG NEWS;
Floridians at Last Have a Vote to Cheer

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 10

 BODY:
All day Saturday and into that evening, people here waited hopefully for a decision, an outcome. They sat in front of television sets and watched experts analyze the contest and theorize on first one candidate, then another. Others gathered in bars, restaurants and just on sidewalks, talking in small groups, hoping, some even praying.
It was not just the big story, it was the only story. 
 Would a winner ever be named, in what had become one of the closest contests in history?
It seemed, to them, to take forever.
Then, on Saturday evening, the question on so many minds was finally answered. The candidate who had won the hearts and souls of most people here had the votes he needed.
It was over.
"I was shocked," Chris Weinke, quarterback for the Florida State University Seminoles, told reporters after winning the Heisman Trophy.
That other thing, the recount mess, might not be over -- and may never be over, it seems to many people -- but that story was overwhelmed here in the Florida Panhandle. Tallahassee, after all, is home to both the Florida Supreme Court and Florida State University.
Many, many beers were emptied. Many, many war cries rang through the night. Many, many people, rescue workers said, were still drunk when the sun came up.
The presidential election could wait, and would wait, anyway. Waiting is what it has been about. The United States Supreme Court on Saturday halted the recount ordered by the Florida Supreme Court, so Tallahassee, as reporters said, was no longer the story, anyway.
In Tallahassee, where the Seminoles are heading toward what many here hope will be another national college football championship, Mr. Weinke, a senior quarterback, had won the nation's highest individual football award. As in the presidential race, it was close. He edged Josh Heupel, the quarterback at Oklahoma, 1,628 votes to 1,552.
"I voted for Bush, but every vote should be counted," said Travis Oaks, 40, at Tallahassee's Central Fire Station. He could live with the winner, no matter who it was.
So, he was asked, if Mr. Weinke had been edged out by Mr. Heupel or some other candidate, would he be satisfied with that outcome, too? "No," he said immediately. "That's two different things, presidential politics and football. In football, it's win at all costs."
Some people had doubted that Mr. Weinke would win the Heisman because of his age. He is old for a college athlete at 28, after delaying his college football career to play minor league baseball.
The top story in The Tallahassee Democrat, the day after a dizzying, history-making day in that other big contest, carried a dignified banner headline:
"Weinke credits Heisman win to experience."
Beneath that, was this:
"Court cuts short recount."
That, said many people here, was how it should have been.
"It the biggest story in this city," said T. J. Almond, a student at Florida State who is majoring in applied economics.
At the Tallahassee Central Fire Station, firefighters said it was just more fun to talk about one race -- the Heisman contest -- than the other.
"Football here is big time," said Mr. Oaks. "The big story here would be if we did not have a quarterback or running back in the Heisman race."
The Heisman competition would have taken precedence anyway, he said, but the on-and-on presidential race has worn people down and numbed their interest.
People here found comfort in the Heisman victory for another reason, Mr. Oaks said. For weeks, Floridians have seen their state ridiculed around the country, and seen it become the focus of late-night television sarcasm and comedy.
"I hate to see Florida look like a bunch of idiots," Mr. Oaks said. If some other state had been the deciding one in this election, its elections process, too, would have shown itself to be imperfect, he said.
Football games have a final whistle, and almost always there is a winner and a loser.
Kyle Henson, 11, of Land O' Lakes, Fla., said there had been a little talk in his school about the election, "but all the people are talking about the Heisman."
When the presidential election is over, Mr. Weinke will still have an advantage over the president-elect, joked Ed Rosenberg, the manager at A. J.'s sports bar.
"His election," Mr. Rosenberg said, "is more credible."

LENGTH: 1283 words

HEADLINE: In a Charitable Mood? Just Pick, Then Click

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
The Hunger Site, the Internet's first click-to-donate venture, was an instant hit -- a no-charge way to help save lives.
It was so simple: Go to the computer, sign on to TheHungerSite.com, click the "Donate Free Food" button, and, with each click, every business advertising on the site would donate a half-cent to the United Nations World Food Program, enough to buy a quarter-cup of grain for the world's poorest people. 
 Web surfers leaped at the chance to contribute to a cause -- with someone else's money. Last December, when the Hunger Site had been up about six months, it was getting more than eight million clicks a month, generating about $40,000 for the food program from each of that month's dozen business sponsors for a total of $480,000.
Everyone was happy: The United Nations food program got new income, and new interest in its work. Sponsors got a thousand pairs of eyes on their advertisements for every $50 they paid, and a bolstered reputation for social responsibility. And the site's visitors had the pleasure of helping the poor.
"I go to the Hunger Site just about every day," said Kris Berggren, a freelance writer in Minneapolis. "How can you pass it up? It's so easy, it helps kids, and it doesn't cost me anything."
But these days, the Hunger Site has hit rocky times. In November, the United Nations World Food Program suddenly ended its participation, concerned about the finances of the organization that now runs the Hunger Site and troubled that the donations were being passed on more slowly. Though the Hunger Site now supports two other food programs, it has fewer visitors and fewer sponsors, in part because of the new competition it spawned.
A galaxy of click-and-donate sites has sprung up in recent months, modeled on the Hunger Site. One site pays for mammograms for poor women. On one site, each click gets 15 seconds of care for a child with AIDS, and on another site each click buys a vitamin A capsule to be distributed by Unicef.
The range, the specificity and the gimmicks are all stunning:
*The Environmental News Network has a click-to-donate index, www.enn.com/interact/freedonate .asp, listing dozens of sites offering free donations to plant trees, save bats, help orphans, cure Parkinson's disease, shelter the homeless and more.
*Ecologyfund.com lets those interested in saving open land choose where their money should go. Click on the parrot, and Mexico's largest conservation group gets a donation that will pay for 16.5 square feet of Sierra Madre forest. Click on the bear, and the Nature Conservancy of Canada gets money to conserve 0.8 square feet of Canadian wild land. Or click on all seven pictures, and pay for the preservation of 283 square feet around the world. Do it every day for a year, the site advises, and preserve a whole acre, free.
*Stargiving.com combines the American passions for celebrities, contests and charity. Visitors can click for a free donation (paid for, that is, by a corporate sponsor) to a star's favorite cause and then register for a chance to meet that celebrity. Every click on Magic Johnson, for example, generates a contribution to the Magic Johnson Foundation, and one wins dinner and a Lakers game with the former basketball star.
Just how much these sites will produce for charity -- or for the for-profit companies that run them -- remains an open question. While the United Nations Food Program got more than $3 million from the Hunger Site in 18 months, no other site has produced anywhere near that kind of money. And most of the sites are run by start-up companies struggling to break even.
Still, most beneficiaries love the click-to-donate sites, as much for consciousness-raising as for any income they produce.
"As a fund-raiser, I love it because it gets our name out there, heightens awareness of our work and doesn't cost us anything," said Sheri-Lynn Armstrong, development director of the Nature Conservancy of Canada, the beneficiary of an EcologyFund.com site.
The Hunger Site was the brainchild of John Breen, a computer programmer from Bloomington, Ind., who created a site showing a map of the world, with one country darkening every 3.6 seconds to represent a death from hunger. The sponsors agreed to pay the United Nations food program for each click on the "Donate Free Food" button; only one click a day by each visitor would be counted. But as the number of visitors skyrocketed, the time and costs involved in running the site rose, too, and by late last year, Mr. Breen was overwhelmed. In February, he sold the site for an undisclosed price to GreaterGood, a Seattle-based online shopping mall that gave part of its sales to charity.
Since then, the site has become more obviously commercial, offering extra donations if visitors buy holiday wreaths or Hunger Site hats, or click the link to Amazon.com and make a first-time purchase there.
GreaterGood, which has created five more click-to-donate sites since buying the Hunger Site, takes a 25 percent cut of the donations to cover its costs, and has recently been having cash-flow problems.
While the Hunger Site still draws far more traffic than the other sites, it has suffered since GreaterGood took over. Early in November, the company decided that the United Nations food program should not be the only beneficiary, and added two other food programs, Second Harvest and Mercy Corps. On Nov. 23, the United Nations food program ended its relationship with the Hunger Site, announcing that it had received only $200,000 of the $371,675 the site raised between June and September.
GreaterGood wired the additional $171,675 to the United Nations food program on Dec. 6, but Abby Spring, the food program's spokeswoman, said the relationship would not resume.
"When John Breen started the Hunger Site, the agreement was that when someone clicked, the sponsor would send the money directly to the food program," Ms. Spring said. "After the GreaterGood became the intermediary, we felt the money was coming in too slowly. We're deeply grateful that the Hunger Site created more awareness of our work, and gave us $3 million, but as a matter of integrity, and for the future of this kind of site, we thought it was important to let the public know that the money wasn't coming as quickly as it was supposed to."
GreaterGood was surprised by the food program's action. "We were only 20 days late on that payment," said Lynn Ridenour, the marketing director. "And we had been warning them since September that we were expecting a shortfall because of cash flow problems and sponsors who were slow in paying what they owed."
Despite its troubles with the Hunger Site, Ms. Ridenour said GreaterGood was committed to click-to-donate sites.
"We started the breast cancer site and the kids with AIDS site in September, our land-mine site just went up Nov. 30, and based on e-mails from visitors to our sites, we're going to be starting an animal-rights site," Ms. Ridenour said. "It's a promising field, even though the economics are very different from a year ago. Sponsors are not so willing to pay a flat fee for the eyeballs anymore. Instead, they want to pay on the basis of the further actions the visitors to the site take, like buying something."
Operators of the other click-to-donate sites face the same problem.
"We're all trying to develop new revenue streams, to get ourself into a break-even position," said Greg Hesterberg, a founder of EcologyFund .com, one of the click-and-donate sites that passes on 100 percent of the donations it generates. "The whole economics of the Internet are changing so fast it's hard to know where this will go."

HEADLINE: Gene-Altered Corn Changes Dynamics Of Grain Industry

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa

 BODY:
At the Archer Daniels Midland Company's plant these days, the arriving truckloads of No. 2 yellow corn all need to pass the same test: they are checked for odor, damage, moisture, and something called Cry9C.
A seven-member crew divides, sifts, weighs, grinds and even sniffs the corn samples -- a practice that grew more complicated a few weeks ago, after Kraft Foods recalled millions of taco shells possibly containing StarLink, a genetically engineered variety of corn that produces the Cry9C protein. The corn is not supposed to be in the human food supply because of concerns it might trigger allergic reactions. 
 Now, after a series of recalls, nearly every major food and agriculture company is frantically testing for Cry9C. The result has been a costly disruption to the nation's grain-handling system. Scores of trucks, rail cars and river barges are being turned away daily by inspectors who say that a splotch of red dye has turned up on what looks like a home pregnancy test, meaning their corn is not fit for food.
"It's a logistical nightmare," said Steven Phillips, the grain merchandiser at East Central Iowa Co-op in Hudson, a supplier to the plant here. "We had 15 truckloads of corn rejected last week."
The costs for the corn's developer, Aventis CropScience, are huge. It has promised to find markets for this year's StarLink crop and to compensate farmers, elevator operators like Mr. Phillips and processors for some of their expenses. Aventis received less than a million dollars in licensing fees over the last three years on StarLink, but the controversy could cost the company several hundred million dollars to resolve.
The StarLink episode has also raised the decibel level in an already high-pitched debate over the agricultural use of biotechnology. Though most farmers seem to favor biotech crops, saying they deliver higher yields or cut down on chemical spraying, many here in Iowa say they are growing wary.
Grain processors are warning farmers about next year's harvest, with Archer Daniels running radio commercials emphasizing that its plants will not accept genetically altered crops that do not have worldwide approval. And some farmers are questioning whether to plant even varieties that have been approved for human consumption
"I don't know what I'm going to do," said Chris Huegerich, a farmer in Breda, Iowa, who grows Roundup Ready soybeans, a bioengineered variety that can be exported worldwide. "I want to do Roundup Ready beans but I'm worried something might happen. You just don't know."
Planting of StarLink, in any case, is moot; Aventis has already withdrawn its license for further sale. And no actual health hazards have been established from StarLink or any other bioengineered crops on the market. But some agricultural experts say they are worried that the StarLink case is simply a harbinger of more troubles to come.
Among other things, they say, the Cry9C mess shows how complicated the logistics of biotechnology can be for a grain-handling system that typically ships undifferentiated crops in bulk.
"We're not cut out to segregate," says Gary Alberts, a spokesman for the Iowa Institute of Cooperatives, a trade association for elevators. "We handle a lot of grain in a hurry. We're built to load a rail car in a day."
Yet now that farmers can choose between traditional and biotech seeds, new sorting, segregating and distribution needs are arising that may radically alter the dynamics of a grain-handling system built on economies of scale.
In the United States, a few big food makers have said they will seek conventional crops because of consumer concerns, but for the most part they have contracted directly with farmers to grow, say, nonbiotech corn for Frito-Lay chips. So there has been relatively little need for testing or segregation in the general grain supply.
But with increasing skepticism among consumers in Europe and Japan about bioengineered food, and in some cases new requirements for labeling, the need to separate bioengineered and conventional crops has grown. And so there may be more scenes like the roadblocks set up to stop any StarLink corn from getting into processing plants.
On a chilly morning in Cedar Rapids, a steady stream of semis was pulling up under a canopy at the inspection site to have their loads tested before entering the Archer Daniels corn processing plant, where raw corn is turned into high-fructose corn syrup, corn starch and other products.
Inspections have always taken place at processing plants, to check the quality, moisture and weight of crops, but these days two additional men are sitting by a coffee grinder, grounding up corn samples, shaking them up in water, dipping tiny strips into the solution and then waiting 10 minutes for the results.
By 9:45 a.m., the inspectors had rejected 9 trucks out of 213, each filled with about 950 bushels of corn. The number of trucks turned away is striking, since less than 0.5 percent of this year's corn acreage nationwide was planted with StarLink seed. The elevators that shipped the corn are then stuck with it until they can find an alternative buyer for another use.
The inspections have clearly slowed the process of shipping corn to market, and some farmers and truckers complain that the tests being used, intended to detect Cry9C in one kernel of corn out of 400, are flawed.
"It's all in the probing," said one trucker, who asked not to be identified. "You have 10 samples that test positive and then one that doesn't. It's all the luck of the samples."
Farmers and truckers say their loads could be rejected over the presence of just one StarLink kernel in a batch of grain sampled from the 950 bushels. And while the truckers, and farmers, have been promised compensation, they say the difficulty of finding new buyers, and possibly losing out in some markets, has been troubling.
To ease the situation, Aventis has asked the Environmental Protection Agency to approve StarLink for human consumption for four years, to allow the StarLink corn already harvested to work its way through the food chain. In the meantime, several processors are asking the E.P.A. and food companies to make a tiny percentage of Cry9C acceptable in food, as they do with many other impurities.
"When the handler makes the decision, they have to have realistic expectations," said an Agriculture Department official. "When they have zero tolerance, it's impractical."
Farmers may be the hardest hit by all the testing. Even some who knew nothing about StarLink say it has turned up in their harvest.
"I didn't grow any StarLink corn, but I got contaminated by a neighbor," said Keith Weller, 50, who farms near Westside, Iowa. "This issue of contamination is a real problem."
Some farmers who planted StarLink say they were not told about 660-foot buffer zones mandated by the E.P.A. between StarLink corn and corn grown for food, and they say pollen may have drifted even longer distances, leading to cross-pollination with a neighbor's crop.
Randy Kohorst, a 43-year-old corn and soybean farmer in Arcadia, Iowa, says he planted 200 acres of StarLink. But he says he was told nothing by the Garst Seed Company of Slater, Iowa, which sold him the seed, about buffer zones or marketing restrictions.
"We had it harvested before we heard it was a problem," he said. "And it was commingled, so now all my production is contaminated."
Now he is stuck with a StarLink crop and complaining about lost marketing opportunities.
A spokesman at Garst said that the company was informing farmers about the requirements placed on use of StarLink corn. "It's unfortunate some customers say they weren't informed about the program," said Jeff Lacina, the spokesman. "But we worked hard to get that message out."
And corn prices -- already in a slump -- may decline further this year because exports to Japan, the largest purchaser of American corn, are down because of concerns about StarLink, which has also been found in food there.
Mr. Kohorst and other farmers say the problem may be costing them more than the 25-cent premium Aventis is offering for the StarLink crop.
Elevator operators, who buy crops from farmers and then ship them to giant processors or feed lots, are also facing inconvenience, despite receiving extra transportation expenses from Aventis.
For Aventis, containing the spread of StarLink is not easy. The company says it has accounted for 90 percent of the 350,000 acres planted in 2000, but it admits that the 1998 and 1999 harvests are either buried on farms and elevators (in an undocumented fashion) or have already reached the market and entered the food stream.
To help deal with the problem, the company has supplied Cry9C test kits to grain elevators and processors around the country. It also says it will help farmers who did not plant StarLink but whose crops were contaminated by cross-pollination to find a market for their corn, and will consider additional compensation in some cases.
The bigger cost, though, could be borne by the biotech industry, which has spent billions of dollars over the last decade to develop genetically altered crops that mean higher yields for farmers and may some day deliver medicines and vaccines as well.
That effort, of course, could be upset if farmers decide not to plant biotech crops like Roundup Ready soybeans and corn, which are bioengineered to resist a common Monsanto herbicide called Roundup. Though the soybeans can be sold everywhere, the corn is unapproved in Europe.
"StarLink has definitely set back the biotech industry, maybe five years," said Lewis W. Batchelder, a senior vice president at Archer Daniels, which is based in Decatur, Ill.
Regardless of what farmers decide to plant, Jim Magnuson, general manager at the Sully Cooperative Exchange, an elevator in Sully, Iowa, says farmers need to pay more attention next year.
"For a producer, the lesson is to know exactly what you're planting," he said. "We as an industry have operated on the handshake. But what we know now is that in a big, bad world, those assurances no longer apply."

HEADLINE: Former Chief Of Romania Retakes Office Over Rightist

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania, Dec. 10

 BODY:
In what experts called a showing of political maturity, Romanians today gave former President Ion Iliescu another term in office, rejecting an ultranationalist by a large margin.
Exit polls indicated that Mr. Iliescu had won 70 percent of the vote in his runoff against Corneliu Vadim Tudor, who had run on a promise that he would "liquidate the mafia" that has drained the economy but is infamous for his magazines' screeds against Jews, Hungarians and Gypsies. The final vote will not be known for a day or two, but recent exit polls have been accurate here. 
 Minutes after the polls closed, an angry Mr. Tudor charged that the vote was "the biggest fraud in the history of Romania" and claimed that pollsters had been paid $150,000 to invent data, bribe election monitors and sabotage vote-tallying computers.
"How can Mr. Iliescu have won the whole pot?" he demanded, wondering if the likely winning party and election officials "really think we are so stupid?" He said he would complain to an international human rights court and called the results "a victory of the Antichrist."
Television commentators refused even to discuss his charges. Emil Hurezeanu, who covers Romania for German radio, called the statement "delirium and self-parody"; and Cornel Nistorescu, editor of Evenimentul Zilei, a national daily, said: "We have more important things to discuss tonight."
When he voted at noon today, Mr. Tudor made an impromptu speech that accused his opponents of "crucifying" him and conducting a "lynching campaign." He said he was the victim of "a huge electoral fraud perpetrated by a former K.G.B. agent" -- Mr. Iliescu -- who is also "an atheist free-thinker with the blood of the people on his hands" as well as a tool of Moscow "since it lost Yugoslavia and now wants to get to the Balkans through Romania.
"Inside every child born is another Vadim Tudor, who will know what to do to protect this country," Mr. Tudor added. He said repeatedly that he is not a vengeful man and, borrowing Jesus' dying words, added: "Forgive them, God, for they know not what they do."
Mr. Iliescu said later that Mr. Tudor's failure to concede and his claims "show him for what he is: not qualified to be president or even a politician."
Mr. Iliescu's own victory speech, delivered seconds after the polls closed at 9 p.m., was a promise "to reform a suffocated economy in order to fight poverty, starvation and misery," to pursue integration with the European Union, membership in NATO and a partnership with the United States; to enforce laws against "those who have stolen our national property" and to pursue "dialogue, tolerance and cooperation."
During Mr. Iliescu's last presidency, from 1990 to 1996, he was seen as at heart a socialist who could not bring himself to close dying factories or shrink a bloated bureaucracy. Asked tonight if he had become a convert to Western-style market economics, he answered: "Life forces us to change. Those who don't are eliminated."
Despite intense interest in the race outside Romania, turnout appeared to be even lower than for the first round of voting two weeks ago, when it was less than 60 percent.
Exit polls suggested that Mr. Iliescu had picked up most of the votes for the four centrists and a moderate ethnic Hungarian candidate, who were eliminated in the first round. Many young voters, who heavily backed Mr. Tudor in the first round, apparently came over to Mr. Iliescu's side. One poll suggested that 15 percent of voters who picked Mr. Tudor the first time switched to Mr. Iliescu, while only 4 percent switched the other way.
Neither side conducted a get-out-the-vote campaign, as is routine in American elections.
Ilie Neacsu, secretary of Mr. Tudor's Greater Romania Party, said the idea was not even discussed because it "would be taken as electoral campaigning, or as propaganda." Under Romanian law, campaigning is illegal in the last 48 hours before an election.
Lucia Ceuca, a spokeswoman for Mr. Iliescu's Party of Social Democracy, said there was no voter-turnout plan, but mayors from her party were authorized to prod people to vote if turnout seemed low. In the 1996 election, she said, the party tried something like a get-out-the-vote effort. It hired political science students, some of them educated in the United States, to telephone voters, "but we received negative publicity -- people said these were poisoned phone calls."
This year, confident of victory, they did not repeat the effort.
Political experts repeated their frustration that the center-right coalition that may have begun an economic turnaround last year had been unable to pick a single candidate and had knocked itself out of running in the first round, allowing an extremist to get close to the presidency.
Dorel Sandor, a political analyst, said that the world had seen "a rational vote in the second round" and that the new government "can rely on that maturity."

HEADLINE: CONTESTING THE VOTE: THE TEXAS GOVERNOR;
BUSH'S AIDES SAY AN END IS IN SIGHT

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 10

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush returned here this afternoon from his ranch, with his advisers saying they were now increasingly optimistic that the Supreme Court would effectively end the presidential race in his favor, perhaps within the next 36 hours.
In public, Mr. Bush's army of lawyers, advisers and aides, led by former Secretary of State James A. Baker III, were careful not to assert that victory would be theirs after the Supreme Court heard arguments on Monday morning. In television talk show appearances today, Mr. Baker said "it absolutely is not a foregone conclusion" that Mr. Bush would prevail. 
 But should the court decide in Mr. Bush's favor, the campaign already has a plan for assuming power. After waiting for what one adviser said would be a "decent but short interval" for a concession speech by Vice President Al Gore, Mr. Bush would appear on national television, probably before an audience of supporters, and deliver a speech laden with talk of reunifying the country. Drafts of the text are already changing hands among top aides here, in Florida and in Washington.
"Everyone's feeling reasonably good," Gov. John Engler of Michigan, one of Mr. Bush's strongest supporters, said in a telephone interview this afternoon. "Monday is a day when we could finally have this incredible election ended."
Mr. Engler dismissed any suggestion that Mr. Bush's authority would be undercut if he took office through a judicial ruling that permanently halted the hand recount.
"People will move on," he said. "I don't think this will linger."
While some Bush staff members flew to Washington today for the Monday arguments, most stayed in Florida, just in case. "We're not turning off the coffee machine here," one of Mr. Bush's top aides said from Tallahassee, noting that the Republican nominee was keeping a large number of staff members on hand in case they needed, once again, to monitor ballot recounts in more than 50 counties.
"But I don't have much doubt about the eventual outcome," the aide said. "Now the only question is the interim outcome."
The Bush camp's fear, the aide said, was that Justice Anthony M. Kennedy or Justice Sandra Day O'Connor would defect from the conservative alliance that granted the stay on Saturday afternoon. "They're wild cards," the aide said.
From the start, Mr. Baker's preferred method of winning the presidency for Mr. Bush has been clear: a definitive ruling from the United States Supreme Court that would prevent a hand recount and with it, the risk that Mr. Gore could suddenly take the lead. That would make it unnecessary for the Florida Legislature to name an alternative slate of electors, a route to the Oval Office that Mr. Baker fears could undercut Mr. Bush's claims to legitimacy.
While some Bush advisers believe they could win a recount, it is a road Mr. Baker said again today he did not want to travel.
Tucker Eskew, a top Bush adviser, said, "We view any recounts as attempts to manufacture votes, so we take no pleasure from any kind of recount at all."
While Mr. Baker and other members of the legal team prepared for Monday's oral arguments, here in Austin aides were once again mapping out a strategy for Mr. Bush if victory came in the next few days.
Celebrations, they have determined, will be muted, nothing like the victory party that started in front of the Texas Capitol on election night. Then, within a day or two, Mr. Bush would conduct, in rapid succession, a series of announcements of top White House aides and cabinet officials.
Andrew H. Card Jr., a Bush family loyalist and former automobile industry lobbyist, would become the chief of staff; he is already operating out of a corner office of the Bush campaign headquarters here. Gen. Colin L. Powell would almost certainly be named secretary of state, and Condoleezza Rice the national security adviser. Two other important posts, defense and treasury, are undecided.
There is particular concern among some of Mr. Bush's allies in the financial world that the three names floated for the treasury post, all current or former Wall Street executives, have not generated much excitement, and some fear that none of them have the experience managing the kind of foreign economic crises that punctuated the Clinton years.
"This needs to be thought through again," said one informal economic adviser to Mr. Bush. Other aides are cautious about discussing cabinet choices before Mr. Bush has sealed an election he has often thought was about to end.
Mr. Baker, somewhat testily, spent much of the day answering queries about whether a candidate installed by a 5-to-4 Supreme Court decision could assume all the moral authority a president needs. "I think all this talk about legitimacy is way overblown," Mr. Baker said on ABC's "This Week." Some Democrats acknowledged that they were raising the question of legitimacy to bolster their own argument that the only way the next president will be fully accepted by the country is to continue the recount.
Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, a Republican ally of Mr. Bush's who was considered for his running mate, took strong exception to those arguments today.
"Look," Mr. Ridge said in an interview, "if it's 5-4 or more in the Supreme Court, it's over. The vice president has to take the pegs out of the tent, fold it, and go home. For a while you heard Republicans saying they wanted a unanimous decision from the court. But if Democrats can get so excited by a 4-to-3 victory in Florida, we can be just as happy with 5-4 in the Supreme Court."
"What goes around," he concluded, "comes around."

HEADLINE: For Deliveryman, Hard Work, Small Tips and Vindication

BYLINE: By SUSAN SAULNY 

 BODY:
The sparkling glass doors of an Upper West Side high-rise open before him, courtesy of an eager top-hatted doorman, and Marcel Mweze makes his way through the gilded lobby to an elevator, where, as he has so many times before, he pushes the button for Penthouse A.
The lavish surroundings could easily have the familiar feel of home for someone like Mr. Mweze, who is fluent in three languages and has a degree in business. 
 But Mr. Mweze does not live in Penthouse A. He is there to deliver groceries from the Food Emporium, one of several grocery chains in the city that use deliverers -- many of them, like Mr. Mweze, immigrants from Africa -- to shuttle groceries around neighborhoods where people are either unable or unwilling to lug their own bags. Customers pay Food Emporium $3.95 for the service. The $3.95 goes to the store, not the delivery person.
Last week the chain agreed to pay its 110 deliverers a total of $3 million in back wages to settle a lawsuit in which it was accused of violating the federal minimum wage law. The deliverers contended that even with tips, they worked long hours, often six and seven days a week, for far below the $5.15 hourly minimum.
On Friday, the day after the settlement was announced, word has spread among other service workers Mr. Mweze usually passes on the street. On his way to the Food Emporium on Broadway and 68th Street, he is heralded as a "millionaire!" by a man selling flowers on a corner. Another man on the street asks him when he is going to quit pushing his delivery cart. Mr. Mweze just smiles.
His portion of the settlement could be as much as $30,000. "You do not really know what you are going to get," he says.
The same is true of his tips. "Sometimes you deliver 20 bags and get $2," says Mr. Mweze, 31, who came to New York five years ago. "Sometimes you deliver two bags and get $2. Sometimes they say only 'Thank you' and smile." Most deliverers are pleased when they get $1 a bag, he says.
On Friday Mr. Mweze's workday starts at 9:28 a.m. He carries four bags one block and rides the elevator at 2000 Broadway near 69th Street up 22 flights. His tip: $1.
Back at the store, there is not much demand for deliveries. Mr. Mweze is sent out again an hour later, with a total of 17 bags, for three destinations. He piles the plastic bags onto an aluminum cart, careful not to break the light bulbs, damage the eggs or bend the rolls of wrapping paper.
He looks like an odd version of Santa Claus as he leaves the store, pushing the cart through the frost. "It is not easy for an African to walk through snow," he says, laughing.
He continues west on 68th Street to No. 88 and rides to the 11th floor, where he receives $2 for dropping off two bags. So far so good.
At the next stop, though, 101 Central Park West, he encounters the deliverer's worst situation: a doorman building with a sign at the service entrance reading, "All deliveries and packages must be left on the bench." Mr. Mweze knows what this means: If there is a tip to be had for the nine bags of groceries, it will go the doorman or another building employee. He leaves empty-handed.
The last stop on this round is 145 West 67th Street. "I have something special for you for the holidays!" Kate Weller gushes when Mr. Mweze rings the door of her 36th-floor apartment. She gives him $3 for the six bags of groceries and a white envelope, whose contents Mr. Mweze will not disclose.
"He's my favorite guy," Ms. Weller says. "He works so hard and is always so polite."
At 11:18 a.m. Mr. Mweze reports to the store's dispatcher, picks up 10 bags and heads back into the snow. First stop: 155 West 68th Street, two bags to the seventh floor. On the way up, Mr. Mweze says he is thankful for elevators. He collects $2 and heads up Broadway to 70th Street, where eight bags dropped off at a penthouse apartment near Central Park West earn him $2 and a thank you.
Mr. Mweze is showing no signs of physical fatigue as he makes the return trip to Food Emporium. But the same lobbies and elevators that he sees day after day are not terribly exciting, so, he says, his thoughts often turn to that house he wants to buy someday, maybe in Minnesota, and the great job he wants to find, perhaps after he uses some of the money he will get from the legal settlement to attend classes.
Mr. Mweze studied marketing in Burundi, and planned to follow in his father's footsteps and own a business. But that dream ended about six years ago, when tribal warfare in Burundi escalated and the country's economy collapsed.
Nothing on the Upper West Side reminds Mr. Mweze of Burundi. "My feet are here, my mind is there," he says.
At 11:44 a.m., he heads out again for a relatively quick trip, delivering 14 bags to three locations over five blocks. Total tips: $8.
On his way back to the store he says: "People think that if you push a cart you must be a stupid guy. This is about how to make the living, nothing else."
Over the next two hours he delivers 28 bags to five locations and receives $9 in tips, money that will go toward paying his $280-a-month rent in the Bronx. He shares an apartment with seven other men, but his room is his own.
Much of a deliveryman's good fortune depends on serendipity. After a lunch break for chicken fingers and fries, Mr. Mweze carries a Food Emporium customer's bags just outside to the curb where a cab is waiting. The man hands him $5.
It is nearly 3:45 p.m. and the dispatcher is waiting for Mr. Mweze to deliver 16 bags to three addresses. At the first, Sophia Strong, 91 and an author, addresses Mr. Mweze as "sir" and gives him $2 for her four bags. He gets nothing from the next customer, who requested a delivery to an office in Lincoln Center, then $2 from a woman at 55 Central Park West. After walking 13 blocks back to the store, he is cold and damp.
Mr. Mweze packs four more deliveries onto his cart at 4:45 p.m. and makes $2 at each stop. It is 5:10 p.m. and officially his day could be over, but he cannot resist two final deliveries and the tips they might bring. So at 5:30 p.m. he departs yet again. This last trip takes 19 minutes, covers four blocks and earns him $7.
He is tempted to take yet another order, but fatigue has started to set in. He decides to go home and sleep. Mr. Mweze takes only Tuesdays off.
"This job, it is not a great job, but it is better now," he said heading home. "It's like life; you work your way through it."

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Imagine a Day When Candor Rules Politics

BYLINE: By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
JUST about now, we suspect, the general public is ready to sign on to a classic journalistic fantasy. Pretty tame, as fantasies go. To wit, politicians would suddenly be compelled to dispense with evasions and platitudes and tell the truth.
Maybe for a full day, like in that 1997 Jim Carrey film, "Liar Liar," about a compulsive liar who, to keep a birthday pledge to his son, had to be honest for 24 hours. 
 Think of the possibilities.
Al Gore wouldn't say he wants a recount because every vote should count. Nope, he'd say he wants a recount so he could move into the White House already.
George W. Bush wouldn't say that he opposes more vote-counting because the Florida's votes have already been counted. No, he'd say he might lose a recount.
Joseph I. Lieberman, Mr. Gore's running-mate, would break his silence on the subject and admit that he is thrilled he had the prescience to keep his day job as a United States senator.
James A. Baker III, the Bush post-election pointman, wouldn't denounce the Florida Supreme Court's 4-to-3 decision on Friday to count more votes as an affront to democracy. He'd say, darn the luck. If only Jeb Bush had become Florida's governor sooner, the state's top court -- now six Democrats and one independent -- would surely include at least one Republican by now.
Closer to home, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani would admit that he wants the Board of Education to be a mayoral agency not only because the current hybrid system guarantees unaccountability. But also because, with a year left as mayor, Mr. Giuliani wants to broaden his legacy. Rescuing the school system from more than 30 years of bureaucratic chaos would surely qualify.
If truth reigned, Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, would concede that her union opposes mayoral control not because it prizes educational independence, but because City Hall could cut into the union's power.
The Rev. Al Sharpton would finally admit that Tawana Brawley was not kidnapped and raped in 1987. Mr. Sharpton, who said last week that he cannot afford to pay the $65,000 he owes to a former Dutchess County assistant district attorney for defaming him in the hoax, still hasn't set the record straight.
If forced to be candid, Gov. George E. Pataki, an "observer" of Florida's short-lived vote count, wouldn't tell CNN that he is seeking "a fair election;" he'd say he wouldn't mind trading up, from Albany to Washington. Or at least guarantee warm treatment from a Bush administration.
Maybe Andrew M. Cuomo would even admit -- if consigned to a moment of truth -- that he's lavished taxpayer dollars on self-promotion to help his likely race for governor of New York. Mr. Cuomo, secretary of Housing and Urban Development, just sent out 30,000 glossy, full-color copies of "Vision for Change," a 150-page report, complete with a narrated CD-Rom.
THE report glowingly assesses HUD, of course. Nary a mention of how speculators and non-profit groups allegedly defrauded a federally insured mortgage program right under HUD's nose, worsening the blight in poor neighborhoods and creating the false, damaging impression that Harlem was going through a real estate boom. The program is under investigation, with HUD's full cooperation.
"You can't say everything in every report," Mr. Cuomo said. "This was an overall story of management reform." That explains it. Management reform. That's why the report includes 19 photographs of Mr. Cuomo -- at Yad Vashem in Israel and on tour in China; with such luminaries as the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson; Mr. Gore; former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres; South Africa's President Thabo Mbeki; Martin Luther King III; Gov. Gray Davis of California; Bob Vila; Sarah Jessica Parker; and Kweisi Mfume, president of the N.A.A.C.P. Good management for sure, though perhaps not of housing.
Just a standard report, says Mr. Cuomo, and economical because the department used to publish 12 reports for $750,000, and this report consolidated them, for $421,000 (including the CD-Rom).
"If it saves money, fine, but it needs not to be a promotional piece, so obviously political," said Rep. Robert W. Ney, Republican of Ohio and vice chairman of the House subcommittee on housing and community opportunity.
Counters Mr. Cuomo: "This is a strategy of harassment, of Congressional harassment of the executive."
Maybe it is a vast Congressional conspiracy?
Would make a good film. Wonder if Jim Carrey is available.

HEADLINE: CONTESTING THE VOTE: THE REACTION;
Justices Are Final Arbiters Of Vote, Lawmakers Say

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Prominent Congressional Democrats and some Republicans said today that the United States Supreme Court should be the last word in the divisive, monthlong standoff over the contested presidency.
But Senator Trent Lott, the highest-ranking Senate Republican, did not discourage the Florida Legislature from acting on behalf of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, should the nation's highest court unexpectedly find in favor of Vice President Al Gore in his quest for recounts. 
 As House and Senate members spoke a day before the Supreme Court was to hear arguments on whether to allow manual recounts to resume in Florida, they began to look beyond the contested election to how to govern. The lawmakers said they were keenly aware of the difficulties of making government work with a split Congress and a president who, no matter who prevails, would probably face lingering questions about his legitimacy.
"If this is concluded in the next 48 hours, the person who is on the losing side of this should go and meet with the winner," said Senator Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, on "Fox News Sunday." He added: "They should make an appearance together. There should be an immediate call for national unity and for accepting the results of this election, getting about the country's business."
A day after Democrats criticized the United States Supreme Court for its 5-to-4 vote Saturday to stop the recount that had begun just hours earlier in Florida, party leaders sought to moderate any anticourt tones.
On Saturday, some angry Democrats had said the Supreme Court had diminished its credibility. But today, Democratic leaders said they would rally around any court decision, and they sought to contrast themselves with Republicans who have used phrases like "judicial aggression" and "unelected judges" while objecting to rulings in favor of Mr. Gore by the Florida Supreme Court.
"We have a court system," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader. "We have a rule of law in this country. And I have said from the beginning we have got to stick with it."
Asked whether Mr. Gore should concede if the court found in favor of Mr. Bush's effort to stop the recount, Mr. Gephardt said on ABC's "This Week," "I believe he will, and I think George Bush would do the same thing if it were the other way around."
Mr. Torricelli also said of the expected Supreme Court ruling: "I believe that probably is the last word, and it's the last chance to have this issue not go to the United States Congress. I think it would be very regrettable if the fight in Florida became a fight in Washington."
Under the Constitution, Congress can approve or reject the members of the Electoral College. If Florida's electors were in dispute, Congress might face a bruising fight.
But in his appearance on CBS's "Face the Nation," Mr. Lott, the Senate majority leader, declined to call for the Florida Legislature to hold off on naming Bush electors should the United States Supreme Court unexpectedly support Mr. Gore's drive for a recount.
"I am sure that they would prefer not to have to step in," he said of the Florida lawmakers, "but they do have a role to play, and I think they are prepared to do that."
Asked whether he would support such a step, Mr. Lott, of Mississippi, said, "Well, I wouldn't oppose it." He added that it was not his first choice.
"I don't want that to happen," he said. "We have an important agenda for the American people we have to tend to. And every day that this is delayed is making that a little more difficult."
But Senator Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, said the Supreme Court "should be the final word."
"I think everybody in America would respect that," he said.
After a month of uncertainty over who would be president, lawmakers started to weigh how the president would be able to govern after the bitter election. And despite the oft-stated recognition that Congress needs to close ranks behind whomever is elected, the partisan divisions stood out in stark relief.
While some Republicans have said that if elected, Mr. Bush should shy away from pursuing his proposed $1.3 trillion, 10-year tax cut, saying it is too polarizing, Mr. Lott said he thought Mr. Bush should seek large tax-rate reductions to keep the economy growing.
But Senator Tom Daschle, the minority leader, said today, "I don't think that's possible."
Senator Daschle, of South Dakota, said on CBS that a drive by a Bush administration for the full tax cut would send a signal that the calls for bipartisanship were not serious.
Mr. Daschle said Democrats would support some tax cuts, but added: "I don't think we would ever go to the magnitude that George Bush has proposed. It would destroy the fiscal opportunities we have to retire the debt in the not-to-distant future."
Asked on NBC's "Meet the Press" if he could work with Mr. Gore should the vice president be elected president, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, put the onus on Mr. Gore.
"That would depend on President Gore," he said. "He would have to rise above the history of being partisan and he would have to extend the invitation of let's work together and get this to work."

HEADLINE: Long Island Bishop, James McHugh, Dies at 68

BYLINE: By SHAILA K. DEWAN 

 BODY:
Less than a year after becoming the spiritual leader of Long Island's 1.4 million Roman Catholics, Bishop James Thomas McHugh, an anti-abortion leader, died yesterday. He was 68.
Bishop McHugh, the head of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, died of liver and gallbladder cancer, said Joanne C. Novarro, a spokeswoman for the diocese. 
 His illness was diagnosed a few months after he became the designated successor to Bishop John R. McGann in February 1999. But when he was installed in January, his doctors said the cancer was in remission.
Born in Orange, N.J., on Jan. 3, 1932, Bishop McHugh spent most of his school and working life in New Jersey, attending the Immaculate Conception Seminary in Darlington. He was ordained in 1957 and became a priest with the Archdiocese of Newark. Before moving to the Long Island diocese, he had been the bishop of Camden for 10 years.
He was an expert on issues involving human life, including abortion, the death penalty and euthanasia. In 1965, he became the director of the family life bureau of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops.
In 1971, Father McHugh was appointed papal chamberlain by Pope Paul VI, and Pope John Paul II made him a prelate of honor in 1986.
In 1972, Father McHugh became the National Conference of Catholic Bishops' first director of pro-life activities, said Msgr. Francis Maniscalco, a spokesman for the conference.
Bishops in the United States looked to Bishop McHugh and a handful of other prelates to articulate the church's position on human life issues, Monsignor Maniscalco said.
Bishop McHugh also specialized in demography and population matters, traveling to three United Nations conferences on population and three international conferences on women with the Vatican's delegation.
Part of his job was to help rebut what the Roman Catholic Church sees as exaggerated projections of world population growth, Monsignor Maniscalco said, and to encourage policies of economic development rather than population control.
"He was a tenacious defender of innocent human life," said John Carr, the director of social development and world peace for the bishops conference. "Part of it was loyalty to the church's teachings, and part of it was his conviction that this was the moral measure of our society."
After leaving the conference, Monsignor McHugh went to graduate school in Rome, where he earned a graduate degree in moral theology in 1981.
In 1987, he was appointed auxiliary bishop of the Archdiocese of Newark, and was ordained a bishop in 1988. The following year, he became the bishop of Camden, where he focused on encouraging Catholic education and on drawing men to the priesthood, said Monsignor Maniscalco.
Although some of his time in the Diocese of Rockville Centre, which covers Nassau and Suffolk Counties, was consumed by his battle against cancer, he did complete negotiations with the teachers of the diocese's two Catholic high schools, ensuring that the teachers' contracts contained a clause saying that the teacher supported the Catholic faith and teachings, Mrs. Novarro said.
Bishop McHugh is survived by his mother, Caroline Scavone McHugh, and a sister, Sharon Foster.
Mrs. Novarro said that the Vatican had not yet chosen a successor for Bishop McHugh, and that a group of priests in the diocese would choose an administrator in the interim.
Bishop McHugh was with Cardinal John O'Connor, the archbishop of New York, in the last few hours before the cardinal's death in May. And yesterday, Archbishop Edward M. Egan of New York said he and Bishop McHugh had been friends since the 1960's.
"During these months of illness, he continued to preach the sanctity of life," Archbishop Egan said. "Only now he added his own example of the beauty of life, even when it is attended by sickness and suffering."
