LENGTH: 2299 words

HEADLINE: Foie Gras and Short Ribs: Harlem's Rich New Menu

BYLINE: By ERIC ASIMOV 

 BODY:
A TICKLE of excitement passes through New York's partying crowd when an 18,000-square-foot restaurant like Jimmy's Uptown gets ready to open. Even before it welcomed its first paying customer the day after Thanksgiving, fashion magazines had stopped by for photos and parties, the New York Knicks had staged a celebration there and Woody Allen had given a party for his cast and crew after wrapping a production. Business as usual for any high-budget new restaurant wanting to zoom into its opening on a jet of publicity? Perhaps.
But Jimmy's is in the center of Harlem, in a blocky white two-story building at Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard and 130th Street. Across the street is a somber housing project, but Jimmy's is a sleek world of white, yellow and purple, filled with onyx, mahogany and custom-made chairs imported from Italy and covered in baby-soft leather, with a menu of Hudson Valley foie gras and short ribs braised in cabernet sauvignon and a 75-bottle wine list. 
 Jimmy's may be making the biggest splash in Harlem, but other new restaurants are struggling up from among the old-time fast-food shacks and after-church retreats. This new wave began a couple of years ago with several places that tried to update the fluorescent, threadbare image of restaurants in the neighborhood as Harlem tentatively joined the economic revival that has driven up the price of real estate almost everywhere in Manhattan. For the most part, these are not like the restaurants of Smith Street in Brooklyn, where ambitious young chefs, fleeing Manhattan real estate prices, have established a world of up-to-the-minute culinary ideas for a hungry market of former Manhattanites. Jimmy's aside, Harlem's new restaurants exert a home-grown charm aimed mostly at Harlem's longtime residents, staying true to Southern and Caribbean themes.
The most significant of the new restaurants, in culinary terms, is Bayou, a handsome second-floor spot that opened on Lenox Avenue this year and serves perhaps the most authentic Creole food in New York. Its brick walls and brass lamps look like those in countless other bars and grills in other parts of the city, but in Harlem, Bayou is in the vanguard of inviting designs. The real attraction, though, is the food -- dishes like sherry-laced turtle soup and crayfish etoufee that draw a diverse crowd from all over New York as well as local politicians and business types.
Cafe Largo, which opened in 1998 on the largely Hispanic western edge of Harlem, also broke the Harlem design mold with its warm brick walls and pressed tin ceiling. Its lively crowd, including new Harlemites and students from the City University of New York, go there for pastas and well-executed Hispanic dishes, like chunks of boneless chicken with yellow rice, made piquant by pickled peppers, olives and bay leaves.
Sugar Shack, a lounge and restaurant that opened in 1998, is another young Harlem veteran. With a low-key, jazzy vibe that echoes its plush red and black colors, Sugar Shack attracts a well-dressed crowd of local professionals who stop there for the nightly music and poetry performances as well as the food, which, truth be told, strays little from the standard Harlem formula of fried chicken, shrimp and collard greens.
"It's changed drastically," said Odell Holland, owner of the Sugar Shack. "When I first opened everyone thought I was crazy."
For longtime residents, the new arrivals not only expand the choices but can make life easier. "I have lots of visitors, and I think it's great I don't have to take them downtown for brunch," said Sydney Kai Inis, who has lived in Harlem for 20 years and owns One Good Thing, an arts and collectibles shop on Lenox Avenue.
Amy Ruth's, which opened a year ago serving standout Southern dishes, is already expanding, while Norma Jean Darden, the caterer and cookbook author who serves classic Southern dishes at Miss Mamie's Spoonbread Too on 110th Street, opened the bigger and more inviting Miss Maude's Spoonbread Too this year at Lenox Avenue and 137th Street. Even old-style Harlem establishments are doing well. Charles's Southern-Style Kitchen, which serves maybe the best fried chicken in New York, now has an all-day breakfast outlet on Frederick Douglass Boulevard near 151st Street.
What you won't find in Harlem, so far, is a diversity of cuisine. Italian, Japanese and Indian restaurants have so far not made the trek. Even Jimmy's, whose chef, Linda Japngie, cooked at Bouley Bakery, La Caravelle and the Mark, has interspersed its menu with dishes like horseradish grits, mustard greens, corn bread croutons and plantain bread pudding.
While these new places have created a bustle within Harlem, Jimmy's, which can seat 400 to 500 people in downtown splendor, and several more ambitious restaurants that are scheduled to open in the next few months are inspiring the ready-made cliche about a second Harlem Renaissance. Sugar Hill Bistro, in a 100-year-old Victorian-style town house on 145th Street near Harlem Hospital, will serve refined Southern dishes, while Mongoose Bar and Grill, on Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard near 135th Street, will have a menu that its owner, Leon Ellis, calls quasi-Italian.
"It's economic development," said Jimmy Rodriguez, a bearish, soft-spoken man in a black goatee and a Gucci suit who also owns Jimmy's Bronx Cafe, a glittery hangout near Yankee Stadium, and is planning to open Jimmy's Downtown on East 57th Street. "Retailers are realizing the great potential of income that can be made. The perception that you can't go to Harlem, that it isn't safe, is no longer there."
Harlem, of course, has perennially been touted as the next great neighborhood for real estate, a hope that has just as perennially fallen short, and the obstacles facing new restaurants may be just as daunting. Established investors and restaurateurs alike are leery of the unproven market, while the specter of an economic downturn is almost too much to contemplate. Any number of cautionary tales can be trotted out to discourage would-be restaurateurs.
For years people have been trying to revive Minton's Playhouse, at 118th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, a 10,000-square-foot tribute to Harlem's heyday that would include a restaurant, a lounge and a jazz club. Restaurateurs as well known as Drew Nieporent have dropped out of the project because of difficulty getting financing. When it finally looked last summer as if construction on Minton's would get under way, the principal investor, Kevin Ingram, a Wall Street executive who had no experience in the restaurant business, pulled out at the last minute.
"Opening any restaurant takes a lot of money," said Jerri Banks, a food and wine consultant who worked on the Minton's project. "Many people have wanted Harlem to take its place as an entertainment and dining mecca, as it once was, but a restaurant is a basic business, and you have to know you're going to have a return. It's hard to open a restaurant as a social experiment, particularly on that level."
Apart from Jimmy's, which Mr. Rodriguez managed to finance privately, many of Harlem's new restaurants are helped considerably by the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, an economic development agency that gives low-interest loans and special training to small businesses.
"We're underserved, and we want to increase the standard and variety of cuisine in the community," said Terry C. Lane, the agency's head. "Bayou is the classic example of that: a different cuisine than soul food that is extremely successful. It brings diversity to the area. I think Mongoose and Sugar Hill Bistro will do the same thing."
That may be, but the going has not been easy for Sugar Hill Bistro or its guiding force, Dr. Michael Jones, a surgeon who has lived in Sugar Hill for 13 years and has tried to recruit colleagues to move to Harlem, only to be asked, "Where do we eat?"
Dr. Jones said that he and his partners, who also live in the neighborhood, were unable to get loans from banks because they had no restaurant experience. So they pooled their own money and got a $300,000 loan from the empowerment zone. "The biggest attractions in the neighborhood are the homes, so we purchased this landmark house, renovated it and are opening it as a restaurant," he said.
"The concept is Southern American plantation cuisine, not glorifying the scraps like soul food but the food at the plantation table," Dr. Jones said.
To succeed, Sugar Hill will have to attract diners from other parts of the city as well as the tourist buses that unload their passengers at Sylvia's. "Clearly, there's been an influx of people buying houses of over a half-million dollars in the neighborhood, but it's not enough to sustain us," Dr. Jones said. "We hope to be a destination spot that will not only glorify Harlem, but Sugar Hill and Hamilton Heights."
Not every new restaurant in Harlem is that ambitious. Marc Calcano, who opened Cafe Largo, is a former police officer who still lives in the building he grew up in, around the block from the restaurant, his first. He said his goal was simply to serve the people in the community, and on a recent Saturday afternoon, the dining room, with its bistro look, was bustling with couples and groups of friends sipping bloody marys and mimosas with brunch.
"We don't pretend to be cuisine experts," Mr. Calcano said. "We offer a dining experience for a community that hasn't had something like this. You have a lot of diners, but you don't have a place for families to sit down and relax, at least not on Broadway."
Bayou's owner, Michael Eberstadt, is not a cuisine expert, either. He worked in social services and had no connection to Harlem when he opened his first enterprise, Slice of Harlem, a pizza place at 135th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard, in 1998. "I wanted to open a business in an inner city and create jobs that way," Mr. Eberstadt said. "I didn't care if I was selling pizza or selling shoes, but business was great."
This year he opened a second Slice on Lenox Avenue and then Bayou on the second floor above the new Slice.
Mr. Eberstadt had noticed that few restaurants in Harlem would deliver food, and he capitalized on that in his pizza business. Later, before opening Bayou, he walked the streets observing traffic patterns before settling on his Lenox Avenue site, not far from Sylvia's. Perhaps his biggest coup was finding Steve Manning, an experienced chef from Clancy's in New Orleans, who just happened to be resettling in New York. Mr. Manning has easily navigated the tricky New York waters, avoiding cliched blackened dishes while giving Bayou the feeling of a true Louisiana outpost.
So far, Jimmy's appears to be drawing the celebrities and corporate events it needs to build an uptown buzz. It has luxuries like platters of oysters in a raw bar and a more clubby bar and lounge upstairs, even a roof garden where tropical drinks can be served in warmer weather. Other restaurants are going to have to rely on the conventional foundation of foot traffic and visibility. When Mr. Ellis of Mongoose opened his first restaurant, Emily's, at Fifth Avenue and 111th Street eight years ago, it struggled to attract patrons. "We were a trailblazer, and you have to hang around until the patrons come in," he said.
He says Emily's has done better recently as downtown customers have felt more comfortable with the neighborhood. Still, it has irked him that many outsiders still feel that going to Harlem is an adventure. Nothing would make Mr. Ellis happier than for the sense of novelty to wear off.
"When a person comes to a place in Harlem, it should be like going to anyplace in the city," Mr. Ellis said. "Not, 'I went to a restaurant in Harlem,' just, 'I went to a restaurant.' "
 
Big Welcomes, Bold Tastes
OF the restaurants that have opened in Harlem in the last couple of years, these are among the most appealing:
AMY RUTH'S -- 113 West 116th Street; (212) 280-8779. This attractive little place, soon to expand, offers Southern dishes that are up to date yet honor tradition. Waffles (whole grain with real maple syrup) and salmon croquettes are the stars at breakfast, while tender short ribs and spicy shrimp over rice lead the procession of dinner dishes.
BAYOU -- 308 Lenox Avenue, near 125th Street; (212) 426-3800. One taste of the exceptional turtle soup here, thick with bits of turtle meat and smoky andouille sausage, and you know that the chef, Steve Manning, is a fine New Orleans hand. His 10 years of experience in New Orleans also show in dishes like snapper Alexandria, sprinkled with roasted pecans and drenched with lemon butter, and his own delicious invention, fried oysters and spinach with melted Brie.
CAFE LARGO -- 3387 Broadway, near 137th Street; (212) 862-8142. This welcoming cafe is a respite from the diners and takeout places on Broadway. The menu breaks little ground, but the dishes, whether chunky sopa de pollo, grilled skirt steak or piquant chicken and rice, are generally well executed and occasionally superb.
JIMMY'S UPTOWN -- 2207 Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard, near 130th Street; (212) 491-4000. Jimmy's ambitious menu stays true to Southern and Caribbean themes while passing them through the refining prism of French techniques. In its early days, the kitchen has been erratic, but highlights include meaty crab and corn fritters, a fresh and attractive seasonal salad, tender short ribs braised in red wine and pork tenderloin with sweet-plantain bread pudding.
MISS MAUDE'S SPOONBREAD TOO -- 547 Lenox Avenue, near 137th Street; (212) 690-3100. The dining room is bright and cheery, and Southern favorites like smothered pork chops and fried shrimp are done exceedingly well. ERIC ASIMOV

HEADLINE: Scarce Slots? Hold an Auction

BYLINE: By Robert H. Frank; Robert H. Frank, an economics professor at Cornell, served as chief economist for the Civil Aeronautics Board from 1978 to 1980.

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
In April, Congress passed a law intended to stimulate competition at La Guardia Airport and increase service to small communities. In response, the Federal Aviation Administration substantially increased the number of flights allowed to operate at La Guardia, already one of the nation's busiest airports.
Unfortunately, La Guardia simply couldn't handle the new traffic. Something had to be done, and a week ago, the F.A.A. rolled back the number of daily flights to pre-April levels. Then it held a lottery for operating slots that gave preference to nine small airlines. 
 Reducing operating slots in this way clearly ameliorates crowding. But it does so in a wasteful way, one that guarantees continued unfairness and frustration for area travelers.
Slots at crowded airports are a valuable economic resource, much like scarce seats on an oversold flight. History has taught us a valuable lesson about how best to allocate seats on oversold flights, one with a message for the problem of crowded airports.
Carriers once handled oversold flights on a first-come, first-served basis. If 120 passengers presented tickets for a flight with 100 seats, only the first 100 got to go. For passengers coming from connecting flights, this was like a lottery. If your connecting flight was late, you got bumped.
This solution never considered that individuals have different needs. People with urgent schedules were often forced to wait, while those less pressed made their flights.
Parallel issues arise with overcrowded airports. Just as a plane can accommodate only so many passengers, an airport can handle only so many operations. So every time a 19-seat Beechcraft 1900 uses La Guardia, the F.A.A. must deny permission to some larger plane -- say, a Boeing 757 with several hundred passengers. Today, even among carriers currently authorized to use La Guardia, delays and flight cancellations are legion. More important, a host of carriers would like to provide large-aircraft service to La Guardia but are not authorized to use the airport at all. That means some travelers have to use less convenient airports, just as someone has to wait when flights are oversold. In both cases we have a strong interest in minimizing total inconvenience.
On this score, the La Guardia lottery is even worse than first-come, first-served. Not only does it make no attempt to minimize the number of diverted passengers, but it actively increases their number by setting aside special slot allocations for carriers that serve small communities with small aircraft.
There are better ways to solve both problems. In 1979, the Civil Aeronautics Board called for carriers to offer cash payments, free tickets or other rewards to induce volunteers to relinquish their seats on oversold flights. Passengers could decide for themselves how important it was to avoid waiting. Those with pressing business simply wouldn't volunteer. The board's proposal was adopted and soon became widely recognized as both more fair and more efficient than the earlier system.
Scarce operating slots at La Guardia can be allocated in essentially the same way. Rather than give them away by lottery, the F.A.A. could sell them to the highest-bidding airlines. If the market value of a slot were, say, $5,000, carriers would have to charge travelers on a 20-passenger flight $250 more for a one-way ticket, while those on a 200-passenger flight would have to pay only $25 extra. Passengers on small flights would thus have a strong incentive to divert to less crowded times or less crowded airports.
For oversold flights, the auction solution works because it gives people an incentive not to use a scarce seat unless its value is high to them. Similarly, auctioning operating slots at crowded airports creates an incentive to use those airports only if the value of doing so is high.
Granted, this doesn't do much for passengers from Ames, Iowa, who want to visit New York City. But they can still fly to nearby airports, especially in Westchester or Long Island. And if aviation authorities really wanted to help the citizens of small communities, they could sell scarce slots to the highest bidders, then give cash compensation to those communities that suffered as a result.
Even if such compensation is impractical, we should bite the bullet and realize that the best way of minimizing the inconvenience we impose on air travelers is to charge handsomely for the convenience of landing at La Guardia.

HEADLINE: Yes, It's About Money

BYLINE: By Andrew Zimbalist; Andrew Zimbalist is a professor of economics at Smith College and author of "Baseball and Billions."

DATELINE: NORTHAMPTON, Mass.

 BODY:
Alex Rodriguez, the 25-year-old all-star shortstop, this week signed a contract with the Texas Rangers that will make him the highest-paid player in the history of sports. The contract -- for $252 million over 10 years -- has drawn harsh criticism as an example of the runaway spending that is ruining the sport.
Yes, the deal is extravagant. Two years ago Tom Hicks, the Rangers' owner, bought the team, along with the lease on the stadium near Dallas and options on about 200 acres of surrounding land, for $250 million. Is Rodriguez worth more than the team? Crazy as it seems, he almost is. 
 Hicks is a crafty businessman. The contract itself isn't quite as high as it sounds: it includes long-term deferred money that reduces its net present value to $180 million. But, more fundamentally, Hicks is betting that Rodriguez will help fill his 49,000-seat stadium, allowing him to raise ticket prices, sell more concessions, increase parking revenue, and so on.
And there's a kicker. Hicks wants to sell the right to name the ballpark, and he is developing the surrounding acreage. If Rodriguez brings a championship, Hicks's payoff comes in the form of tens, if not hundreds, of millions of additional dollars in real estate and advertising value.
Like any good capitalist, Hicks is attempting to maximize his profits. He expects that Rodriguez alone will produce well over $25 million a year in value for all his investments. There are no guarantees, of course. Should Rodriguez be injured, his guaranteed contract will leave Hicks hurting. And should Rodriguez stay healthy, Hicks still needs to find some way to strengthen a pitching staff with one of the worst earned-run averages in the American League last year. Can Rodriguez pitch, too?
While Hicks's deal with Rodriguez might make sense for the Rangers, it may not make sense for Major League Baseball. The imbalances in the revenues of baseball's haves and have-nots have grown acute over the last decade. The top- and bottom-earning teams were $30 million apart in 1989; in 1999, the spread was more than $160 million. Since 1995, out of 189 post-season games, only three have been won by teams with payrolls in the bottom half.
Unlike typical businesses, baseball needs balanced competition. That is not to say that all teams should be equal in their resources and their ability to win games: the most successful league would have the big cities' teams win most often because they lift the television ratings the most.
But it's not healthy for the sport to be dominated only by the richest teams. When the biggest city's team wins the championship four of five years, and begins to play its crosstown rival for the championship, as happened in the Subway Series, inequality has gone too far. Too many Americans, feeling left out, will yawn and turn away.

HEADLINE: Compaq Sees Weak Results This Quarter

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
In another sign of weakness in the personal computer business, Compaq Computer said today that its sales and profits in the fourth quarter would be lower than expected.
Compaq said it would post sales of $11.2 billion to $11.4 billion, up 7 percent from a year ago, but nearly 10 percent below its earlier expectations. It forecast that its profit from continuing operations would be 28 to 30 cents a share, below the 36 cents Wall Street had expected. 
 In recent weeks, several big computer makers including Gateway, Micron Electronics and Apple Computer have announced sales shortfalls, as have chip makers like Intel and Advanced Micro Devices.
"This isn't a Compaq problem; it's an industry problem," said Kevin McCarthy, an analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston.
While Compaq's sales in October and most of November were as the company expected, sales to consumers were weaker than expected over the Thanksgiving weekend and continued to lag in December, when sales to small business and Internet companies started to fall off as well.
Demand from larger corporations remains strong, the company said, but price competition, always vigorous, has accelerated.
"We have been rocking and rolling and doing pretty significant growth," Michael D. Capellas, Compaq's chief executive, said in a conference call with analysts. "Even with 20-20 hindsight, it would have been difficult to predict this at the beginning of the quarter."
Compaq is the No. 1 maker of personal computers worldwide, although in the United States it is second to Dell.
Separately, Compaq said it would take a write-off of more than $1 billion, reflecting the drop in the stock of CMGI, the Internet incubator. Compaq received a 16.4 percent stake in CMGI last year, worth $2 billion at the time, in return for an 83 percent stake in Alta Vista, the Internet search engine that Compaq had acquired when it bought the Digital Equipment Corporation. CMGI's shares were at $48 when the deal was struck. They shot up to $163, but have since fallen, to $11.88 yesterday.
Compaq's shares rose 53 cents, to $20.77, yesterday in regular trading before the earnings announcement. After hours, the shares fell to $19.75.
Consumer demand for PC's has fallen sharply after growing at a 30 percent annual rate from the middle of 1998 to the middle of this year, said Roger Kay, an analyst with IDC, a research company. Demand had surged, he said, as prices under $1,000 made computers affordable for a much broader portion of the public at the same time as the Internet gave people new uses for them.
But now, he added, computer sales are being sapped by the slowing economy and rise of intriguing new gadgets like hand-held organizers and digital cameras.
IDC expects personal computer sales worldwide in the fourth quarter to grow by 20 percent over the year-earlier period. But sales to United States consumers will grow only 10 percent, down from its previous forecast of 21 percent, a shortfall of 500,000 computers.

HEADLINE: A High-Ranking Democrat Lobbies for a Dues Break From U.N.

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the highest-ranking Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, came to the United Nations today to do a little politicking.
In the Security Council and in a closed-door meeting later at Ambassador Richard C. Holbrooke's official residence with diplomats from a range of nations, Mr. Biden put himself in the middle of the conflict over the level of dues for the United States. He left the impression that if the rest of the world would give Congress the lower dues it wants for the regular United Nations budget, there might be a slight relaxation of the hard line on reducing American payments for peacekeeping. 
 He noted, as other members of Congress visiting here have recently, that there is far less hostility toward the United Nations in Congress now, and more knowledge about it, than there has been for many years.
Mr. Biden, a Delaware Democrat, visited just as diplomats here were beginning to believe that they may after all come up with some figures that the Republican-led Congress could accept. That would mean lowering the percentage of the United Nations operating budget billed to the United States to 22 percent, from the current 25 percent.
A group of Latin American nations is also leading an effort to work out a compromise on the peacekeeping budget that would eventually reduce American payments to about 26 percent, from 30.
Congress passed a law in 1995 saying it would pay no more than 25 percent of the peacekeeping budget. Some diplomats are concerned that if they agree to their part of Mr. Biden's deal and lower American payments to the regular budget to 22 percent, Congress may still balk at the peacekeeping figure of 26 percent, and there is no guarantee that in future years Republican-controlled committees will not come back demanding even more cuts.
Senator Biden had jointly devised the Congressional position with the Foreign Relations Committee chairman, Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina. He said he spoke for himself today when he saw room to maneuver in the Senate. He told reporters and diplomats that he would not have tied budget payments to a host of conditions, the most important being a change in dues.
"But quite frankly," he said, "my view is not a majority view." He added that a reduction to 22 percent in regular dues by the General Assembly, which handles financial decisions, is an absolute requirement. Without that, he said, diplomats can forget the whole package.
Many members of the United Nations are concerned that their payments will go up if the United States pays less. Few deny that the existing scales for both regular budget assessments and peacekeeping are out of date. China, for example, pays next to nothing, though its economy has grown enormously. But many diplomats still bridle at the way the United States gave the United Nations a take-it-or-leave-it ultimatum that holds American payments hostage until rates change. The United States is $1.7 billion in debt to the United Nations.
European anger was demonstrated again today in the Security Council by Ambassador Jean-David Levitte of France, which currently holds the rotating European Union presidency. He reminded Mr. Biden that the European Union had the same gross national product as the United States but pays nearly $1 billion more a year.

HEADLINE: Kodak Cuts Its Profit Forecast For Third Time This Autumn

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The Eastman Kodak Company sharply lowered its profit estimates for the next two quarters yesterday, saying that an abrupt slowdown in the economy was weakening film sales.
This was the third time since September that Kodak had cut its profit forecast. 
 "We are seeing quite a bit of slowdown in the consumer business," Daniel A. Carp, Kodak's chairman and chief executive, said yesterday at a meeting with analysts in New York. "It started in September and it has carried on and gotten worse through Thanksgiving."
For the fourth quarter, Kodak now expects to earn 65 to 75 cents a share, considerably less than the $1.07 a share that analysts expected.
In the first quarter of 2001, the company expects to report profits of 50 to 60 cents a share. Analysts had been expecting first-quarter earnings of about 89 cents a share. The company expects sales to rise 4 percent to 6 percent for all of 2001.
Kodak said it would counter a slide in demand with tougher cost controls, cuts in capital spending and a $200 million reduction in inventories. There are no plans to lay off employees, but Kodak said it would impose hiring limits. And Mr. Carp suggested that if conditions worsened, job cuts were likely.
Investors, who have pushed the price of Kodak stock down sharply this year, did not punish the shares yesterday. They rose $1.50, to $41.06. The stock has fallen 36 percent this year.
"The stock is moving this way because this had been widely anticipated," said Jonathan Rosenzweig, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. "We knew the film business was weak."
At the analysts' meeting, Mr. Carp said demand had fallen in both the United States and Europe. Emerging markets, in contrast, remain a source of growth.
"We are assuming gross domestic product growth will be in the range of 2 percent to 2.5 percent in 2001," he said. "It's a lot more fun when the economy is growing at a rate of 4 percent or more."
The company expects growth to accelerate in the third and fourth quarters of 2001. Still, Mr. Carp acknowledged, "I am nervous about the second half."
Jack L. Kelly, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said he was sympathetic to Kodak's situation, even though this was the company's third warning since September.
"I am not skeptical at all about the economy-slowing rationale Kodak used," he said. "I have seen it too much in the last two months, and it really started in the summer."
Mr. Kelly said that in 1998 and 1999, film shipments were up about 14 percent and roughly 8 percent, respectively, far above the historical average of 4 percent to 5 percent.
For the first two quarters of this year, the rate of increase was 7 percent to 8 percent, he said. It slowed slightly during the first two months of the third quarter and then plunged in September.
"In September, that number was zero, and the fourth quarter is going to be zero," he said.
Mr. Carp said Kodak was maintaining its market share with the rival Fuji Photo. Sales in wholesale clubs compensated for a loss in share in retail channels. And pricing has remained stable.
Kodak is the largest seller of film in the United States, with an estimated 65 percent of sales. Fuji accounts for about 25 percent, according to analysts.
Mr. Rosenzweig said that Kodak might find it difficult to expect market share to expand further and that it could see it begin to erode.
"They have kicked everyone else out of the wholesale club area," he said. "There is no more share to gain there. So, at some point next year, wholesale will not be giving them much of a boost. The question, therefore, is: Are they going to be able to halt the decline they are experiencing in the food, drug and mass merchant markets?" 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Daily News Owner May Sell Business Magazine to Gruner & Jahr

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
In a move that if completed would further pare down his media empire, Mortimer B. Zuckerman is negotiating to sell Fast Company, the five-year old business magazine, to Gruner & Jahr.
Mr. Zuckerman, who also owns The Daily News in New York and U.S. News & World Report, did not return phone calls for comment, but executives at Fast Company and Gruner & Jahr confirmed that he was negotiating to sell the magazine. The news of the negotiations was first reported on the media Web site Inside.com on Monday, which estimated the sale price at more than $200 million, an estimate supported yesterday by an executive involved in Mr. Zuckerman's media holdings. 
 Fast Company, aimed at Internet entrepreneurs and technology managers, is considered the most successful and problem-free of Mr. Zuckerman's media properties.
Circulation is 538,000, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations. Newsstand sales -- a major barometer of a magazine's vitality -- were up 35 percent in the first six months of 2000, and total paid circulation was up 64 percent for the first six months of 2000. Ad pages are up by 34 percent, to 1,443, for the year to date, according to the Publishers Information Bureau; revenue is up 117 percent, to $70.3 million for the year to date.
Mr. Zuckerman, a real estate developer, has made a reputation as a businessman who can navigate unpredictable markets. He thinks the time may be right to turn the spigot off at Fast Company, the Zuckerman media executive said. Though still strong, the market for Internet advertising -- one of the advertising mainstays of Fast Company -- is softening. The number of magazines dealing with many of the same issues covered by Fast Company has grown, with titles like Red Herring, Business 2.0, Wired and The Industry Standard eating up market share.
Mr. Zuckerman, the executive said, is in the process of paring down his empire to those holdings for which he feels a passionate affinity. In September 1999, Mr. Zuckerman sold The Atlantic Monthly, the 141-year-old monthly magazine, to the National Journal Group, a Washington magazine publisher and research firm, for about $10 million.
"You read Fast Company and it doesn't really deal with the issues that Mort is interested in," one executive said. Mr. Zuckerman is interested in issues of global economy more than Fast Company's articles, which are aimed at the Internet entrepreneur and technology manager.
Gruner & Jahr, the publisher of eight consumer magazines in the United States and more than 80 magazines worldwide, has been looking to expand ever since Bertelsmann A.G., the German media company that owns 74.9 percent of Gruner & Jahr, sold its stake in AOL Europe last year for about $8 billion. Daniel B. Brewster, the chief executive of Gruner & Jahr since May, has been given a significant war chest to reinvigorate the company.

HEADLINE: G.M. Phaseout of Olds Is at Center of a Range of Cutbacks

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 12

 BODY:
General Motors said today that it would gradually shut down its Oldsmobile division over the next several years, ending production of cars that symbolized sophistication and affluence through most of the 20th century, but came to be seen as simply dowdy.
Stuck with its largest supply of unsold cars since the 1991 recession in an auto market that has slowed significantly, G.M. also announced that it would eliminate 10 percent of its 66,000 salaried jobs and 11,000 contract positions in the United States and Europe. The company said it would close a 2,000-employee assembly plant in Britain. 
 Rick Wagoner, G.M.'s chief executive, said that the job cuts would come, "primarily through voluntary separation and early retirement programs."
Blue-collar workers will be largely insulated from layoffs. The same G.M. assembly plants in the United States that make Oldsmobiles build similar cars for other divisions, like Chevrolet and Buick, and will stay open. G.M. hired tens of thousands of factory workers a year in the 1960's and now has 6 to 8 percent of its blue-collar work force retiring each year. So instead of dismissing them, it can more easily transfer its blue-collar workers as factories close.
Still, G.M. confirmed the long-expected closing of a 900-employee engine factory in Lansing, Mich., Oldsmobile's hometown.
While G.M. warned that its profits would take a hit, the decision to end the Oldsmobile brand was welcomed on Wall Street, where investors bid up G.M.'s stock 19 cents a share to close at $51.75.
G.M. will continue to sell its current Oldsmobile models but will not develop any new ones. Production of each of the current models will be halted once the price they can be sold for falls below the cost of assembling them, said Ronald Zarrella, president of North American operations at G.M. The money that otherwise would have gone to designing and promoting new Oldsmobile models will be spent on other vehicles instead, particularly Saturns, which will replace Oldsmobiles as the cars that G.M. relies on most to fight foreign brands in the United States.
Oldsmobile dealers criticized G.M.'s decision to shut down the division. They argued that executives of the 103-year-old division had erred in abandoning older buyers of large cars the last five years in an unsuccessful attempt to woo younger, better-educated customers instead.
"It's a very sad day -- we've been an Oldsmobile dealer since 1932," said J. Chapman Morris Sr., whose family dealership in Fillmore, Calif., also sells Chevrolets. "They left a market that's still there."
But Wall Street has been calling for years for Oldsmobile to be shut down. After selling more than a million cars a year in the late 1970's and again in the mid-1980's, the division has lost so many customers that its sales are projected at a mere 300,000 this year.
Despite the plunge, Oldsmobile executives, long powerful within the company, continued to use the division's storied history and nearly universal name recognition within the United States to win billions of dollars from G.M.'s board to invest in sportier models like the Intrigue and Alero. Those models failed to reverse the slide.
Oldsmobile was founded by Ransom E. Olds in 1897, six years before the creation of the Ford Motor Company. It produced four cars in its first year. In 1901, the Oldsmobile Curved Dash quickly became the nation's best-selling car. Eclipsed by Ford's success with the introduction of the Model N in 1906 and the Model T in 1908, Oldsmobile was sold at the end of 1908 to the new General Motors, which had been set up a couple of months earlier and had previously owned only Buick.
In the "ladder" of G.M. divisions, Oldsmobile was a cut above Chevrolet and a step below Buick. Oldsmobile built a reputation for performance, with innovations like automatic transmissions, and for understated elegance, with a style that contrasted with the flashier image of Cadillac.
G.M. executives became alarmed in the early 1990's that they were losing market share among baby boomers to Toyota, Honda and other foreign brands and designated Oldsmobile as the company's "import fighter" division. Big cars that appealed to older drivers, like the Oldsmobile 98, were replaced by smaller, more nimble models like the Aurora, Alero and Intrigue.
But while older buyers fled Oldsmobiles for rival large cars like the Mercury Grand Marquis, younger buyers did not step forward to replace them. John P. Wolkonowicz, a partner at the Bulin Group, an automotive consulting firm in Northville, Mich., said that his company's research found that Oldsmobile sold no more cars last year to baby boomers -- those Americans born from 1946 to 1963 -- and younger buyers than it did in 1991. Simultaneously, it lost much of its market among older Americans.
"The G.M. approach to brands says you can make a brand anything you want it to be, all you have to do is change the product," Mr. Wolkonowicz said. "In reality, the customer sets bounds on what a brand can be."
Mr. Zarrella defended G.M.'s overall brand management strategy, while acknowledging that the company's Oldsmobile division had not survived the effort to transform it. "We tried to do a very difficult thing, which is to walk away from a customer base," he said at a news conference today. The result, he said, was "lots of positive demographics -- the problem was, there weren't enough of them."
Oldsmobile also suffered from the relative success of two other G.M. divisions: Pontiac, which has captured the performance image that Oldsmobile once held, and Buick, which meets the needs of a big slice of the large-car market with vehicles like the LeSabre, the nation's best-selling full-size car. "Oldsmobile had too much in common with all the rest" of G.M.'s divisions, said David Martin, the executive director of brand consulting at the Interbrand Corporation in New York.
Until now, G.M. had been leery of shutting down Oldsmobile partly for fear of lawsuits from dealers, who could argue that the company was breaking its franchise agreements with them by continuing to sell many models but only under other brand names. Indeed, even as G.M. is phasing out its Oldsmobile division, it is creating its first new division since Saturn a decade ago and laying plans for new dealerships, to sell Hummer sport utility vehicles.
Harold Wells, the chairman of the National Automobile Dealers Association, and an Oldsmobile dealer since 1956, said today that G.M. should provide assistance to the dealers. "G.M. needs to move quickly to take into account the millions of dollars that dealers have invested in facilities, equipment, personnel and training," he said in a statement. "They deserve nothing less than fair compensation."
Mr. Wagoner said that G.M. would try to assist dealers, while making sure that parts and service remained available for current owners of Oldsmobiles. Only 63 of the 2,801 Oldsmobile dealers do not have franchises of other brands.
"I'm not going to speculate on lawsuits, because our real intention is to work individually with dealers," he said.
G.M. also provided several warnings today about its profits. It said that it would take a one-time after-tax charge of $900 million to $1.5 billion in the fourth quarter to cover the various moves announced today. Losses in G.M.'s European operations will deepen in the fourth quarter compared with the third-quarter loss of $181 million, G.M. said.
Excluding special charges and gains, G.M.'s operations will remain profitable over all in the fourth quarter, earning $550 million to $600 million, the company forecast. But G.M. had to take action on Oldsmobile anyway because of its persistent losses, Mr. Wagoner said, adding, "The car side of the business has been under pressure for several years, and Oldsmobile has been in the red."

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT;
Changes of Scenery Taken to the Ninth Degree

BYLINE: By TANYA MOHN 

 BODY:
Rick Lukianuk loves watching the surprise on people's faces as he describes his journey from the upper echelons of corporate America to small-town academia -- or, put another way, from coping with stress to having a ball. "I can see it in their eyes," he said. "They say, 'Wait a minute, you can actually do what you want to do?' "
Just 17 months ago, Mr. Lukianuk, 43, was vice president and general counsel for Fischer Scientific Worldwide in Hampton, N..H. Today, he is the high school principal at the Portsmouth Christian Academy in Dover, N.H. It is an unlikely career switch, one that he himself would never have predicted. 
 But a new brand of career counselor is helping managers afflicted by the early stages of burnout find new jobs that they love rather than ones dictated by their resumes. Many of these executives have made a bundle in the decade-long economic boom, so they can often afford the risk.
Mr. Lukianuk practiced international law for 17 years, first at a division of United Technologies in Dearborn, Mich., and then at Fischer Scientific. The frequent travel was tiring him out and, worse, limiting the time he spent with his wife and two children, age 14 and 11.
"It was a great job," he said, "but I knew with that kind of pace, I wouldn't be able to keep it up forever."
So he contacted New Directions, a Boston firm that works with senior managers and professionals. New Directions says it focuses on identifying what clients want to do, not what they think they should be doing.
"We really try to get our clients to slow down and get into neutral and to think about where they are going," said Jeff Redmond, the firm's managing director. "When they do that, then they start thinking about, 'Well, maybe I've had my traditional phase of my career, now I'd like to do something different.' "
After an intensive period of testing and personal assessment that confirmed Mr. Lukianuk's strengths and interests, he took up the headmaster of Portsmouth Christian on a long-standing offer to teach an introductory law class. It would be fun, he figured, and bring him closer to his children, who attended the school.
"It took about four to six weeks to figure out I just loved teaching," Mr. Lukianuk said. Years before, he recalled, he had thought about becoming a history teacher, "but that kind of got lost along the way."
Still, the course was little more than a diversion until the school's principal resigned and Mr. Lukoanuk was asked to take the job. His first instinct was to refuse because of the lower salary, but New Directions set up a meeting with a group of senior-level lawyers so he could sound out his peers. He expected them to ask, "Are you crazy?" he said. Instead, their message was: "If there was any way to do something you are passionate about, do it."
So he took a closer look and concluded that the basic management skills he had picked up in corporate America, like establishing budgets and planning strategy, were crucial to running a school, too. Besides, he could be involved in activities he loved, like music and theater.
He said yes.
He moved to a smaller house, got smaller cars and today enjoys simple pleasures, like raking leaves with his children, that once eluded him. "I always traded time for money," Mr. Lukianuk said. "Now, I'm downscaling in a lot of ways, but I'm upscaling my life."
This is the kind of transition that New Directions prides itself on. Mr. Redmond, a former executive recruiter, helped start the firm more than a decade ago so he could represent job seekers rather than big companies. It has since opened offices in Wilton, Conn., and New York.
New Directions encourages clients to do volunteer work while job hunting, arguing that it will give them perspective and reduce the anxiety of the search. When Bill Boysen left Bristol-Myers Squibb in 1999 after 26 years, he did a stint at SoundWaters, a nonprofit in Stamford, Conn., that educates people about Long Island Sound and its watershed. Mr. Boysen, who had spent most of his tenure at Bristol-Myers as a senior financial officer, agreed to run the organization. Today, he works on a small island in a recently restored 18th-century house with geothermal heat and floor coverings and countertops made of recycled tires and soda containers. He sometimes also works on SoundWaters' 80-foot schooner. "I ended up doing something which I dreamed about," he said.
Another client, W. C. Bird, said farewell to his responsibilities as vice president for human resources at S. D. Warren, a division of Scott Paper, to buy and run Ash Mill Farm, an 11-acre bed-and-breakfast in Holicong, Pa. He remembers telling Mr. Redmond of New Directions, "I don't have a clue what I want to do. I want you to prod me, poke me and give me every test."
Yet another client, Chris Ridley, departed WGBH, the Boston public TV station where he was vice president for corporate communications, to start For the Birds, a Concord, Mass., backyard wild-bird store. "I can't believe anyone can make a living doing this -- to have a job this fantastic, this much fun," he said.
While no official statistics exist on how many people embark on new vocations, counselors say demand for career advice is surging. Susan Eubanks, associate executive director of the National Board for Certified Counselors in Greensboro, N.C., says the number of requests for referrals has shot up to about 300 a month today from 30 to 40 eight years ago. And Juliet Miller, executive director of the National Career Development Association in Columbus, Ohio, says, "It used to be that you just sent out a resume, and you'd get a job. Now we're really helping people look at who they are, what they really want to accomplish in their life."
Ian Summers, a career consultant, helps clients ranging from marketing directors and graphic designers to a fighter pilot and a small-town Indiana ear, eye and nose doctor who was "bored out of his mind" until he took up writing novels about doctors.
Mr. Summers's workshops in a renovated barn in Stockton, N.J., often begin with his burning incense and asking participants to begin "vacuum cleaning the universe" -- scanning the world for jobs that match their interests, not their skills.
Sometimes that even means staying put. Several years ago, he counseled a renowned economist who was thinking about leaving his profession. "I helped him to evaluate what he stood for," Mr. Summers recalled. After attending a two-day workshop, he said, the economist decided to remain in his field. After that, Mr. Summers said, he "approached his work from his heart."

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
In the Tank?

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
Even cynics were a bit startled by the revelation that Justice Clarence Thomas's wife has been employed by the Heritage Foundation to gather resumes for potential appointments in the next administration. But let me leave ethical issues to the experts and focus on a different question suggested by the story: To what extent will a Bush administration, if that's what we're about to have, be staffed by people from Heritage and its sister institutions? Are we about to enter an era of government by professional ideologues?
Heritage describes itself as a think tank, a term originally applied to nonpolitical institutions like the RAND Corporation. Whether it is really appropriate for organizations like Heritage depends on what you mean by the word "think." Most of Washington's so-called think tanks don't have to ponder the issues -- they already know the answers. The Heritage mission statement makes no bones about it: the institution's purpose is to "formulate and promote conservative public policies." Can you imagine any circumstances under which Heritage researchers might recommend a tax increase, or a new environmental regulation? I didn't think so. 
 Since the policy recommendations that come out of Heritage, or the Cato Institute, or even the American Enterprise Institute are so predictable, what purpose do these organizations serve? Good question.
The important think tanks are all very much institutions of the right. Jon Corzine notwithstanding, left-wing multimillionaires are not exactly the norm. So liberal think tanks don't have anything like the resources or the influence of their right-wing counterparts. Some might cite the Brookings Institution as an exception -- but Brookings isn't liberal the way the conservative think tanks are conservative. Put it this way: Even A.E.I., the most moderate of the big right-wing think tanks, lists Newt Gingrich among its "scholars."
The glory years of the think tanks were the 1970's, when they provided an alternative to what was perceived -- with some justice -- as the liberal bias of academia. The think tanks were places where neoconservative intellectuals could think the unthinkable and say the unsayable. They provided a new element in the national dialogue, to such an extent that Daniel Patrick Moynihan famously declared that "the Republicans have become the party of ideas." And of course the think tanks provided the intellectual shock troops for the Reagan revolution.
But that was a long time ago. Neoconservative ideas are no longer radical; they have become trite. And the intellectual need for an alternative set of institutions is itself far less apparent than it was. In the field I know best, economics, academia no longer has a recognizable liberal bias; free markets command great respect, and many of the best-known professors are also committed Republicans. Nonetheless, the think tanks are bigger and better financed than ever. What is their purpose?
Mainly they have become waiting rooms for the conservative nomen klatura -- a class of intellectuals among whom talent is much less important than political reliability. The people whose resumes Mrs. Thomas has been helping put together are professional ideologues, who currently earn a living by repeating conservative slogans but hope that they will soon be under secretaries and assistant secretaries.
This hope doesn't have to be fulfilled. While a few Friends of Bill got special consideration in the early years, the Clinton administration was in general staffed by people notable more for their ability than their ideological fervor. In the economic area, the administration attracted some very impressive talent, including at least one likely Nobel laureate (Joseph Stiglitz, chief economic adviser from 1995 to '97).
George W. Bush could do the same -- staffing his administration with able Republicans from the business and academic worlds. But will he?
If Mr. Bush becomes president, the thing to watch is whom he appoints -- not so much to the glamorous cabinet positions as the less visible but crucial second and third tiers. If those slots are filled by people from Wall Street and Stanford, people who have made their reputations independent of their politics, good. If they are filled from Heritage and Cato and A.E.I., forget the rhetoric -- he's a divider, not a uniter. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Technology Shares Retreat, Moving Nasdaq 2.8% Lower

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Technology stocks fell yesterday while some old-line consumer stocks had a modest day in the plus column.
The Dow Jones industrial average was led slightly higher by Procter & Gamble and Eastman Kodak. But the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell more than 2 percent.
After the market closed, Compaq Computer said that it would miss fourth-quarter sales projections by 8 percent to 10 percent while earnings per share would fall about 8 cents below current estimates. Compaq rose 53 cents, to $20.77, in regular trading, then slipped as low as $19 after hours before rebounding to about $20. Because investors have already been made well aware of the sharp slowdown in the personal computer business -- including an announcement from Advanced Micro Devices on Monday -- Compaq's news may have little effect. 
 To some extent yesterday, investors may have been distracted by the United States Supreme Court, which is expected to make a decision soon that could determine who will be president. "The market is getting increasingly nervous about how many wild cards are out there," said Todd E. Petzel, chief investment officer at Commonfund, a firm in Wilton, Conn., that manages money for nonprofit institutions.
The Dow gained 42.47 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,768.27, while the technology-heavy Nasdaq lost 83.33 points, or 2.8 percent, to 2,931.77. So far, the Nasdaq has managed to move back above the 3,000 level for just one day -- Monday -- in the last three weeks. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 9.02 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,371.18.
Qualcomm, JDS Uniphase and Oracle pulled the Nasdaq and the S.& P. 500 lower. But Microsoft rose for the third consecutive day, up 31 cents, to $58.38, after trading as high as $60.
The rally of some stocks yesterday seemed to show that investors feel the recent declines in many stocks have already factored in enough bad news on sales and earnings.
For example, Eastman Kodak helped drive the Dow higher, even though it dished out its own disappointment. Kodak said the slowing economic growth was cutting into film sales. It projected fourth-quarter earnings of 65 to 75 cents a share, well below the $1.07 a share expected by Wall Street, according to First Call/Thomson Financial. Kodak rose $1.50, to $41.06.
Procter & Gamble also drove the Dow higher after it confirmed that it would meet its earnings forecast of 91 cents to 93 cents a share for the fourth quarter. Its stock jumped $2.88, to $71.94.
In another sign that investors are no longer being surprised by companies that downgrade their earnings and sales expectations, Advanced Micro Devices managed to slip just 6 cents, to $17.25, after being up for most of the day. The chip maker said on Monday night that weak demand for personal computers would result in flat fourth-quarter revenue and earnings of just 50 to 60 cents a share, below the 68 cents a share forecast by analysts. Intel, A.M.D.'s big rival, made a similar announcement last week.
Delphi Automotive Systems, the largest maker of automobile parts, said yesterday that it expected sales to be flat to lower in the fourth quarter and next year. But the company also said it was thinking of selling off major parts of its business. The stock had a small gain, rising 50 cents, to $12.25.

Treasury Prices Rise
By Reuters
Bond prices edged up yesterday as investors walked on eggshells ahead of a Supreme Court decision that could end five weeks of legal squabbles over the presidency.
Treasuries came under mild pressure in morning trading as dealers took profits after a powerful run-up in prices in recent weeks.
But players squared up positions ahead of reports on consumer spending and inflation scheduled to be released later this week, which are expected to point to further evidence of a slowing economy.
The price of the 10-year Treasury note gained 3/32, to 103 1/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.34 percent from 5.36 percent. The 30-year bond rose 3/32, to 110 12/32. Its yield fell to 5.53 percent from 5.54 percent.

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

ASIA
 
AFGHANISTAN: U.N. AIDES PULL OUT
Eight United Nations officials have left Kabul for security reasons, fearing a violent reaction if the organization goes ahead with an American and Russian request to hit Afghanistan with more sanctions. The proposed curbs include an arms embargo against the Taliban, without a similar ban on opposition forces. Barry Bearak (NYT)
 
SRI LANKA: READY FOR PEACE
The government announced that it was prepared to begin peace talks with the separatist Tamil Tigers, but rejected demands to lift an economic embargo on rebel-controlled areas. It also said there would be no immediate de-escalation of the military campaign as a predicate for negotiations. Barry Bearak (NYT) 

INDIA: PARLIAMENT TIE-UP ENDS
Seven days of paralysis in Parliament has ended with the nation's political parties agreeing to a debate about contentious plans to build a temple on the ruins of a destroyed mosque in Ayodhya. Opposition legislators have been furious with remarks by Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee, above, in support of the temple construction. Barry Bearak (NYT)
 
JAPAN: EMPEROR FOUND GUILTY
Closing a symbolic trial of Japan's World War II leaders, a mock tribunal found the late Emperor Hirohito guilty for his army's policy of systematically forcing Asian women into sexual slavery. "Superiors can be responsible for the acts of their subordinates if they'd known or should have known that these acts had been committed," said Gabrielle Kirk McDonald, one of four judges at the Women's International War Crimes Tribunal. (AP)
 
KOREAS: NORTH AND SOUTH MEET
High-level government negotiators from South and North Korea met to set the tone for future relations between the two former adversaries. In Pyongyang, Unification Minister Pak Chae Kyu of South Korea told his counterpart, Chon Gum Jin, that there was a perception that North Korea was not improving relations as quickly as promised. Both sides will open full talks today. (AP)
 
EUROPE
 
BRITAIN: TIES TO NORTH KOREA
Britain and North Korea agreed to establish diplomatic relations, and Foreign Secretary Robin Cook said the decision was "taken in recognition of the significant progress" in the dialogue between the two Koreas. In a sign of its opening up to the outside world, Pyongyang has this year already established formal ties with Canada, Italy and Australia. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
TURKEY: U.S. CLOSES CONSULATES
The United States closed its consulates in Istanbul and the southern city of Adana for what an embassy official in Ankara said were security reviews. The official declined to say what led to the review or whether there had been a specific threat. The embassy remained open because it is considered more secure. American officials have expressed concern recently about possible attacks sponsored by the exiled Saudi Osama bin Laden, who Washington believes was behind the 1998 bombings of its embassies in Kenya and Tanzania. Douglas Frantz (NYT)
 
TURKEY: A POLICE PROTEST
About 3,000 policemen marched through Istanbul to protest the overnight ambush of a police bus that killed two officers and injured 12. Waving guns and chanting slogans, the police demanded better protection and tougher sanctions against criminals. The attack on the bus occurred in a neighborhood where the police clashed last week with protesters opposed to moving inmates to small-cell prisons from the current dormitory-style rooms in Turkish prisons. Douglas Frantz (NYT)
 
FRANCE: LAWYERS STRIKE
Courts ground to a virtual standstill as 35,000 lawyers staged a nationwide strike to demand more pay for providing legal aid to the poor. "It's the first time in history," said Francis Teitgen, a spokesman for Paris lawyers. Mr. Teitgen attacked the government for failing to offer more money and said Britain's budget for free legal advice was 10 times larger than France's. (Reuters)
 
SWITZERLAND: MAD COW MOVE
Reacting to the growing number of cases of mad cow disease in surrounding countries, Switzerland has banned the sale of meat and bone meal from its livestock. Such animal-based feed is suspected of spreading the disease to people. The ban, starting January, will affect some 100,000 tons of feed a year, most of which has been exported to Denmark, Germany and the Netherlands. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)
 
GERMANY: HELP FOR IMMIGRANTS
Germany's commissioner for foreigners announced a $282 million annual program for immigrants and said integration had been an area neglected in the past. The program puts special emphasis on language courses and measures for helping new arrivals, with migrants to be given a voucher for 600 hours of German lessons and tuition in living skills. Victor Homola (NYT)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
PERU: REBEL GIVES UP
Capt. Ollanta Humala Tasso of the army, who mutinied and fled into the Andes with a band of soldiers two months ago to protest the corruption of the armed forces, said he is giving up his rebellion. The officer has requested a meeting with the interim president, Valentin Paniagua, and said he is ready to face justice. Clifford Krauss (NYT)
 
TRINIDAD: ELECTION VICTORY
Prime Minister Basdeo Panday's governing United National Congress gained a narrow victory in Trinidad's parliamentary election, but the opposition appeared set to begin a legal challenge. Mr. Panday's party won 19 seats and former Prime Minister Patrick Manning's People's National Movement gained 16 seats. But Mr. Manning said his party would file court documents challenging the candidacies of two Congress winners. (Reuters)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAQ: TROOPS WITHDRAWN
Iraqi troops have withdrawn from positions they took in a weekend incursion into a Kurd-controlled part of northern Iraq, Kurds in the region said. Kurdish factions have controlled most of northern Iraq since Baghdad was defeated in the 1991 gulf war. The Kurdish enclave is protected by American and British jets that enforce a no-flight zone over northern Iraq. No fighting was reported in the incursion. (Agence France-Presse)
 
AFRICA
 
GHANA: RUNOFF SET
The opposition candidate John Kufuor and John Atta Mills of the governing National Democratic Congress will meet on Dec. 28 in a runoff in the presidential election, the electoral commission said. Its chairman also gave the final results of the Dec. 7 election, in which no candidate won an outright majority. Mr. Kufuor of the New Patriotic Party polled 48.35 percent of the vote, with 44.85 percent for Mr. Mills. (Reuters)
 
BURUNDI: INTERNATIONAL AID
International donors meeting in Paris agreed to grant Burundi some $440 million in relief, reconstruction and development aid, the World Bank announced. The announcement came at the close of a two-day conference led by South Africa's former president, Nelson Mandela. He has been mediating peace efforts in Burundi, laid waste after seven years of civil war. (Agence France-Presse)
 
IVORY COAST: COUNTING BALLOTS
President Laurent Gbagbo's Ivoirian Popular Front will be the dominant force in the new Parliament after Sunday's general election, but with no absolute majority will be forced to work with the former governing party. Latest results give the Front 91 seats in the 225-seat Parliament and the Democratic Party 70 seats. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Medical Journal Bars Authors' Prepublication Comments

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN 

 BODY:
In a move that renews debate about when new research findings should be disclosed to the public, The Journal of the American Medical Association has tightened its rules about what scientists and research institutions can say before their results are published.
Authors "must not participate in press conferences or issue press releases before publication," the journal said, and authors "must refrain from granting interviews" about their findings unless journalists agree to hold the information until after the journal publishes it. Also, authors were admonished not to tell other people that they had submitted a manuscript to the journal. 
 The policy comes at a time when proponents of electronic publishing and the Internet are challenging traditional print scientific journals to allow speedier dissemination of research findings. The restrictions and embargoes that journals have imposed on their contents in recent years have created a contentious issue between journalists, who contend that the measures restrict the gathering of news in a timely way, and journal editors, who say their scrutiny protects the public from misleading information.
The new rules revise a 1991 policy that said the journal preferred that new findings be released to the public at the time they were published. Dr. Catherine D. DeAngelis, the journal's top editor, said that in making the change she was simply detailing what has been a working but largely unwritten policy in recent years. Dr. DeAngelis said the clarification was necessary so that "people understand" the rules. The journal is one of a group of publications owned by the American Medical Association, the largest doctors' organization in the country.
Dr. George D. Lundberg, Dr. DeAngelis's predecessor, who was dismissed as editor of the journal, said in an interview that "the use of the word 'must' in this context sounds far more proscriptive than the practice we maintained at JAMA in the 1990's." Dr. Lundberg, who wrote the 1991 policy, also said that "this seems heavy handed and could intimidate authors, especially younger investigators."
There are four exceptions to the journal's new policy, which are rarely needed, Dr. DeAngelis said in an interview. They are: presentations at scientific meetings; testimony before government agencies; clinical alerts issued by the National Institutes of Health; and urgent public health information.
Many scientists who submit manuscripts believe "they are on to something that is the most important thing since sliced bread, and they want it out there," Dr. DeAngelis said.
"Fine," she added, "put it out there, but don't submit it to JAMA."
JAMA and a few other journals have begun to post such articles on their Web site. Dr. DeAngelis said she was "very confident" that her policy would "never hurt the public."
Referring to journals that restricted what scientists could say before their papers were published, Dr. Edward J. Huth, a former editor of the Annals of Internal Medicine, said that he had long felt that such journals "were basically looking after economic self-interest."
Indeed, such restrictions have helped vastly increase profits for journal owners that include professional organizations like the American Medical Association. The restrictions are often referred to as the Ingelfinger rule after Dr. Franz Ingelfinger, who imposed them when he was editor of The New England Journal of Medicine. Dr. Ingelfinger said that he imposed restrictions to protect his journal's newsworthiness and economic self-interest. Many journals that have adopted the rule do not disclose their profits or what they do with them.
JAMA's new policy contrasts sharply with two editorials the journal published in 1981 that criticized the Ingelfinger rule and the "buttoned-lip syndrome" that reporters encountered at scientific meetings. The 1981 editorials were not cited in the new policy.
The journal's new policy appears in the same issue as a paper from a team headed by Dr. Cary P. Gross of Yale that analyzed the use of a stroke-preventing operation for patients in seven states after the release of information about the procedure in clinical alerts, scientific meetings and published reports. The surgery rates increased significantly and inappropriately after the alert's release but slowed after the publication of the studies. Among the possible reasons cited for the pattern was that one published study contained caveats not included in the alert.
However, the scientific leader of one of the studies declined to answer questions at a news conference in 1994 because his team was submitting a paper to JAMA.
"It does not make sense to do this halfway," Dr. Gross said in an interview.
"We need to find more effective ways to disseminate information, because the current system is not working efficiently," he said, to allow patients and doctors quick access to full details.

HEADLINE: Navy Sets Referendum for 2001 on Puerto Rican Test Range

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 12

 BODY:
Residents of the Puerto Rican island of Vieques will vote on Nov. 6, 2001, on whether to oust the United States Navy from their island, which has been used for decades as a bombing range and base for war games, officials said today.
Navy Secretary Richard Danzig set the date for the long-promised referendum in a letter to Gov. Pedro Rossello on Monday. For the first time, the Navy will ask the 9,300 residents of Vieques whether they want the Navy base on the island. 
 The Vieques bombing range became the object of protests after a civilian security guard was killed in a botched bombing run there in April 1999.
Dozens of protesters occupied the Vieques Navy base for more than a year, forcing a halt to live-fire training. The federal authorities forcibly removed them last May, and the Navy resumed war games in October.
Residents say more than a half-century of military exercises on the island have threatened their health, stunted the island's economic growth and damaged marine life and air quality.
The Navy has argued that the hilly, 33,000-acre island off Puerto Rico's east coast is the only place it can properly conduct simultaneous land, sea and air exercises and is essential to battle readiness.
Under a deal between Governor Rossello and the White House, the Navy was allowed to continue training with inert ammunition on Vieques for three years, and residents would hold a referendum to decide if they wanted the Navy to leave the island by May 1, 2003.
In his letter to Governor Rossello, Mr. Danzig said that at least 90 days before the November referendum, the Navy would submit the language to be used on a second option, which would permit indefinite Navy training with live fire.
The second option carries with it a $50 million incentive through economic development projects in the community.
An additional $40 million is being spent before the vote, under the accord brokered with the White House.
Mr. Danzig also sent a letter to Gov.-elect Sila Calderon of the pro-commonwealth Popular Democratic Party, warning that unless her administration supported the White House agreement, the Navy would not be obliged to follow it.
In her campaign for governor, Ms. Calderon promised to quickly enact tougher noise regulations that would ban Navy shelling of Vieques. The regulations would become effective six months after passage.
"The transfer of land and many of the projects cannot go forward without your assurance that your administration will fully support the agreement," Mr. Danzig wrote to Ms. Calderon.
The governor-elect, who takes office in January, was on vacation and could not be reached for immediate comment today.
The letter was made public today by Governor Rossello at a news conference.
"This should come as no surprise to anyone," Governor Rossello said of Mr. Danzig's letter. "If she doesn't abide by the agreement, then in essence there is no agreement."
