HEADLINE: BUSINESS TO BUSINESS;
The Internet Gives Corporate Banking a Do-It-Yourself Look

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE 

 BODY:
ANYONE can be a travel agent, stock trader or retailer, thanks to the Internet. Now companies are becoming their own bankers as well, turning to online transactions or Web marketplaces that limit, or even eliminate, a traditional banker's role between buyer and seller. That can cut into the services that have defined corporate banking for generations.
Automakers, large retailers and industrial companies have had banking or finance operations for years to help underwrite customer purchases, raise capital or support other credit functions. Analysts predict that other corporations will become their own banks, using outside institutions for only the most complex financial transactions. 
 Banking has never truly been about finance, say those who are remaking the staid world of corporate banking. It has been about access to information about finance. The Internet allows information to flow instantly between the parties in a transaction. Earlier systems had built-in delays because of mail, fax or phone delivery, and multiple levels of management needed to approve payment.
Using open Internet standards, participants can revise an invoice anywhere a Web connection exists. Invoices become a work-in-progress, subject to changes and, potentially, resolutions. On the Web, corporate controllers receive last-minute reports on dozens of accounts, which a decade ago might have required multiple phone calls.
The change allows controllers to reclaim "float," the interest on bills that have not been paid and that used to require weeks to collect. They can accumulate balances across a corporation's various divisions, to earn higher interest rates. And they have greater control about releasing payments.
"The typical treasury can save 25 or 30 percent in cross-border transactions that can cost a company anywhere from $15 to $30 each," said Octavio Lorente, the chief executive of Celent Communications, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass. "And every dollar the company saves represents a dollar out of the bank's profits. It's strictly an information-based function that you really no longer have to pay for if you choose to create an internal, virtual bank."
Over the last few years, nonbank companies, like Ariba Inc., CommerceOne Inc. and BankServ have devised alternative ways for companies to make transactions. Companies can use their software to send transactions through the Automated Clearing House network in North America or the Swift system in Europe, both of which process electronic payments. Other companies are performing functions handled previously by banks, including credit checks, foreign currency trading and credit card and check processing.
In late 1998, Hamilton Sundstrand, the aerospace manufacturing division of the United Technologies Corporation, began a program using NetTransact -- a Web-based system that allows companies to present billing information and receive payments electronically -- to send secure invoices to clients. The company used the system to share and monitor invoices with clients instantly around the world. Other corporations like Nabisco and Frito-Lay used the system, which was initially developed by the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
"We can capture savings in invoicing, accounts receivable, collections and cash flow all at the same time," said Thomas Rogan, the chief financial officer of Hamilton Sundstrand, based in Windsor Locks, Conn. "In the aerospace industry, we have relatively few customers -- these are companies like Boeing Corporation or American Airlines -- and they don't hold up payments because they're short of cash. But they won't pay if they don't get the right part and the right paper in the right place at the right time."
Instead of waiting 30 to 60 days to learn about problems with an invoice, Mr. Rogan added, the company can get a response, fix the problem and collect payment before it becomes delinquent. That has repercussions for logistics, finance, manufacturing and departments working together, said Barbara Macy, the manager of financial electronic commerce at Hamilton Sundstrand.
The company has not yet identified the total savings from its online initiatives, but in the two years the company has used NetTransact, it reported a 10 percent reduction in its daily outstanding sales, a measure of corporate receivables. Hamilton Sundstrand has a small number of invoices compared with other firms, Mr. Rogan said, with average sales of $5,000 to $10,000. He predicted that if only 20 percent of customers participated, the company could speed up collection of as much as 80 percent of its receivables. Another benefit was the opportunity to convert a paper trail, confirming delivery of the company's goods, to an electronic platform because many of its buyers and suppliers already exchange data electronically.
"Our customers seem more willing to contact us, and the communications channels have widened," Ms. Macy said. "Many of our international customers pay by wire transfer, and that can cost $35 or $45 per transaction. Plus our customers can print out the paperwork and get processed for customs payments or transportation. That represents both a cost saving and time saving."
Turning the presentation of billing information and payment into an interactive process is changing a system that has relied on trust since its beginnings. Ninety percent of the estimated 12 billion business-to-business billing transactions in North America are done on paper, with about 10 percent handled electronically, said Joseph Mullen, the chief operating officer at Bottomline Technologies Inc., a company in Portsmouth, N.H., that acquired NetTransact from Northern Trust.
Mr. Mullen said the online invoice system was comparable to programs that allow packages to be tracked online. Using NetTransact, both parties can discuss discounts or changes. United Technologies invested $10 million in Bottomline Technologies and has expanded its system to other operations.
"We estimate that 30 percent of invoicing is incorrect," Mr. Mullen said. "If clients say, 'There's a mistake, I'm not paying until you correct it,' then an astute executive knows this system is about getting paid faster. Companies don't keep money in a safe within their offices. Instead of competing with a trusted financial institution, they want to find ways to cooperate with them. The bank may lose its lockbox business, but will find new services to provide."
Banking services are becoming a commodity, said Stephen Franco, a managing director at U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray, an equities research firm in San Francisco. Conservative bankers, reluctant to adapt to new technology, are being forced to reckon with the Net and its ability to speed up processes, cut costs and improve services.
"The bank's role as a gatekeeper is ending," Mr. Franco said. "Right now, there are different companies working on escrow services, credit, authentication and other services. Banks have won their clients' trust over the past 100 years. And large corporations have multiple banks for the same reasons they have multiple suppliers -- they don't want to be held captive. Today's banks will be marginalized if they let it happen."

HEADLINE: Mississippi Urged to Drop Stars and Bars From Its Flag

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 12

 BODY:
A state commission recommended today that Mississippi hold a referendum next year and vote to eliminate a Confederate symbol from the state's flag.
The 17-member biracial commission, appointed by Gov. Ronnie Musgrove, said the state could heal old wounds by eliminating the Confederate battle flag from the state flag's top left corner. The recommendation will be forwarded to the Legislature, which convenes on Jan. 2. 
 "I'm elated this day has finally arrived," said State Senator David L. Jordan, a civil rights leader. "We don't need to draw lines and be polarized over an emblem."
But John Thomas Cripps, who plans to run for governor in three years on a Southern heritage platform, described the commission's recommendation as "political correctness" that was "at the expense of history."
Governor Musgrove, a first-term Democrat, appointed the commission this summer to consider new flag designs. Mr. Musgrove acted after the State Supreme Court ruled that, technically, the current state flag had no official standing, because the 1894 law so designating it was repealed in 1906, although apparently inadvertently.
The commission held a series of hearings characterized by death threats against several members and bitter disputes between blacks and whites in attendance.
In the end, the commissioners proposed a design in which the Confederate symbol would be replaced by a red box bearing 20 stars, representing, in part, Mississippi's admission to the Union as the 20th state. But they also recommended that the matter be put to a referendum, a compromise intended to accommodate backers of the current flag, who expect large numbers of Mississippi's white majority to turn out in support.
The recommendation was adopted today by voice vote. The only dissent among the 17 commissioners came from a black member who opposed the referendum.
Only one other state has the Confederate battle flag in the design of its state flag. That is Georgia, where black political and civic leaders have pushed for a similar change.
In South Carolina, the Legislature agreed this year to remove the Confederate battle flag from atop the Statehouse. But that state remains under an economic boycott led by the N.A.A.C.P., because rather than removing the battle flag entirely, the lawmakers, in a compromise, repositioned it to a spot in front of the Statehouse.
Here in Jackson, supporters of a new flag design hinted that the boycott being waged in South Carolina could be duplicated in Mississippi.
One black member of the commission, Representative Edward Blackmon Jr., said that if Mississippi voters defeated the new flag, "the economic and public relations consequences will be disastrous."

HEADLINE: ARTS IN AMERICA;
A Glass Half Full: The Potter as Prodigious Pragmatist

BYLINE: By Jo Thomas 

DATELINE: CLEVELAND

 BODY:
When Eleanor Roosevelt first saw Viktor Schreckengost's "Jazz" bowl, a ceramic punch bowl in an electric shade of turquoise that celebrates and pokes fun at night life in New York, she was so delighted that she commissioned two more.
Since then millions of Americans have seen and used Mr. Schreckengost's designs without ever knowing his name: bicycles, dinnerware, riding mowers, lawn chairs and those small cars and fire engines children pedaled on the sidewalk in the 1940's and 50's. 
 The work of Mr. Schreckengost, a pioneer in industrial design, went on display at the Cleveland Museum of Art on Nov. 12 in an exhibition that will continue through Feb. 4.
Shortly before the show opened, Mr. Schreckengost, who is now 94, arrived to see how the installation was going. "I think people will ask, 'Why did you do so many different things?' " he said as he gazed at the profusion of objects. "But, why not?"
Most of his relatives were potters, with some exceptions like Ossee Schreckengost, who was a catcher for the old Philadelphia Athletics and was mentioned in the Frank Sinatra movie "Take Me Out to the Ball Game." His father worked for the French China Company in Sebring, Ohio, and Viktor, who worked there through high school, decided never to become a potter, enrolling instead at the Cleveland Institute of Art to study cartooning. But when he saw modern Viennese ceramics in 1929 he decided to make ceramic sculpture his life's work.
After graduation he went to Vienna to study with Michael Powolny, then returned to Cleveland as the youngest teacher at the Institute of Art and as a designer for Cowan Pottery, where he made the "Jazz" bowl, now an Art Deco classic, in 1930.
For inspiration he drew on memories of a stroll uptown from Times Square to the Cotton Club in Harlem then down to Radio City Music Hall, and the bowl depicts skyscrapers awash with stars, bubbles, bottles and blue light. Its revelers are oblivious to Prohibition and half expecting a hangover.
He sent the bowl and a bill for $50 to the company that ordered it. Then Mrs. Roosevelt sent a check and an order for two more bowls, one for her home in Hyde Park and one for the White House. She was certain that her husband would win the presidency in the 1932 election.
In December 1931 Cowan Pottery folded and Mr. Schreckengost began to design dinnerware for restaurants. The lower-priced restaurants wanted cups in which coffee cooled rapidly, allowing a quicker turnover. Nightclubs wanted cups that would keep the coffee hot, so paying customers would linger. The Statler Hotel chain, which was selling beer for five cents a glass, wanted mugs that did not hold much, so Mr. Schreckengost designed one with a bottom that extended halfway up the mug.
In 1932 he designed what was perhaps the first line of modern dinnerware for American hotels and restaurants, "Econo-Rim," for Onandaga Pottery in Syracuse. He reduced the width of the rim on the plates and increased the capacity of the well, making it possible to serve what appeared to be a larger meal on a smaller plate.
In the same year Mr. Schreckengost also changed the look of the American truck. Ray Spiller, chief engineer of the White Motor Company in Cleveland and the husband of one of his students, asked him to design a truck in which the engine would sit under the cab.
Back then the length of a truck was limited by law to 42 feet. Mr. Schreckengost's final design took five feet off the front of the truck and added five feet to the hauling area. With the money to be earned with extra cargo space, the entire truck could be paid for in a single year.
Later Mr. Schreckengost designed toy vehicles that children could actually drive: pedal cars and trucks, fire engines and racing cars, all made to fit the proportions of children measured in homes, hospitals and playgrounds, long before the age of ergonomics.
Later Mr. Schreckengost reasoned that the appeal of pedal toys could be extended to lawn mowers, and in 1969 he began to design riding lawn mowers for both the Murray Ohio Company and the Craftsman brand of Sears, one like a tractor and one like a golf cart.
He also designed bicycles for Murray, which sold millions of them under as many as 108 different labels for Sears, Roebuck and Company, Western Auto and later Kmart and Wal-Mart Stores Inc. His first bicycle, the Mercury, streamlined with sculptured chrome, was exhibited at the 1939 World's Fair in New York.
Henry Adams, the curator of American painting at the Cleveland Museum, writes in the catalogue for this exhibition that the phrase "industrial design" was not coined until 1927. That was the year Henry Ford abruptly shut down production of the Model T to retool for the more visually appealing Model A at a cost of $18 million in what one observer called "the most expensive art lesson in history."
"An amazing number of objects that we handle every day did not exist until about a century ago," Mr. Adams says. "Other things, while they existed, are utterly different from those used for most of human history. Few changes in human history have been so far-reaching and momentous as this change in 'ordinary objects.' "
Mr. Schreckengost founded the design department at the Cleveland Institute of Art in the 1920's and taught several famous automotive designers, including Joe Oros, designer of the 1965 Ford Mustang.
One morning recently before going to see the current show, Mr. Schreckengost offered a critique to students who were designing tables and chairs. "Instead of getting it up to scale," he said, "they were down to a quarter-size. There is no way anybody could determine whether a table's worth a damn down at that size."
One of his best-known designs is the metal Beverly Hills lawn chair of 1941. In preparation he cut a barrel down to the right height, put a mound of soft clay covered with plastic on top, and, he said, "stood outside the dining room and offered everyone a chit for a drink if they'd sit down on it."
"I had 428 fannies sit on that. Then I took it right in and made a mold off of it. If you sit on it, it's wonderful."

HEADLINE: A Tale of Two Germanys;
Gunter Grass on His New Book and His 'Strenuous Homeland'

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: CASAIS, Portugal

 BODY:
As a late autumn sun warms the red tiles of Gunter Grass's getaway here, northern Germany could not seem farther away. Yet even in this isolated corner of southern Portugal, where the author escaped a year ago to prepare his Nobel address to the Swedish Academy, where he vacations every summer with his grandchildren, where he now fills his afternoons painting watercolors, Mr. Grass never quite leaves Germany.
His "strenuous homeland," as he likes to call it, is the principal theme of his literature. It is his favorite topic of conversation. It is also the frequent target of his wrath. 
 Germany, of course, is no less haunted by Mr. Grass. Since the publication of "The Tin Drum" in 1959 turned him into a household name at the age of 32, he has gone out of his way to lecture, even hector, his fellow Germans on their past and present failings. He has done so in novels, plays and essays as well as in political speeches and newspaper articles. And all too often he has said what many people did not want to hear.
When his latest novel, "Ein Weites Feld," was published in German in 1995, he provoked a fresh scandal by portraying German unification in 1990 as West Germany's de facto occupation of East Germany. Naturally, Mr. Grass was unrepentant. Indeed, attacks on the book -- including a photograph on the cover of Der Spiegel, the mass circulation news weekly, showing a well-known literary critic tearing up the novel -- helped sales reach 350,000 in one year.
Five years later, with the book finally appearing in the United States under the title "Too Far Afield" (Harcourt), this 1999 Nobel laureate in literature feels further vindicated: he believes that time has proved him right.
"The reality is much darker than I presented it," said Mr. Grass, 73, peering over half-moon glasses and puffing on his trademark pipe. "The wall has gone, but Germany is still divided. People in the East were happy in 1989 when the wall came down, but then the West Germans arrived like colonizers. They didn't accept that the East Germans had a different biography, that they had gone from Hitler to Stalin, that they had never had a democratic experience."
"They had to live their own lives," he went on. "But West Germans said: 'Forget about it. It was all a mistake. Now do as we did in the West and you will be happy.' But we didn't know each other and we still don't know each other. The ignorance in the West makes it very difficult. Further, West Germany now owns East Germany. This is a terrible kind of colonization, and it will go on. So what I try to show in my novel is how it began, its criminal beginnings."
In its central political message, the 658-page book targets Treuhand, the government body charged with privatizing or shutting down thousands of East German companies after unification. Translated in English as the Handover Trust, it is presented in "Too Far Afield" as a heartless instrument of capitalism that put millions of East Germans out of work and handed over the economic remnants of the Communist regime to avaricious West German investors.
"Treuhand worked for four years without any democratic control," Mr. Grass said.
The novel's literary embrace, however, is far wider. At one level, it tells its story through two former East German government workers: Theo Wuttke, erudite, eccentric and dreamy, who had been a guide and a lecturer at the Cultural Union; and Ludwig Hoftaller, Wuttke's "day-and-night shadow," who had worked as a spy for the Stasi. Both now 70, they end up with jobs in the Handover Trust.
But the novel also works on other levels. Wuttke, for instance, is not only an expert on the 19th-century historian and novelist Theodor Fontane (who is referred to here only as "The Immortal"), but he also identifies with Fontane to the point of being known as Fonty and of frequently reliving this writer's life. Hoftaller's personality, on the other hand, merges with that of Tallhover, a 19th-century spy for the Prussian empire and its successor, the Second Reich.
Mr. Grass, in turn, uses Fontane-Wuttke and Tallhover-Hoftaller and their collective memories to lead readers through Germany's convulsed history from its first unification in 1871 to its second unification in 1990. Some of this is symbolized by the Treuhand headquarters in former East Berlin. Built for the Nazis' Air Ministry, it was called the House of Ministries under Communism and, after Treuhand had done its work, it became the country's new Finance Ministry.
Reviewing "Too Far Afield" in The New York Times Book Review on Nov. 5, James J. Sheehan described it as "a quieter, gentler book" than "The Tin Drum" and "far more interesting and accessible" than Mr. Grass's "self-indulgent" novels of the 1970's and 80's. "It is the work of a seasoned craftsman," he wrote, "certain of what he wants to do, completely in control of his gifts."
At center stage throughout the book is Berlin, a city that was home to Mr. Grass for 35 years until he moved to Lubeck, a northern city, in 1995. During his long years in West Berlin, he rarely visited the East: he was declared persona non grata there after the publication of his 1966 play, "The Plebeians Rehearse the Uprising," about the 1956 workers' revolt in East Berlin. Then, when the wall came down, he immediately began traveling in East Germany.
"I had always believed in the possibility of unification, but from the beginning, I said we have to go slowly and carefully," he recalled. "But Helmut Kohl was interested only in winning the 1990 election. East Germany had paid more for the lost war than West Germany. We had the Marshall Plan, freedom, a mild occupation. They had the Soviet Union. We had to share the burden. But Kohl was afraid of raising taxes. So we destroyed the East German economy."
Even here, sipping white wine on the shaded terrace of his Portuguese home overlooking an empty valley 10 miles from the Atlantic coast, this writer never lets go. He denounces Germany for turning away asylum-seekers. He accuses mainstream German politicians of encouraging the extreme right by criticizing immigration from the third world. He also worries that younger German writers do not speak out.
"The line for young writers is, 'Don't touch politics,' " he said. " 'Only tell your story. Look to American literature.' Many young writers are influenced by American writers, not always the best. And they are afraid to touch political problems. Then they are astonished when they are victims of political developments. For me, politics is a terribly important part of reality. If I ignore it, that is also a political action."
Unlike many younger writers, of course, Mr. Grass has had his own life shaped -- or rather misshapen -- by politics. Born in 1927 in the port of Danzig (now Gdansk in Poland), he was 12 when the city was incorporated into the Third Reich in 1939. Like other children, he was a member of the Hitler Youth and, at 16, was recruited into the army, only to be captured in 1945 and held prisoner for almost a year. He was then released into a devastated Germany.
His first dream was to become a sculptor, but when he sought entry into the fine arts academy in Dusseldorf, a friendly professor told him to return a year or two later. "The school had no coal for heating, so he told me to find a job as a stone mason," Mr. Grass recalled. "It was very good advice: not to begin with artwork but with gravestones. They are always needed. Also, the farmers would pay for the gravestones with potatoes or half a pig, so we had food."
Finally he was able to study art, first in Dusseldorf, then in Berlin, where he joined an avant-garde circle known as Gruppe 47. It was also in Berlin that Mr. Grass first tried his hand at poetry.
"Then one of the older writers of Group 47 said to me, 'You have to stop playing the artist, you have to be confronted with some resistance to find what you really have to write about,' " he said. "I told him about my background in Danzig and he said, 'Write about it.' I had never thought about writing a novel. It will be my first and last novel, I presumed."
The result was the picaresque "Tin Drum," which with his subsequent "Cat and Mouse" and "Dog Years" became known as the Danzig Trilogy and established Mr. Grass as the foremost German writer of his generation. No less significantly, in "The Tin Drum," through the testimony of 3-year-old Oskar Matzerah, who stopped growing, Mr. Grass revived the specter of the Nazi years in a Germany that was eager to forget.
Since then, Mr. Grass's life has consisted of a long battle against political amnesia. He accepts his own guilt for the past ("I belonged to the Hitler Youth and I believed in its aims up to the end of the war") but recognizes that a problem arises with many young Germans. "I see this with my own children and grandchildren," he said. "I tell them, 'You are not guilty, but you have to take care that things like that never happen again.' That's all. And that's enough. They have the memory."
In the angry debate that preceded the recent decision to build a Holocaust memorial in Berlin, unsurprisingly, Mr. Grass also had an opinion: he was opposed to a memorial dedicated only to Hitler's Jewish victims.
"They are separating the Jews, just as the Nazis did," he said. "It is a mistake. There should be a memorial to all the victims of the Nazis; Jews, of course, but also 500,000 Gypsies, hundreds of thousands of Poles and Russians, everyone."
Ever the maverick, always the outsider, Mr. Grass is, of course, used to being impugned. "It's fun for some critics to attack me," he said with a chuckle. Indeed, when he finally won the Nobel Prize in literature (he had long been a contender), it was also read as an endorsement of his political bluntness. "In public debate, he is a source of strength and of irritation," the Swedish Academy noted admiringly.
For Mr. Grass, though, the Nobel Prize was a reward for a lifetime of writing, from "The Tin Drum" to "Too Far Afield." Further, he observed, he has always firmly rejected the idea that a writer can serve as a nation's conscience.
"You cannot delegate your conscience to writers or anyone else," he said. "I don't speak out because I am a writer. My profession is a writer, but I speak out because I am a citizen. I think the Weimar Republic collapsed and the Nazis took over in 1933 because there were not enough citizens. That's the lesson I have learned. Citizens cannot leave politics just to politicians."

HEADLINE: Irish Peat Company Adapts to Change

BYLINE: By BRIAN LAVERY 

DATELINE: DUBLIN, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Of all the economic changes taking place in Ireland, few are as dramatic as the ones occurring at the national institution known for supplying peat.
For 50 years, Bord na Mona has provided bricks of the dried plant matter, cut from the ground of Irish bogs, to power plants that burn it to generate electricity. 
 Despite the opening of a $110 million peat-fired plant late last month, however, peat may soon lose its age-old status as Ireland's favorite fuel. Such operations are losing ground to cheaper and more efficient alternatives, like gas-fired power plants and wind farms. Only a handful of other peat companies operate in Ireland, and they serve small local markets.
Bord na Mona, a state-owned company once reviled by conservationists for destroying ecologically sensitive bogs, has responded by reducing costs sharply; cutting its work force in half, to 2,000; and reorienting itself toward what it says are environmentally friendly peat products.
One traditional product, sphagnum peat moss, sold under the Shamrock brand by the Scotts Company, already makes Bord na Mona Ireland's largest exporter by volume. Each year, it ships 15,000 containers, each 40 feet long, to supply gardens in countries like Britain, France, the Netherlands and the United States.
But it is also exploring new uses for peat, including soaking up offensive factory odors and filtering residential sewage from North Carolina to California. Revenues from environmental products rose 25 percent, to 12.3 million euros ($10.9 million), in the company's last fiscal year.
Still, environmental products accounted for only 9 percent of revenues from peat sales in the year to March 2000, up from 2.3 percent in the 1996 fiscal year. That increase was also partly a result of a decline in sales of other products.
"The big challenge is to grow the environmental business in the U.S.," said Donal Clarke, a Bord na Mona spokesman. "It could be enormous for us."
Bord na Mona recently received regulatory approval for its residential sewage filter, called Puraflo, in several states. Licenses are pending in other states.
Puraflo, which is designed to supplement or replace septic-tank systems, uses peat fiber rather than the soft brown peat bricks sometimes seen blazing in Irish pubs. Peat fiber, from the roots and stems of bog cotton plants, contains microbes that help to clean wastewater.
The market for such systems has just begun to grow, said Martin Hally, president of Bord na Mona's environmental products unit in the United States. The Environmental Protection Agency said in September that peat appears to be more efficient in treating effluent in septic systems than traditional sand filters, though long-term data is not yet available.
Puraflo's advantages over traditional septic systems include a smaller drain field and minimal maintenance, Mr. Hally said.
United States revenues from Puraflo will hit $2.5 million this year. Bord na Mona expects them to pass $4 million in 2001. "We are a very significant player in the market over here," Mr. Hally said.
Bord na Mona already sells environmental products, including Puraflo, in Ireland. In England, it sells peat-based air filters to chemical manufacturers to let them capture odors from their production plants.
Bord na Mona's new interest in the environment is cautiously welcomed by some Irish conservationists. For decades, Bord na Mona acted like an arrogant landowner, with minimal regard for the environment, said Peter Foss, chairman of the Irish Peatland Conservation Council.
But during its restructuring in the early 1990's, Bord na Mona promised not to excavate new bogs, and sold several fragile sites to conservation agencies. It also pledged to rehabilitate bogs into farmland or forest after harvesting the peat.
For some environmentalists, almost anything is better than using peat for fuel. "Taking peat and burning it is the most unecological thing you can do with it," said Dr. Foss.
Diversification has improved Bord na Mona's bottom line as well as its image. The company said in March that its annual profit had increased 35 percent, to a record $12.4 million, on total sales of $174 million. (Bord na Mona also deals in oil and coal.)
European Union rules and the desire for greater competition are pushing the Irish government to privatize most of its companies, This is typically done through a stock market offering.
While Bord na Mona became a public limited company, comparable to a corporation in the United States, in January 1999 to prepare for eventual sale to the public, the government does not intend to sell shares soon, said a government press officer, Richard Moore.
Company officials say they are not worried about stock sales. "We are not concerned as to who our shareholder is," said Mr. Clarke, the Bord na Mona spokesman. "We know which way the wind's blowing."

HEADLINE: Artists vs. Dot-Coms: Fighting San Francisco's Gold Rush

BYLINE: By BILL HAYES 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
ON the evening of Dec. 2, AK Press, an anarchist book publisher, held an eviction party, an increasingly common occasion here. Four years after moving into an unheated warehouse in the Mission District, it had fallen victim to spiraling rents. "Dress warm," the invitation warned. A few blocks away, on newly fashionable Valencia Street, restaurants offered valet parking. But AK Press's guests -- a mix of graying bohemians and magenta-haired young activists -- arrived mostly by bike or by bus.
"We need to live in a neighborhood of political writers, activists and artists," said Craig Gilmore, 50, an AK editor in a waist-length braid and a "Class War!" T-shirt. "Until now, that's been the Mission District. But when our lease is up, our rent will triple, which makes it impossible to stay." 
 When AK Press moved into the warehouse in 1996, the Mission was still a predominantly Latino and working-class neighborhood, dotted with tacquerias and auto-body shops. Today, more than 400 Internet firms are based there and in the adjacent South of Market district, an area which, along with nearby Potrero Hill, has come to be known as Multimedia Gulch.
The dot-com gold rush is blamed for introducing Manhattan-style traffic jams and unwanted development into San Francisco's famously picturesque neighborhoods, while skyrocketing rents drive out artists, cultural groups and working-class families. According to the California Association of Realtors, the median price of a single-family home in San Francisco is now $463,990, a 25.9 percent increase since October 1999. Meanwhile, there are 7.5 evictions a day, according to the San Francisco Tenants Union, an advocacy group.
During the summer, a citywide coalition of artists, activists and nonprofit groups collected 30,000 signatures, 10,000 more than was required, to place an antidevelopment referendum called Proposition L on the November ballot. While the measure would have actually increased the amount of new office space that could be built in the city, it would have banned such development from the Mission and other largely residential neighborhoods. It would also have closed a loophole that allows Internet companies to occupy and construct "live/work lofts," meant for artists, that are exempt from certain development taxes.
Proposition L was defeated by a paper-thin margin of 0.4 percent. A less restrictive slow-growth measure backed by Mayor Willie Brown also failed, leaving San Francisco's current regulations unchanged.
Antidevelopment activists staged more than three dozen rallies in the days leading up to the Nov. 7 election. In one of the campaign's more enduring images, a group of demonstrators calling themselves Art Strikes Back smashed a computer with a baseball bat outside city hall. Oddly enough, many supporters of Proposition L work for dot-coms, and their campaign relied heavily on the Internet to organize meetings and reach voters and the news media.
Mara Brazer, the president of the San Francisco Partnership, a pro-business nonprofit group, defended the dot-com industry, saying that the slow-growth advocates unfairly vilify an industry that helped pull San Francisco out of a punishing recession in the 1990's and created some 40,000 local jobs. "The Internet industry has become a scapegoat," she said, "partly due to a mythology that's built up about young, latte-swilling, S.U.V.-driving dot-com millionaires."
Ms. Brazer predicted that the slowdown in the nation's economy and deflation of the dot-com boom that appear already to be under way will curb city growth. Across the country, dot-com layoffs in November were up 55 percent from October, according to a survey conducted by Challenger, Gray & Christmas, a national employment service.
The slow-growth movement is particularly ardent in San Francisco, Ms. Brazer said, because of its geography. The city is just 47 square miles, and it is bordered on three sides by water, so there is limited room for growth. "Everybody wants to see the city preserved just as it was when they fell in love with it," she said.
Proposition L's defeat does not appear to have ended the movement. Organizers of the measure have been working with sympathetic members of the Board of Supervisors to draft legislation that would accomplish what Proposition L had proposed. "And if that all fails," said Debra Walker, a Mission District painter and co-chairwoman of the "Yes on L" committee, "we're ready to get new signatures and go back as soon as we can on a special election."
On the night of AK Press's eviction party, Susan Schwartzenberg, 49, a photographer, stood on its warehouse's back patio, projecting her photographs of demolished neighborhood landmarks and artists' studios on a cement wall. The images illustrated the book "Hollow City" (Verso), written by Rebecca Solnit. Ms. Schwartzenberg has been evicted twice in the last two years. In 1998, she lost her work studio when an Internet firm leased the entire building. Next month, she will vacate her studio at Market and Seventh Streets -- "the last vestige of skid row," she calls it. The eight-story building was bought by a Michigan-based real-estate development firm.
"The whole flavor of San Francisco is changing so drastically," Ms. Schwartzenberg said. "New condominiums spring up overnight. I remember old bookstores or some curmudgeonly writer who used to live up there and I think: What happened to him? What happened to that bookstore?"

HEADLINE: Honey, They Blew Up The Housewares

BYLINE: By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
AS Edwin Perez described it, he might have been helping an untrained rider onto a stamping horse.
"She was frightened," Mr. Perez, a salesman at Gracious Home on the Upper East Side, said of a recent customer who was looking at a 13-quart Le Creuset enameled cast-iron pot. "By the weight." 
 Mr. Perez's client walked in looking for a pot to make rice in. The French oven, which weighs 23 pounds empty and 49 pounds when topped off with liquid, is the largest piece Le Creuset makes. It might have been designed for potluck at Versailles. "Most people think it's too big," Mr. Perez said. "But where are you going to go with this? A few feet, stove to table. You're not going up stairs with it."
The woman left the store, listing like a boat -- the sink-size pot in a shopping bag.
During the last few years of economic balance, there has been a strange kind of inflation at work in and around the home. Things are getting bigger, and more powerful: houses, cars, furniture . . . toothbrushes. Throughout the local domestic ecology, more is more.
"We do big and bigger; we never do small," said Scott Ballard, a vice president for merchandising at Henredon Furniture Industries, the North Carolina manufacturer that led the parade for furniture's ballooning scale. Its Visage collection includes 4-by-5-foot coffee tables and canopy beds that are nine and a half feet high -- living large, sleeping large.
The American appliance is pumping up. Dumbo -- the new national bird -- has landed. Houses themselves are increasing in size. Last year, 16 percent included three-car garages.
Sports utility vehicles have seized the high road in high-income households. General Motors' Hummer, to be introduced in 2002, will require a commercial truck's running lights because of its width: more than six and a half feet.
Indoors, 14-foot ceilings are increasingly standard, even in the bedroom. And furniture is inflating as fast as it can to close the gap.
"We're following the trend in the construction industry," Mr. Ballard said. "People want these giant places to cocoon -- building up, scaling up. The economy's been good, and people want to show off what they've got." What the cocoon produces -- Henredon's 8-foot-tall, 5-foot-wide silver floor mirror, for instance -- might make a plausible plot development for "Alien 4."
This year, entertainment went big at home too. Pushed by the popularity of newly inexpensive DVD players, the television and the stereo system are transmogrifying quickly into the home theater. Your own personal uniplex -- now appearing in a room near you. What was a 13-inch screen and a boombox is likely to be instead a wide-screen television with a surround-sound 5.1 "home theater in a box" -- a separate audio receiver, five speakers and a sub-woofer.
"The sub-woofer is a low-frequency effects channel," said Maureen Jenson, editor of Home Theater magazine. "You hear the thump, thump, thump of dinosaur feet in 'Jurassic Park.' " You might also think your neighbors are clog-dancing with sofas strapped to their shoes.
"A lot of people buy these systems because they want them to be loud," Ms. Jenson said. "Powerful explosions -- 'Terminator' types. They love home theater."
NPD Intelect, a technology and electronics industry market analyst, reports that $1.3 billion worth of DVD players have been sold in the United States in the last 12 months, and close to $300 million in home theaters in boxes to go with them. Be afraid. Be very afraid.
Appliances in other parts of the house, like the kitchen, are showing bigger biceps too. The new Cuisinart DLC-X Plus is a 20-cup food processor -- that's "soup's on" for a typical family of 14 -- with a one-and-a-half-horsepower motor. Chain saws have two to four horsepower. In a test this week, the Cuisinart chipped a carrot into dust in two seconds.
"Horsepower sells," said Jack Switzer, a manager for the lawn mower division at John Deere. Walk-behind lawn mowers have doubled in horsepower since 1987.
The Cuisinart, six cups larger than the company's largest consumer model, was developed for the food service industry, but is being sold at stores like Bloomingdale's because of its immediate appeal to nonprofessional cooks.
"Retailers see these products at trade shows and say, 'Oh, I can sell that,' " said Mary Rodgers, senior manager of marketing and communications at Cuisinart. "Clients are putting in super-duper kitchens, and they want the super-duper small appliances to go with them."
Popular at Broadway Panhandler is the Waring Mega Pro bartender's blender, which operates at 27,000 rpm -- 10,000 more than a household unit. Making the margaritas will make you dizzier than drinking them. Williams-Sonoma's new item -- a Kenwood standing mixer -- has a seven-quart capacity and a 725-watt motor. Most models have 350 watts. The company also has in the stores a commercial Italian panini grill that heats up to 575 degrees -- that's serious fried bologna.
"People are desperate for power," said Deanna Magrane, a buyer at Broadway Panhandler. "They see it as, 'This is what the professionals use.' They watch the Food Network or Emeril Lagasse or Martha Stewart, and they upgrade to more specialized things." Ms. Magrane said that customers come into the store with tape measures, to be sure cookware like Le Creuset's 13-quarter will fit into their ovens.
Gillette's Braun Oral-B 3D Excel toothbrush, when it arrives in this country from Europe next year, will rest conveniently in conventional American medicine cabinets. But it is not until you turn it on that you will understand its magnitude.
With a brush head that makes 40,000 pulsations a minute (hovering hummingbirds' wings beat 3,000 times during the same minute) and 7,600 simultaneous side-to-side oscillations, the $79.99 plastic speed stick is being positioned as the BMW of the bathroom. Nothing on the market goes faster. Gillette's oral care products represented $16 million in sales last year. "Power brushing" is the fastest-growing segment in the company's portfolio.
Ever hear the expression, "wipe that smile off your face"? It could happen.
The escalation into the bigger, more powerful home could end more quickly than it began. A national recession not withstanding, the beginnings of a revolt might be here.
"There's been a plea for moderation on the part of furniture retailers this season," said Powell Slaughter, an editor at Furniture Today, a trade weekly, speaking of the trend toward larger lifestyles. "They're telling manufacturers, 'At least give us the option of having something normal size.' People in condos, with eight-foot ceilings, can't fit this stuff in the room." Ten-foot-tall beds don't play well in towns like New York.
But Ahn Le, of Lawrenceville, Ga., outside Atlanta, loves her newly installed nine-and-a-half-foot-tall Henredon bed -- even after two days of attempted delivery this week. The first truck wasn't large enough; the second crew was too small. Three struggling men, including Ms. Le's son, who pitched in, finally got it upstairs, but couldn't get it through the door of the 13-foot-tall bedroom.
"My son's girlfriend said, 'It's a huge bed,' " Ms. Le, who is five feet tall, said. "I had just seen it in a catalog.
"I like it even more now," she explained. "It's beautiful. It's king-size."

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Fall as Consumers Turn Cautious

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Retail sales fell in November for the first time in seven months as car sales slumped and demand slowed for many retailers at the start of the holiday shopping season, government figures showed today.
"Retail sales have suddenly fizzled out as worries over heating costs this winter and a stock market decline have suddenly made Americans very cautious," said Chris Rupkey, senior financial economist at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd. in New York. 
 Sales decreased 0.4 percent in November after being unchanged in October, the Commerce Department said. Excluding automobiles, sales rose 0.2 percent, the smallest gain in three months, after a 0.4 percent increase in October.
Personal spending in the fourth quarter is shaping up to be the weakest in a year and a half, prompting General Motors and Whirlpool to cut production and lay off workers. Since November, sales at Wal-Mart Stores have fallen below expectations. And specialty clothing chains like Gap and Abercrombie & Fitch have reduced prices to lure shoppers.
Separate figures from the Labor Department showed that the costs of imported goods are contained. That is impeding the ability of United States companies to raise prices as they strive to stay competitive. Import prices rose 0.2 percent in November after falling 0.5 percent in October. Excluding petroleum, import prices fell 0.1 percent after showing no change a month earlier.
Import prices are 0.5 percent higher over the last 12 months, when the cost of petroleum is excluded. That compares with a 0.2 percent decline for the 12 months ended November 1999.
Sales at auto dealers fell 2.2 percent in November -- the biggest decrease since a 4.9 percent slump in July 1998. In October, auto sales fell 1 percent.
Automakers sold 16.6 million vehicles at an annual rate last month, the slowest pace in a year, even as G.M. lowered prices. That was down from a pace of 16.9 million units in October and the slowest since a 16.6-million-unit pace in October 1999.
Sales at general merchandise stores, which include department stores, fell 0.2 percent after rising 0.5 percent a month earlier. The drop in sales at general merchandise outlets was the largest since a 0.4 percent decrease in May 1999.

HEADLINE: U.S. Panel to Weigh Auction Certificates

 BODY:
A federal judge named two experts yesterday to study a provision allowing Sotheby's Holdings and Christie's to pay $100 million of a $512 million civil antitrust settlement in the form of discount certificates to future auction sellers.
The rest would be paid in cash to about 100,000 auction customers who have sued the two auction houses on charges of price-fixing and other collusion. 
 Judge Lewis A. Kaplan, in United States District Court in Manhattan, said he was appointing the experts to advise the court on the two auctioneers' plan for valuation of the certificates and the competitive consequences of issuing such certificates.
The experts he named are Kenneth G. Elzinga, a professor of economics at the University of Virginia, and Denise Martin of National Economic Research Associates in White Plains. Judge Kaplan asked them to file their report by Jan. 16 and told Sotheby's and Christie's to provide the information they request.
He set Professor Elzinga's fee at $450 an hour and Dr. Martin's fee at $375 an hour, plus expenses.

SECTION: Section A; Page 3; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1141 words

HEADLINE: In China, MSG Is No Headache, It's a New Treat

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Dec. 8

 BODY:
At the upscale market on Wangfujing Street, the can stands proudly, unapologetically on its shelf, beautifully displayed in a clear-fronted white gift box festooned with gold seals, roses and red ribbon. And why not? It is, after all, "the king of Chinese seasonings," the box proclaims.
Soy sauce? Ginger? The spicy pepper that gives Sichuan cooking its zing? Guess again. It is monosodium glutamate, MSG. And in China its popularity is booming. 
 "Recently, consumption has been going up every year," said Wang Jiaqin, vice president of the China Fermentation Industry Association, which tracks MSG use. "Chinese people have gained more understanding of how to use it. They are comfortable with it. And that's why it is now in every home and market."
MSG is a cultural Rorschach test. Mention it to Americans and their minds jump immediately to "Chinese restaurant syndrome," a malady of after-dinner headaches, flushing and dizziness for which MSG has long been blamed. But for Chinese it conjures up different images: mouth-watering stir-fried spinach or the perfect shark's fin soup.
The average Chinese person now eats an estimated 1.3 pounds of MSG a year, Ms. Wang said, six times as much as just a decade ago. And while most people use it as a flavor enhancer, in recent years some have even been touting its healthful effects: some food scientists here say it improves mental alertness, and it is sold in little red packets carrying images of playing children -- as a drink to fight childhood constipation.
Zhang Chen, a senior chef who has worked in some of Beijing fanciest hotels, estimated that more than 95 percent of restaurants and 70 percent of households now use MSG daily, a sign, he said, of China's economic prosperity. And what about the holdouts?
"In poor areas in the countryside, they can't use it because of their low living standard -- I mean they can't even afford meat," he said, sadly shaking his head. "But if the economy develops, they'll be able to try it and see how delicious it makes food, and then they'll surely use it too."
Adding to the allure, MSG is known in Chinese as wei jing, which literally means flavor essence.
Although MSG and Chinese restaurants are inextricably linked in the American psyche, the chemical was actually invented in Japan, where per capita consumption still outstrips that in China. It was first brought to China about a century ago but has only started gaining popularity in the last decade, during China's era of economic reform, since a growing number of Chinese can now afford it.
A derivative of an amino acid already present in the human body, MSG is manufactured by fermenting a variety of grains, including corn, potatoes and rice.
In 1987 the World Health Organization, a United Nations agency, placed MSG in the safest category of food ingredients, along with salt, vinegar and the like. In 1995 the United States Food and Drug Administration concluded that "MSG and related substances are safe food ingredients for most people when eaten at the customary level," although the report acknowledged that some people, especially those with asthma, might have transient symptoms if very large quantities were consumed.
China is today the world's leading producer of MSG, which is mostly sold for cooking. But Chinese factories also use it to make medicine and even a hard candy with a salty taste that is popular in West Africa, Ms. Wang said.
Chefs and other experts here are generally perplexed about the concern that has surrounded MSG in the West. They note that the United Nations removed restrictions on the use of the additive in 1987 and that the F.D.A. labels it as "generally safe."
Mr. Zhang, the chef, who teaches cooking at the Beijing Service and Management School, said that when he worked in Switzerland for a year, he was forbidden to use MSG after a customer fainted at her table. His boss explained that a very small number of Europeans are allergic to MSG, but he remains unconvinced that such an allergy is real.
"I've worked in restaurants since 1963 in China, and I've never heard of such a problem," he said, adding: "Look, this is a very big country, and people eat a lot of MSG. I think if people were getting sick it would be obvious.
"The government researches these things, and a lot of dangerous food additives, colorings and sweeteners are forbidden. But MSG is not among them."
Ms. Wang, 60, an earnest engineer with close-cropped hair, says she has eaten "lots of MSG" for decades without ill effect. "The more you use it, the more you want to add," she said. She falls backs on a conspiracy theory to explain why MSG got its bad reputation in the West.
"I think some restaurant owners were jealous of the good business of Chinese restaurants," she said, "so they started this rumor about MSG."
If people react badly to MSG, she added, it is only because their bodies are not accustomed to it -- noting that most new foods take some getting used to. "Like me, I can't even look at mutton, much less eat it," she said, expressing a common aversion to a meat more associated here with Mongols and other sheepherding minorities than with traditional Chinese fare.
Although there have been occasional articles in the Chinese press concerning possible side effects of MSG -- hair loss has been a big worry -- in recent months a spate of magazine articles and promotional events have touted not only its safety but also its health benefits.
During "MSG Nutrition Promotion Week" this September, an article in the China Light Industry News said: "Chinese pharmaceutical food scholars believe it has health-enhancing and brain-supplementing effects."
"It can strengthen the appetite of the old, the physically feeble, pregnant women and children with poor appetite," the article said, "thereby enhancing nutrition and encouraging improved health."
But experts emphasize that for maximum effect, MSG must be used properly. Mr. Zhang said it should not be eaten by nursing mothers or infants under 3 months old. Ms. Wang said that under age 1, consumption should be "limited a bit."
But she added that for older children, "you can put it in vegetable juice to make it tastier."
"Kids have a very sensitive palate," she said, "so they'll appreciate it."
For now almost all of the 650,000 tons of MSG produced in China is sold domestically for use in cooking. But look out: the China Fermentation Industry Association is holding more promotional activities, and its manual suggests myriad uses -- in food processing, pharmaceuticals, industry and agriculture. (Feed it to pigs -- it will make them grow fatter, quicker!)
"I know that not too many people now use it in America," said Ms. Wang, noting that China hopes to enter the World Trade Organization soon. "We certainly hope to open the American market."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
New Bush Status Does Little To Fuel Sustained Rally

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Although investors awoke yesterday morning with the apparent certainty that the next president had finally been chosen five weeks after the election, there was no celebration for Gov. George W. Bush in the stock market.
While all three major gauges shot higher after trading began, they quickly gave up their gains, with the Nasdaq composite index falling quickly into negative territory. Only the Dow Jones industrial average remained, barely, in the plus column, even though there were reports early in the day that Vice President Al Gore would make a speech in the evening. 
 At the close, the Dow was up 26.17 points, or 0.2 percent, to 10,794.44, after surging 147 points in the morning. The technology-heavy Nasdaq fell 109.00 points, or 3.7 percent, to 2,822.77. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was off 11.19 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,359.99.
There was no immediate Bush rally because investors have been concentrating more on the fact that economic and corporate earnings growth is slowing more sharply than many of them had expected.
That theme was emphasized again yesterday morning when the Commerce Department reported that retail sales dropped an unexpected 0.4 percent in November, the first decline in seven months.
In addition, as the court battles over the Florida vote had continued, it appeared more and more likely that Mr. Bush would win, especially after the Supreme Court stopped the hand-counting of ballots in Florida on Saturday. So many investors had already factored in a Bush victory.
"There are four nagging issues for the stock market," said Thomas M. Galvin, chief investment officer at Credit Suisse First Boston. "Politics, profits, telecom spending and semiconductor inventories. Now I only have an answer on one and the other three will not be quickly resolved. The political crisis was nothing more than a sideshow that created a distraction from a deteriorating economic picture."
Several so-called Bush stocks did rally. These stocks, which include oil, drug and tobacco shares and Microsoft, are expected to do better under a Bush administration than a Gore administration. Pfizer, which rose $1.81, to $45.81, helped curb the loss in the S.& P. 500. Exxon Mobil, up $1.13, to $87.69, and Philip Morris, up $2.50, to $40.81, helped lift the Dow. Mr. Galvin argued that the drug and tobacco stocks were probably helped more by being good defensive plays on a day of new data showing that the economy was slowing.
The Nasdaq was held back by declines in Cisco Systems, Veritas Software, Siebel Systems and Ciena. A late sell-off of Microsoft, whose antitrust battle is expected to fare better under a Bush administration, added to the swoon of the Nasdaq, Dow and S.& P. 500 in the afternoon. After climbing $2.13 early, Microsoft finished down $1.13, to $57.25.
Investors' concerns about the slowing economy were heightened by the retail sales decline and reinforced by disappointing earnings warnings from several companies.
Whirlpool, the appliance maker, said it expected fourth-quarter earnings of about 98 cents a share, roughly 30 percent less than Wall Street estimates, according to First Call/ Thomson Financial. Shares of Whirlpool dropped $2.75, to $41.44.
Compaq Computer's shares were down $2.67, to $18.10. After the stock market closed on Tuesday, Compaq said that it would miss fourth-quarter sales projections by 8 percent to 10 percent while per-share earnings would fall about 8 cents below current projections of 36 cents a share.
And Charles Schwab, the leading online broker, said that it might miss its fourth-quarter earnings forecast of 14 cents a share because of a decline in trading volume and a fall in the value of assets under management.
One measure of the effect of the economic and corporate earnings slowdown versus the uncertainty of the election is how far the three main gauges are still below where they were on Election Day. The Nasdaq is still down the most, off 17 percent since Nov. 7. The S.& P. 500 index is down 5 percent since then and the Dow is off 1 percent.
For investors, the issue going forward is how much slower the economy and corporate earnings might grow and how soon the Federal Reserve will step in to lower interest rates to stem the decline. Fed policy makers next meet on Tuesday. Currently, analysts expect the Fed to change only its so-called bias to neutral from leaning toward higher interest rates. A rate cut is not expected until the first quarter of next year.
Since Oct. 1, Wall Street forecasts for earnings growth for the S.& P. 500 in the fourth quarter have fallen to 12.7 percent on Nov. 7 from 14.8 percent and to 10.4 percent since then, according to First Call. The estimate for earnings growth for technology companies has gone from 29 percent on Oct. 1 to 17 percent on Nov. 7, and to 10 percent now.
Chuck Hill, the director of research at First Call, said that he expected growth forecasts to fall even further, based on the recently reduced earnings forecasts made by Compaq, General Motors, Eastman Kodak and others.
He also expects that earnings forecasts will dwindle as the holidays approach, only to be followed by a new burst of corporate warnings in the first weeks of the new year. "When we come to the first weeks of January, we will see some subsequent downgradings," Mr. Hill said.

Treasury Prices Rise
By Reuters
Bond prices rose yesterday after a report showing a drop in retail sales in November reinforced bond market hopes that a slowing economy will soon spur the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates.
Fixed-income investors, weary after five weeks of political and legal wrangling over the presidential election, turned their attention back to economic fundamentals, which remain very supportive of government bonds.
The price of the 10-year Treasury note rose 23/32, to 103 24/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.25 percent from 5.34 percent on Tuesday. The 30-year bond rose 14/32, to 111 16/32. Its yield fell to 5.46 percent from 5.53 percent.

HEADLINE: In Downturn, An Overhaul For Whirlpool

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 13

 BODY:
In yet another sign the economy may be slowing, the Whirlpool Corporation announced a major reorganization today and said that it would cut up to 6,300 jobs, or about 10 percent of its work force, because of weakening demand for its products.
The company, the nation's biggest maker of home appliances, also warned that its fourth-quarter profit would be lower than expected. Whirlpool attributed its troubles to a sagging economy and stiff price competition in the appliance industry. 
 "There are lots of uncertainties impacting consumers today," said David R. Whitwam, the chairman and chief executive of Whirlpool, who noted that a drop in stock prices, among other things, has weakened consumer confidence. "Our products after all are postponable; they can decide to fix a washer and not buy one."
The profit warning was the second in three months for Whirlpool, which in late August projected sharply lower earnings for the second half of this year, saying that higher interest rates, a weaker housing market and a drop in consumer confidence have helped soften demand for its washers, dryers, ovens, microwaves and other appliances.
Shares of Whirlpool fell $2.75, to $41.44 on the New York Stock Exchange, dropping the stock nearly 50 percent below its price in August 1999, when it topped $77 a share.
Whirlpool is not alone, of course. Nearly every major appliance maker is suffering a steep downturn. Maytag, Electrolux and GE Appliances are also reporting weaker demand for their products, particularly in the United States and Europe, where price wars have raged and production costs have risen.
Wall Street analysts say the entire industry is being rocked, and investors are beginning to wonder about profit forecasts, particularly at Whirlpool, which has gone through several revampings over the last decade.
"People are obviously skeptical given that Whirlpool went through this a few years ago," said Justin Maurer, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. "But this is a tough business right now, and they're doing everything they can to get through it."
Whirlpool, which is based in Benton Harbor, Mich., offered few details today about what plants might be closed or what jobs might be cut, but the company said it would take a series of charges for the reorganization next year totaling about $300 million to $350 million.
The company said the revamping should result in savings of $225 million to $250 million a year once fully carried out.
The company's slide has been huge. Wall Street analysts had forecast profits of $7 a share early in the year but dropped their estimates to about $5.58 a share after the August profit warning. Now, they are reducing their expectations to $5.18 a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial.
Whirlpool executives said the sharpest drop in demand had occurred this quarter. The company, which has about 36 percent of the United States appliance market, had projected industrywide sales to drop 2 percent to 3 percent in North America this quarter, but early figures show that industrywide demand has fallen about 8 percent, and there has been no letup in pricing pressure, something the company factored into its earlier projections.
"That's a precipitous drop and quite unexpected," Mr. Whitwam said. "That's a faster drop than we usually get in a down cycle."
Whirlpool is also coping with a tougher retail environment and changes that favor lower-cost models and direct selling and delivery to homes.
Earlier this year, Circuit City decided to stop selling appliances at its retail outlets, dealing a blow to several appliance makers. And Home Depot and Wal-Mart Stores recently entered the home appliance market. General Electric has made deals with these companies to ship directly to customers' homes, using its own logistics service. The changes mean reduced inventories and smaller retail staffs to ship, deliver and install home appliances. Whirlpool does not sell at either outlet.
So while Whirlpool and Maytag are suffering through a particularly sharp downturn, GE Appliances says it has gained market share. "We're gaining in a soft market," said Terry Dunn, a spokesman for GE Appliances. "I don't believe our competitors can say the same thing."
Next year, however, Whirlpool says it expects the early part of the year to be rough, with improving prospects in the second half. The company said it was forecasting profits of 15 percent next year, even though the industry will be flat.
Wall Street's reaction? "Well, they're not buying it," said Chuck Hill, director of research at First Call, noting that two analysts had revised their numbers to show a profit gain of just 1 percent next year.

HEADLINE: Mexico Chief Pushes New Border Policy: Free and Easy Does It

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: CIUDAD JUAREZ, Mexico, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Irma Anzures was driving back to Juarez this afternoon over the Free Bridge, after a little shopping in El Paso, when Mexican customs officials pulled her over for a routine inspection.
Then the president of Mexico stuck his head in the window. 
 "How's it going?" President Vicente Fox asked Ms. Anzures, 43, who runs three fast-food restaurants in Juarez with her husband. "How are the people treating you? Everything O.K.?"
A million Mexicans who live and work in the United States are coming home for Christmas, and Mr. Fox, as their new president, wants to welcome them back to a changed country.
The Free Bridge is not always free. On the United States side, in El Paso, officials take pains to stop suspicious people, routinely backing up traffic a mile or more. On the Mexican side, in Juarez, officials sometimes take money for nothing. "People have a lot of complaints, especially about bribes disguised as fines or fees," said Lizbeth Vela, a 21-year-old business administration student.
Mr. Fox dropped in at the Free Bridge on a two-day tour of border posts and stations, part of a campaign he began with his inauguration speech 12 days ago. He wants the millions of Mexicans crossing the border in both directions each year to travel freer and easier, possessing more visas from the United States to work legally, and facing fewer shakedowns from Mexican border officials when they come home. He also wants Mexican-Americans to enjoy full dual citizenship, including the right to vote from the United States by absentee ballots.
All this is part of his larger vision: that in 20 years' time, maybe less, maybe more, the border will no longer be a barrier, fortified by armed guards, but a mere line on a map dividing two partners in a common market, and with much more in common than what divides the United States and Mexico today.
It was that way once and it will be again, said Jose Posada Pompa, 80, a citizen of Juarez since 1933 and a loyal member of Mr. Fox's National Action Party since 1941.
"In those days, you walked to El Paso and back freely," said Mr. Posada, a retired mining businessman who turned out at the bridge for a glimpse of Mr. Fox. "I went to school in El Paso as a child. The two cities were like one family. You were free to go as you pleased. It was beautiful.
"It all changed when the cities grew in population, when the peso kept falling, and of course, we were ruled by a dictatorship for so many years, without the possibility of change, and we were able to develop nothing," he said.
For generations, Mexico regarded people who left for the United States as turncoats who would sell their patrimony for a fistful of dollars. That began to change more than a decade ago. The Mexican government, anticipating the advent of free-trade pacts with the United States and the closer ties that billions in new commerce would create, began quietly reaching out to Mexican-Americans through consulates, community organizations and public relations campaigns.
Mr. Fox, as is his style, has turned up the volume.
He sees the millions who have left for the United States as courageous and creative souls who "want to dream the American Dream."
"We want to salute these heroes, these kids leaving their homes, their communities, leaving with tears in their eyes, saying goodbye to their families, to set out on a difficult, sometimes painful search for a job, an opportunity they can't find at home, their community or their own country," he said on Tuesday during a stop at a border post just south of the Arizona border in Nogales.
The economic power of Mexicans in the United States is huge in Mexico.
Their remittances -- the money that the migrants send back home -- can be a huge boon to poor villages and towns in a nation where perhaps half of the nearly 100 million people are dirt poor.
Though estimates vary, the best guess is that the workers among the roughly eight million Mexicans living in the United States send between $6 billion and $8 billion back to their families every year, making them at least the third-biggest legitimate force in the Mexican economy, after oil and tourism. (Figures for the underground economy, led by drug trafficking, are notoriously unreliable, but certainly are measured in billions).
Mr. Fox wants his heroes to come home, eventually, but first he says he has to create the economic conditions that will draw them back. He has said over and over that illegal immigration from Mexico will not cease until the Mexican economy can provide more jobs and better pay, offsetting the demand for Mexican labor in the United States.
Roughly 1.5 million Mexicans are arrested annually trying to cross the border illegally. The migrants are dying at a rate of one a day in the process -- 369 deaths in the year ending Oct. 1. -- mostly from heat, thirst or exhaustion, but increasingly under fire from United States border officials or citizens defending their land from intruders. Mr. Fox has appointed a cabinet-level official, Ernesto Ruffo, to a newly created post overseeing the border and the plight of migrants.
The United States should see legal migrants in a different light, said Isela Arrendondo, 24, who works for the Chihuahua state convention bureau in Juarez. "I know the United States is worried about drugs, illegals, contraband and such things," she said. "But legal travel, with passports and visas -- there's a human right to travel freely, and not be regarded as a criminal."
Mr. Fox may have little power to change the way the United States regards Mexican migrants, legal and illegal. But on this tour -- a campaign, really, exhorting officials to clean up their acts, in much the same way that he sought votes during his three-year campaign for president -- he is trying to make the border a better place for a homecoming.
"We've got to build in this delicate terrain," he told a group of customs officials. "On one hand, to comply with the law, and on the other, to have the heart and the desire to embrace our fellow countrymen and brothers."

HEADLINE: Congress Revives Bill On Investment In Poor Areas

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Congressional Republicans and White House officials, locked in a bitter political standoff for much of the year, said today that they had reached a bipartisan agreement reviving legislation to provide tax credits and other incentives for investment in economically depressed areas.
The agreement resulted from months of negotiations between President Clinton and Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois. It is one of the few bills on which they collaborated. 
 Mr. Clinton championed the initiative in trips to some of the most destitute corners of America, including the Mississippi Delta, East St. Louis, Ill., Appalachia and the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota.
The proposed tax breaks, Mr. Clinton said recently, are not just another antipoverty program, but a way "to open new markets to American investors here at home, to bring prosperity to people and places who've been left behind" in the longest economic expansion in American history.
John P. Feehery, a spokesman for Mr. Hastert, said, "The 'new markets' community renewal bill is in the final package of legislation" negotiated this week by Congress and the White House.
Mr. Feehery said the bill, worth $25 billion over 10 years, "could serve as a model of bipartisan cooperation for the next Congress," which convenes on Jan. 3.
The legislation to revitalize poor neighborhoods will probably be added to a bill providing money for the Departments of Education, Labor, and Health and Human Services. Mr. Clinton and Congressional leaders have agreed to provide $108.9 billion for those agencies.
Negotiators from Congress and the White House said they worked out most of the details today, clearing the way for final adjournment of the 106th Congress within a week.
Republicans, including Mr. Hastert and Representative J. C. Watts Jr. of Oklahoma, chairman of the House Republican Conference, embraced the antipoverty bill out of a conviction that slashing taxes would stimulate investment and economic growth.
The bill encourages investment in depressed urban and rural areas by abolishing the tax on certain capital gains. Individuals would pay no capital gains taxes on the sale of businesses or business assets held in such neighborhoods for more than five years.
"The zero capital gains rate is something conservatives can be proud of," Mr. Feehery said. At the same time, he added, Mr. Hastert "feels good" because he worked on the bill with members of the Congressional Black Caucus including Democrats like Charles B. Rangel of New York and Bobby L. Rush and Danny K. Davis, both of Illinois.
The bill would provide tax credits to subsidize the wages of workers in depressed areas and would establish venture capital funds to invest in such neighborhoods. It also would offer tax credits to banks and other financial institutions that make investments and loans in low-income areas. These credits, proposed by Mr. Clinton, are meant to enhance the return on such investments.
The antipoverty legislation was included in a tax bill that was pronounced dead last week by Republican leaders on Capitol Hill. But the Republicans and White House officials said today that they had rescued the parts of the bill intended to revitalize poor communities.
In an interview today, Mr. Watts, who grew up in a poor neighborhood in Eufaula, Okla., said: "Last week I thought this legislation was on its last ounce of oxygen, was beyond the reach of the 106th Congress. But the speaker called this morning and said, 'We will be able to do the community renewal bill.' "
Gene Sperling, the president's economic policy adviser, said: "The 'new markets' legislation has broad bipartisan support. The president reached out early to Speaker Hastert. They've made it a joint effort."
The measure builds on the concept of enterprise zones and similar ideas devised more than 15 years ago by two New Yorkers, Mr. Rangel, a Democrat, and Jack F. Kemp, a Republican who served as secretary of housing and urban development under President George Bush.
Under the new legislation, poor areas across the country would apply to the federal government for designation as "renewal communities," and 40 would be chosen.
"In underserved communities, capital formation is always a challenge," Mr. Watts said. "This bill offers a way to create capital by wiping out the capital gains tax."
Owners of retail clothing stores, theaters, supermarkets and other shops -- small businesses and big corporations alike -- could qualify for the tax breaks if they invest in depressed communities.
