PUB-DATE: December 15, 2000

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 42; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 4781 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:

 A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.
 
Museums
 
"GIORGIO ARMANI," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 17). The Guggenheim has served up another plateau of urban history: a retrospective of the Milanese fashion designer Giorgio Armani. What it lacks in depth it makes up for with sparkle, and Robert Wilson's architectural transformation of the museum's rotunda may be the best yet. In an inverted version of a life class, instead of the undraped body, the show offers just the drapes. The mannequins have been pared down to the edges of the costumes, and they cluster in groups in the building's structural bays, spatial modules with the proportions of shop windows. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $8 students and the elderly (Herbert Muschamp). 

* "THE EMBODIED IMAGE: CHINESE CALLIGRAPHY FROM THE JOHN B. ELLIOTT COLLECTION," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 7). In China the written word has traditionally been the highest art form and a source of political and emotional power. To see that power in action, check out this grandly scaled exhibition, which brings together two superb calligraphy collections -- from Princeton University and the Met -- in the most comprehensive survey yet seen in these parts. The dozens of scrolls covered with handwritten words collectively radiate a kind of conversational buzz and suggest a richly varied cast of personalities: fastidious court functionaries, impulsive social agitators, unworldly monks, visionary poets. Together they offer an icebreaking introduction to an art that to anyone who doesn't know Chinese can seem unapproachable. Hours: Sundays, and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5 for students 12 and older and the elderly (Holland Cotter).
 
 LEE KRASNER, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 7). Despite its restless energy and moments of formal power and elegance, Lee Krasner's career in this economical retrospective looks more like one of tantalizing frustration than real fulfillment. In the 1950's and early 60's, Krasner painted splattery, ambitious Abstract Expressionist works, but they look indebted to other artists, Pollock and de Kooning mainly. Where she looks most herself is in collage; a set of large collages on canvas from the early 50's have raw density or explosive buoyancy. Collages made in the 1970's using 40-year-old charcoal drawings have a beautiful Cubistic elegance; they are the best works of her career. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. on the first Saturday of each month); Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students and the elderly (Ken Johnson).
 
 * "SOL LEWITT: A RETROSPECTIVE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Feb. 25). Unexpectedly, the most beautiful exhibition by a living artist in a New York museum in a long time and an antidote to the nonsense in several other museums around town. Just about every other wall is covered with wall drawings, alternately eye-popping and gossamer. Those out there (you know who you are) who run from any artist linked to Conceptualism may want to stop and re-evaluate your views after seeing what's here. The master of chaste white cubes has undergone a transformation since his last retrospective in the late 70's. Now opulence emerges from the same seemingly prosaic instructions he came up with years ago. The appeal is still to patient observation, a lesson for everyone, delivered elegantly. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, and Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8 for students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman).
 
 * "OPEN ENDS," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9480 (through Jan. 2). The third and final cycle of "MOMA 2000" covers 1960 to the present and fills nearly the entire museum with almost a dozen different theme shows. "White" is one theme. Memorial art is another. Childhood and lost innocence is yet another. Like previous installments in this year-and-a-half-long navel-gazing reconsideration by the museum of how to present its permanent collection in anticipation of its future home, the show has the effect of being clever and a little too solipsistic: it's about smart curators making occasionally vivid and previously unseen connections among disparate works without making particularly fresh sense of the period as a whole. It's artistic game playing, highly pleasurable up to a point. The themes are always arguable, which is part of the game. This also becomes an occasion for the museum to parade acquisitions during the last decade, which include Gerhard Richter's series of paintings based on the Baader-Meinhof gang, occupying an entire room and probably the exhibition's high point. Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays, and Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8:15 p.m. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and the elderly (Kimmelman).
 
 * "RAIN OF THE MOON: SILVER IN ANCIENT PERU," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through April 22). Symbols of power and prestige in ancient Peru, gold and silver were equally revered, and Peruvian metalsmiths acquired great skill in the techniques of working them. This show deals with silver, harder to capture and preserve than gold, dating from the late first millennium B.C. to the Spanish conquest in the 16th century. The objects range from nose ornaments and ear pieces, some of them amazingly large, to human and animal figures, like a famous Inka llama whose hanging fleece is evoked by the rippled, crumpled sheet of silver that covers its body. As most gold and silver objects in Peru were melted down by the Spanish conquistadors, this show -- half from the Met's collection and half from loans -- amounts to a bonanza. It is the first devoted to the subject of pre-Columbian Peruvian silver. Hours and admission: See above (Grace Glueck).
 
 * BRIDGET RILEY, "Reconnaissance," Dia Center for the Arts, 548 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 989-5566 (through June 17). Once overly identified with Op Art, this British abstract painter never got her due in anti-Op New York, but a beautifully installed show of 40 paintings from 1961 to 1984 should change things. Concentrating on the early black-and-white paintings that made Ms. Riley famous, it presents stringently pure yet accessible works that have, at their best, extended the optical potential implicit in the work of Mondrian, Josef Albers and Ad Reinhardt. At their weakest, their meticulously calibrated patterns can be so aggressive that they virtually kidnap the eye, take it on a joy ride and leave it in a crumpled heap. Either way, the overall effect is of an artist of unusual dedication who has remained loyal to the original premises of her art and yet steadfastly refused to repeat herself. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students and the elderly (Roberta Smith).
 
 * SCYTHIAN GOLD. "The Golden Deer of Eurasia: Scythian and Sarmatian Treasures From the Russian Steppes," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Feb. 4). "Gold of the Nomads: Scythian Treasures From Ancient Ukraine," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 21). Certain kinds of art are box-office gold. Art made of gold is one of them, and there's a Fort Knox-size supply of the precious stuff in these two opulent exhibitions. The Brooklyn show is a survey-style glimpse at some exquisitely wrought 14-carat objects drawn from museums in Ukraine, where the Scythians put down roots in the first millennium B.C. The Met has drop-dead museological rarities from the State Hermitage Museum, but the focus here, which gives the proceedings a kind of treasure-hunt thrill, is on a cache of objects excavated fairly recently from tombs belonging to non-Scythian people whose identity is something of a mystery. Ideally, the two shows should be seen together: they offer a really substantial archaeological update on the last big Scythian showcase in these parts, the Met's smash-hot "In the Land of the Scythians" of 25 years ago. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).
 
 * "JOHN WESLEY: PAINTINGS 1961-2000," P. S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through Jan. 14). For 40 years Mr. Wesley's paintings have maintained the same mild form of constructive lunacy. The art world has a handful of indispensable visionaries like Mr. Wesley, who help to keep everyone else honest. You may not enjoy his show, the first full-dress local retrospective, only because simple pleasure is not the intended effect. The images are borrowed from magazines and comics: Blondie and Dagwood, Donald Duck and young naked women, painted flat, like coloring-book designs, with delicate black outlines and off-key colors. The style alludes to Matisse, Hokusai, Greek vase painting, Art Nouveau, Toulouse-Lautrec. Emotion is there below the comic exterior, and it is pathos, mostly. Mr. Wesley offers up sex as unquenchable desire and woeful male inadequacy, a black comedy of men chasing after women they can only dream about. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5 (Kimmelman).
 
Galleries: Uptown
 
LYONEL FEININGER, "From the Gelmeroda Cycle," Achim Moeller, 167 East 73rd Street, (212) 988-4500 (through Jan. 26). The painter of misty yet precisely gridded Cubist cityscapes was always an excellent and versatile draftsman. In this fine exhibition of small drawings, mostly from the teens and all focused on a single church in the village of Gelmeroda near Weimar, Germany, we see the artist working with an exquisitely sensitive touch in styles ranging from sketchy naturalism to vigorously gestural Expressionism to crystalline abstraction (Johnson).
 
 * "FROM THE ARTIST'S STUDIO: UNKNOWN PRINTS AND DRAWINGS BY MARY CASSATT," Adelson Galleries, 25 East 77th Street, (212) 439-6800 (through Dec. 22). This extraordinary exhibition presents 120 prints and drawings from a heretofore privately held collection. Covering the entire course of Cassatt's printmaking career, it features multiple states of many of the great color etchings that she produced after seeing a show of Japanese woodcuts in Paris in 1890. These intimate images of women in private domestic moments or tending children are as striking for their abstract structure as for their incipiently erotic sensuality (Johnson).
 
 LASZLO MOHOLY-NAGY, Ubu, 16 East 78th Street, (212) 794-4444 (through Dec. 22). Moholy-Nagy (1895-1946), the once hugely influential Modernist and Bauhaus educator, is today only hazily remembered. This extensive and diverse sampling of small works on paper shows why. The show is like a hall of mirrors that palely reflect many more interesting artists: Rodchenko, Mondrian, Man Ray and others. Moholy-Nagy's dream of fusion among art, science and industry shows in a Constructivist formalism that, while not unplayful, has a bland, corporate impersonality (Johnson).
 
 ERNEST LAWSON, Gerald Peters Gallery, 24 East 78th Street, (212) 628-9760 (through Dec. 22). Although a member of the gritty realists known as the Ashcan School, Lawson (1873-1939) is better known today as a landscapist whose loosely brushed Impressionist-style canvases had little to do with Ashcan urban concerns. His palette was generally on the low-key side, which served him well in the quiet, brooding landscapes -- particularly of Manhattan's upper reaches, like Inwood and the Harlem River -- that were his strength. His handling of white could be lyrical, as demonstrated in wonderful scenes of snow, beaches and atmospheric effects (Glueck).
 
 JAUME PLENSA, "Twin Shadows," Richard Gray, 1018 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, (212) 472-8787, and Galerie Lelong, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 315-0470 (through Dec. 22). This 45-year-old Catalan, who lives in Paris and Barcelona, has an impressive flair for theater. At Gray, video-projected, God-like eyes survey a broad table covered in red velvet that bears engraved glass balls spelling out elemental dualities like "semen-blood" and "night-day." At Lelong, recorded sounds of lovemaking issue from below a wooden deck; glass ball works mounted on opposite walls spell out the themes: "dream" and "desire" (Johnson).
 
 LAURIE SIMMONS, "Tourism, 1984," Skarstedt Fine Art, 1018 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, (212) 737-2060 (through Dec. 23). Known for her photography of constructed miniscale scenes, Ms. Simmons concocted "Tourism, 1984" after a harried visit to the Acropolis that year. She decided that such glamour destinations might be better experienced in reproduction, the way most of us know and remember them anyway. So she photographed her doll-size "Teenettes" against sites blown up from bad slides: Las Vegas, the Great Wall of China, the Taj Mahal and other cliche attractions. The 60-by-40-inch Cibachromes play up the nostalgia-knowledge foisted on us by reproductions. To make it more fantastical, the stiff little mannequins that stand agape at the backdrops take on the coloration of the slides. It's enough to deter you from world travel for quite some time (Glueck).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
MATTHEW BARNEY, JENNIFER PASTOR, CHARLES RAY, Barbara Gladstone, 515 West 24th Street, (212) 206-9300 (through Dec. 22). Mr. Ray recreates to surprisingly elegant effect a 1971 work based on fundamental principles of sculptural abstraction. Ms. Pastor presents a towering representation of a monstrous wedding cake. Mr. Barney's elaborate assemblage with honeycomb-cocooned car seats encased in octagonal cabinets relates mystifyingly to his latest film, "Cremaster 2." The shift from Mr. Ray's early formalism to Mr. Barney's obscure symbolism speaks volumes about the evolution of art over the last three decades (Johnson).
 
 MEL BOCHNER, Sonnabend, 536 West 22nd Street, (212) 627-1018 (through Dec. 22). Mr. Bochner's new paintings give fresh immediacy to his enduring preoccupation with the tension between perceptual and conceptual experience. Contemplating a series of near-Minimalist red-and-white works with 12-inch dimensions graphically indicated, your mind oscillates between mathematical abstraction and the vibrant punch of color and shape. For some viewers, this may prove too dryly self-reflexive; for analytical philosophy buffs, it may be deeply absorbing (Johnson).
 
 MEL CHIN, Frederieke Taylor, 535 West 22nd Street, (646) 230-0992 (through Dec. 23). The avant-garde environmentalist Mr. Chin presents a virtual reality video game called "Knowmad," produced in collaboration with a group called the Knowmad Confederacy. Viewers-as-players drive through a series of nomadic, desert tents with lush kaleidoscopic interiors based on traditional rug patterns. Whether or not one's geopolitical consciousness regarding Middle Eastern tribal society will be raised, as the artist hopes, the game is fun to play (Johnson).
 
 SPENCER FINCH, "Up," Postmasters, 459 West 19th Street, (212) 727-3323 (through Dec. 23). This clever Conceptualist offers a variety of works inspired by the idea of looking or being "up," including pictures of a stain on his bedroom ceiling, a glowing watercolor representing the smell in an airplane at 35,000 feet, views of the Milky Way painted with Tang and a dazzling installation of suspended lights configured according to the molecular structure of blue pigment that matches the sky over Los Alamos (Johnson).
 
 BERNARD FRIZE, Cohan Leslie and Browne, 138 10th Avenue, near 18th Street, (212) 206-8710 (through Dec. 23). In his first New York solo Mr. Frize, a French painter who has exhibited widely in Europe, presents resinous abstract paintings that suggest what Morris Louis might be doing today. Mr. Frize is oriented more to process than form, however; excepting one lovely striated veil painting, the interest is more in his inventively matter-of-fact ways with materials and procedures than his pictorial effects (Johnson).
 
 LIAM GILLICK, Casey Kaplan, 416 West 14th Street, (212) 645-7335, Chelsea, (through Dec. 23). This English sculptor and writer combines Minimalism and interior design to suave but dryly intellectual effect. Colored Plexiglas and aluminum "Platforms" suspended overhead, a large aluminum and white Plexiglas partition, an oak and aluminum floorpiece, soothing electronic music and a Sol LeWitt-like mural may prompt deep thoughts about modern, institutionalized society. But the modular decor is not so rich as to stand on its own as a compelling esthetic experience (Johnson).
 
 * "THE IMPERIAL GAZE," Sepia International, 148 West 24th Street, (212) 645-9444 (through Dec. 30). The British photographer Samuel Bourne was in India for only seven years (1863-70), but he took thousands of pictures, established a lucrative business and became well known for his cityscapes and pictures of architectural monuments. The pictures that resulted are part of one of the richest bodies of photographic work to emerge from British India (Cotter).
 
 JILL LEVINE, Art Resources Transfer, 210 11th Avenue, near 24th Street, (212) 691-5956 (through Dec. 31). All three of this gallery's project spaces are devoted to a survey of Ms. Levine's buoyantly quirky wall-sculpture. Since the late 1980's the artist has been assembling standardized plastic foam parts -- balls, rings, cones, cubes -- into funky configurations painted in various ways: Constructivist-style, intricate patterns or trompe l'oeil. Most recently, she has covered them with Hindu imagery, setting up a Pop-brokered marriage of East and West (Johnson).
 
 "MODERNISM DEFINED: JULIUS SHULMAN AND RICHARD NEUTRA," Yancey Richardson, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 343-1255 (through Jan. 6). Now 90, Mr. Shulman began photographing the buildings of the modernist architect Richard Neutra in 1936. His black-and-white images of clean, airy, minimally furnished houses from the 1940's and 50's are more than just lucid documents; each glowing miniature conveys a heavenly vision of modern serenity (Johnson).
 
 "PROCESS/REPROCESS: JAPAN AND THE WEST," Leslie Tonkonow, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 255-8450 (through Dec. 23). This disconnected but highly suggestive show mixes Western artists who have been influenced by Japanese traditions (like Richard Serra, James Lee Byars and Richard Tuttle) with Japanese artists who have been oriented to Western avant-gardisms (like Yayoi Kusama, Yoko Ono and Nikki S. Lee). What is most remarkable is how many different modes of artmaking are thus embraced, from Abstract Expressionism and Minimalism to Fluxus to the latest kinds of photographic and video performance (Johnson).
 
 LORDY RODRIGUEZ, "States," Clementine, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 243-5937 (through Dec. 23). Mr. Rodriguez's extraordinarily detailed, beautifully handmade ink-on-paper maps look normal from a distance, but up close you discover they are totally zany. Following a systematically reimagined United States geography, New York has been moved to Michigan; Connecticut occupies a western coast and is engulfed by Montana; the capital of Kansas is Miami. These plausibly rendered yet fantastic revisions of reality are oddly exhilarating (Johnson).
 
 * CINDY SHERMAN, Metro Pictures, 519 West 24th Street, (212) 206-7100, (through Jan. 6). With her latest untitled series Ms. Sherman is back in front of the camera lens again, disguised as women who, you might say, used to be somebody, maybe. They grin at the camera in clownish make-up, wobbly wigs and discount blouses, proud, valiantly oblivious to, or simply defiant of, our condescension, like the beauty pageant queen who drops her baton in the talent contest but keeps beaming. Formal devices by Ms. Sherman get overlooked because of the human element: the pattern of pigtails against plaid shirt; the purplish freckled face of a woman with purple shirt and purple cap. This formal order becomes a rational structure that gives to the work its mix of frigidity and heat, a perfectly ambiguous cocktail for an ambiguous moment and an antidote to the weary sophistication of which there is too much in art now (Kimmelman).
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
KIM DINGLE, "Never in School," Sperone Westwater, 121 Greene Street, (212) 431-3685 (through Dec. 22). In dainty dresses and Mary Jane shoes, two small troublemakers, Fatty and Fudge, use classroom and playground for their subversive antics: fighting, taking off their clothes, writing dirty words on a blackboard and generally mess-making. What brings it all off is Ms. Dingle's chronicling of their cartoony doings in a satirical painting mode usually reserved for high-art subjects. Velazquez, meet Fatty and Fudge (Glueck).
 
 KEVIN LARMON, Curt Marcus, 578 Broadway, near Prince Street, (212) 226-3200 (through Jan. 6). Mr. Larmon, who has been exhibiting regularly in New York since 1984, updates the old Surrealist-Abstract Expressionist connection. Working toward the centers of raw plywood panels, he layers grisaille glazes over loose, swirling pencil lines, creating murky depths, serpentine biomorphic forms and tension between illusory dream space and the raw immediacy of paint and wood (Johnson).
 
 "A NEW YORK CIRCLE," Susan Teller, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 941-7335 (through Dec. 30). Selected by a veteran New York modernist painter, Fannie Hillsmith, this exhibition of works by friends and acquaintances evokes a mid-century period when the progressive art world was far smaller and more intimate than today and the common language was Cubism. Besides Ms. Hill smith's own robust Cubist still lifes, the show includes fine small works by such luminaries of American art as Louise Nevelson, Suzy Frelinghuysen, A. E. Gallatin, Alice Trumbull Mason and Charles Shaw (Johnson).
 
Other Galleries
 
ANDREW FORGE, New York Studio School, 8 West Eighth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 673-6466 (through Jan. 6). A Pointillist-derived system of colored dots has for years been the lyrical basis of painting by Andrew Forge, the English-born painter, critic and teacher. Worked on the canvas in dense but nuanced arrangements made from close observation of "places, seasons, times of day, conditions of light," the dots usually can't be read as specific imagery. But sometimes they hover on the edge of representation, evoking trees, a pond and other aspects of nature. To be savored rather than looked at hurriedly, they resonate in the mind (Glueck).
 
 * "HARD PRESSED: 600 YEARS OF PRINTS AND PROCESS," AXA Gallery, 787 Fifth Avenue at 51st Street, (212) 554-4818 (through Jan. 13). A thumbnail history of exploration in the field of fine art prints, from earliest woodcuts to digital technology, running from Durer to Kiki Smith, from Rembrandt to Robert Rauschenberg and beyond. Woodcuts, intaglio prints, drypoint etchings, lithography and newer techniques are carefully explained and illustrated, with notable early examples like Rembrandt's drypoint "Three Crosses" and more current events like Peter Halley's unlimited edition "Superdream Mutation" (1993), which existed only on a computer screen (Glueck).
 
Last Chance
 
CARL CHENG, "Nature Observed/Art Tool 2000," Sculpture Center, 167 East 69th Street, (212) 879-3500 (through tomorrow). The long-overdue New York debut of this California artist has as its centerpiece an extraterrestrial landscape made entirely of sand and spread out across the gallery floor. Its topographic features -- hills, canals and cryptic pictograph patterns -- were shaped by a computer-driven metal cylinder that resembles a player-piano roll but is as sensitive to the touch as a drafting pencil. Mr. Cheng has been inventing such "art tools" for more than 30 years, and he is definitely on to something worth knowing a lot more about (Cotter).
 
 DAMIEN HIRST, Gagosian Gallery, 555 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 741-1111 (through tomorrow). The Damien Hirst Universe is a big, shiny place with mathematical grid paper printed on the walls, pale pristine dot paintings and many large vitrine sculptures, including two outfitted as gynecological examining rooms and filled with water and fish. It shows the artist moving beyond the dead animals and putrefying flesh that catapulted him to fame while clarifying and enriching the grandiose themes of his art: life and death and their complex, sometimes oppressive relationship to science and commerce. It contains some undeniable duds, but if it doesn't win over those who have resisted the work of this notorious young British artist, it won't be for lack of trying (Smith).
 
 SUSANNE KUHN, Bill Maynes, 529 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 741-3318 (through Thursday). Applying black ink to parchment-like pages, Ms. Kuhn, a German painter, makes haunting primordial wilderness scenes in an intricately linear cartoon style. Her images of towering pines, craggy cliffs, dismal swamps and radiant skies call to mind Caspar David Friedrich, while her graphic vocabulary evokes traditional Japanese landscape painting, Art Nouveau, German Expressionist woodcuts and contemporary comic books. Though satirically hyper-romantic, her pictures nevertheless exude a genuinely affecting spirituality (Johnson).
 
 HENRI MICHAUX, Zabriskie, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 752-1223 (through tomorrow). This is a good complement to the Michaux exhibition at the Drawing Center through Wednesday. Here semi-abstract watercolors and gouaches by the French artist-writer, who died in 1984, display his quietly playful ways with luminous color, dreamy human and animal figuration and calligraphic mark-making. (Johnson).
 
 "PASTORAL POP!," Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, 120 Park Avenue, at 42nd Street, (917) 663-2453 (through today). Nature-inspired kitsch is the theme of this delirious seven-artist show. It includes Rob de Mar's comical landscape in the form of a spindly tree, Lisa Ruyter's psychedelic update of Seurat's "Grande Jatte," Alyson Shotz's grove of weird plant machines, Peter Gould's transformation of the guard station into a bucolic cartoon, Jason Middlebrook's Styrofoam stone wall planter, Katrin Asbury's diorama in a planter and Rachel Feinstein's suspended Rococo-style pitcher exploding flowers like a pinata (Johnson).
 
 * "UNTITLED PASSAGES BY HENRI MICHAUX," Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 219-2166 (through Wednesday). The books of the Belgian-born French poet and writer Henri Michaux are not exactly unknown on these shores, but his considerable achievement as a visual artist -- a self-taught one -- has yet to gain a solid foothold. This show of more than 100 works on paper should change things. Spanning the late 1920's to the late 1970's, it includes examples of his finely textured "mescaline" drawings, his raucous inkscapes and his animated, often preening calligraphies. It reveals an artist profoundly influenced by Asian art who mined the fault line between language and sign, text and drawing, image and abstraction, manifesting the flow of human thought and energy in different, often hypnotic ways. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Free (Smith).
 
 * SUE WILLIAMS, 303 Gallery, 525 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-1121 (through tomorrow). A decade ago Sue Williams was making rage-filled, clotted, sometimes outrageously funny works about the tribulations of women. Now she's painting like late de Kooning: confetti splashes of red, yellow and blue, calligraphic pirouettes, sweeping curves and minor skirmishes, mostly spare on big, bare white canvases. It is as if she were seeing how far she could push this sort of elegant abstraction before alienating her old audience, which, in terms of approach, is not so different from her button-pushing early work (Kimmelman).

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
A Strategic Region That Straddles Two Civilizations

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:

EASTWARD TO TARTARY
Travels in the Balkans, the Middle East and the Caucasus
By Robert D. Kaplan
367 pages. Random House. $26.95.
President-elect George W. Bush could do a lot worse in preparing for the foreign affairs part of his job than to read "Eastward to Tartary" by Robert D. Kaplan, a scholarly and adventurous journalist who roams the less-traveled regions of the globe and writes about them knowledgeably and with sophistication. 
 Mr. Kaplan is the author, among other books, of "Balkan Ghosts," which achieved a certain notoriety when it was reported to have influenced the American decision not to intervene in the Balkans on the ground that savage ethnic violence there was inevitable and unstoppable. Mr. Kaplan replied that he had never intended that conclusion to be drawn.
He calls "Eastward to Tartary" a sequel to "Balkan Ghosts." Like that book, it is an effort to "anticipate the problems" that loom in an important region of the world, what he calls the Greater Middle East, where he traveled in 1998 and 1999. Mr. Kaplan took a trip from Hungary to Israel, via Romania, Bulgaria, Turkey, Syria, Lebanon and Jordan; and another trip from Turkey to Turkmenistan, passing through the former Soviet republics of Georgia, Armenia and Azerbaijan.
As always, Mr. Kaplan is intellectually bold and confident in his judgments. He is not the kind of writer to plunge by bus or train across desert and mountain and find himself perplexed by the human panorama he witnesses. He draws attention to longterm trends that other writers have little noted, like the growing power and influence of Turkey in the Middle East and Central Europe and the importance of the alliance between Israel and Turkey -- "a seismic shift," he calls it. This entire book is illuminated by an unillusioned intelligence and a steady sort of attention to deeper, longer-range trends rather than what might be called headline-news ephemera.
In at least one instance, this focus on the geostrategic reality risks ignoring another reality, that something can be of decisive importance simply because everybody thinks it is. Writing before the latest Palestinian uprising on the West Bank, Mr. Kaplan says that "the outcome of the Israeli-Palestinian peace talks" is "predictable and therefore uninteresting." Still, Mr. Kaplan may be right in his longer-range vision of the Middle East, where the fate of ethnically divided countries like Syria, Iraq and Jordan may prove of more enduring significance than the fate of the Palestinian state.
"For decades I have heard that there would either be a Greater Israel or a Palestinian state," Mr. Kaplan writes near the end of the Israeli-Arab portion of his book. "It turns out that there will be both: a Palestinian ministate -- without control over its skies or main highways -- situated within a dynamic Israel that will continue to attract workers from across the border, making it the stabilizing force of historic Greater Syria, even as the current Syrian state weakens after decades of Soviet-style calcification."
Throughout, Mr. Kaplan talks to intellectuals, political leaders and people on the street; he makes observations on material conditions -- the degree of dilapidation, the stylishness of dress, the quantities of briefcases and cell phones. He stays keenly attuned to the parallels between present and past and to the influence of what might be called the deep culture, the patterns of belief and behavior that go back hundreds, or even thousands, of years.
The impression here and there is less that Mr. Kaplan makes discoveries and more that he confirms what he already knows from his previous trips, his wide reading and the bracing realpolitik philosophy that he carries along with him like volumes of law in his saddle bags.
Here is Mr. Kaplan ruminating about Stalin during a journey to Georgia, the dictator's birthplace: "To say that the Oriental influence was merely incidental to his character is to ignore its essentials. The monumental use of terror, the very grandeur of his personality cult, and the use of prison labor for gigantic public-works projects echo the ancient Assyrian and Mesopotamian tyrannies. The liturgical nature of Stalin's diatribes, which became the standard for official Communist discourse, bore the influence of the Eastern Orthodox Church, in one of whose Georgian seminaries Stalin studied as a youth."
This is a fascinating comment, and it relates to one of Mr. Kaplan's underlying themes: of civilizations dividing on either side of the Carpathian Mountains. On one side is the Enlightenment-Reformation West, with its stress on laws, institutions and the individual. On the other is the Ottoman-Byzantine East, prone to caliph-style despotism, to tribal ties and obedience to the chief. Mr. Kaplan invokes the importance of this scheme numerous times. He uses it, for example, to explain the reasons for Hungary's relative economic success and the stagnation of Romania and Bulgaria.
But Mr. Kaplan is never guilty of simplified thinking. He has his themes -- among them the Communist heritage of poverty, organized criminality and squalor; the slow, sad substitution of narrow nationalism for the multi-ethnic cosmopolitanism of the defunct empires -- but he also appreciates the role of the individual in history, the fact that, given the individual, nothing is inevitable. His portraits of relatively unknown leaders like Emil Constantinescu of Romania, Petar Stoyanov of Bulgaria and Heydar Aliyev of Azerbaijan are shrewdly succinct, and he has a good eye for the telling detail: the look of the young men he notices hanging around with their elders at the office of a nationalist Bulgarian organization.
"It was a combustible mix," Mr. Kaplan remarks. "Bitter old men and impressionable young thugs, the mix from which Romanian fascism had emerged."
Near the end of his journey -- by bus and by trans-Caspian freighter to Turkmenistan -- Mr. Kaplan reaches Tartary itself, the historic Turkish regions of Asia. His stress is on the wild-west oil-producing areas that have been much in the news. "What Vietnam was to the 1960's and 1970's, what Lebanon and Afghanistan were to the 1980's, and what the Balkans were to the 1990's, the Caspian region might be to the first decade of the new century: an explosive region that draws in the Great Powers."
In other words, the recommendation to the next head of the greatest power of them all: read this book. If there is a better, more sophisticated and informed primer to the emerging powers and problems of the Greater Middle East, I don't know what it is.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: WEEKEND WARRIOR;
Launching That Small Steel Missile, Hoping Not to Hit the Bar Stool

BYLINE: By PETER DeMARCO 

 BODY:
How I wasn't getting slaughtered in the first darts competition of my life, I still can't explain.
Maybe the beer I downed with my new teammates had steadied my nerves, as many players claim. Maybe those pointers that the champion chucker Roger Herbert had given me were paying off. Maybe I was just plain lucky. 
 Whatever the reason, the Magic Marker scoreboard propped against the bar wall showed I needed 34 points to win our game of "501," in which rival players start with 501 points apiece and subtract the numbers they hit on the board in a race to reach zero. My opponent, a quiet but slick-shooting 20-something named Anwar, needed a scant 14 points for victory. But it was my turn to shoot.
The wedges on a dart board are numbered from 1 to 20, but there are paper-clip-size strips of green and red that are worth a double or triple score, like Scrabble squares. Nikki, Austin, Pat and the rest of my teammates from Bar East, a team in the C division of the New York Dart Organization, huddled around and told me to hit the double 17 strip and "double off" to win the game.
Pinching the six-inch sliver of tungsten and steel between my fingertips, I stepped to the shooting line, about eight feet from the wall, and squinted to locate No. 17 on the board's perimeter, finding it where the 5 would be on a clock. The target looked very small and very far away, but my teammates were cheering for me, a good Sting song was playing on the jukebox, the bar was alive with chatter and, with a full tank of gas, I was on a roll.
I shot, and my dart whizzed through the air, miraculously landing on double-17 real estate, as if it had been scripted. My teammates went into a frenzy, offering me congratulatory fist taps and a victory beer. Needless to say, I was pumped, and could barely wait for my next game to begin. "It's a dart rush you've got," the team's captain, Megan Mitchell, a bartender, told me. She was right. In just one night, the game had completely seduced me.
A pleasing mix of strategy, skill, etiquette and, as mentioned, luck, darts is easy for a beginner to pick up, yet so difficult to master that the best of players usually go their whole lives without shooting a perfect game. It is eminently open and accessible, as there are men's, women's and mixed teams. It usually costs nothing to play, and it is extremely economical in terms of equipment and space requirements.
The game dates back to the 12th century, when the British began throwing foot-long spears at wooden targets like felled trees and beer kegs when they weren't in battle. Over the years a circular dart board emerged, and bird feathers were attached to the spears (and later, fancier darts) for better flying. The sport hit its stride around 1900, when paper fins or "flights" replaced feathers, and a Lancashire carpenter invented the numbering system, according to Patrick Chaplin, an Englishman with the rare distinction of being a dart history Ph.D. candidate.
British soldiers carried dart boards with them in World War II, helping spread the game to 45 countries, but England remained the mecca, with professional players there today earning upward of $300,000 a year. Some 4.5 million Americans play darts, according to one study, and there are leagues in every major city, including seven within New York's five boroughs and Westchester County. There are also regional tournaments with $10,000 prizes and a National Darts Hall of Fame in Martinsburg, W.Va.
Most players, though, seek enjoyment, not enshrinement. League nights are big social events, with plenty of food (one Bronx player I met raved for five minutes about the meatballs served at a Crotona Avenue pub) and camaraderie. "You make a lot of friends," said Nikki Lumpress, a Bar East player and a development assistant for New York Theater Workshop. "It's the best thing in the world outside college."
Unfortunately, my earlier forays into darts had been anything but enjoyable. Few friends played, and the handful of times I tried shooting, my darts flailed in the air, sometimes missing the board completely. Embarrassed, I stuck to shooting pool.
Those not-so-fond memories made me a bit anxious as I waited at Nathan Hale's, an after-work watering hole near City Hall, one Friday afternoon for my first darts lesson to begin. My teacher, Roger Herbert, an assistant vice president with Salomon Smith Barney Inc., is both president and singles champion of the New York Dart Organization, the city's biggest league with 1,000 players and 60 sponsoring bars. When he arrived, he reviewed the rules of "501" and "cricket," a game in which players vie to be the first to make three tallies on each number from 20 to 15, as well as the bull's-eye, plus finish ahead in total points.
We moved to the shooting line and, with rapid-fire instruction, Roger told me his secrets, advising me to align my shooting arm with the target and to let my forearm and wrist do all the work. The throwing motion should resemble a karate chop, he said, with my wrist and forearm pointing straight at the ceiling to start and straight at the board when finished. Finally, he said, aim slightly above the target, as gravity will drag down the dart.
As I shot away, he occasionally barked out commands like "Look board! Look board!" and "Zen! Be the dart!" and reminding me, above all, not to drink a beer with my shooting hand, as glass moisture can affect grip. Thirty minutes later, I hadn't noticed much improvement, but my guru was ebullient, predicting that with a few more hours of practice, my shot would begin to click.
Following his advice, a few days later I meandered down to the Dart Shoppe at 30 East 20th Street near Gramercy Park to buy my own set of darts. There were dozens of models in the window cases, so I asked the proprietor, Jim Birmingham, for advice. "There's no dart out there that will make you a better player," he said. "It doesn't matter if the dart costs $6 or $60. It's what you feel comfortable with." I told him my budget was $25, and he outfitted me with a set of three 24-gram darts, a fairly standard weight, for $22.50.
I then flipped through a book with hundreds of "flights," some with sports logos, some with half-naked women on them, and picked out a nifty blue-and-white checkerboard pattern.
The next week I stopped by my local bar, Tap-a-Keg on Broadway near 105th Street, for daily workouts, sometimes bringing my friend Nathan or my girlfriend, Kristi, along. At first, my shooting was miserable, with an upholstered bar stool absorbing the brunt of my misses. Eventually I settled into a comfortable stance, remembering to keep my throwing arm straight and to hold the dart gingerly with all five fingers. From there, it was a matter of refining my eye-hand coordination, and by the night of my league debut I was landing about a third of my shots -- not great, but a big improvement.
Through my travels I met some players from Bar East, and they invited me to join them on their league night. I arrived at Sam Beckets on First Avenue about 7:15 p.m., expecting to find my teammates engrossed in pregame drills. Instead, they were sitting around the bar, munching on Cheddar Goldfish crackers and playing computer poker. "Practice?" scoffed Austin Gurney, a plywood distributor. "There is no practice." Division C teams, unlike those in the higher A and B tiers of the league, are laid back, I was informed.
Dart teams typically have 6 to 10 players. On a league night, half a dozen members of each team play singles 501 games; then pairs of players from each squad play doubles cricket and doubles 501 games. All told, the two teams play 24 games in three to four hours. I was scheduled to play one game of singles 501 and two games of doubles cricket. As mentioned, I won my first game, recording 96 points in one three-dart round by hitting a double 20, a double 18 and a single 20. The score was so good it earned me a mention in the league newsletter.
My cricket partner was our team's other Austin, Austin Dooley, a former merchant mariner who took up darts because "on a ship, you can't play pool." And truth be told, he carried us. In quick order, he made three tallies on Nos. 20, 19, 18 and 17, thereby "closing them out," while I struggled just to close out the 15. My lone contribution was a round where I hit the 17 wedge with all three darts, earning us some valuable points.
Austin eventually nailed a bull's-eye for the win, and, following tradition, we shook hands with our opponents first, then with each other. Our second game, not quite as contested, also ended in a win for us. Bar East was leading in overall points, so Captain Megan bought drinks for everyone, and there were toasts to all, including a certain hot-shot rookie.
"Good darts," Megan said to me. "You're on the roster, buddy. We expect you here next week." That would be great, I replied. And with my nonshooting hand, I finished my drink.
 
Being the Dart
Dart boards can be found in hundreds of bars across the city, and rarely does it cost anything to play, though you may be obliged to buy a drink or two. There are seven leagues in the five boroughs and Westchester County, and most have both fall and spring seasons. For a listing of more than 100 Manhattan bars with boards, visit the New York Dart Organization Web site at www.nydo.com. The group is the largest of the leagues in the metropolitan area, with more than 1,000 players. Call (212) 374-9529.
The Gotham City Darts League, based in Brooklyn, has all-female teams as well as a summer season. Call (718) 258-4944; Web site:
gothamcitydarts.tripod .com.
For information on other leagues, local and national, see the Darters.com Web site at:
www.darters.com/usa/.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles 

LENGTH: 1134 words

HEADLINE: Favorable Lease Deals May Be Fading Fast

BYLINE: By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
THE boom in leasing that propelled the auto market to sales records shows signs of fizzling out, as auto companies' finance subsidiaries and other lenders confront some discouraging financial facts.
Fast disappearing are the short-term discount leases that made cars affordable for many consumers who could not handle high monthly payments. Big banks and finance companies are backing out of the lease business, burned by lower-than-expected values for vehicles returned by customers when their leases are up. 
 Those projected values, called residuals, have often been set higher than the actual value of the cars and trucks returned when the leases end. High residuals are commonly used to make leases more affordable, since the monthly payment is typically calculated on the difference between the residual and the purchase price. The higher the residual, the lower the payments.
Artificially high residuals pose no risk to consumers, but they can be costly to financial institutions that write leases and that must sell vehicles, when they are returned, for less than they are valued on the books.
 "The market has fundamentally changed," said George Borst, chief executive of Toyota Financial Services. "The free ride on leasing has come to an end."
Leasing for personal use has dropped to 29 percent of the car market this year, from 32.5 percent last year, according to CNW Marketing Research of Bandon, Ore.
Collectively, lenders will lose an estimated $10.4 billion this year because they overestimated how much cars and trucks would be worth at the end of their lease terms. That figure could climb to $11.1 billion in 2001, CNW's president, Art Spinella, said.
In 1999, lenders lost money on 84 percent of the formerly leased cars when they were subsequently sold as used cars at auction or by dealers, according to the Consumer Bankers Association. The average loss was $1,920 a car, the association estimated.
Those losses are scaring off some big lessors, including two just this month. GE Capital Auto Financial Services stopped accepting lease applications as of Dec. 1. One of DaimlerChrysler's financing units, Debis, told dealers last week that it would no longer write leases and that they would instead have to go to the auto-finance divisions of Mercedes-Benz and Chrysler. First Union, the nation's sixth-largest bank company, quit the lease business almost 18 months ago. Bank of America and the Bank One Corporation have also scaled back leasing.
David Littmann, chief economist at Comerica Bank, predicted that those banks' retreat, plus auto companies' growing skittishness, would make leasing less popular. He said he expected the leasing business, which has hovered around 30 percent of the market for five years, to drop as low as 18 percent next year.
Though leasing has long been available, its popularity is relatively new. Until the mid-1990's, only about 5 percent of consumers leased cars.
Everything changed in 1995, when a wave of sticker shock prompted Mercedes-Benz and the Ford Motor Company to offer attractive discount-leasing plans, hoping to persuade buyers to concentrate on low monthly payments instead of on high sticker prices. Consumers quickly took to the deals, and banks and other lenders jumped in.
"The customer demand was like a snowball," Mr. Spinella said. "People were coming in and saying, 'I want a lease and I don't want to pay more than $300 a month.' "
The deals helped automakers to sustain an unprecedented sales streak, culminating in last year's record of 17.3 million units. Leasing contributed to the rise of sport utilities; many consumers who could not afford loan payments on $30,000-plus trucks found they could handle monthly lease payments that were hundreds of dollars less.
But now, tools like inflated residuals, which sparked record sales in the late 1990's, have come back to bite the automakers. In trying to back away, companies are finding how addicted consumers have become to low-cost lease offers. In an effort to cut its expensive inducements, Chrysler halted lease deals on Jeep Grand Cherokees in May, and sales of that model collapsed.
"It was like the rug had been pulled out from under us," said John Vermillion of Wolfchase Chrysler-Jeep in Bartlett, Tenn. He estimates that 99 percent of his Grand Cherokee customers lease, not buy.
Mr. Vermillion said he had not had trouble arranging leases for customers since then. But he said Chrysler's approach had changed; instead of setting a high residual value for Grand Cherokees, the company is giving dealers an incentive of $2,750 per vehicle, which he is using to cut the price from an average of $35,000 to around $32,000. That reduces a customer's lease payment without inflating the residual value.
With banks pulling back, it will be harder for consumers to comparison-shop, since they have fewer choices to scout. The typical lease customer compares deals from four financial institutions before choosing a package, according to Consumer Reports, which explores the intricacies of leasing in its January issue. Car shoppers have also used the Internet to find lease deals they otherwise might not know about.
A spokesman for Ford Motor Credit, Dan Jarvis, contends that moves by banks to stop writing leases actually help customers, because auto company financing arms are better equipped to assist them. Banks, he contends, rely primarily on residual values set by the Automotive Lease Guide.
Ford takes that guide's numbers into account, but also collects data from its dealers, who play a big role in clearing out formerly leased vehicles from their lots and can give the company snap information on the prices that customers are willing to pay.
"We have the experience and the expertise when residuals become a question," Mr. Jarvis said. Ford Motor Credit finances roughly a million leases a year, about a quarter of Ford's American sales. Its leasing business is up slightly this year, according to CNW, and Mr. Jarvis said he did not expect the numbers to drop next year.
But leasing has declined significantly at other companies, particularly Toyota. Two years ago, 60 percent of Lexus luxury vehicles and 35 percent of Toyotas were leased. This year, that has dropped to 35 percent for Lexus and 22 percent for Toyota. Even so, Mr. Borst said there would always be deals available for the most desirable customers, especially in the luxury market.
And if demand becomes too sluggish, discount deals are likely to return in some form, most likely for short-term periods in regions where the offers are most needed to spur sales. Mr. Vermillion, the Tennessee dealer, said: "The bottom line is that the manufacturer still has to move the product. They're not going to say, 'Whoops, we aren't going to lease anymore.' "

HEADLINE: Gucci Posts Strong Growth, But Share Price Declines

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE

DATELINE: MILAN, Italy, Dec. 14

 BODY:
The Gucci Group N.V., the luxury goods giant that has been on an aggressive acquisition spree, reported strong revenue and profit growth in the third quarter, largely thanks to the performance of its flagship Gucci division.
But investors, apparently troubled by cautions about a challenging period next year, reacted by pushing the share price down almost 6 percent. 
 Gucci said group operating income rose 92 percent, to $133 million, on a 101 percent increase in revenue, to $615 million. Gucci said fully diluted net income per share rose to $1.12, against 97 cents in the third quarter last year.
Gucci said it expected diluted earnings per share to rise next year to $3.40. That is more than the $2.10 it estimates for this year, but below the 1999 level of $3.48.
Gucci operates out of Italy but its shares trade on the Amsterdam exchange, where they dropped 5.6 percent to close at 98.80 euros today.
The caution in Gucci's forecast was attributed in part to the prospect of a slowdown in the United States economy, Gucci's biggest market. But it was also linked to continuing heavy costs related to the task of turning around Yves Saint Laurent, the fashion house that Gucci acquired last year as part of its acquisition drive.
Gucci, which has emerged in recent years as the No. 3 global luxury goods group, has been pushing to compete with the market leaders, LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton of France and Compagnie Financiere Richemont of Switzerland, which controls such brands as Cartier.
In talks with analysts today, Gucci executives attributed their cautious forecast for 2001 to the prospect of lower interest income on liquid assets, because of reduced United States interest rates; a $20 million one-time charge related to the purchase of a maker of branded Gucci clothing; and a projected $50 million loss at Yves Saint Laurent.
Gucci expects the pressure on earnings because of lower licensing royalties as it draws distribution from licensees to itself, and because of heavy spending to develop new products and refurbish and open exclusive Yves Saint Laurent boutiques.
But Domenico De Sole, Gucci's chief executive, said he expected "significant improvement" in Yves Saint Laurent's performance in 2002, as the stores run directly by the unit perform well.
Gucci's strong results came despite continuing legal battles with LVMH, a major shareholder. Last year, LVMH lost a battle for control of Gucci, after Gucci thwarted overtures by the LVMH owner Bernard Arnault and sold a controlling stake to the big French retail group controlled by the French investor Francois Pinault, a rival of Mr. Arnault. In recent months, Gucci and LVMH have been caught up in mutual recriminations and court suits.
In part at least Gucci's response appears to be a headhunting campaign in the ranks of Mr. Arnault's talent. On Tuesday, Gucci announced it had hired a senior LVMH executive, Thierry Andretta. Earlier this month, Gucci shocked the fashion world with the news that it had lured Alexander McQueen, the iconoclastic Scottish designer for Givenchy, an LVMH property, into Gucci's ranks. Today Gucci said it was hiring Giacomo Santucci, a senior executive at Prada, the Italian fashion house that is another LVMH ally.
Last year, Gucci also acquired Sergio Rossi, an exclusive Italian maker of women's shoes, and Boucheron, the jewelry and perfumes house that is a fixture of the Place Vendome in Paris. Thanks to the sale of shares to Mr. Pinault, Gucci has a war chest of about $2.5 billion, and Mr. De Sole made clear that he was continuing to hunt for acquisitions.
Today, Gucci said it had acquired an 85 percent controlling stake in the exclusive Swiss watchmaker Bedat & Company, whose timepieces can sell for up to $30,000. Bedat's founders, Simone and Christian Bedat, are expected to help run Gucci's luxury watch interests.

HEADLINE: Run to the Right, Not the Middle

BYLINE: By Gary Bauer; Gary Bauer, a domestic policy adviser to President Ronald Reagan, is chairman of the Campaign for Working Families.

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va.

 BODY:
Now that George W. Bush has just prevailed over Al Gore in a long, costly, vitriolic struggle over the presidency, he is getting plenty of advice. Pundits, political consultants and Republican advisers are telling the president-elect that he must go slow, run to the middle, avoid controversial issues and share power. As is often the case when there is a Washington consensus -- the advice is wrong.
Certainly, the new president should be agreeable whenever possible and try to rise above petty personality differences that poison Washington. But when it comes to the fundamental policy differences between the two parties -- those cannot, nor should not, be swept under the rug. 
 It is always political suicide to forsake your base and crush its hopes and dreams. Mr. Bush will need the continued loyalty and passionate support of millions of traditional conservative voters to weather the inevitable political firestorms of the next four years. And conventional wisdom nothwithstanding, he could never move left enough for the liberals to be satisfied.
By taking the advice to do little and accomplish it slowly, he would find himself leading no one, building nothing and disappointing his best friends. It is a path destined to end in four years.
Of course Mr. Bush will have to seek the support of Democrats in a closely divided Congress. But the coalitions he should seek are not in some mythical "center." Instead, Mr. Bush should move boldly ahead on a conservative governing vision -- the same one that he emphasized during the better moments of his campaign and that he touched on in his gracious acceptance speech on Wednesday night. On each initiative he will find significant numbers of Democrats willing to vote with him.
Even before taking office, Mr. Bush can send a strong message with his appointments. For example, he should name a pro-life attorney general who believes all our children should be protected by the law. Mr. Bush should also nominate Supreme Court justices who believe the same.
Once in office, Mr. Bush should immediately repeal a long list of executive orders President Clinton issued over eight years. These fiats have hurt economic growth, by overregulating small businesses, worsened our energy crises by stopping drilling for oil and natural gas, and promoted a radical social agenda including financing international family planning groups that provide abortions abroad. Will liberals object? Of course they will. But Jesse Jackson, Barney Frank and Ted Kennedy will never support him no matter what he does.
Next, Mr. Bush should send four bills to Capitol Hill: a tax cut that combines marginal rate tax relief with an easing of the marriage penalty and an increase in the child tax credit; an immediate ban on partial-birth abortions; an education reform bill with a strong voucher provision; a new budget that rebuilds the American military and speeds work on a missile defense system. These initiatives will rally the people who voted for him, and significant numbers of Democrats in Congress are likely to support them as well.
Finally, Mr. Bush can surprise his critics by proposing campaign finance reform. He should support a bill equally tough on the big union and big business soft money contributions that are corrupting our politics.
Liberal leaders and special interest groups will resist these actions, and pundits will criticize them. Yet sizable majorities of the American people will support Mr. Bush. More importantly, Mr. Bush will show the rest of the country that he is a man of his word and a man of action.

HEADLINE: Prices Paid to Producers Go Up Slightly as Business Inventories Rise

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Prices paid to producers in November showed the smallest gain in three months and business inventories rose in October, government figures showed today, indicating that companies have little latitude to raise prices.
The Producer Price Index rose 0.1 percent in November, reflecting declining computer costs and tame prices for automobiles, after rising 0.4 percent in October, the Labor Department said. Stockpiles of unsold goods rose 0.6 percent in October, according to the Commerce Department. 
 The report on producer prices suggests that inflation is becoming less of a threat to a record economic expansion that is about to enter its 11th year. The report on the index, a measure of prices received by producers for their goods, also raised investor hopes on Wall Street that Federal Reserve policy makers were closer to cutting interest rates.
The November increase in producer prices was the smallest since a decline of 0.4 percent in August. The core rate, which excludes energy and food, was unchanged after falling 0.1 percent a month earlier.
Through November, the overall index has increased at a 3.9 percent annual rate, compared with a 3 percent pace of increase in the corresponding 11 months last year. The core Producer Price Index has increased at a 1 percent annual rate, compared with a 0.8 percent pace in the period a year earlier.
The Fed's efforts to slow the economy and control inflation seem to be taking hold. A separate Labor Department report showed initial jobless claims declined 32,000, to a level of 320,000 for the week ended Dec. 9 from 352,000 the previous week.
The four-week moving average of claims, a less volatile indicator, fell to a level of 343,250 last week from 345,250, which was the highest in almost two and a half years.
"There's a clear weakening in the labor market; it's just not losing momentum very rapidly," said Mark Vitner, an economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C.
The costs of goods, other than rising energy prices, have been tame.
Energy prices rose 0.4 percent in November after rising 1.4 percent in October as declines in the costs of residential power and heating oil partly offset an increase in natural gas and gasoline.
Still, consumers probably will not see relief on energy costs in coming months. The Labor Department will release its Consumer Price Index statistics on Friday. Analysts expect a 0.2 percent increase in November, the same as a month earlier.
Business inventories rose in October after rising 0.2 percent a month earlier, the Commerce Department report showed. The rise in inventories was attributed to a 0.2 percent fall in business sales.
Slower job growth, declining stock prices and higher costs for energy have eroded consumer willingness to spend. This pushed up the inventory-sales ratio -- a measure of how long it would take to clear out current inventories at the current sales pace -- to 1.35 months, the highest since May 1999.
Retailer inventories rose 0.9 percent in October, reflecting increased stockpiles at auto dealers, department stores and other businesses except for building materials outlets.

HEADLINE: THE 43RD PRESIDENT: THE TECHNOLOGY;
2 University Presidents Will Try to Improve Voting

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 14

 BODY:
Like many other Americans, Dr. David Baltimore, the president of the California Institute of Technology, found the technological snarls involved in the presidential election a national embarrassment. Unlike most others, he was in a position to do something.
He called Dr. Charles M. Vest, the president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Technological problems must have technological solutions, they concurred. 
 Today, the two presidents of the two science-and-engineering universities announced that they were channeling some of the brainpower of their institutions into solving the riddle of how to improve the United States' voting system.
Their idea is not unique. Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, has said he will propose a bill allotting $10 million for the study of voting methods to the Federal Election Commission and an additional $250 million as matching funds to help states adopt improved systems.
But Dr. Baltimore said in a bicoastal news conference today that he concluded that "the institutions in America that best understand technology had a responsibility to help to repair the voting process so that we wouldn't see anything like this again."
"It's too late to do anything about this year," he said, "but this is a project to look out for the future."
The two universities said Vartan Gregorian, president of the Carnegie Corporation, had agreed to recommend that the corporation's board finance the project's first phase with a grant of $250,000.
That phase, tentatively scheduled to last about six months, will be used to define the criteria of an acceptable system and evaluate the technologies in use, from paper ballots to optical scanners to Internet voting; the project will then either recommend existing systems or design a new one.
"The idea," Dr. Baltimore said, "is to produce a system that is foolproof, secure, simple to operate and affordable so that it can be in every precinct in America. The system should also give everyone a record of their vote, so they know exactly what they have done at the polls."
The project, which is in the planning stages, will bring together professors of political science, cognitive science, design, computer science and engineering.
Actually putting a uniform polling system into place will probably cost billions of dollars, said Thomas Palfrey, a Caltech political science and economics professor, but, he argued, that seems "a small price to pay for modernizing our democracy."
The two university presidents said they had not broached the idea yet to anyone in government; they received word only Wednesday that financing was probably on the way.
Though the project could theoretically conclude that paper ballots were the best system, it seemed likelier that it would favor more modern technology.
"We are at a technological point where the probability of finding a somewhat radical solution to this using recent advances in information technology is highly likely," Dr. Vest said.
It is also much more likely, he said, to be doable in a simple and cheap way than it would have been even five years ago.
Neither he nor others discussed specifics of a possible solution. But Prof. Nicholas Negroponte of the Media Laboratory at M.I.T. offered an example of an area for improvement. There should be a system of feedback when a person votes, Professor Negroponte said, much as a person pushing an elevator button gets the feedback of seeing it light up when pushed.
Those undertaking the project did not promise perfection.
"In engineering there is no such thing as 100 percent fail-safe," said Stephen D. Ansolabehere, a political science professor at M.I.T.
But they seemed compelled to try.
As Dr. Vest put it, "A nation that can send a man to the moon, that can put a reliable A.T.M. machine on every corner, has no excuse not to deploy a reliable, affordable, easy-to-use voting system."

HEADLINE: Nemuro Journal;
The Russians Have Come, and They're Welcome

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: NEMURO, Japan

 BODY:
With its rolling, barren bluffs and rocky coastline, and its migratory white whooper swans outnumbering people here each winter, this frigid crab-fishing town is about as deep into the backwater as one can get in this heavily urbanized and modernity-crazed country.
The modest grid of streets and unfussy manners of its residents give this small town the feel of Down East Maine -- 20 years ago that is. When a foreigner checked into one of the two hotels, a request for a room with an Internet-friendly phone drew a puzzled stare. Moments later came the discovery that cable television and CNN had not reached the northeastern tip of Japan either. 
 But if globalization's electronic forms have made scant inroads here, that has not stopped this town from showing Japan, a country whose self-image is of an island nation unto itself, that internationalization begins with both hearty and heartfelt neighborliness.
Street signs throughout this town are in Russian, residents study the language in high school and in adult night class, and Russians mill about in the shops downtown -- not just accepted, but eagerly welcomed, and increasingly served by Russian-speaking staff.
This is a far cry from many other places on Japan's northernmost island. In Otaru, for instance, a famous spa town, Russians and all other foreigners are officially unwelcome at local hot springs and watering holes. Of course, with Russian-held territory -- four islands vigorously claimed by Japan that were seized by the Soviet Union at the end of World War II -- easily visible from here on a clear day the people of this town appreciate better than most that you cannot choose your neighbors.
But the fact that they went one step further and chose to embrace neighbors from a country long regarded with suspicion and hostility in Japan owes itself to a handful of townspeople, mostly business people, with a keen sense of enlightened self-interest. Many, in fact, point to Kinichiro Suzuki, the owner of a clock shop who, scratching his head for ways to boost his business about five years ago, decided to try to attract Russians.
"We wanted to expand our business, but when we looked at the situation of Nemuro, we realized that things were pretty stagnant," Mr. Suzuki said. "Everywhere else in Hokkaido was restricting the docking of Russian ships, but we decided to open up. There are no secrets to what we did; our policy was a customer is a customer, and we tried to provide them with good products at reasonable price."
The decision paid off with enough new customers to justify expanding his business to include a range of goods, from compact discs to eyeglasses. And the economic life of the town has been changed in much the same way, as the annual number of Russian visitors has far outstripped the town's population of 34,000. But convincing people at first seemed like a long shot.
"The reason those other towns are barring Russians from baths and snack bars is because Japanese don't like being around Russians," Mr. Suzuki said. "When we began targeting the Russians, we feared that our customers would feel the same way. But we found that the people of Nemuro don't harbor any revulsion for Russians. We want to have good relations with them. Who knows, one day it may even help us recover our lands."
Russians here readily attest to the fact that relations are exceptionally good in this town.
"I really like it here, and the people are very friendly," said Tatyana Vurkova, a young woman from Vladivostok who works in a downtown shop mostly assisting Russian customers. "The only problem is that it is really cold!"
Just outside the port, where Russian ships bring 40 tons of crab to market most days, hangs a large billboard that reads: "Return of the Four Islands Will Strengthen Friendship Between Nations. They are traditionally Japanese territory."
But along the frigid docks, a friendly if linguistically hobbled banter prevails between Japanese buyers and the Russian crews. After unloading their catch, many of these workers catch buses to town to shop for new and used refrigerators and ovens, bicycles and televisions, which they cart back to towns in Sakhalin and Kamchatka.
"There are some hard feelings among some people around town about the lost territory, and for some people, the idea of Russians shoplifting or getting drunk around town creates a bad impression," said Takashi Inoue, head of the Nemuro Fishermen's Association. "But for those of us in business with the Russians, things are great. They are really contributing to the economy, and plus, their behavior is not so strange after all."
At Nemuro High School, there are more signs of the growing links between this town and its northern neighbor. In addition to offering Russian to students, the language is taught to adults in heavily subscribed night classes.
"I was very surprised and impressed by the interest of the people here in our language," said Natalya Boyko, a Russian professor recruited from the University of Vladivostok to teach here for one year. "Moreover, the people are really fascinated with our culture and ways. I am constantly being invited by people to demonstrate Russian cuisine for them."
The school principal, Fuminori Sato, said: "In Nemuro we have a perception that foreigners are our neighbors. Unlike other Japanese people, we don't feel any strange feeling toward them. Instead, we want to build friendships with them, and are starting with their language."
Although they speak of the issue guardedly, given the years of frustrated diplomacy aimed at recovering the northern islands, many here say they hope this friendship will help ease the vexed questions of shared history between the countries, which have fought two bitter wars in the last century.
"The Russians have not yet said they are ready to return our islands, but they are learning to live with us," said Mr. Suzuki, the clock shop owner. "Together, we are building up a sort of mutual faith. The Russians who visit Japan will see our advanced facilities and our hospitality and come to respect. Regardless of race or ideology, respect is something people can learn to share."
