HEADLINE: Meet Me At 60th And 60th;
Many Drivers Find Streets of Queens A Confusing Maze

BYLINE: By SARAH KERSHAW

 BODY:
The mission was simple: to find a coffee shop in Corona, Queens.
The man on the mission was equipped with a large and detailed Hagstrom map, a car with a full tank of gas, a master's degree in economics with a concentration in urban planning and an address from the telephone book. The Yellow Pages listed the coffee shop, El Pasillo, at 37-69 103, Corona. 
 The first problem for the man, Robert Wood, 34, a math guy from Manhattan who volunteered to try to not get lost in Queens, was the matter of the number 103. The possibilities in Queens for that number are 103rd Street, 103rd Avenue, 103rd Drive and 103rd Road. Ditto for 37 and 69, numbers that Mr. Wood deduced contained crucial information about a cross street (or avenue or drive or road).
In the scheme of things, Mr. Wood had it easy with 103 because other numbered streets in Queens can also be found in the form of places -- as in 65th Place -- as well as lanes, terraces, courts and crescents. Crescents are less common; one of the loveliest crescents, 246th, can be located (although not by Mr. Wood) looping through a fancy nook of northeast Queens, just off 57th Drive, which in that part of Queens is actually the continuation of 244th Street before it becomes 245th Place and then 62nd Avenue.
So at 2:09 p.m. on a recent Saturday, Mr. Wood, his palms only mildly sweaty at this stage, set out for the Corona coffee shop from points west. He got himself onto the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and exited soon after arriving in Queens, pulling over at 65th Place and Laurel Hill Boulevard in Woodside, about two miles from Corona.
Looking in the street index, Mr. Wood determined that he was, in fact, in search of 103rd Street because there is no 37-anything for 103rd Avenue, Drive or Road. "I'm going to do this in stages," he said confidently, adding that he planned to hop over to 69th Street, head north to 37th Avenue and then cruise over to 103rd Street.
One block later, Mr. Wood was lost. Five miles and 35 minutes later, Mr. Wood was more lost. "Welcome to Maspeth," read a sign that might as well have said "Welcome to the Bermuda Triangle" because even experienced navigators of Queens consider Maspeth difficult.
"Is there someone out there who's really proud of this system?" Mr. Wood said, shortly after zooming by the intersection of 65th Place, 62nd Street and 52nd Avenue and discovering that in Maspeth, some of the numbered avenues, like the one he was taking in the wrong direction, briefly change to named avenues.
The chances of Mr. Wood's finding the coffee shop seemed to grow slimmer with every passing street, road, avenue, drive, lane, place and terrace. More on this later.
Mr. Wood was flummoxed, but not alone. His deep sense of disorientation is shared by others who shop, visit, work and even reside somewhere in the 112 square miles that make up the vast borough of Queens. United Parcel Service drivers and florists making deliveries, social workers making home visits, reporters covering breaking news, cabdrivers, tourists, census takers -- all have been sucked into the vexing vortex of the Queens street system at one time or another.
"Even with a map, you don't know where you are going; you need a person," said Gigi Stone, who has covered Queens for New York 1 News for three years and who lives in the borough as well. "I'm shameless at this point. I just keep my window down and yell."
Laura Bell, a proofreader for a Manhattan advertising agency who has lived in Long Island City, Queens, for four years, said flustered people constantly stop her to ask for directions while she is walking her dog. She said she was usually too confused herself to help them out.
"They usually seem like they're at a point where they think they're never going to get out," she said. "Queens is a bit of a twilight zone."
Some lost souls may be surprised and even flabbergasted to know that there is a highly sophisticated logic to the whole thing, a rational, mathematical street-naming system with an inventor and fans. True, they may never understand the system, but it is regarded by historians and other experts who can grasp it as a stroke of masterly urban planning.
Some experts say the confusion most often occurs among people who spend little time in the borough or who have not taken the time to try to understand the street-naming system.
"Very often this arrives from the snobbery of Manhattan," said Vincent Seyfried, a Queens historian who grew up in Ridgewood, not far from the neighborhood where Mr. Wood wound up en route to Corona. He added that while Manhattan's rectangular grid system can be easily understood, Brooklyn and the Bronx have no real universal grid system.
"Queens is the easiest by far of all the boroughs," Mr. Seyfried said. "It's a very simple pattern."
This was a very interesting notion, one that required a visit to the topographical bureau at Queens Borough Hall, at 120-55 Queens Boulevard, the office responsible for naming and mapping the streets.
The task of explaining the pattern fell to Moghabhai Desai, the bureau's chief engineer, a gentle and patient man whose office is crammed with maps.
First, there was the matter of the jingle. Charles U. Powell, a chief engineer in the bureau who designed the street-naming system in 1911, modeling it after the Philadelphia grid system, was faced with staunch opposition to his plan from Queens residents. So he wrote a little jingle to clarify things and mailed it out.
In Queens, to find locations best
Avenues, roads and drives run west;
But ways to north or south 'tis plain
Are street or place or even lane.
The jingle was not helping.
So Mr. Desai went on. The street-naming pattern was used to gradually -- though never completely -- unify the streets of the 60 or so self-contained villages that existed in Queens when it was incorporated into New York City in 1898. It was clear to borough officials then that Queens needed a coherent system. There were 40 Washington Streets. Each village had its own house-numbering method. It was a mess.
So Mr. Powell came up with a plan to rename the streets according to the grid and impose a uniform system of numbering the houses. It took 17 years, and Mr. Powell faced so much resistance that some parts of the borough retained named streets. This is why there are no numbered streets in some neighborhoods and a mix of names and numbers in others.
The system works like this: avenues run east and west and streets run north and south, the opposite of Manhattan's system. The avenues were given consecutive numbers, but there were often additional parallel streets in between the avenues that needed names, so they were assigned the same numbers and called roads or drives, in that order.
So if there was a street between 65th and 66th Avenues, it would be called 65th Road. If there was another one, it would be called 65th Drive. But there is no uniformity. Sometimes there are roads and drives between the avenues, sometimes there is only a road. Sometimes the avenues run consecutively with nothing in between, depending on the neighborhood.
The same went for streets. If there were additional streets that needed naming between the consecutively numbered streets, they were called places and lanes, in that order. So between 71st Street and 72nd Street, there could be a 71st Place and a 71st Lane. Again, that depends on the neighborhood. In Glendale there is a 71st Street and a 71st Place, but in Middle Village, only a 71st Street.
Breathe. Crescents and hyphens are next.
Curved roads that were not parallel with either the avenues or the streets were assigned numbers and called crescents, courts or terraces. The longer roads, like Queens Boulevard, were called boulevards and not assigned numbers.
Mr. Desai was asked about the hyphenated addresses. He explained that the house-numbering system was designed to indicate the exact location of an address. The number before the hyphen is the cross street, and the number after the hyphen is the position on the block.
So 37-69 103rd Street would be on 103rd Street between 37th Avenue and 38th Avenue (unless there is a 37th Road or a 37th Drive before 38th Avenue), house No. 69 on the block.
The cross streets (or avenues, roads, drives, places or lanes) can tell you where in the borough -- east, west, north or south -- an address is. The streets, starting with First Street on the borough's western edge, increase as they go east. The avenues, starting with Second Avenue, increase as they go south. This is important because someone looking for 71st Street could be looking for an address in Jackson Heights or in Glendale, neighborhoods that are miles apart. If the cross street in the address is a low-numbered avenue, like 20th (that is low for Queens), the address is in the north, but a higher-numbered avenue, like 88th or 165th, would put the address in the south.
That about covers the system. Oh, but there are dozens of exceptions, like changing street angles, sudden bursts of named streets, dead-end streets and other interruptions in the grid that render the logic useless in some parts of the borough.
Still, said Mr. Desai at the conclusion of his explanation of the street-naming system, getting around "shouldn't be that difficult."
Mr. Wood might disagree. Granted, he was driving without an explanation, but he did have a map.
"The minute you veer off course, you can't be sure what's happened," he said as he pulled over at Perry Avenue and Hamilton Place in Maspeth to study the map yet again.
He devised a plan to get to Roosevelt Avenue, his ticket to Corona. He took Hamilton to 65th Place, and planned to take 51st Avenue east to Junction Boulevard, which would take him to Roosevelt. His plan went slightly awry when 51st Avenue changed into Garfield Avenue, but he stumbled onto 69th Street and, remembering his original plan, took that to Roosevelt, where he turned right and got into a major traffic jam.
He moved along Roosevelt, which is one block south of 37th Avenue, the cross street for the 103rd Street address he was searching for. He made his way slowly through Woodside into Corona, turning onto 37th Avenue. He began to see encouraging numbers, like 98 and 99.
He pulled up to 103rd Street. He was at the corner of 37th Avenue and 103rd Street; the coffee shop was just down the street -- either to the left or to the right on a one-way street. There was a rush of euphoria, and then another of self-doubt.
He was close enough, he decided, and did not want to take another wrong turn. "I'm going to count my blessings and declare victory," he said, continuing east along 37th Avenue in search of the next address: 111-01 111th Avenue.

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about the confusion caused by the street-naming system in Queens misidentified the author of an explanatory rhyme about the street grid. He was the humorist Ellis Parker Butler. (Charles U. Powell, the engineer who designed the grid in 1911, distributed the verse widely.)

HEADLINE: U.N. Economic Panel to Study Ways to Help World's Have-Nots

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Secretary General Kofi Annan named a high-level advisory panel of international financial experts today and gave them five months to come up with concrete ideas to help poor countries that are falling farther and farther behind a global economic boom.
The panel will be led by Ernesto Zedillo, the former president of Mexico, who is an economist. Among its members are Robert E. Rubin, the former United States treasury secretary and now chairman of Citigroup's executive committee, and Jacques Delors, a former president of the European Commission and finance minister of France. Other members will include a labor expert and the head of a major private relief organization, Oxfam. 
 "Development has been the twin objective of the United Nations alongside international peace and security," Mr. Annan said at a news conference with Mr. Zedillo this morning. "Development cannot happen without resources, especially financial resources," he said, noting that official development assistance has been in steady decline for well over a decade. He said that poor countries are so far in debt that many of them are paying more in interest and loan payments to industrialized countries than they are receiving in aid from those countries.
"It is vital that we turn the situation around," he said. "But how?"
The naming of the panel on financing development is another unusual initiative by a secretary general who is willing to reach outside the United Nations for expertise and opinions. It is also a move to inject a dose of financial expertise and realism into the agenda of a United Nations conference on how to finance development that will be held in early 2002.
The panel will not approach the problem the usual way -- by looking primarily at traditional patterns of foreign aid for answers to the paradox of growing poverty amid plenty -- often in the same country. Instead, it will be expected to study the full range of economic factors affecting development, from trade, investment and debt relief to the failure of many nations to raise more of their own money domestically.
This year, according to United Nations figures, foreign direct investment around the world -- money invested in a country from outside -- will total more than $1.1 trillion, twice what it was three years ago. But less than a fifth of that total goes to developing nations, and most of that to 20 countries with already growing economies. The poorest nations attracted only about 0.5 percent of investments made abroad in 1999.
At the same time, foreign aid has been falling, especially from the United States, which during the Clinton administration slipped well behind all other industrial countries in the proportion of gross domestic product given in assistance. Over all, foreign aid to the poorest countries fell nearly 25 percent during the last part of the 1990's.
Also serving on the panel will be Abdulatif al-Hammad, president of the Arab Fund for Economic Development; David Bryer, director of Oxfam; Mary Chinery-Hesse, a former deputy director general of the International Labor Organization; Rebeca Grynspan, former vice president of Costa Rica; Majid Osman, a commercial banker who was formerly finance minister of Mozambique; and Manmohan Singh, former finance minister of India and a major architect of its economic liberalization policies.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Big Chemical Companies Reshuffling Units

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Today, it was the German chemical giant BASF A.G. On Thursday, it was DuPont of the United States. And last month it was Aventis S.A., the French pharmaceutical company.
Amid seemingly endless corporate reshufflings, the world's biggest chemical companies are facing a fundamental choice: chemicals or drugs? Except for a few holdouts, most have decided they can no longer do both. 
 Today, BASF announced that it would sell its drug business for $6.9 billion to Abbott Laboratories Inc. The sale ends three decades of effort by BASF to buy its way into the pharmaceutical industry, with its lure of higher profit margins and higher stock valuations.
DuPont reached a similar verdict a day earlier, when it announced plans to sell off its pharmaceutical business. With revenue of $1.9 billion, analysts say the operation is likely to be worth at least $5 billion.
Both companies will refocus their money on the older and dowdier chemical industry, where profit margins are lower but scales are much bigger. And they are not alone. In the last few years, chemical companies have been buying and selling units at a furious pace as they search for the perfect lineup of businesses that will allow them to be among the dominant producers in a few selected areas.
At the same time, companies like Aventis have put themselves through precisely the opposite transformation. Aventis, formed last year from the merger of Hoechst A.G. of Germany and Rhone-Poulenc S.A. of France, has abandoned the chemical business entirely to focus on what it called "life sciences" pharmaceuticals and agricultural products like genetically modified seeds and pesticides.
Three weeks ago, Aventis decided that even this was too much of a spread. Executives are now trying to sell off Aventis Crop Sciences, apparently persuaded that there is not enough overlap with the drug business and worried that slow growth was putting a drag on the parent company's performance.
"If you look strategically, there is a difference in the cultures required for success in the pharma industry compared to what is required in the chemicals business," said Peter Blair, a chemical industry analyst with Salomon Smith Barney in London. "In pharma you need to be innovative and have strong research. In chemicals, you need to be the low-cost producer."
Indeed, only a handful of companies are still trying to push ahead in the two very different worlds. One is Bayer A.G., which will always be famous for its aspirin but which derives most of its profits and sales from chemical products. The other is Akzo Nobel N.V. of the Netherlands.
Last week, Bayer said it had hired two investment banks to evaluate its strategic options. That immediately produced speculation that Bayer might be thinking about a corporate overhaul, but that now appears unlikely. Company executives insist they are not looking for radical changes, and analysts say Bayer is merely looking for help in listing its shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
Analysts say that Bayer and Akzo are different from most other chemical companies, because they derive a very large portion of their profits from pharmaceutical products. Where BASF and Du Pont receive only about 10 percent of their earnings from the drug business, the pharmaceutical share of earnings is 30 percent at Bayer and 45 percent at Akzo.
In general, however, experts say the traditional conglomerates are out of step. "The large chemical companies like BASF and DuPont have recognized that they can never reach the critical mass that they need in the pharmaceutical business," said Martin Stone, an analyst with HSBC Securities in London.
BASF's pharmaceutical business has a pretax profit margin of only 7 percent, Mr. Stone said. By contrast, the margin is about 30 percent at the world's biggest pharmaceutical companies.
The allure of pharmaceuticals has always been their extremely high profitability. But the industry has become increasingly concentrated through gigantic mergers, and companies need huge amounts of capital for research, development and marketing.
The chemical industry operates on much lower margins, and some of it is extremely vulnerable to cyclical swings in the industrial economy. But for companies that can build up enough scale, achieve top efficiency and dominate particular segments of the market, profits can be quite healthy.
In trying to sort themselves out, European chemical and drug producers have been trading businesses worth billions of dollars for the last three or four years. Those deciding to focus on chemical companies have been buying up rivals in segments where they can be dominant players.
Clariant A.G. of Switzerland, now the world's largest producer of specialty chemicals, was formed through the merger of businesses spun off in the mid-1990's from what was then Sandoz of Switzerland (which later merged with Ciba-Geigy) and Hoechst in Frankfurt.
More recently, the pharmaceutical companies Novartis and what is now Astra-Zeneca have spun off their crop-science businesses into a new company called Syngenta A.G., which has sales of more than $7 billion.
The mixing and matching reached nearly fever point today in Germany. Just as BASF was announcing the sale of its drug business to Abbott Laboratories, two German chemical companies made a $2 billion bid for a British rival -- all the while trying to wrap up their own merger.
Degussa-Huels A.G. and SKW Trostberg A.G., which are both controlled by the German utility conglomerate E.ON A.G., made a 1.3 billion bid ($1.9 billion) for the British rival, Laporte. Degussa and SKW have each been through a raft of mergers and takeovers. Now the two are merging, because their former parent companies Veba A.G. and RWE A.G. recently merged to form E.ON.
Even with that merger, the carousel is not ready to stop. Degussa and SKW have already announced their intention to sell off about $3 billion worth of businesses, in an attempt to simplify their combined company. But one thing they will certainly not use the money for is an acquisition in the drug business.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
After 8 Years, O'Neal adds College Degree to His Resume

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 15

 BODY:
The great poets are forever being quoted in earnest and solemn commencement addresses, but this undoubtedly was the first speech ever filigreed with the words of Keats, Coleridge, Frost and Shaq.
Shaquille O'Neal received his bachelor's degree from Louisiana State University today, eight years after he left early to pursue fame and fortune in professional basketball, movies and rap music. Even with an economic downturn on the horizon, job prospects appeared encouraging for the new graduate. 
 "I'd like to thank Mr. O'Neal for dramatically increasing the starting salary of this graduating class," Dr. Mark A. Emmert, the university chancellor, said to a spasm of laughter.
O'Neal is the most prominent of about 30 players -- including Allan Houston and Larry Johnson of the Knicks -- the National Basketball Association says have completed their degrees during their professional careers.
Their diplomas are seen as antidotes to statistics nationwide indicating that players in men's basketball and football graduate at rates significantly lower than the general student body.
"I'm very proud of him," Lucille Harrison, O'Neal's mother, said in an interview. "He made a promise to me, he set his goal and he achieved it."
If a degree in general studies ever seemed superfluous for anyone, it would seem so for O'Neal, who at 28 will earn more than $19 million this season with the Los Angeles Lakers as part of a seven-year contract extension worth $152 million. Still, he promised his mother that he would get his diploma, and today he did.
At a morning commencement, the playful O'Neal sat on the dais with university officials and enlivened a sober ceremony by proclaiming that L.S.U. now stood for Love Shaq University.
That's an improvement, at least, over his claim of previous years that it stood for Learn Slowly University.
"Can you dig it, can you dig it?" O'Neal said in a deep baritone, as if he were speaking to a Lakers crowd at a victory parade instead of an august gathering of caps and gowns.
And so what if he didn't qualify to wear the hoods bestowed on honors graduates. He commissioned his own, fashioning a golden scarf with the words "Shaq is finished" and "For you, Mom."
"For people who think money and fame are important, they are only a small piece of the pie," O'Neal said in a short speech to his fellow graduates in the same arena where he had once played basketball. "You need an education to feel secure." And, to much laughter, "I feel secure that I can get a real job now."
During this moment of dunk and circumstance, as the local newspaper called it, a member of the L.S.U. board of supervisors told the audience that O'Neal now truly deserved to be called by his self-administered honorific, the Big Aristotle.
And in delivering the commencement address, the university's provost quoted O'Neal's words along with those of the great poets, citing his remarks earlier this week that he could now do anything because "I am an educated man."
"You had it just right, sir," Daniel M. Fogel, the provost, said to O'Neal.
The 7-foot-1, 315-pound O'Neal joked to reporters that he was the class valedictorian, saying he had achieved a 4.6 grade-point average on a 4.0 scale. He has played down the rigor of his education, saying that he took his standardized test scores in high school by giving random answers to a rap beat in his head ("A to B, C to D"), and proclaiming that he would receive his degree in "crayon biology."
Yet, it was clear that he held graduating from college in the same esteem as he did winning an N.B.A. title last season, along with being named the league's most valuable player.
"With all I've accomplished, if I don't have an education to handle these things, nothing matters," said O'Neal, who with the Lakers' blessing missed tonight's game against Vancouver and will rejoin the team on Sunday in Toronto. "I have a lot of money, but I wouldn't be able to handle it without an education."
It was unclear whether O'Neal, who is heavily involved in charities, including a program to provide computers to inner-city children, had donated money to L.S.U. A spokesperson for the university said he had no knowledge of that.
O'Neal, the stepson of a former Army sergeant, met Dale Brown, then the L.S.U. coach, while living in Germany and came here on a scholarship after attending high school in San Antonio. He left for the N.B.A. after his junior season in 1992, promising his mother -- in writing, the story goes -- that he would complete the 28 credits he needed for a degree.
A year and a half ago, according to Emmert, the L.S.U. chancellor, O'Neal contacted him about completing his graduation requirements. A program of correspondence courses and independent study -- some on campus, much online -- was devised. "Thank God for the Internet," said O'Neal, who even ordered his size XXXL cap and gown through the World Wide Web.
Learning to concentrate on his studies while living the peripatetic life of a professional basketball player left him frustrated many times, said O'Neal, who added, "I had to reteach myself to study." He said he took such courses as geography, agronomy and kinesiology to complete his degree.
"We treated him like any other student," said Freddie Martin, the head of the L.S.U. agronomy department. "He had to do the work like everyone else."
When O'Neal hesitated to complete his courses last summer after winning an N.B.A. title and the league's M.V.P. award, his academic adviser, Mike Mallet, said he admonished him, "You're going to be a dumb M.V.P. if you don't put some time in the classroom."
O'Neal complied. And today he became a potent symbol of the value of pursuing and completing an education even after the accomplishment of great personal and professional success. This message, L.S.U. officials hoped, would be particularly resonant in Louisiana, where 21 percent of the population does not have a high school diploma and where only 69 percent of college freshmen return for their sophomore years. "When kids get blinded by things that are fleeting, this puts the focus on things that are lasting," said Charles Weems, a member of the L.S.U. board of supervisors. "It's a big statement to young people that whether you're successful or struggling, if you stay with it, you can do it."
Not every graduate believed that O'Neal deserved such prominent attention on the commencement dais. Scott McWhorter, who received his doctorate in chemistry, said that while he felt O'Neal's degree was legitimate, "It shows the power of the almighty dollar."
"He's sitting with the chancellor," McWhorter said. "What did he do that no one else did except make a lot of money for his athletic prowess? It kind of demeans the meaning of education, what we're here for."
Many of the graduates interviewed, however, said they were impressed that O'Neal had completed his degree even when he could afford to buy a large part of the university.
"I think he's a stand-up guy," said John Tiernan, who received a bachelor's degree in the college of arts and sciences. "He's obviously doing this because he values his education. That's a lot more than you can say about a lot of people in his position. If you gave me a million dollars, or $30 million, I'm not sure I'd have the same motivation. I'd like to say I would. I think it's pretty respectable."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Stocks Fall Sharply on Record Volume

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Stocks fell sharply yesterday on record trading volume, pushing the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to a new closing low for the year. Only a late-day rebound kept the Nasdaq composite index from ending just a few points from its low.
The decline was set off by a sell-off in Microsoft, which said after the market closed Thursday that it would miss Wall Street's forecasts for its fourth-quarter earnings. 
 The report follows similar announcements by Intel, Compaq Computer and others that confirm slowing economic growth and slower consumer spending, which is cutting into their sales.
It seems that as long as the stream of earnings disappointments continues, the stock market will have a hard time finding its feet. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S.& P. 500 index have now given up the gains they made after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, indicated on Dec. 5 that the central bank would cut interest rates if the economy showed signs of heading into a recession.
"The election is finally behind us, and we are back to business, and business stinks," said Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company. "In the first half of next year, you will be lucky to do 2 percent growth. But, more importantly, the profits are going to be very disappointing."
The Dow fell 240.03 points, or 2.3 percent, to 10,434.96. The technology-heavy Nasdaq dropped 75.24 points, or 2.8 percent, to 2,653.27, while the S.& P. 500 lost 28.78 points, or 2.2 percent, to 1,312.15. Its previous closing low was 1,314.95 on Nov. 30. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 1.56 billion shares, just beating the 1.54 billion traded on Nov. 30.
Some of today's decline and volume was caused by the rapid buying and selling associated with the quarterly expiration of stock index futures, options on indexes and options on individual stocks.
Microsoft projected late Thursday that it would report earnings of 46 to 47 cents a share in the current quarter, 5 percent to 6 percent below analysts' estimates, and earnings of $1.80 to $1.82 a share for the fiscal year ending in June, about 5 percent below expectations. Microsoft's stock was down $6.31, to $49.19. It traded as low as $48.06, its lowest intraday trade in more than two years.
Other technology stocks also fell, including Intel, which was off $2.69, to $32.44. Among the other big technology losers were I.B.M., Hewlett-Packard, Cisco Systems, Qualcomm, EMC, Compaq Computer and JDS Uniphase.
Stocks that are hurt when the economy and consumer spending slows also declined. Among them were Home Depot, down $1.94, to $41.94, and Wal-Mart Stores, down $1.19, to $49.88. Morgan Stanley's index of so-called cyclical stocks was off 1.9 percent.
Shares of America Online, down $1.04, to $48.96, and Time Warner, off $1.78, to $72.72, dropped the day after the Federal Trade Commission approved their merger and cleared the way for the creation of the world's largest media company.
The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note was at 5.17 percent, down from 5.21 percent on Thursday. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 5.42 percent, from 5.44 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Moses Abramovitz, 88; Led U.S. Economic Association

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
Moses Abramovitz , a former president of the American Economic Association and a leading authority on the causes of growth and business cycles, died Dec. 1 at Stanford University Hospital. He was 88.
The cause was complications after he was admitted to the hospital with a gastroenterological condition, said Paul David, a fellow economic historian at Stanford University. 
 Mr. Abramovitz of Stanford, Calif., held the William Robertson Coe Professorship in American Economic History, taught at Stanford for 30 years and served as department chairman.
"He was one of the pioneers of the modern study of economic growth, and his discoveries and analysis shaped the thinking of the profession," said Prof. Gavin Wright, also an economic historian at Stanford. He also helped build Stanford's department into one of the world's best.
Mr. Abramovitz was not active in policy debates. But his careful, fact-based research was central to many of the most important policy decisions of his time.
A paper he published in 1956 made the argument, startling at the time, that rapid growth in living standards in the United States in the first half of the 20th century could not be fully explained, as had been widely assumed, by the growth of the labor force and capital equipment. Instead, about half of the rate of growth was attributable to productivity growth -- the ability of corporations to take given amounts of labor and equipment and turn out an ever increasing amount of output.
Citing the research by Mr. Abramovitz and by Robert Solow, Nobel laureate at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, economists concluded that the economy would prosper by emphasizing spending on research and education, the keys to lifting productivity.
Mr. Abramovitz also studied convergence of productivity, finding that the further behind the United States the other industrialized countries were, the faster they were likely to close the gap. But when he extended his research to developing countries, the generalization broke down. He elaborated the notion of "social capability," arguing that poor economies would not develop automatically. They had to build legal, political and cultural institutions that would encourage growth.
But Mr. Abramovitz's most significant contribution in his field may have preceded his academic career. During World War II, he served on the War Production Board with Simon Kuznets, a creator of modern systems for measuring economic activity and an eventual Nobel laureate. President Franklin D. Roosevelt had created the board to help plan for war.
In 1942, President Roosevelt and the military proposed a huge armament program. The proposal started a "feasibility debate," as to whether the economy could churn out the planes, tanks and artillery that the military said it needed and yet have enough capacity left over to produce food, clothing and other civilian goods.
Mr. Abramovitz, with Mr. Kuznets and others, brought modern measures of economic capacity to bear, arguing that the military's plan was infeasible and if it was tried, would lead to shortages and economic dislocation. According to Prof. Michael Edelstein of Queens College the board's findings were influential in convincing the Roosevelt administration to cut back its demands and avoid severe wartime shortages.
Mr. Abramovitz was born in Brooklyn in 1912 and earned his bachelor's degree in economics summa cum laude from Harvard University in 1932 and his doctorate from Columbia University in 1939. He served as chief of the European industry and trade section of the Office of Strategic Services and, during 1945 and 1946, served as economic adviser to the United States representative on the Allied Reparations Commission.
Mr. Abramovitz is survived by his son, Joel,, and two granddaughters, Rachel and Sarah, all of Newtown, Mass. His wife, Carrie, died in 1999.
Mr. David, who was a co-author with Mr. Abramovitz on several papers, said, "He remained the least-ego-involved scholar among all the truly distinguished economists I have had the privilege of knowing."
Indeed, Mr. Abramovitz recounted with great modesty his role in the reparations debate during the waning days of World War II. Treasury Secretary Henry Morgenthau had proposed a plan to deindustrialize the German economy. A research team at Office of Strategic Services, led by Mr. Abramovitz, wrote a memorandum arguing that the Morgenthau plan would destroy German's capacity to export and, therefore, leave it unable to pay for food and other essential imports. The memorandum outraged Mr. Morgenthau.
At a meeting with Ed Mason, the chief economist at O.S.S., Mr. Abramovitz, and another eminent economist, Emile Despres, Mr. Morgenthau angrily asked, "Who is responsible for this?" Mr. Abramovitz later recalled, "Mason looked at Despres, and Emile looked at me. I had no one else to look at. The buck stopped with me. So, rather meekly, I said I was responsible."

HEADLINE: THE 43RD PRESIDENT: SECOND CAREERS;
Lucrative Lobbying Jobs Await Many Leaving Government Service

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
Business is out shopping these days, and what it is looking for does not come cheap: former senators, retired and defeated congressmen and top officials leaving the White House. Washington may be in transition, but for business, all this changing of hands is a hiring opportunity -- creating a new crop of ex-officeholders leaving top positions and now being considered for new jobs as corporate lobbyists.
Need some help with financial services in Washington? What about Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, a Republican who just lost his re-election bid? He even has a major financial instrument -- the Roth I.R.A. named after him -- and he is considered a prime catch. So is departing Senator Connie Mack, an affable Florida Republican who retired, or Senator Spencer Abraham, a defeated Republican of Michigan, who not only has a law degree from Harvard, but also is considered an expert in high-tech issues. 
 While the mating dance between the newly unemployed officials and a lobbying industry hungering for new talent is nothing new, it is operating at a fever pitch this year. For starters, with a new House, a new Senate and a new Republican administration, there will be thousands of fresh faces and new issues to lobby. Moreover, with Congress so closely divided between Democrats and Republicans, there is an increasing demand by business for members from both sides of the aisle, especially on such issues as tax cuts, Social Security reform and Medicare.
"The lawmakers who will be making the biggest killings are those who were the biggest names and who sat on the most powerful committees," said Charles Lewis, executive director of the Center for Public Integrity, a nonprofit group in Washington. "Folks like that are potentially worth extraordinary amounts of money, and lobbying firms will shell out for them."
From a business standpoint, if there is any lesson from the last decade, it is that Washington is an increasingly important force to be reckoned with -- either for good, as the many telecommunications companies that benefited from government policies found, or as a force that can hurt, as Microsoft found when the government filed an antitrust suit against it. As a result, business is increasingly willing to pay for Washington expertise -- seven-figure salaries for brand-name senators and $200,000 to $400,000 for those lower in the pecking order.
The biggest names leaving the Hill, of course, are getting the most attention. Take Senator Roth, former chairman of the Senate finance committee, or Senator Mack.
"Senator Roth would be viewed as having essentially total access to other committee members of matters amounting to billions of dollars," said Wright Andrews, a lobbyist and former president of the American League of Lobbyists. "And Mack is well respected and a nice fellow. He's been on the banking committee, so that is his natural constituency."
A spokesman for Senator Abraham said that "many groups have contacted him with opportunities, and his record in the Senate brings a lot to the table." The spokesman, Joseph H. Davis, added, "There is a lot he is interested in, and he's worked on a broad range of issues and has been on a lot of committees."
As for Senator Mack, "He's been engaged in discussions with many different business groups," said Nancy Segerdahl, a spokeswoman. "His focus is medical research and biotech, and he is very much involved in conversations with many companies in this area."
Others who are frequently mentioned include Representative Bill McCollum of Florida, who headed Banking, Judiciary and Intelligence subcommittees; Thomas J. Bliley Jr. of Virginia, the former House Commerce Committee chairman; Representative Bob Franks, the New Jersey Republican who failed in his Senate bid; departing Representative John Edward Porter of Illinois, who is considered an expert in Latin American affairs, and Representative Matt Salmon, an Arizona Republican who was on the International Relations Committee. And the list goes on.
From the Clinton administration, top prizes are Defense Secretary William S. Cohen; Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser; Deputy Treasury Secretary Stuart E. Eizenstat; and two former lobbyists, John Podesta, the White House chief of staff, and his deputy, Steve Ricchetti. Just this week, the Boeing Company announced it was hiring Thomas R. Pickering, a departing under secretary of state, for its Washington office.
In making the trek from Congress to the lobbying firms clustered on K Street in downtown Washington, many of these departing officials will be following a well-trod path. Already such marquee names as former Senators George J. Mitchell and Bob Dole are employed by the lobbying powerhouse of Verner, Liipfert, Bernhard, McPherson & Hand, which represents such giants as Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and Brown & Williamson Tobacco.
"Anyone who has been in the Congressional leadership or had high-profile positions in the administration and who have had experience working the business community are going to be very attractive," said Robert S. Walker, chief executive of the Wexler Group, a major lobbying firm and a former Republican congressman from Pennsylvania.
Of course, Congressional ethics rules prohibit departing members from lobbying on the Hill in the first year after they leave office. The executive branch has similar restrictions. But these rules are easily skirted as the former lawmakers are hired as "strategic advisers," directing other lobbyists until they can make direct contacts.
A couple of factors make these ex-members of Congress and former White House officials such prize catches. Star-power names provide a comfort level for corporations lobbying in Washington.
"It's a lot easier to sell your board on the idea when they are getting assistance from someone they know," said Kenneth Feltman, a lobbyist and president of the American League of Lobbyists. "That's the value of a name like Dole or Mitchell."
Even more, many departing lawmakers have an intimate knowledge of complicated government policies affecting business, as well as how business issues will play politically.
"It is impossible to calculate the value in helping clients in having a person who is as intimately familiar with the legislative process and who has the depth and breadth of relationships as former members of Congress," said Elliott Portnoy, an attorney with Arent Fox Kintner Plotkin & Kahn, whose lobbying roster includes former Senator Dale Bumpers of Arkansas and former Senator John Culver of Iowa.
On top of that, former congressmen have perks that ordinary lobbyists do not have -- access to the floor of the House and Senate and use of the Congressional Research Service and Library of Congress.
And, while some say that with a closely divided Congress, only gridlock will result, others say there will still be plenty of work for lawmakers-turned-lobbyists.
"Gridlock? That's ridiculous," said James J. Albertine, who heads his own lobbying firm. "Congress will still spend $2 trillion next year. And when you spend that kind of money, you get into all kinds of activities affecting business. That means your business needs lobbyists more than ever."

HEADLINE: THE 43RD PRESIDENT: CONGRESS;
Speaker Clarifies Stand on Bush's Tax Plan

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Seeking to clarify his stance on tax cuts, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert said today he supported President-elect George W. Bush's across-the-board tax cut but would prefer to start by passing smaller cuts piecemeal on the House floor.
Mr. Hastert insisted in a statement today that he is in lock step with Mr. Bush on tax policy but that the political reality of a narrowly divided House led him to prefer winning approval for smaller tax cuts one at a time, starting with two bills that have drawn bipartisan support: one cutting taxes for some married couples and the other repealing the federal tax on estates. 
 That approach is also supported by Representative Tom DeLay, the majority whip from Texas and a hard-line conservative.
"I support across-the-board tax relief because I believe it is one of the fairest ways to cut taxes," Mr. Hastert said. "I also believe that across-the-board tax relief may help the economy avoid a recession."
"Because we had such success in passing bipartisan measures to end the marriage penalty and the death tax in this session of Congress, I believe that these two bills could quickly be enacted in the law at the beginning of next year," Mr. Hastert added. "That is why I advocate that we start with these two bills in the 107th Congress."
President-elect Bush reiterated today his desire to see his $1.3 trillion tax package clear Congress and become law and expressed optimism that that would occur.
"I haven't had a chance to talk to the speaker yet," Mr. Bush said at a news conference today. "But what I found to be positive is the speaker was recognizing that we need some tax relief. And I have made it clear to the speaker once before that, you know, I campaigned on a package that I thought was fair and fiscally sound and responsible, and I strongly believe that."
Mr. Hastert's press secretary, John P. Feehery, said "there was some miscommunication" on Thursday at Mr. Hastert's news conference.
On Thursday, Mr. Hastert was asked whether he would seek passage of an across-the-board tax cut like the one Mr. Bush has advocated or stick to smaller pieces of the overall proposal. He said he favored dealing with the tax package in smaller pieces, a remark that was taken as an effort to distance himself from Mr. Bush's plan.
Ari Fleischer, Mr. Bush's press secretary, said he called Mr. Hastert's staff this morning to ask about news reports on Mr. Hastert's remarks.
Representative Roy Blunt, the Missouri Republican who spearheads Mr. Bush's House liaison team, said Mr. Hastert's approach to tax cuts is best.
"We can pass anything in his tax package, as long as we pass it as a stand-alone item," Mr. Blunt said. "As you begin to package those together, it becomes more difficult."

HEADLINE: SUNY Hospitals Seek Loans, Not Subsidies, to Cover Gap

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
The budget gap for the State University of New York's hospitals has ballooned to $230 million, about 13 percent of SUNY's operating budget, but the university is not asking for any state subsidies to close that gap, according to the university's budget request for next year, which was released yesterday.
The university plans to borrow from the state to cover the gap, as it has for the last two years, while it continues to try to solve the problem, university officials said. 
 H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, has expressed concern that if SUNY does not press the governor and the Legislature for money to close the gap, the university may have to raise tuition or reduce the amount of money spent on instruction. So far, however, the university has relied largely on borrowing to close the gap.
SUNY is seeking a $1.8 billion operating budget for its 30 state-operated and statutory colleges next year -- a $132 million increase, or 7.5 percent.
The university has turned to consultants at PriceWaterhouseCoopers for advice on how the gap might be closed. But the consultants concluded earlier this year that the gap could not be closed by the hospitals themselves.
Edward F. Cox, a SUNY trustee and chairman of the board's finance and administration committee, said that SUNY had sought to give its hospitals more flexibility to compete with private hospitals and bring in more revenue. "Unfortunately, there has been no reaction from the political community," he said, "so we have this problem. There is not much more we can do as trustees."
The rest of the budget message was generally more upbeat. Of the $132 million budget increase SUNY is seeking, $42 million is for contractual increases for faculty and staff. It is also asking for $50 million for new initiatives, including $40 million to improve quality and $5 million to help colleges that are struggling to shift their missions.
Brian T. Stenson, SUNY's vice chancellor for finance and business, said yesterday at a meeting of the finance and administration committee that SUNY would like to change its financial structure "so the operating budget of the university does not depend on the payments of the hospitals."
SUNY officials say their problems stem from the state's requirement that SUNY's medical centers in Stony Brook, Brooklyn and Syracuse pay $116 million a year to cover fringe benefits for their employees, a sum they were once able to pay but can no longer afford because of belt-tightening brought about by the growth of managed care. Instead of paying the money directly to the state, the hospitals are supposed to pay the money to SUNY. If the hospitals fall short, as they have for several years, SUNY must scramble to cover the shortfall in any way it can.
Two years ago, the hospitals paid $39 million of the $116 million assessment, leaving a $77 million gap. Last year they paid that $77 million plus $2 million of the next $116 million assessment. They entered the current fiscal year with a $114 million bill from last year on top of the $116 million they owe for this year.
Mr. Stenson said that SUNY did not know what the hospitals would be able to pay this year.
The state has not always asked the hospitals to cover employee benefits. In the 1980's, the state subsidized the hospitals, which serve as teaching hospitals for medical students and provide care for the indigent. In 1990, the state stopped paying the subsidy. Two years later it asked the hospitals, which then had financial surpluses, to share their bounty. But changes in the economics of health care in recent years have turned surpluses into red ink for many hospitals, including SUNY's.
John Clarkson, deputy director for fiscal research and policy analysis in the comptroller's office, said that the university could not continue to roll the obligation over year after year.
"Eventually they'll run out of room to borrow," he said.

HEADLINE: THE 43RD PRESIDENT;
Congress Finishes Its Work By Approving Spending Bill

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Congress tonight finished its work for the year and approved a huge spending bill after President Clinton reached agreement with a powerful Alaska senator on a compromise to protect an endangered species of sea lion.
The House passed the omnibus spending bill by a vote of 292 to 60, and the Senate approved it by voice vote. This cleared the way for final adjournment of the 106th Congress, which began nearly two years ago with the Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton. 
 The $450 billion bill provides money to hire teachers, repair crumbling schools, finance biomedical research and increase Medicare payments to hospitals and health maintenance organizations. It also provides $25 billion worth of tax credits and other incentives for individuals and businesses to invest in some of the nation's poorest communities over the next 10 years.
In addition, the bill grants legal status to nearly 700,000 immigrants whose status is either illegal or questionable.
White House officials said they rejoiced at passage of the bill, which they believe will perpetuate President Clinton's priorities for the government long after he leaves office.
"I am pleased that Congress and I have reached agreement on a budget for the coming year," Mr. Clinton said. "It is a budget that is fiscally responsible, pays down the debt and makes vital investments in our nation's future. In education, health care and community renewal, this budget provides more opportunity for more Americans than ever before."
Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois said the bill laid a good foundation for President-elect George W. Bush to build upon. "Republicans have boosted education spending by 50 percent since 1995," providing $44.5 billion in the current fiscal year, which began on Oct. 1, Mr. Hastert said.
Today's action closes a long-running battle between Mr. Clinton and Congress over the federal budget.
Lawmakers spent much of the last two years debating big issues like taxes, patients' rights, prescription drugs and the financing of election campaigns.
The disputes that delayed adjournment today involved smaller issues of concern to a handful of senators, but passions ran just as deep. Senator Ted Stevens, the Alaska Republican who is chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, said he would not let Congress adjourn until it allowed fishermen to continue harvesting pollock and cod off the coast of Alaska.
The Clinton administration plans to tighten restrictions on such fishing because, it says, the pollock and cod are essential food for an endangered species of sea lions. Senator Stevens said the new restrictions would devastate the fishing industry and "create ghost towns in my state along the shore from Kodiak all the way out the Aleutian chain."
Heather Weiner, a lawyer at the Earth Justice Legal Defense Fund, an environmental group, said the number of sea lions in western Alaska had declined sharply, to fewer than 20,000 today from 175,000 in 1960. In a scientific study issued on Dec. 1, the Clinton administration said that commercial fishing was a significant factor in the decline.
Sylvia M. Mathews, deputy director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, said the compromise would allow fishermen to continue fishing for pollock and cod, but would not suspend the Endangered Species Act, as Mr. Stevens had originally proposed.
"We will protect fishing incomes and harvesting at 1999 levels," Ms. Mathews said.
The bill, she said, will provide $50 million of economic assistance to Alaska. Of this sum, $20 million is for projects to protect the sea lions and to control whales, which Mr. Stevens says are killing the sea lions. The bill provides $30 million for direct payments to individuals and businesses to protect the livelihood of Alaska fishermen.
Senator Stevens said, "I can't say that we won this argument, but I can say that we have reached a conclusion that will allow approximately 90 percent of the fishermen to return to fishing in January."
Ms. Weiner said she was disappointed by the compromise. "The Endangered Species Act is not waived," she said. "It is intact. It remains to be seen if the sea lions will survive as well. Under this compromise, the fishing industry can put up roadblocks to delay conservation measures."
No compromise was reached on a separate issue that held up the adjournment of Congress. Senators from Northeastern states had threatened a filibuster in their efforts to secure more assistance for Amtrak.
They had offered a proposal to help Amtrak issue $10 billion worth of bonds to develop high-speed railways. The government would have indirectly subsidized the bonds by providing a tax credit to investors, in place of the interest normally paid on bonds.
Republican leaders of Congress blocked the proposal, saying Amtrak should first demonstrate that it could operate profitably. Supporters of Amtrak withdrew the threat of a filibuster after Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Senate Republican leader, and several committee chairmen promised to consider similar legislation next year.
"That is good enough for me," said Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, a strong supporter of Amtrak, who rides the train to and from Washington. "I will withdraw any attempt to delay consideration of this final bill."
Since the start of the fiscal year on Oct. 1, Congress has passed 20 stopgap spending bills, each lasting for several days at a time, and it passed another one today, financing the government until President Clinton signs the omnibus spending bill.
The bill passed tonight will temporarily revive a provision of immigration law that allowed large numbers of people to obtain green cards while residing in the United States. Since this provision of the law expired in 1998, some immigrants have been forced to leave this country and return to their homelands while pursuing their visa applications.
This provision, known as section 245(i) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, will be reinstated for four months. Immigrants must apply by April 30, 2001.
However, Republican leaders of Congress killed another proposal that would have helped certain immigrants who are subject to deportation because they committed relatively minor crimes before 1996. Under a 1996 law, a large number of offenses, including misdemeanors, were retroactively defined as aggravated felonies requiring deportation.
Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, said he was outraged that Congress had adjourned for the year without passing legislation to relieve the "blatant unfairness" of the 1996 law.
"A stunning piece of cruelty is left uncorrected," Mr. Frank said. "The 1996 law has ruined families, destroyed lives and inflicted pain on innocent children."
The legislation passed tonight provides $35 billion over five years to improve coverage for Medicare beneficiaries and to increase payments to hospitals, home health agencies, nursing homes and managed care plans. Lawmakers of both parties said they hoped the higher payments would stem the exodus of H.M.O.'s from Medicare.
Under the bill, people with Lou Gehrig's disease, also known as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, could immediately qualify for Medicare coverage, without having to wait 24 months as required under current law.
Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said the bill included $1.6 billion over the next five years for health programs and providers in New York. That includes $751 million for New York hospitals, especially teaching hospitals and small rural hospitals; $800 million for children's health insurance; and $116 million for H.M.O.'s.
The bill will make it easier for children in low-income families to get health benefits through Medicaid and the Children's Health Insurance Program, created by Congress in 1997. Many uninsured children are eligible for those programs but not enrolled. Under the bill, states could enroll children at schools, child support enforcement agencies, homeless shelters and other sites.
The measure guarantees that people leaving welfare for work will be able to keep their Medicaid coverage for 12 months. A law authorizing such coverage was due to expire on Sept. 30 next year.

HEADLINE: Oil Patch Is Coming Back to Life As Natural Gas Prices Set Record

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY 

DATELINE: WOODWARD, Okla.

 BODY:
No Lear jets are parked at the local airstrip anymore. The toys of the oil boom days disappeared when prices collapsed nearly two decades ago. Only the wild memories remain, like the time one oilman flew his friends to New Orleans for lunch because he wanted fresh oysters.
The bust destroyed every corner of the beleaguered oil patch, from West Texas through Oklahoma into southern Kansas, but it never quite killed the hope that the good times would come again. There was even a bumper sticker that pleaded, "Dear God, please give me another oil boom and I promise" not to blow it all this time around. 
 Their prayers may now be answered.
With winter approaching and natural gas prices hitting all-time highs in December, the oil patch is coming alive again. The rest of the country is probably not celebrating the rise in natural gas prices, since energy officials are predicting 50 percent increases in home heating bills. But many people here believe that the nation's growing appetite for natural gas is reviving an area once left for dead.
"I don't know how long it will last," said A. J. Jacques, whose company, Cheyenne Drilling, is operating at full capacity, "but it's the closest I've seen to a boom in 20 years."
Even as people here are daring to be optimistic, the memories of the bust temper any premature exuberance. The days of highflying, conspicuous consumption are remembered fondly, yet no one expects to see them again.
But the brick storefronts on Main Street are nearly all occupied. Many of the trucks and cars parked outside are new. For now, that is more than good enough.
"There have been some lessons learned," said Rodney Myers, a vice president with the Apache Corporation, one of the nation's largest independent oil companies, which is aggressively exploring for natural gas outside Woodward. "I don't think we're at a point in time where people are buying helicopters or ranches or taking big trips to Las Vegas with their 57 best friends."
No one is saying -- yet -- that this could rival the crazy boom days of the late 1970's and early 1980's, when a peak of more than 4,500 drilling rigs operated in the United States. Then, the derricks were searching primarily for oil. Now, many of those same derricks are drilling again, this time for natural gas. Since January, the price of natural gas has quadrupled, in part to meet the demands of a new generation of electrical plants that run on gas, which is considered a "clean" fuel.
Until recently, the price of natural gas was so cheap that companies could not justify drilling new wells. Now, with some experts predicting that production will need to increase by 25 percent to meet demand, the number of rotary rigs operating in the United States has more than doubled in the past 18 months, to 1,090, more than 800 of them in search of natural gas.
In Kansas, the number of drilling permits has nearly doubled in the past year. Employment in the Texas oil field town of Odessa has increased by almost 6 percent in the last three months. Here in Woodward, oil field equipment once sat rusting like junked cars. Now every drilling rig for miles is booked in advance. Roughnecks are in such demand that some companies have raised salaries from about $11 an hour to more than $16.
"I can't keep but thinking that we're going to have at least two to five years of good times," said Kerri D. Martin, president of Diamond Services Company, which has seen gross revenues nearly double in the past year. "I can't see any reason it's going to go south."
Bill Gilmer, a senior economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, said the level of domestic activity was the highest in a decade. For the most part, huge multinational companies like Exxon Mobil have largely left the oil patch to concentrate on larger, more lucrative fields overseas. But rising gas prices have attracted independent producers like Apache and others.
"They are making a ton of money," Mr. Gilmer said. And the money is trickling down. Service companies in towns like Woodward or Elk City, Okla., or Perryton, Tex., are thriving.
Inside his shiny new pickup truck, Bobby Alexander drove through the huge, brown prairies of the Oklahoma panhandle last week. In the distance stood a derrick, then a mile or so later, there was another one and then another. Mr. Alexander began as a roughneck in the 1970's but left the oil business in 1986 at the very bottom of the bust.
In February, though, he bought into Cheyenne Drilling with Mr. Jacques, and his timing has been impeccable. All 12 of Cheyenne's drilling rigs are under lease by production companies. Only last year, the price of natural gas was less than $2 per million British thermal units. This month, the price went higher than $9 before falling slightly.
"We had no idea that prices were going to go like they are," Mr. Alexander said, smiling as he drove. He said companies were optimistic that they could be profitable even if prices fell to half the current level. "It looks like this could last a little bit longer."
In the late 1970's and the early 1980's, the high price of oil attracted thousands of people from Missouri and Louisiana, all looking for work. They slept under bridges or in tents at the nearby state park. Money seemed to be everywhere. At the height of the boom, more than 100 aircraft were based at the tiny local airstrip, quite a fleet for a town of less than 20,000 people.
"We had a pretty good Air Force for a while," Mr. Alexander said.
But everything began collapsing in 1983 when the combination of bad bank loans and plummeting prices crushed the oil economy. The migrants who had come to work in the oil fields disappeared, almost overnight. The town went years without issuing a permit for a new building or home.
"Our city budget went from about $10 million to about $3.5 million in four and a half years," said Dr. John Hawkins, an optometrist who serves as the town's part-time mayor. Now, he reports, local sales tax receipts have risen steadily all year, a reflection of improving times.
It is the memories of those hard times that are shaping the more restrained attitudes today toward the record natural gas prices. There is a stubborn pride shared by those who survived. For years, Mr. Jacques, of Cheyenne Drilling, scoured auctions and junkyards to piece together the equipment to build drilling rigs and stay in business.
Mr. Martin, 41, the president of Diamond Services, need only consult with his father, Kenneth (Buster) Martin, who once placed his last $25,000 on his banker's desk as collateral to keep the company running. The senior Mr. Martin cut wages, sold equipment for 20 cents on the dollar and recalled that his company survived literally week to week.
"No one knows what depressed is," the senior Mr. Martin recalled. "I got up depressed in the 80's. And I went to bed depressed."
The younger Mr. Martin added: "He keeps me pretty well grounded. I'm more of a go, go, go type. He keeps me in check."
The most immediate problem is finding enough workers. Many people are reluctant to return to the boom-and-bust oil economy, particularly at a time when jobs are plentiful in other sectors of the economy. "You almost feel like you're recruiting for a pro team," the younger Mr. Martin said of competition for new employees. "There are some companies I've heard that have a sign-on bonus."
One old-timer who may be unable to resist the promise of more good times is J. D. Hodges, now 63. Before the bust, Mr. Hodges owned a helicopter that he landed on a pad atop his office building. He also bought a Lear jet with a crew, and was known to take friends on impromptu trips to New Orleans and Las Vegas when the mood struck. He lost it all in the bust, then re-emerged in the trucking business. In recent days he bought a drilling rig.
He has not decided whether he will sell the rig for a profit or go back into business himself.
"Natural gas is in vogue and it will be for decades to come," he predicted.
As yet, everyone is optimistic but maybe not ready to buy a Lear. There is a custom-made motorcycle in the window of Cycle City, a local Harley Davidson store. It is painted orange and costs $60,000.
The buyer, by the way, is in the oil and gas industry.

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
TURKEY: OCALAN PLEA
The European Court of Human Rights will hear an appeal brought against Turkey by the jailed Kurdish separatist leader Abdullah Ocalan, 51, and his lawyers said he would make a broad defense of his actions on historical and political grounds. The court said he would be tried next year before 17 judges. Douglas Frantz (NYT) 

NORTHERN IRELAND: PROTESTANT PACT
Protestant guerrillas signed a statement calling off an internal feud in the Belfast area that had taken seven lives and forced 200 families from their homes. Two paramilitary groups were pitted against each other in what the police said was a dispute involving drug-dealing, turf wars and bad feeling among leaders. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
NORTHERN IRELAND: SINN FEIN CASE
The High Court in Belfast said it would rule next month on a legal challenge by Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A., to a decision by the Assembly's first minister, David Trimble, to ban its ministers from meetings with their counterparts in the Irish government. Mr. Trimble acted to placate critics within his Ulster Unionist Party who want to pull out of government with Sinn Fein to protest the I.R.A.'s refusal to begin disarming. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
RUSSIA: MOVE ON MEDIA TYCOON
Tax officials went to court to seize the media empire of Vladimir Gusinsky, the tycoon under arrest in Spain on what the Kremlin says are fraud charges and he says is a political vendetta. Tax officials said the Gusinsky empire is insolvent. Mr. Gusinsky called it another effort by President Vladimir V. Putin to silence powerful critics, including him. Michael Wines (NYT)
 
BOSNIA: YUGOSLAV TIES
Yugoslavia and Bosnia established diplomatic relations, ending eight years of enmity after the breakup of the Yugoslav federation and a three-year war in Bosnia. The countries' foreign ministers signed a protocol in Belgrade, declaring that the step would ensure that war would no longer be possible in the region. Carlotta Gall (NYT)
 
SPAIN: ILLEGAL IMMIGRANT NUMBERS QUADRUPLE
The number of illegal immigrants detained while trying to enter Spain from Morocco has quadrupled this year compared with 1999, officials said. More than 3,500 people, mostly Moroccans and sub-Saharan Africans, were arrested last year in Spanish waters or on the southern coast, and almost 15,000 have been detained so far this year. Benjamin Jones (NYT)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
SAUDI ARABIA: AMERICAN NOT SOLE SUSPECT
An American citizen arrested last week is just one of several suspects in an explosion that killed a British man in Saudi Arabia on Nov. 17 and has not been firmly linked to the blast, the official news agency reported. An unidentified Interior Ministry official, quoted by the Saudi Press Agency, said earlier statements about a proven link between Michael Sedlak and the explosion were unfounded. (AP)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
CANADA: PORNOGRAPHY RULING
The Supreme Court ruled that restrictions on importing hard-core pornography, including homosexual erotica, were constitutionally legitimate infringements on freedom of expression. But it also declared that customs officials had unfairly singled out homosexual pornography as opposed to heterosexual material, and it struck down one section of the Customs Act to put the onus of proof on the government, not the importer. (Reuters)
 
ASIA
 
KOREAS: CONTENTIOUS TALKS
South and North Korea agreed to open a high-level economic dialogue this month to discuss rebuilding the North's dilapidated economy and providing it with electricity. The last-minute agreement followed four days of talks, the most contentious discussions between the countries since their leaders agreed to work toward reconciliation. The two sides had argued over how the South should help ease the North's electricity shortages. (AP)
 
NORTH KOREA: TIES TO SPAIN
Madrid will establish diplomatic relations with North Korea in an effort to assist "the process of reconciliation and normalization on the Korean peninsula," officials said. The move follows a decision by a number of European nations, including Britain, Austria and Germany, to set up formal ties with the Communist state. Benjamin Jones (NYT)
 
PHILIPPINES: CONFLICTING TESTIMONY
President Joseph Estrada and his chief accuser made directly contradictory statements about a $100,000 check that is a key document in Mr. Estrada's impeachment trial. The president said that an American consultant working for him accepted the check but that he was unaware the money came from illegal gambling lords. But Luis Singson, a provincial governor, charged that he gave the check to Mr. Estrada and that the president knew it was gambling money. (AP)
 
INDIA: BEAUTY PAGEANTS BANNED
The head of Uttar Pradesh banned beauty contests, saying they violated traditional culture. His move follows a wave of success by Indian women in beauty pageants abroad, prompting dozens of competitions to spring up in India. "There is no place for vulgarity in our society," said Rajnath Singh of the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party. "We must uphold traditional social values, which do not permit this kind of vulgar display of beauty." (Reuters)
 
AFRICA
 
CONGO: KABILA AGREES TO TALKS
President Laurent Kabila of Congo has agreed to meet with his political opponents, armed and unarmed, in Libreville, Gabon, on Dec. 21 and 22, the Congolese foreign minister, Leonard She Okitundu, said at the United Nations. Mr. She Okitundu said the government had released all political prisoners in advance of the meeting, but did not give a number or the names of those freed. The Congolese are campaigning to keep the United Nations actively involved in Congo. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Climb a Bit As Factory Production Slows

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Declining costs of apparel and computers kept consumer prices from accelerating in November, while industrial production fell for a second consecutive month, government data showed today. The reports added to expectations that the Federal Reserve might cut interest rates as early as next month.
"The inflation threat clearly seems to be fading as the economy cools," said Oscar Gonzalez, an economist at John Hancock Financial Services Inc. in Boston. 
 The Consumer Price Index rose 0.2 percent last month, matching the gain in October, the Labor Department said. The rise matched analysts' expectations.
A separate report from the Federal Reserve showed that production at factories, mines and utilities fell 0.2 percent in November after a 0.1 percent decline in October, the first back-to-back declines since mid-1998, when a strike at General Motors forced automakers and parts suppliers to shut down for 54 days. Analysts had expected no change.
The core consumer price rate, which excludes energy and food, rose 0.3 percent in November after a 0.2 percent rise the previous month. Excluding the biggest rise in tobacco prices since April, the core rate would have risen 0.2 percent.
"There really wasn't any pressure anywhere except in tobacco prices," said Tim Rogers, chief economist at Briefing.com, a market analysis company in Boston. "The pressure down the road is weakening," he added. "Few expect inflation to accelerate here."
The primary inflation threat this year has been energy prices. Though crude oil costs are showing signs of falling, natural gas prices are close to a record. The Labor Department's statistics showed energy prices, which account for about a tenth of the index, rose 0.1 percent in November, the smallest increase since August. The price of crude oil, which in September rose to a 10-year high of $37.20 a barrel, has stayed below $30 a barrel for the last 10 days.
The price of clothing fell 0.4 percent in November after rising 0.3 percent in October. Personal computer prices fell 2.6 percent in November after falling 1.5 percent in each of the prior two months.
The industrial production report showed manufacturing output fell 0.5 percent in November, the steepest drop since June 1998. Capacity utilization, which measures how close to full output factories, mines and utilities are operating, fell to 81.6 percent from 82.1 percent.
