HEADLINE: THE 43RD PRESIDENT: THE PRESIDENT-ELECT;
SAYING DOWNTURN IS POSSIBLE, BUSH TRUMPETS TAX CUT

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 15

 BODY:
George W. Bush said today that he was concerned about a "possible slowdown" in the economy and called the change in the economic outlook an argument for going forward next year with his campaign proposal for a sweeping, $1.3 trillion tax cut across a decade.
Mr. Bush, who is to be sworn into office in January as the 43rd president, touched on the economy as he sat next to Senator John B. Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat, in front of a garland-bedecked fireplace in the Texas Governor's Mansion and before an array of cameras. 
 Mr. Bush said that Mr. Breaux had made clear that he did not want to leave the Senate to serve in the president-elect's new cabinet. But with Mr. Breaux's presence giving Mr. Bush an aura of bipartisanship, he went on to praise Mr. Breaux, who is known on Capitol Hill as a deal-maker who can swim against the partisan tides. "John Breaux has got the attitude that I have," Mr. Bush said, "that when you put your country ahead of party politics, it's amazing what can get done."
Mr. Bush also indicated that he would name his first cabinet nominee on Saturday at a school in Crawford, Tex., where he has a ranch. Members of Congress and Bush advisers said that the nominee would be retired Gen. Colin L. Powell as secretary of state.
Asked to confirm that Mr. Powell would be named, Mr. Bush smiled. "There's a lot of rumors," he said, "and there's going to be a lot of rumors between now and when I name my cabinet. I would hope people would give me the benefit of allowing me to name the person on our own timetable."
He added, "I think America will be pleased with the choice."
Mr. Bush spoke about the economy and his tax-cut proposal a day after the speaker of the House, Representative J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, publicly counseled that tax relief would be better handled in small bites, with tax cuts passed step by step and piece by piece. Clarifying his comments today, Mr. Hastert said he supported Mr. Bush's sweeping plan, and merely felt it would be easier to enact a bit at a time.
While it is unusual for a president to speak about a slowdown for fear of rattling financial markets, Mr. Bush and his running mate, Dick Cheney, have repeatedly struck similar themes for several weeks. Their outspokenness now not only helps to make the case for a tax cut, but could also inoculate them from responsibility for any possible recession by assigning it as the legacy of the Clinton administration.
Today, Mr. Bush cited troubles in manufacturing and automobile sales, high energy prices and jittery financial markets in explaining "my concerns about a possible slowdown." He said that such potential indicators of a robust economy running out of steam were "one of the reasons I feel so strongly about the need to reduce marginal rates in our tax cut." And he said, "I look forward to going to Washington to make the case that the plan that the people heard in America is the plan that I hope to get passed."
The staged appearances -- Mr. Breaux one day, Mr. Powell the next -- are being choreographed by the president-elect and his aides to send a message of reconciliation after a divisive election which he narrowly won in electoral votes while losing the popular vote.
One adviser to Mr. Bush said Mr. Powell, who was born in Harlem as the son of Jamaican immigrants and rose to be chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, would be named first because his presence would send several important signals. The adviser said that Mr. Powell's appointment would be comforting to foreign leaders and would be a sign of inclusiveness to blacks who voted for Vice President Al Gore.
After his transition planning was slowed for five weeks by the dispute in resolving the presidential election, Mr. Bush is now racing to assemble his cabinet and determine his policy priorities, as lawmakers on Capitol Hill warn that the narrow margin of Republican control in the House and the 50-50 split in the Senate will require huge efforts to build coalitions.
The tax-cut proposal was one of the clear dividing lines in the campaign just ended. Mr. Gore proposed only $500 billion in tax cuts, most of them for specific needs, like a college education or retirement savings. Most Democrats oppose cuts of the magnitude proposed by Mr. Bush.
In Texas, when he first came into office as governor in 1995, Mr. Bush quickly struck up a relationship with Bob Bullock, then the Democratic lieutenant governor. Many have wondered who Mr. Bush's Bob Bullock might be in Washington. The signs today were that it could be Mr. Breaux, who thanked Mr. Bush "for the opportunity to have some real good discussions."
"I am so honored that he would come," Mr. Bush said. "He's a practical man and he's got common sense." He said the two men had discussed health care issues and education and that Mr. Breaux had given "his commitment to work with me."
Though Mr. Bush is aching to put at least one Democrat in his cabinet, it was not clear whether he had actually offered a job to Mr. Breaux. If Mr. Breaux left the Senate, Louisiana's Republican governor would most likely name a Republican in his place, ending the 50-50 split.
"The senator made it clear he wants to stay in the Senate," Mr. Bush said.
The president-elect, however, made progress on other fronts. One adviser said that Mr. Bush was prepared to name a justice of the Texas Supreme Court, Alberto Gonzales, to be his White House counsel, filing out his White House staff. Mr. Gonzales, 45, a former corporate lawyer with a degree from Harvard, served as general counsel early in Mr. Bush's governorship. Mr. Bush then named him as the Texas secretary of state and then to a vacancy on the court.
Dan Bartlett, a spokesman for Mr. Bush, confirmed that Mr. Bush had discussions with Mr. Gonzales, but said Mr. Bush had not made a final decision. Officials said Mr. Bush's announcement of a White House team -- including Condoleezza Rice as national security adviser -- was expected on Sunday.
Mr. Bush said he hoped to have his cabinet named within "a couple of weeks."
For the first time today, a senior Bush transition official said that as the president-elect searches for a Treasury secretary, he would not limit himself to Wall Street.
The official said, "President-elect Bush's approach is to look at a number of places. We're looking at Wall Street. We're looking at the Hill. We're looking at think tanks. We're looking at Wall Street, but it's certainly not limited to Wall Street."
Mr. Bush's appearance today was the first time he spoke to reporters since Mr. Gore conceded on Wednesday night.
Asked to describe how he felt, Mr. Bush said, "I didn't sleep that well that night." He then spoke almost in awe of the calls of congratulations coming in one after another on Wednesday from foreign leaders.
"The great responsibilities of the job," he said, "are, you know, very evident."

HEADLINE: Move Possible For Garden (But Where?)

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Even as New York City proposes to build an Olympic stadium over the West Side rail yards, quiet negotiations are under way to move Madison Square Garden, the Knicks and the Rangers to a different site, on Ninth Avenue and 31st Street.
The proposal by Cablevision Systems, owner of the two New York teams, is only the latest example of how real estate developers and team owners are hungrily making plans for the manufacturing district and rail yards on the far West Side of Manhattan, as they have done for nearly 80 years, ever since Col. Jacob Ruppert sought unsuccessfully to build a stadium for the Yankees there. 
 Next door, at Ninth Avenue and 33rd Street, real estate executives say, the investor Harvey Schulweis and the developer Jerry I. Speyer are negotiating with the National Basketball Association to build a 1 million-square-foot office tower that would house the association's film studios, now in New Jersey.
And farther west, Robert Wood Johnson IV, who bought the New York Jets earlier this year for $635 million, wants to build a billion-dollar football stadium and annex to the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center over the vast Long Island Rail Road yards. The project, said Jay Cross, president of Jets Development, makes sense either on its own, or as part of New York's bid to play host to the Summer Olympics in 2012.
It is unclear whether the Olympic proposal (which also includes a proposed Garden site), the Jets stadium, a rebuilt Garden on Ninth Avenue, the N.B.A. complex or any other development now in the planning stages will ever be built. But with the city's economy booming and vacant office space virtually nonexistent, the relatively low-scale far West Side of Manhattan from 42nd Street south to 28th Street is once again in play.
"It's clearly the next development zone in the city because of its proximity to a major transportation hub and the lack of major sites in Midtown," said Richard B. Clark, president of Brookfield Financial Properties, which owns a site at the northwest corner of Ninth Avenue and 31st Street.
The emerging issue is exactly how the development will take place -- willy-nilly, or as part of a master plan. The Olympic proposal includes rail links and an extension of the No. 7 subway line south from Times Square, a domed stadium that would be converted for use by the Jets, and a site for a relocated Madison Square Garden on 10th Avenue. The Olympic bid has the support of the mayor and the governor and dovetails with a proposal by New York's Department of City Planning to rezone the manufacturing district west of 10th Avenue, between 28th and 42nd Streets, to allow a forest of skyscrapers.
But members of the local community board and the South Hell's Kitchen Neighborhood Association complain that a highly subsidized stadium is of dubious economic value, while acknowledging that perhaps the convention center does need to expand to attract major conventions.
Ross Graham, a member of the community board, said she favored a more comprehensive planning effort that would include affordable housing, parks, some office development and the preservation of the area's light manufacturing companies.
Then there are builders who say that development will inevitably march onto the West Side, even if proposals for rezoning, the Garden and the Olympics fade away.
"The folks talking about stadiums and everything else are going to be out of office in a year," said Jules Demchick, president of J. D. Carlyle Development, which is building a large 43-story, mixed-use project between 33rd and 34th Streets, west of Eighth Avenue. "Government has to focus on public transportation over there and development will follow, without any additional help. There's nowhere else on the island to go."
According to several real estate brokers, the N.B.A. is talking to Mr. Schulweis about a development on his site, at Ninth Avenue and 33rd Street, which is already zoned for a 33-story tower. Mr. Schulweis would say only that "the city is rampant with rumors."
Mr. Clark of Brookfield Properties, whose site is next door to Mr. Schulweis's site, was equally taciturn. Although the Olympic plan includes a new site for Madison Square Garden, Cablevision is seriously considering the Brookfield site instead, according to real estate executives.
The site is opposite the James A. Farley General Post Office, which is to become a new version of the old Pennsylvania Station, torn down in the 1960's to make way for the current Garden. A rebuilt Garden on the Brookfield site would be a block from the hub of subways and commuter trains on Seventh Avenue, where the old Garden would be demolished to make way for two new skyscrapers.
Unlike the Olympic site between 10th and 12th Avenues, it would not require the building of a new subway line. Brookfield, however, would need to acquire Mr. Schulweis's parcel to create a new Garden.
A spokesman for the Garden said no decision had been made, but Cablevision has hired a consultant to explore whether to move to a new location or renovate the existing structure.
All of the proposals now surfacing are an echo of earlier schemes to develop over what was once known as New York Central Railroad's 30th Street Yard, a network of freight tracks that stretched north to 37th Street.
Ousted from the Polo Grounds by the New York Giants in 1922, the suddenly popular Yankees sought to cut a quick deal to build a new stadium over the rail lines. But Colonel Ruppert's plan was scuttled by the War Department, which had reserved the yards for antiaircraft gun emplacements. The Yankees headed to the Bronx.
Beginning in the 1930's, there were efforts to cover over most of the rail yards and build warehouses and factories on top. Richard Ravitch, a builder who later became chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, erected the Westyard Distribution Center in 1967 on 10th Avenue between 31st and 33rd Streets. In the early 1980's, the state built the Javits center over another part of the yards.
When the M.T.A. took over the rail yards in the early 1980's, Mr. Ravitch said, he made sure that it was possible to build pillars between the newly reconfigured tracks for a platform that would support office towers, hotels and apartment buildings. "There was a lot of interest in those air rights," he said.
In 1982, Gulf and Western Industries came calling. The company, which then owned the Garden, was threatening to move the Rangers to New Jersey and the Knicks to Long Island, but wanted to know if it could build a smaller new arena at 12th Avenue. It ultimately agreed to stay put after Mayor Edward I. Koch granted a property tax break now worth more than $125 million.
The issue surfaced again in 1988 when Paul Reichman, the Canadian real estate tycoon who was then the largest commercial landlord in Manhattan, quietly put together a $2.5 billion plan to move the Garden to 12th Avenue and build eight million square feet of office space on Seventh and Ninth Avenues.
At the same time, Mr. Schulweis was planning his nearby office tower; Harry Macklowe, a developer, got approval to build an office building a block away; Julien J. Studley and Arthur Cohen wanted to build a 1,560-room hotel on a pier across from the convention center, and Arthur Imperatore proposed a residential tower on 36th Street. None of the projects survived the recession of the early 1990's.
But the M.T.A. did develop a master plan in 1989 that envisioned a seven-block development over the 30 acres of rail yards, with proceeds from the sale of development rights going to transit programs. The plan depicts a series of residential towers facing 12th Avenue and the Hudson River, with office towers on 11th Avenue and retail on 10th. In the 1990's, there was talk of the Yankees moving to a West Side stadium, but there was widespread opposition.
Still, the developers remain optimistic. "It's only a matter of time before the West Side opens up," Mr. Schulweis said.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
Starks Thrives At Garden

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
Hearing his name in association with the new team still puzzles him sometimes.
" 'John Starks of the Utah Jazz' -- it does sound funny, doesn't it?" said the player who wanted to remain a Knick for life. 
 All last season, Starks campaigned to return to his former team. Whether he was asking to be waived by Chicago or playing for the league minimum, the most popular role player in franchise history would have loved to play one more game in orange and blue.
In retrospect, he understands now how a guard-dominated team did not need him. And perhaps showing he is no longer a few fries short of a Happy Meal, Starks's decision to join John Stockton and Karl Malone in the Western Conference has proved to be a stroke of brilliance.
Last night, showing the same heart that won the soul of Madison Square Garden for eight seasons, Starks also brought his streaky jump shot. He was on, dumping in a team-high 18 points on an economical 7-of-13 night from the field.
Gone was the shooter whose career seemed destined for a bad end at Golden State. Returning was the emotional player who put his index finger next to his lips, quieting a smiling and reflective Spike Lee after dropping in a 3-pointer from the right wing.
Sometimes locked in a one-on-one duel with his good friend Allan Houston, Starks found one of many sieves in New York's defense and contributed mightily to one of the worst Knick losses at home in recent memory, an 89-58 shellacking.
"I think I know a little bit about the Garden," Starks said after the Jazz improved to 17-6. "The shot felt good. The guys did a good job of finding me. I just had my mind clear to get up and shoot the basketball."
It is too early in the season for him to pass judgment on these Knicks, he said, adding that he thought Larry Johnson's absence because of injury hurt the team. Better than most people, Starks knew the feeling of playing poorly in front of a fed-up Garden crowd and did not want to rub salt on the Knicks' wound.
Asked about how Coach Jeff Van Gundy was coping, he said: "I know he's disappointed. He would like a little bit more out of that. To only score 58 points is kind of tough. But this team is going to bounce back."
In Salt Lake City, Starks has weathered the snow, the traffic lights that never seem to change and a town that closes down about 10 p.m. on Fridays.
Starks said he speaks to Patrick Ewing about once a week, offering him the same moral support that Ewing offered him when Starks was exiled to Golden State in the trade for Latrell Sprewell almost two years ago.
"I think about all the old Knicks," Starks said. "It's like, 'Where are they now?' I crack up about that all the time, especially when I see Patrick in that Seattle uniform. It just doesn't look right.
"He called me and talked about how it rained all the time. I told him, 'You better watch out, Big Fella, you're going to get depressed out there. You're going to take up drinking.' He just laughed."
An elderly woman who lives in the same Utah apartment complex as Starks leaves newspaper clippings on his doormat each morning. A Jazz loyalist approached him recently and said: "I hated you when you were on New York. But I love you now. You got so much heart."
His boyish features still make Starks, 35, look as if he is about to turn 20.
And on certain nights, he still has the energy of his youth, if not the vertical leap. When he is spotting up behind the arc as he did last night at the Garden, it seems as if Starks never grows old.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
That Dazed Feeling on Insurance Prices

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
IS it time to renew your car insurance? Nowadays, the advice to comparison-shop makes more sense than ever.
Prices for the same coverage typically differ by as much as several hundred dollars from one company to the next. Now rates are rising in general, and many discounts are being discarded while new ones are being offered. And some major insurers have started adjusting prices based on the safety performance of vehicles. 
 Some drivers of big cars and sport utility vehicles that can heavily damage lighter cars in accidents can expect to pay more for liability coverage than drivers of smaller cars. However, owners of those large vehicles may pay less for personal injury and other medical coverage because their passengers are generally better protected.
"At no time in recent history have so many things been happening that can affect what you pay for auto insurance," said Robert P. Hartwig, the chief economist for the Insurance Information Institute, an insurance trade group based in New York.
By shopping, consumers can make the changes pay off. But it takes work -- in many cases, more work than most people put into pricing and buying a new car. There are hundreds of insurance companies and, even with the Internet, no single place, like the Kelley Blue Book for car values, to find the best deal among the myriad combinations of rates.
Consider a 35-year-old man in Brooklyn with a 2000-model four-door Ford Taurus LX and a good driving record. The state minimum required coverage, which includes liability and personal injury protection, can cost as much as $1,294 annually at Atlantic Mutual or as little as $787 at the Erie Insurance Group, according to the New York State Insurance Department. (State insurance departments are good places to start the shopping process.)
But when collision and comprehensive coverages are added -- mandatory for any vehicle bought on credit -- Atlantic Mutual's total annual cost rises to $3,634 and Erie's reaches $3,644. That gives Atlantic Mutual, which at first seemed to be more expensive, the better price by $10.
That is hardly the end of it. Liability and personal injury coverage are often increased as protection against lawsuits. To raise liability coverage for injuries to another car's occupants to, say, $300,000, from the $50,000 minimum, Atlantic Mutual adds $402 and Erie $219. Atlantic Mutual charges $22 to increase the liability coverage for damage to another driver's car to $50,000 -- from the $10,000 minimum -- while Erie charges $24. To increase personal injury coverage for the policyholder to $100,000 -- from the $50,000 minimum -- Atlantic Mutual charges $14 and Erie $11. For the whole package, Erie's coverage comes to $3,898, versus $4,072 for Atlantic's.
The prices published by state insurance departments, the regulators say, are merely intended as a rough guide.
The next step, experts suggest, is the Internet. At Web sites like Insweb.com and Quotesmith.com, consumers can receive comparative price quotations from about a half-dozen companies. Actual prices can vary, because Internet users often misunderstand or deliberately give false answers (like not disclosing a speeding ticket) to the questions used to calculate premium costs. Still, the Internet prices are generally more refined than the regulators' guides.
Insweb does not sell insurance directly on the Web but connects customers to an agent. Most insurance experts suggest that consumers contact two or three agents -- representatives of single companies and those who offer policies from several companies, before closing a deal.
Few people, though, shop so intently. In fact, experts estimate that the vast majority of auto insurance customers do no shopping at all. Many people assume that all auto insurance costs about the same, so they buy from the first agent they call. Indeed, since insurance is regulated, there is no bargaining in most states.
While price is important, most people also want a company that is fair, if not generous, with claims. A ranking of insurance companies by complaints is available from state insurance departments. Of course, friends and neighbors are often very willing to talk about their experiences, too.
What makes the latest pricing changes so tricky for a consumer is that they are not uniform. So far, the only major companies setting prices on safety performance by make and model are Allstate, the nation's second-largest auto insurer, and Progressive, which is fourth. Both companies, as well as State Farm, are using that approach for personal injury and other medical coverage.
Progressive led the way with this pricing years ago when it was a small company selling coverage for so-called nonstandard drivers who had been rejected or canceled by other insurers. Then, its pricing practices affected a small percentage of drivers. But in the last few years, the company has expanded rapidly into the broader auto insurance market.
The Farmers Insurance Group, the third-largest auto insurer, says it will begin pricing based on safety performance by make and model next year, and analysts say most companies are likely to follow suit eventually. But for now, most companies are still averaging the cost of liability and personal injury claims across all the vehicles they insure. And that creates an opportunity for smart shoppers.
According to Mr. Hartwig's calculations, overall auto insurance costs are expected to rise by an average of 2 percent to 4 percent in the coming year, to reflect rising costs for medical treatment and repairs. But some companies may raise prices much more while others hold the line, again creating opportunities for smart shoppers.
Many consumer advocates praised the shift to pricing by make and model safety performance for its fairness, as drivers who cost the insurance companies the most will pay the most. But analysts say the insurance companies were largely motivated by the prospect of gaining market share through price differentiation.
THE insurers are also taking a closer look at the bottom line when it comes to discounts. They want to attract more customers, Mr. Hartwig said, but they are increasingly willing to give discounts only to people who actually have fewer claims. For example, he said, some companies are eliminating blanket discounts for all older drivers and replacing them with discounts for only those who complete a defensive-driving course.
State Farm is trying out a discount of up to 30 percent in Arizona and Maryland for drivers under 25 who complete a 60-day driver-safety program. Many companies give discounts to customers who also insure their homes or other cars.
There are other ways to save money. Consumers can increase the deductible on collision and comprehensive coverage to the maximum, which is often $2,000, so that they would pay for the first $2,000 in losses. They may also drop collision and comprehensive coverage altogether as their car ages and its resale value declines.
The choice of car also affects rates. The more expensive the vehicle, the more it usually costs to repair or replace and, therefore, to insure. The new pricing based on safety performance may add or subtract just a few dollars or as much as $150 or so, probably not enough to determine which car you drive. (On the other hand, the insurance company's vehicle safety ratings may be an important consideration.)
The price of auto insurance varies because insurers' expenses vary and because they come up with different analyses of the risks presented by similar drivers. So why don't the insurance companies just say what kind of customers they prefer and let the others look elsewhere? Mr. Hartwig says the answer is that "most large insurers want to insure everyone."
"They don't want to discourage you in any way," he said, "because more than likely they have a policy they can offer you, whether you've got a clean driving record or a horrible one."

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 5; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2893 words

HEADLINE: Catching Up With Mr. Cuomo

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
I WOULD have liked to have been a justice of the Supreme Court for one case, yes," Mario M. Cuomo said. "It would have been this case."
Mr. Cuomo -- son of a ditch digger, three-term governor and never quite presidential candidate -- was boiling mad. He rejected a seat on the United States Supreme Court, he has said, because he feared it would be the equivalent of having his tongue cut out. He wanted to speak out freely on the issues. 
 Speak out he has. As the world stared in fascination, disbelief and not a little disgust at America's marathon election drama, his bullet-shaped head became a staple on television as he was approached by stations from upstate New York to the British Broadcasting Corporation. To Mr. Cuomo, 68 (and still playing a mean game of basketball), the drama is evidence of an ever fiercer level of partisanship by Republicans. He likens it to the way they pounded on his 20 vetoes of death penalty legislation to beat him in 1994.
"They are ugly people, and they behave in ugly ways," he said.
He doubts that anyone could have swayed the five justices opposed to a recount. But he said he felt energized, not discouraged, by the court's ruling.
"The game is now more exciting than ever," he told his wife, Matilda, at 1 a.m. Wednesday.
She replied, "You're impossible."
He said: "Thanks a lot, sweetheart. Goodnight."
Political passions still run high in this child of illiterate parents, who was rejected by the city's elite law firms because two summa cum laude degrees were canceled out by his Italian background, who went on to fight for the underdog in Queens and then held high state office for 20 years. Along the way he made a speech or two, including the stirring address to the 1984 Democratic National Convention. A generation of New Yorkers learned to love or loathe but never ignore him.
Still, some things have changed. The Cuomos live on Sutton Place South; he glides around Manhattan in black cars; he has a majestic view of Manhattan from his law office window, and he says almost all his legal colleagues are Republicans. Once known for never leaving Albany, he now travels often to Europe. He no longer commits thoughts to his famous diary. His Queens roots, which once loomed like Lincoln's log cabin, seem now as distant as the view from his apartment window.
In 1995, his superb voice touched souls at the funeral of his beloved 92-year-old mother, Immaculata. Then he went straight back to his office at Wilkie Farr & Gallagher to put in some billable hours.
Sometimes he doesn't even sound like a liberal. "I'm representing wealthy people, trying to make them wealthier," he said.
Mr. Cuomo's world turned upside down around 9 p.m. on Nov. 8, 1994, when he knew for sure that he had lost his bid for a fourth term as governor, losing to George E. Pataki. A realization hit him.
"I have no home, I have no job, I have no money," he thought. At 1:30 a.m., in the pitch darkness over the Hudson River, the helicopter taking him back to Albany dipped sharply, and the governor remembered something else: he had only $200,000 in life insurance.
"I got to thinking that if the plane had gone, Matilda would have had to live with one of the kids because I didn't have any money," he said. "How could I get myself into this predicament?"
The short answer was that he had been busy with a succession of state offices, being secretary of state and lieutenant governor before winning the top job in 1982. Unlike previous secretaries of state, he had given up his law practice, and he declined gubernatorial pay raises.
The long answer was that he had been on a crusade to preach his vision of a "sweeter" -- his favorite adjective -- America, in which people look after one another and the government cares. His foes saw only a prima donna on an awesome ego trip, a self-involved Hamlet on the Hudson, but his eloquent speeches roused people in ways politicians seldom do anymore.
Then he lost. Maybe New Yorkers were tired of him, or regarded his quest for a fourth term as plain greedy. Maybe most agreed with the victor, Mr. Pataki, that New York State taxes were too high. Even Democrats criticized his failure to build a stronger party.
But Mr. Cuomo drew solace from Election Day exit polls showing that 60 percent of New Yorkers thought him "a man of great integrity who cares about me." He is not shy in offering excuses for his loss: the lingering effect of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's taxes, President Reagan's budget cuts, the recession of the early 90's.
A few days after the election, the phone rang and on the other end was the unmistakable bray of former Mayor Edward I. Koch.
"Mario, do not be depressed," Mr. Koch said. "There is life after death. Look at me, and you will do everything I'm doing and more."
Like Mr. Koch, Mr. Cuomo now works as a lawyer, writes articles for New York newspapers and has a radio show. The show, "Me and Mario" (broadcast on WAMC in Albany and carried by 46 stations), features Mr. Cuomo and the radio host Alan Chartock discussing issues from baseball to the definition of Judaism to the death of Mr. Cuomo's dog, Ginger.
Mr. Koch and Mr. Cuomo both wrote children's books, but Mr. Cuomo's was published. "The Blue Spruce" (Sleeping Bear Press, 1999), an adaptation of an article he had written for Reader's Digest, is the inspirational tale of a father and son struggling to push a fallen tree back into place.
But Mr. Cuomo, who always had a question for every answer, is still driven by political passions. He travels America giving 50 speeches a year, often to business audiences, refining a message that has become increasingly spiritual. "The truth is that God made the world, but didn't finish it," he says, citing Jewish scripture. "Your job is to finish it."
His son Andrew, the secretary of housing and urban development for the last four years and a likely candidate for governor, said his father "is in heaven; he is paid to speak."
The father's principles are also apparent in the one corporate board he serves on, of the Medallion Financial Corporation, which lends money to small-business owners, mainly immigrants. "We look in their eyes," said the corporation's president, Andy Mustein. "Sometimes the only collateral is somebody's ambition."
 
So Tantalizingly Near, And Yet So Far Away
Mario Cuomo came within grasping distance of the nation's highest prizes. By his wife's count, he was offered a seat on the Supreme Court three times, once by President Carter and twice by President Clinton. Twice, in 1988 and 1992, he passed up running for the presidency, even though he was leading in the polls.
From the perspective of professional pols, he mastered the game. Nixon said for years that he was the Democrats' strongest candidate. In 1988, when President Reagan was asked what "the great communicator" planned to do, he replied, "I think he'll stay as governor of New York."
His celebrity thrives: crowds coalesce around him on streets; men call him a hero, women kiss him.
And given Andrew's political ambitions, the Cuomo name may be in the limelight again. Andrew looks, sounds and is said to think like his father, and, for better or worse, seems to inspire the same passionate love or hate. He is eager for his father's help, and Dad seems more than willing.
"My instinct would be to be all over it, but maybe the manager will want me to stay behind the scenes, just raising money," Mario Cuomo said. "Andrew may even have to overcome his father's image."
Meyer S. Frucher, who was one of Mr. Cuomo's top gubernatorial advisers, cited an October poll showing that only 22 percent of New Yorkers have an unfavorable opinion of the senior Cuomo, and he predicted a prominent paternal role. Still, he urged caution.
"The role of a father in a campaign is a very, very complicated one," Mr. Frucher said. "Just ask W."
Mrs. Cuomo sees nothing complicated about the situation. "If Andrew decides to run, we're going to work our hearts and souls off for him," she vowed.
 
A Politics of Caring, Rooted in the Depression
Mr. Cuomo sits behind his cluttered desk at Wilkie Farr, the jagged skyline sparkling through immense windows. On the wall is his certificate to practice before the Supreme Court and an autographed picture of Joe DiMaggio. He wants people to know he is "not dead yet."
After quoting economists like Adam Smith, he explained that his politics, and his drive to attend to his family's material needs, grew out of his experience in the Depression. When his father lost his job, the Cuomos were befriended by a businessman who let them live in the back of his grocery store in South Jamaica, Queens, if they agreed to run it. All four children were born in that one room, including Mario, the youngest, who was named for a brother who died at 2.
He got a $2,000 bonus from the Pittsburgh Pirates in 1951 to play baseball, but after an injury sidelined him, he used it for an engagement ring for Matilda Raffa (who as First Lady and afterward was deeply in women's health issues and student mentoring) and finished college and then law school at St. John's. He made the rounds of the prestigious law firms, but there was no market for Italian-Americans. He became a successful lawyer on Court Street in Brooklyn, where the phase "ambulance chaser" is no insult.
It all added up to an education.
"I've been married for 46 years and have five children," he said. "That's an education."
"I have nine granddaughters. That's an education."
"I was governor for 12 years. An incredible learning experience."
Almost teasing, he gave the reasons he would have enjoyed the Supreme Court.
"I like being left alone," he said. "I like being able to read, deliberate and then write what I believe to be the truth."
When asked if he would rather make a bright comment on Larry King or write a benchmark Supreme Court opinion, he looked at the questioner and grunted.
The presidency?
In 1991, friends persuaded him to pursue the race he had rejected in 1988 when he thought others were better qualified. But the following year, Mr. Cuomo said, when a campaign would have begun, he was trapped by the unwillingness of the Republican-controlled State Senate to agree on a budget bill.
He says he believes that national Republicans were coordinating the stalemate in Albany to keep him out of the race. "How could I run for president if the economy of my own state was in turmoil?" he asked.
Some friends guess his real reason was an unwillingness to send American soldiers to war, a president's heaviest responsibility at any time. Mr. Cuomo rejects this, pointing out that he demonstrated his toughness during his first week as governor by refusing to yield when rioting inmates at Sing Sing demanded clemency.
Mr. Cuomo answered, "Tell them the answer is no," and went into the bathroom and threw up. The hostages were released in minutes.
He rebutted the idea that he shied away from higher office because he was worried about reporters uncovering Mafia connections in his family, saying that there were none and that nobody had found any despite years of trying.
He added that he resented the recent disclosure that Mayor Giuliani's father went to prison for Mafia activities, saying that had nothing to do with the mayor's own character and record.
In any case, he says he has no regrets about his decisions not to pursue both offices.
"I have never heard him say, 'What if?' " Andrew said.
Shortly after his gubernatorial defeat, an aide mentioned that an advertising agency had asked if Mr. Cuomo would make a Doritos commercial with Ann Richards, who had just lost her bid for re-election as governor of Texas, to one George W. Bush.
"No kidding?" Mr. Cuomo said. "Doritos, huh?"
He did the commercial, and another for Mad magazine. The money went for a down payment on a $600,000 apartment. He then set out to interview law firms.
Jack Nussbaum, chairman of Wilkie Farr, said that despite "the large gap in his resume," referring to his political years, "we knew him to be a man of great intellect."
Dan Rubino, a partner, said Mr. Cuomo writes his own briefs, and, colleagues say, can often be found in the library doing his own research. His assignments have included representing the Philadelphia Stock Exchange in an antitrust case, an Italian drug firm in a copyright case and Sprint in its bid to acquire People's Choice TV.
But some tasks are hard because of his background.
"It's hard for me to go into court, because I appointed 112 judges," Mr. Cuomo said. He has also declined to be on the firm's executive committee. "It's very difficult to be one of nine guys running a little law firm," he said.
Mr. Frucher, who is now chairman and chief executive of the Philadelphia exchange, told of a man who did a double take when Mr. Cuomo walked into a meeting and then appeared nonplused throughout the session.
"It takes a while for people to think of me as a lawyer," Mr. Cuomo complained afterward. "I just don't understand why."
Mr. Frucher answered, "Maybe if you wouldn't sit at the head of the table. . . ."
 
Still in the Game, Still Taking Shots
Mr. Cuomo these days is a study in motion, if not always efficient scheduling. He gave a speech in Phoenix on a Friday, returned to play basketball on Saturday and then went back to Phoenix for a speech on Sunday. He gets bookings through the Harry Walker agency -- he won't say how much he is paid -- but is not under contract there and arranges many of his speeches himself, and he gives many without charge.
His biggest battle last week was not in the political arena. It was on the basketball court, where his team, the Blues ("Play Sad Music When You Play the Blues," say the team's jerseys) was preparing to play the Blacks, the team led by his son Christopher, at an Upper East Side high school.
Christopher, a reporter for the ABC program "20/ 20," anticipated the worst, as usual.
"He will cheat, he will call you out of bounds when you're not," the son said. "He yells and screams about enforcing rules he would never have his own team play by."
The father says he is just glad to be out there, even with the painful cortisone shot he must have in his hand to play. "You play anyway," he said, "because you're running out of time and love the game."
Another day, he showed up at Intermediate School 43 in Harlem at the request of a basketball friend who teaches there. He had passed up an invitation to be on "Nightline" to arrive bright and early.
The children acted cool, yawning for emphasis. Mr. Cuomo began by referring to his new career. "If you have a merger or a big company you want to sell, I'm the guy to see," he said. He tailored his life story to his almost exclusively black audience by describing his experiences growing up in South Jamaica.
"They called us funny names," he said. "Dagos, guineas, greaseballs, wops. You know they're making fun of your mother. You know they're making fun of your father. You know they're making fun of you."
Question time came, and two dozen miraculously energized children waved their hands in the air. What about Governor Pataki?
"I am an ontologist," Mr. Cuomo answered. "That means I believe that everything that exists is good, or God wouldn't permit it to exist. So, in that sense, he is a good governor."
He added salt to feeble praise by saying Mr. Pataki is interested only in helping the rich. Later, he wondered if he had been too kind.
Mr. Cuomo was asked if politicians' personal morality mattered. He said he deplored Mr. Clinton's behavior but did not support impeachment. "We think your soul needs a little work, but the rest of you is functioning very well indeed," he said.
The man, who called the children sir and ma'am, was in his element. "He's pedantic," said his son Christopher. "He's always looking to teach you."
Mr. Cuomo has a playfully thoughtful side. Climbing into a limousine one day, he ruminated on why Lincoln aced Cadillac in the black car business. He moved on to the merits of being a monoecious organism, one in which both sexes exist in one body. This somehow led to taxis and why the price of medallions went up when the city issued 400 new ones for the first time in years.
All of which, perhaps logically, brought the former governor to a Peanuts strip he loves. Charlie Brown's team has lost, 29-0. Lucy says: "Win some, lose some." Charlie replies: "Wouldn't that be wonderful."
A passenger asked whether President Clinton is this era's greatest politician. There was a long pause. Finally, Mr. Cuomo answered: "Yeah, I guess. But politics for what? Winning?"
The car stopped in Purchase, where Mr. Cuomo was to address the Westchester Holocaust Commission. He does not usually write out his speeches, but he said this subject required every word to be right. He spoke of "tormenting, unanswered questions."
Recently, he told his audience, his granddaughter asked about the Holocaust, "Why did they kill them, Grampa?"
Mr. Cuomo struggled, then promised he would explain when she got older. "And you wonder if you'll ever get old enough," he said softly.
There were tears in the audience, and, at the end, long applause. As Mr. Cuomo left, a stranger grabbed his arm and whispered, "My only regret is that you're not running for president."

SECTION: Section 12; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles 

LENGTH: 382 words

HEADLINE: Four-Wheeled Wallflowers, Waiting for a Dance

 BODY:
EVEN in the Super Bowl, players sit on the sidelines. And even as automakers celebrated record sales in recent years, some models haven't had much to party about. Bad things happen to good cars.
This has always been the case. Some vehicles, like the Chrysler Airflow of the mid-30's, were ahead of their time. Others, like the Packard Caribbean and Studebaker Lark, couldn't compete with Detroit's marketing muscle and economies of scale. Still others were undone by poor quality, dated designs or changing demographics. The industry's biggest failure, the Ford Motor Company's Edsel, arrived in the midst of a recession in the particularly vulnerable medium-priced sector of the market. Its sucking-a-lemon styling didn't help matters. 
 More recently, Ford pulled the plug on two exceptional performance cars that started out as mundane family sedans: the Taurus SHO and Contour SVT. Despite critical acclaim, the cars failed to convince enough buyers in their intended market -- driving enthusiasts with a penchant for European road manners -- that Detroit's engineers could match the Germans'.
Currently, a German sedan wearing Cadillac's crest is struggling. The Catera, based on the Opel Omega, found only 756 buyers last month. Problems with the quality of early cars left the Catera under a cloud. Another line of Opel-based cars, the midsize Saturn L-Series, has also been a sales disappointment.
Some other models are sagging under the weight of old age. Sales of the Chevrolet Camaro and Pontiac Firebird, which were last extensively redesigned for 1993, are a fraction of the numbers posted in their glory days. The Acura Integra, due for a revamping, is similarly flagging. Fewer than 9,000 Mitsubishi Diamantes, made in Australia, have been sold this year.
Entire nameplates have been excised. Chrysler perfomed euthanasia on the Eagle division that it inherited from American Motors. DaimlerChrysler is in the process of killing Plymouth, and last week G.M. said it would similarly phase out Oldsmobile.
As for individual models, some with modest sales will surely survive. And some certainly deserve better. The four models featured below are not just undersellers, they are often underrated and underappreciated -- vehicles that have not received their due.

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS;
Finding A Niche as High Tech's Back Office

BYLINE: By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Davenport Institute for Public Policy at Pepperdine University. His column on the Main Street economy appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: grassrts@nytimes.com

DATELINE: KINGSTON, N.Y.

 BODY:
FOR about three decades, this blue-collar city of 23,000, about 100 miles north of Manhattan, was at the epicenter of the technological revolution. Since the early 1990's, though, when I.B.M. shut down its mainframe-testing operation and offices here, idling 7,000 workers, the city has languished.
But like other working-class communities across the country, Kingston is seeking a new niche in the new economy. One Manhattan developer sees the city as maintaining an important position in technology, only in more of a supporting role -- as a center for back offices or warehouses for expanding Internet and other technology businesses. 
 The developer, Alan Ginsberg, bought I.B.M.'s 256-acre Kingston plant in 1998 for $16.5 million and renamed it TechCity. He says bad times for technology companies -- exemplified by the recent sharp drop in their stock prices -- make blue-collar places like Kingston more appealing to new-economy companies. For one thing, rents at TechCity average $10 to $13 a square foot, compared with $50 to $100 in Manhattan and $30 in Westchester County, just north of New York City. "Now people need to find places in the hinterlands that are both affordable and attractive," Mr. Ginsberg said.
Kingston's effort to find its place in the information-age economy also reflects a growing recognition that lower-cost sites may be best for blue-collar functions like technology support, warehousing and distribution. "The Web can't move a box," said John Kasarda, director of the Kenan Institute of Private Enterprise at the University of North Carolina.
Increasingly, Dr. Kasarda said, Web-related companies understand that efficient means of processing orders and storing and distributing products have become as crucial to their success as building efficient electronic portals and offering compelling new products.
THE search for the best homes for these distribution activities -- as well as for customer support and data processing -- is already leading companies to places far afield from conventional high-technology hotbeds like Silicon Valley or Boston's Route 128, or new-media centers like Lower Manhattan or San Francisco's South of Market district.
EToys, an Internet retailer with headquarters in Santa Monica, Calif., has established major distribution sites in Blairs, Va., in the rural south central part of the state, and in Ontario, Calif., 40 miles east of Los Angeles. The sites, which together have 700 employees and cover nearly three million square feet of space, are in relatively low-cost areas with largely blue-collar work forces.
Ted Augustine, senior vice president for logistics at eToys, says that the blue-collar portions of the information economy are best placed in areas that boast easy accessibility and good roads, cheap space and a large blue-collar and middle-management work force. "This is the nonglamorous stuff -- but it's absolutely come to the fore," he said. "It's increasingly seen as critical for success."
The recently completed Ontario site has emerged as a magnet for blue-collar operations. Centered near Ontario International Airport, the area has developed into a center for Internet-related warehousing. It is home to operations of companies like Toys "R" Us, Cooking.com, Home Shopping Network and eToys.
The area's appeal is in large part based on location, price and infrastructure, Mr. Augustine said. The region has freeway and rail access to Los Angeles and Long Beach, a foreign trade entrepot. And rents are as much as 80 percent lower than in coastal sections of Los Angeles County or Orange County, according to John Husing, a local economist. "We have the real estate, and that turns us into a magnet for big space users," Mr. Husing said.
That blue-collar growth is expected to continue. The San Bernardino-Riverside region already has an estimated 220 million square feet of commercial space, and an additional 30 million square feet is planned, if local authorities approve. Since the mid-1990's, nearly 43,000 jobs have been added in manufacturing and distribution.
Across the country in Kingston, Mr. Ginsberg and local business leaders want to develop similar niches for the Hudson Valley region. Although wages here are lower than in Silicon Valley or Lower Manhattan's new-media industry, the business leaders consider warehouse, back-office and other technology support positions as likely to be more attractive than the lower-paying retail and other service jobs that have been the major source of new employment in the area since I.B.M. pulled out.
Eugene R. Gruner, a real estate broker and a longtime business leader in Kingston, said that while unemployment was down and occupancy rates in downtown Kingston were up, most of the new business has come from small, poorly financed business-service companies that use 1,000 square feet of space or less. Technology companies' logistics and support installations, Mr. Gruner said, could help increase local wages and rents.
Yet Kingston still faces many challenges. The city is roughly a two-hour drive from New York City, and it lacks the modern infrastructure being built in places like Ontario. The local airport, Stewart International, does not yet have the capacity to handle the kind of large containers and packages required for large-scale distribution functions.
Despite such challenges, Mr. Ginsberg says he can turn TechCity -- and Kingston -- into a thriving secondary high-technology center. To attract smaller companies, he is breaking up some of the larger expanses at his site, while transforming closed-in, cubicle offices into airy spaces with exposed ceilings.
SO far, Mr. Ginsberg has had limited success. Roughly one-third of TechCity's available space, or around 850,000 square feet, has been occupied. The largest tenant is Fleet Bank, a unit of FleetBoston Financial, which houses back-office operations in nearly 400,000 square feet of office space. Other tenants include FairPoint Communications, a telecommunications service company, as well as a handful of Internet start-ups.
Yet Mr. Ginsberg is hopeful. With the benefit of a 10-year break from New York State on state sales and business taxes, he says that this lagging part of the Hudson Valley can thrive in the new economy.
But he acknowledges that the process will take time. "Lightning changes don't happen overnight in places like this," he said. "Will we get to 75 to 80 percent occupancy? Come back in three years and we'll see."
